title: World Briefing | Europe: France: 'Yes' Vote Gains Ground
description: Poll results released over the weekend indicated that supporters of Europe's draft constitution narrowly outnumbered its opponents for the first time ahead of a May 29 national referendum. Another poll, released yesterday, showed opponents to the constitution still in the lead, but by a narrowing margin. Polls had previously shown a dizzying slide in French support and steadily mounting opposition to the document that is meant to underpin future European laws, establish European military and foreign policy institutions, and define the relationship between the union and member states. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said yesterday that the men painted graffiti and damaged property and subway stations in eight neighborhoods. The men -- Charles Webster, 17, Christopher Fuller, 19, Christopher Sanchez, 20, and Miguel Camacho, 29, all of Queens -- were charged with criminal mischief.

description: Current and former officers and directors of Toys "R" Us stand to receive a total of $187 million for selling the toy retailer, according to a regulatory filing yesterday. The chairman and chief executive, John H. Eyler Jr., is due $65 million, making him the largest individual beneficiary of the expected payouts. The tally was included in a preliminary proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The document was filed in connection with the proposed $6.6 billion buyout of Toys "R" Us by an investment group including Vornado Realty Trust and the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Bain Capital Partners. Toys "R" Us is based in Wayne, N.J.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Surges
description: Brazil's trade surplus continued to surge in April, easing fears that a strengthening local currency would make the country's exports less competitive on world markets. The country posted a record surplus of $3.88 billion last month, up from $1.96 billion a year earlier and $3.35 billion in March, the government said. Exports rose to $9.2 billion in April, while imports totaled $5.33 billion. This year Brazil has run up a trade surplus of $12.19 billion, up from $8.09 billion a year ago. Until recently, most economists were predicting that the trade surplus would narrow in 2005. Now many expect a surplus of about $34 billion, up from a record surplus of $33.7 billion in 2004, according to a central bank survey. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALL, EVELYN
description: HALL--Evelyn. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and staff of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center mourn the death of Evelyn A.J. Hall. Over many years, Mrs. Hall was a stalwart supporter of the Center, primarily concerned that patients be able to receive the most sophisticated, most effective cancer care in comfortable settings to minimize the impact of treatment on their lives. Her generous contributions supported the Brachytherapy Suite and Adult Day Hospital both of which, at their inceptions, represented innovative ways of delivering cancer care. In addition, Mrs. Hall supported the PET (positron emission tomography) program, long-term follow-up studies of pediatric patients, the Clinical Genetics Service, the Patient Free Care Fund, and other Center programs. She also brightened the lives of Memorial Hospital's pediatric patients with her support of The Big Apple Circus Clown Care Unit. Mrs. Hall's forward-looking altruism, energy, imagination, and frienship will be deeply missed. Douglas A. Warner III Chairman, Boards of Overseers and Managers Richard I. Beattie, Vice Chairman Harold Varmus, President John R. Gunn, Executive Vice President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: $5.1 Million Death Settlement
description: The City of Boston paid $5.1 million to the family of a 21-year-old college student who was killed last October when she was struck in the eye with a pepper-spray pellet. The pellet was fired by police officers trying to control a chaotic crowd celebrating the American League pennant victory of the Boston Red Sox over the New York Yankees. The payment, to the parents of Victoria Snelgrove, a student at Emerson College, is apparently the largest wrongful death settlement ever made by the city. Police Commissioner Kathleen O'Toole said the police investigation had found that Ms. Snelgrove "was not the target of any police action nor was she engaged in any activity that would have led police to think that she was behaving unlawfully." She also announced that Deputy Police Superintendent Robert E. O'Toole, who was in charge of operations in the area the night of the riot and fired one of the pellet guns, would retire from the police force after 37 years of service. The commissioner and the deputy superintendent are not related. Pam Belluck (NYT)

description: GREEN--James Wilder. Former Director of the American Federation of Arts, died on April 27, 2005 at the age of 78 after a long illness. Mr. Green was born in Paris. He studied architecture at Yale with Louis Kahn and worked for Paul Rudolph in Florida and Philip Johnson in NY. In 1956, he began a distinquished career at the Museum of Modern Art, first as assistant to Alfred Barr and later with Philip Johnson in the Department of Architecture. He became Director of MOMA's Exhibition Program in 1967. In 1971, he was appointed Director of the AFA, retiring in 1987. In recent years, Mr. Green continued his lifelong commitment to the arts through his philanthrophy and involvement with foundations, including the MacDowell Colony and the Longhouse Reserve in Easthampton. He was Chairman of the Grants Review Committee of the Judith Rothschild Foundation and on the Board of Directors of Village Care of NY. Wilder will be missed by his many dear friends, colleagues and family. A memorial service is planned for later this spring at the AFA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Village Care of NY, 154 Christopher St., NY, NY 10014.

description: A lawyer who gave a Providence television reporter a secret F.B.I. videotape of a corruption investigation was charged with perjury and criminal contempt of court, and has agreed to plead guilty, federal prosecutors said. Robert Clark Corrente, the United States attorney, said the lawyer, Joseph Bevilacqua Jr., who was representing one of the city officials being investigated by the F.B.I., violated a court order when he gave the surveillance tape to Jim Taricani, a reporter for WJAR-TV. In early 2001, Mr. Taricani's station broadcast the tape, which showed an aide to former Mayor Vincent Cianci Jr. taking a bribe. Mr. Taricani was convicted last November for refusing to divulge the source of the tape, and served four months of home confinement. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Stabbing Victim Identified
description: The police have identified the person fatally stabbed in the Bowery on Saturday as Robert Adams, 16, of 68 East Third Street. Mr. Adams lived in the area and possibly knew his killer, said the police, who were investigating whether the killing was related to $40 that Mr. Adams had borrowed. About 7:30 p.m. last Friday, bystanders discovered Mr. Adams trembling and bleeding near a phone booth on a corner of Chrystie and Delancey Streets. He died at Bellevue Hospital Center the next day, the same day his adoptive parents and sister filed a missing person's report. The sister, Teri Adams, said she and her adoptive mother went to the city morgue on Sunday and identified Mr. Adams after hearing a news report that a boy in a Yankees T-shirt had been killed. Andrea Elliott (NYT)

description: STEVENSON--William. Age 87. Died April 29 at home in Manhattan. Born and raised in Freeport, Long Island, N.Y., he was husband to Luzena Firth for 44 years. Residing in Massapequa, N.Y. for 50 years. Military service included being an Army Paratrooper in France during WWII and an Army Major during the Korean Conflict. He worked as a financial executive at Fortune Brands (et al) for 49 years. Survived by a brother, Edward and a son John. Visitations are at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., May 5, 2005 from 5PM-8PM and 11AM-1PM on May 6, 2005 followed by burial in Greenwood Cemetery, Bklyn, N.Y. The Woodpecker in All of Us
description: I have a hard time imagining many people actually calling the ivory-billed woodpecker "the Lord God bird" -- the name doesn't even make it onto the list of more than 20 common names recorded by the bird's intrepid chronicler, James T. Tanner, in 1942. But it makes a terrific headline for a bird reported last week to have been rediscovered after 61 years of official extinction (better than, say, "King woodchuck," one of its other nicknames). It somehow suggests that we have found more than just a missing bird and that God, whom we invoked when we conquered the wilderness, is also present in our effort to get it back.

Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Chip Sales Rise In First Quarter
description: Global sales of semiconductors unexpectedly rose in the first quarter, helped by demand for chips used in cellphones and personal computers, the Semiconductor Industry Association said yesterday. Worldwide chip sales climbed 0.4 percent, to $55.3 billion, in the first three months of 2005, from $55.1 billion in the fourth quarter, the trade group said. March sales increased 2.2 percent, to $18.4 billion, from the previous month, the group said. Better-than-expected sales of personal computers and cellphones, especially in India and China, pushed chip revenue above forecasts, the group president, George M. Scalise, said in an interview. In January, the group had forecast that worldwide sales would fall 4 percent to 6 percent in the quarter from the last three months of 2004. The association has predicted industry sales of $213 billion this year, little changed from 2004. Global sales in the first quarter rose 13 percent from a year earlier, the group said.

title: Afleet Alex Touches Lives With Each Step He Takes on the Track
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 - John Silvertand skipped his chemotherapy session Monday on his oncologist's orders. He has the date of a lifetime Saturday, and it is one he is so intent on keeping that he has already outlived his prognosis by 29 months. He is driving here to watch the horse he bred, Afleet Alex, run in the Kentucky Derby.

description: If the mid-2000's are the new 1950's, how is art in New York responding? With a chorus line of dapper drawings and wheezy old Damien Hirst, a real Ed Sullivan lineup. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOWNSEND, PAUL
description: TOWNSEND--Paul. Friends and supporters of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System are deeply saddened by Saturday's passing of Paul Townsend of Bellport, New York. A life Trustee of the Northshore-LIJ Health System, Mr. Townsend was one of the founders of North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, NY, and served as chairman of the hospital Board of Trustees. He was a Long Island advocate of the highest order, working tirelessly to ensure that the region's economic growth did not compromise the Island's environment and community spirit. He and his wife, Terry, met at the hospital, and later started their own public relations firm before becoming editor and publisher of Long Island Business News. We extend our sincerest condolences to Terry, a daughter, Wendy Townsend of Seattle; sons Tobin of Manhattan and Kim of Glen Head; six grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Dan de Roulet, Chairman Michael Dowling President & CEO North Shore-LIJ Health System

title: Exploring the Inner Voices and Musical Architecture
description: The pianist Peter Serkin has been justly praised as an intrepid explorer of the 20th century's more rugged musical landscapes, but most of his recital on Sunday afternoon at Town Hall steered clear of this terrain. For this program, he chose just a single brief contemporary work by Oliver Knussen, but otherwise spent his time playing -- with great reward -- Bach, Mozart and music by early French and English composers.

title: An Intimate Stage Plan for the Mostly Mozart Festival
description: Although it is going on 6 in dog years, the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center continues to learn new tricks. For 17 orchestral concerts in its 39th season, which opens on July 28, the festival plans to reconfigure the stage at Avery Fisher Hall to create what it calls a greater sense of intimacy and a closer connection between musicians and audience.

title: Therapies: T.M. for Your B.P.? Hmmm . . .
description: According to a paper published yesterday in The American Journal of Cardiology, Transcendental Meditation, or T.M., is highly effective in reducing the rate of death from cardiovascular disease in people with high blood pressure.

title: Hispanic Group Thrives on Faith and Federal Aid
description: PHILADELPHIA - As a Baptist minister, the Rev. Luis Cortes has long sought to build a national network of Hispanic churches, one that would bring new power to an emerging minority. As an elected official, President Bush has long sought a more diverse Republican Party, one that would lure more blacks and Hispanics to a dominant conservative bloc. These days, the two are united by faith, friendship, and a line item in the federal budget called the Compassion Capital Fund.

description: TRAVIS--Sedel. Garfunkel, Wild & Travis, P.C. mourns the passing of our friend, Sedel Travis, mother of our founding partner, Norton L. Travis. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. May their cherished memories help to lighten their hearts at this sad time. title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Marconi Looking For Options
description: The British telephone equipment company Marconi effectively put itself up for sale yesterday, saying that it was weighing its "strategic options" after losing out on a $19 billion contract with the BT Group. BT accounts for slightly more than one-quarter of annual sales at Marconi, which was founded in 1897 by the radio inventor Guglielmo Marconi. The company cut more than 30,000 jobs after rapid expansion during the telecommunications boom of the late 1990's. Now it is reviewing all of its businesses and might make more cuts. Marconi's stock rose 7 percent on the news, to 281 pence a share, giving the company a market value of 586 million ($1.1 billion). Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Woodbridge: Reporting Required For Medical Misconduct
description: Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey signed a bill yesterday that requires hospitals and health care organizations to inform state regulators of misconduct or negligence that poses a danger to patients. Legislators passed the measure to address weaknesses in medical regulations exposed by the case of Charles Cullen, a nurse who has confessed to murdering 24 patients. State officials said Mr. Cullen, who faces more than 127 years in state prison, was able to move from job to job despite a questionable employment record. He had worked at 10 hospitals in New Jersey and Pennsylvania since 1987. The new law requires criminal background checks for all medical professionals.

title: Party On! It's a Civic Duty
description: Like so many science fiction fantasies, Hal Hartley's new film, "The Girl From Monday," begins with a clever satirical premise, then stumbles all over itself trying to tell a coherent, original story. This deadpan comedy, which Mr. Hartley has called "a fake science fiction film about the way we live now," is set in a supremely yuppified New York City. After the Great Revolution, the country has been taken over by Triple M, an Orwellian corporate and political octopus that has established the Dictatorship of the Consumer. (Think of Microsoft run amok.)

title: Spreading the Fun Around
description: DIGITAL media is here to stay, whether it's music, photographs or movies. Unfortunately, the digital files tend to stay on the computer, which in most homes is in a spot more suitable for a single person rather than for blasting out songs for the whole house to enjoy, gathering the family together to watch a movie or showing off vacation slides to Grandma.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Charged With Killing Neighbor
description: A 40-year-old Bronx man was charged yesterday with the murder of a 47-year-old neighbor, whose decomposed body was discovered in a plastic container in a neighborhood Dumpster last month, the police said. The defendant, Edward Small, and the victim, Lydia Frazier, lived in the same building at 2861 Exterior Street in the Bronx. The two knew each other only as neighbors, the police said. Witnesses told the police that Mr. Small was the last person seen with Ms. Frazier while she was alive. Ms. Frazier's legs had been cut off, and the medical examiner said the cause of death was blunt trauma to the head. Mr. Small was charged with second-degree murder. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

description: CBS easily beat all the other networks on Monday, the fifth night of the May sweeps. Its "CSI: Miami" was the most-watched program with an estimated audience of 20.2 million, but "Everybody Loves Raymond" was also strong. With only two original episodes left in the run of the Ray Romano sitcom, Monday's episode drew 19.18 million viewers. NBC placed second for the night in households and among adults 18 to 49, but two-thirds of its lineup showed weakness: "Fear Factor" was down by 25 percent from the equivalent broadcast last year, and "Las Vegas" had its lowest rating ever for an original episode. On ABC, the sinking "Bachelor," with only two episodes left in its season and possibly in the series if ABC decides to cancel it, brought in 8.17 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Steel Maker Posts Profit
description: Brazil's leading producer of long-rolled steel, Grupo Gerdau, said its profit almost doubled in the first quarter, citing higher international steel prices and an increase in sales at its subsidiaries in Canada and the United States. Gerdau, which has several mills throughout South and North America, posted a net profit of 810.5 million reais ($326 million) in the quarter, a 90 percent increase over the 427.3 million reais in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose 40 percent, to 5.83 billion reais, lifted by a 17.5 percent increase in North America. Gerdau also said it had signed a deal with five Chinese metal companies to acquire a new blast furnace and coking oven for its Ouro Branco mill in Brazil. Todd Benson (NYT)

description: The Mars rover Opportunity has driven itself into a rut, and NASA mission controllers are still figuring out how to get it out. A week ago, the rover's wheels dug themselves hub deep into soft soil as it tried to drive over a foot-high dune. Engineers have been testing mock-ups of the rover at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, trying to understand what happened and testing strategies for extricating it. New driving directions may be sent to the rover in the next day or two. Kenneth Chang (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENNETT, MARCIA MARX
description: BENNETT -- Marcia Marx. Age 74, internationally renowned artist, passed away on May 3 in her beloved New York City. She was born in Newark, NJ and attended Yale University, School of Fine Arts. Most recently, she was given a "one woman show" at the Houston Holocaust Museum. She will be missed for her humor, talent and friendship to those she touched in her life. She is survived by her sons, Gregory and Shawn, and her brother Kelly Marx. A memorial service will be held Friday, 4PM at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREEN, JAMES WILDER
description: GREEN--James Wilder. The trustees and staff of the American Federation of Arts are deeply saddened by the loss of its former director, Wilder Green. His leadership and accomplishments at the AFA will always be remembered. His intelligence, creativity, generosity and friendship will be greatly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Barbara Weeden, Chairman Gilbert H. Kinney, President Julia Brown, Director

title: Woman Killed by Husband Was Abusive, His Lawyer Says
description: The Upper East Side man who the police say stabbed his wife to death last week and then tried to do the same thing to himself was described by his lawyer yesterday as a reluctant killer who had been provoked into violence by his wife.

title: TV AZTECA'S OWNER WILL REMOVE IT FROM STOCK EXCHANGE
description: Ricardo B. Salinas Pliego, the billionaire businessman facing securities charges in the United States and Mexico, plans to withdraw the listings of the broadcaster TV Azteca and two other companies from the New York Stock Exchange. In separate statements, TV Azteca, the Elektra retail chain and the cellphone company Iusacell said that excessive regulation had considerably increased expenses and legal risks. Last week, Mexican regulators said they expected to file criminal charges against Mr. Salinas Pliego over a 2003 debt deal that made him a profit of $109 million; the United States Securities and Exchange Commission filed fraud charges against him in January over the same deal. The S.E.C. is seeking to bar Mr. Salinas Pliego from acting as an officer or executive of any company listed on an American exchange. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: What Are the Odds? A Trainer With 5 Shots to Win the Derby

It is not quite symmetrical, but it keeps at a distance those who are both curious about and amazed by Nick Zito, a Brooklyn-born trainer who has five horses ready to run in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday. Considering the stakes involved, Zito can be forgiven for the bunker atmosphere in these tense days leading up to the race.

Hynes. Gabriel Bertonazzi, owner of the club, the Sweet Cherry Bar, at 202 42nd Street, was also charged last year with raping two dancers, prosecutors said. He has pleaded not guilty. title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Woman Dies Of Rare Brain Disease
description: A 26-year-old Dutch woman with the human form of mad cow disease has died in a hospital in Utrecht. The hospital released no other details at the request of the family. Doctors had diagnosed her condition on April 15 as probable variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, contracted from eating cattle infected with mad cow disease. The Dutch Health Ministry said the disease was probably caused by past consumption of tainted meat. John Tagliabue (NYT)

The decision came despite the State Constitution's ban on most forms of commercial gambling.

National Briefing | South: Georgia: City Of Lithonia Is Broke
description: The City of Lithonia is broke and missed its insurance payment of $42,000, leaving its employees and vehicles without liability insurance, said Marcus Lloyd, the mayor pro tem. Mr. Lloyd said city police officers who had been put on desk duty or driven to calls by the DeKalb County police were now temporarily suspended, and the city, which has a population of 2,200, laid off 9 of 20 employees on Friday. Mr. Lloyd said the city was appealing for help to Gov. Sonny Perdue and the Georgia Municipal Association. A spokesman for the governor, Dan McLagan, said, "That's not what the discretionary fund is for." Ariel Hart (NYT)

Paid Notice: Memorials   CITRIN, HILLARY
description: CITRIN--Hillary. Hillary, it has been several years since last I wrote and I would like to let you know what has gone on in our family since then. Your nephew Ethan still has a heart of gold but now it is in the body of a young man. He is handsome and smart and beautiful as you were. Your nephew Hunter is a great athlete and has your sense of humor. You and he would have had a great time together. Luanne is still keeping me together after all these years. And Dad continues to be the strength that he was when you were with us. Luckily for us, his wife, Roz, keeps him well. It has been 23 years and it feels like it was yesterday when I saw you last. All my love, Marc

For Day, It Will Be a Seat Not a Saddle at Churchill Downs
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. May 3 - Pat Day was ready to rush out of bed last Friday, head to the racetrack, climb on a horse for the first time since March and then scour the Churchill Downs barn area for a Kentucky Derby mount. His sense of urgency was understandable. Day had ridden in a record 21 consecutive Kentucky Derbys and was not eager to see the streak end.

title: Peering Behind the Mask of a Mysterious Erotic Novelist
description: Long before French bad girls like the filmmaker Catherine Breillat and the critic Catherine Millet stormed the publicity barricades with their high-flown smut, a button-down woman of letters named Dominique Aury sent temperatures rising. In 1954 this unlikely pornographer created a scandal in France when her erotic novel, "Story of O," was published under the pseudonym Pauline Rage. With its cool tone and feverishly imagined story, the book became a cause clbre, an international best seller and, in time, a source of national pride. For years, many assumed its author could only have been a man.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: Bomb Kills 15 During Leader's Speech
description: An explosion tore through a Mogadishu stadium where Ali Mohamed Gedi, the interim prime minister, was giving a speech, killing at least 15 people and injuring about 40 more, officials said. The bomb went off just after Mr. Gedi had told the crowd that the interim government now based in Nairobi, Kenya, would be willing to drop plans to relocate Somali's capital to the towns of Baidoa or Jowhar if security in Mogadishu were enhanced, witnesses said. Mr. Gedi was making his first trip to the capital since taking office last year. The new government, a broad union of former enemy warlords, is opposed by some Islamic leaders who see it as cutting into their power base. Marc Lacey (NYT)

ICAHN GETS SOME SUPPORT IN BLOCKBUSTER FIGHT
description: The investor Carl C. Icahn received partial backing from Institutional Shareholder Services for his attempt to appoint directors to the board of Blockbuster. Shareholder Services said that Blockbuster investors should appoint Mr. Icahn's nominees, Strauss Zelnick and Edward Bleier, to the board at next week's annual meeting, but vote against Mr. Icahn. Mr. Icahn, Blockbuster's largest shareholder, advocates selling the company to a private equity firm, a strategy opposed by its chief executive, John Antioco. Mr. Icahn should be denied a seat on the board because he lacks media experience and has attacked Mr. Antioco, who has led the company since 1997, Shareholder Services said. Mr. Antioco has called the proxy vote a referendum on Blockbuster's strategy, has urged investors not to back Mr. Icahn's candidates and has threatened to quit if not re-elected.

title: White House Is Pressured By Press Corps Over Sourcing
description: The Washington bureau chiefs at seven major news organizations are pressing the White House to curtail the use of background briefings, which administration officials regularly hold on the condition that the officials not be identified in news reports.

description: Birmingham, England - I was in America at the time of the presidential election last November, on a short book tour. It wasn't the ideal time to promote a novel about Henry James, but I couldn't resist the opportunity to observe at first hand the climax of the campaign, which had been reported with intense interest in the British news media.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Settlement Reached In Ferry Crash
description: The family of a carpet installer who was killed in the crash of the Staten Island ferry in October 2003 will receive $450,000 from the city. It is the first legal settlement related to a death caused by the accident, which killed 11 people, city officials said. The claim, filed by the estate of John A. Valinski, left, a 40-year-old Staten Island resident, is among 191 claims totaling $3.3 billion. Though 79 cases have been settled for a total of $2.7 million, none involved passengers who died, the city comptroller's office said. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Ad Company's Sales Rise
description: The Publicis Groupe, the advertising and marketing company, said revenue rose 2.4 percent, to 887 million euros ($1.1 billion), in the first quarter, as the volume of new business offset the effects of a weak dollar and sluggish ad spending in some European markets. Publicis, based in Paris, said it gained new business worth $1.5 billion in the first quarter, a record for that period, after $1.8 billion in new bookings in the fourth quarter. "This is really huge," said Maurice Lvy, chief executive of Publicis. "The first indications for April are also very good." Eric Pfanner (IHT)

Pozen, whose proposal to overhaul Social Security has been embraced by President Bush, misstated the effect of his plan on retirement benefits of a worker who consistently earned the maximum amount taxed by Social Security -- currently $90,000 a year -- and retired in 2061. The pension would be 17 percent of the final wage in 2061, not 22 percent -- down from 30 percent today, not from 42 percent.

title: The Yankees Go From Bad to Abominable
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 3 - It has never been this bad, Joe Torre said Tuesday, and nothing has even come close. In his 10 seasons as the Yankees' manager, Torre has never experienced this: losing repeatedly, often badly, with nothing positive to fall back on.

title: Rieslings Easier to Drink Than to Name
description: PEOPLE don't talk much about Austrian wines, and for good reason. Unless you are fluent in German, just try saying, "Nigl Kremstal Kremser Kremsleiten," and see how far you get. The characteristically German pileup of consonants fences off these wines from many American consumers. Faced with mouthfuls like "smaragd" or "federspiel," who wouldn't call out desperately for a California chardonnay?

title: Jackson Prosecution Rests After 9 Weeks of Twists
description: SANTA MARIA, Calif., May 4 - The prosecution rested its child-molesting case against Michael Jackson today after presenting an array of witnesses with muddled memories and mixed motives who told a dark and at times bewildering story of sex, underage drinking and conspiracy.

Gesturing toward the curvilinear complex that she had designed for a school and fashion museum in Milan, she likened its podlike classrooms and studios to "bubble gum pulling apart."

title: Keeping the Ancient in an Ancient Greek Saga
description: Continuing one of the oldest theatrical institutions in New York theater, Ellen Stewart, the dreadlocked founder, artistic director and spiritual guru of La MaMa E.T.C., rang a bell on Saturday at the beginning of her new production of "Perseus." "Don't mind me," she said, from a wheelchair. "I'm better than I look." That's saying something, since Ms. Stewart appears decades younger than her age, which she describes as "late 70's -- very late 70's."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Killer Sentenced In Road Rage Case
description: A man convicted of murdering a Liberian diplomat's son after a traffic encounter was sentenced yesterday in Queens Supreme Court to 40 years to life in prison. The man, Oliver Berry, 24, was convicted last month of fatally shooting Josiah Salley, 27, after their cars nearly collided on a South Jamaica street on July 16, 2002. Prosecutors said the men argued, and Mr. Berry later fired his semiautomatic handgun seven times into Mr. Salley's car, killing him and wounding a passenger. Yesterday, Justice Richard L. Buchter called it "murder over total nonsense." Taylor Sele, 21, the victim's brother and a football player at Boston College, denounced Mr. Berry for committing murder over "what should have been a minor traffic incident." Mr. Sele said his father, Edwin F. Sele, a Liberian diplomat at the United Nations, missed the sentencing because he is running for president of Liberia. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL SIGNS NATURAL GAS DEAL WITH LIBYA
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said yesterday that it had signed a deal with the Libyan government to upgrade an existing natural gas plant and develop five additional blocks in the Sirte Basin, the country's major oil and gas region. Shell may spend up to $450 million to upgrade Libya's Marsa Al-Brega gas plant and plans to improve its output by 2.5 million metric tons a year, to 3.2 million tons. The company, which has been struggling to add to its reserves, said it planned to spend a minimum of $187 million on exploration of the five new blocks. Terms of the deals were not disclosed. Linda Cook, Shell's executive director for gas and power, said liquefied natural gas could eventually be shipped from the Libyan fields to North America. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Vallone, a Former Speaker, Endorses Miller in Mayoral Race
description: The City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, picked up an important endorsement yesterday in his bid to become the Democratic mayoral nominee, winning the support of Peter F. Vallone Sr., himself a former Council speaker and candidate for mayor.

title: Ford and G.M. Suffer as Buyers Shun S.U.V.'s
description: DETROIT, May 3 - The latest automobile sales figures show that Americans are increasingly wary of gas-thirsty sport utility vehicles. That was particularly bad news for General Motors and the Ford Motor Company, which both saw their sales slip last month as consumers continued their steady march into Asian car companies' dealerships.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bank's Profit Rises
description: Banco Ita Holding Financeira said its profit rose 30 percent in the first quarter, helped by an increase in consumer lending and rising interest rates. The bank earned 1.14 billion reais ($458 million) in the quarter, up from a profit of 876 million reais in the period a year ago. Ita, which is based in So Paulo, said its loan portfolio grew 27.4 percent from a year ago and 7 percent from the fourth quarter, to 57 billion reais, benefiting from several new partnerships with retail chains allowing the bank to manage their credit portfolios. Todd Benson (NYT)

You will learn how to request sweet shrimp (ama ebi) or additional pickled ginger (gari). And you will know to dip the topping, not the rice, into the soy sauce using your fingers, not chopsticks.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: First Lady Storms Newspaper Office
description: Lucy Kibaki, the wife of President Mwai Kibaki, stormed into the Nairobi office of The Nation early yesterday, confiscated notebooks, tape recorders and pens, and demanded to know the whereabouts of a reporter who had written an article that offended her. Mrs. Kibaki then camped herself for much of the night at the desk of the newspaper's editor, unleashing a fury of broadsides at the staff. When a local television crew arrived, she slapped a cameraman. The first lady was angry at an article that had appeared in a rival newspaper that described how she had three times interrupted a farewell party held by the departing country director of the World Bank to demand that music she said was too loud be stopped. "This is Muthaiga, not Korogocho," she angrily told the crowd of diplomats and other notables at the party, contrasting the plush neighborhood where she lives with one of Nairobi's sprawling slums. Marc Lacey (NYT)

With his late wife, Dr. Mamie Phipps Clark, he founded Northside Center for Child Development in 1946; the first private child guidance center in Harlem. Dr. Kenneth B. Clark was an eminent scholar, social activist and humanist, who dedicated his life to justice and social change. Family and friends will gather on Sunday May 8, 2005 from 2 to 6 P.M. at Benta's Funeral Home, 630 Saint Nicholas Avenue at 141st Street. Funeral services will be held Monday May 9, 2005 at 10 A.M. at Saint Phillip's Episcopal Church, 204 West 134 Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to: Northside Center for Child Development, Executive Office, 1301 Fifth Avenue, NY, NY 10029. 212-426-3412. He will be deeply missed by his friends, colleagues, and above all, his entire family. The Family

title: GENZYME TO ACQUIRE BONE CARE FOR $600 MILLION
description: Genzyme, which makes drugs for enzyme disorders, agreed to acquire Bone Care International for $33 a share to add products to treat kidney diseases. The transaction, set to close in the third quarter, is valued at about $600 million, net of Bone Care's cash holdings of $119 million, Genzyme said. The offer is 38 percent higher than Bone Care's closing stock price Tuesday of $23.83 a share. Genzyme purchased six other companies in the last two years to help reduce its dependence on treatments for rare illnesses such as Gaucher disease. Bone Care, based in Middleton, Wis., expects sales of as much as $83 million for the fiscal year ending June 30. Genzyme's sales in 2004 totaled $2.2 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, MILTON F.
description: ROSENTHAL--Milton F., age 91, died May 2, 2005. Beloved husband of 62 years of Frieda (nee Bojar). Cherished son of the late Jacob and Louise Rosenthal. Devoted father of Anne (Peter) Mitro of Moreland Hills, Ohio; grandfather to Daniel and Roger. Loving brother of the late Alexander Rosenthal. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of Milton F. Rosenthal, a prominent business executive, who served with distinction as a Trustee and Life Trustee for 28 years. Milton Rosenthal's outstanding support of Mount Sinai included the creation of the Frieda and Milton F. Rosenthal Coronary Care Unit and other important trustee initiatives. Mr. Rosenthal will be remembered for his loyalty and thoughtful generosity. title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: No Appeal Of Verdict In Air India Bombing
description: Prosecutors in Vancouver said they will not appeal the acquittal of two Sikh men who were charged in the 1985 bombing of Air India Flight 182, which exploded and crashed off Ireland while flying from Toronto to India, killing 329. In a ruling in March, the judge in the case said the prosecution's chief witnesses against the two men, Ripudaman Singh Malik, 58, and Ajaib Singh Bagri, 55, were not credible. Prosecutors have now concluded that there were no legal errors in the ruling that would allow an appeal. The decision was met with disappointment from the victim's families, who continue to demand a federal inquiry into the failure of the 20-year case. Colin Campbell (NYT)

Two of the teenagers, aged 14 and 15, were not identified by the police. The third teenager was identified by the police as Angel Cespedes, 16. The beating left the Rev. Jorge Fernandez, who is a priest at Our Savior parish, hospitalized with injuries that included a broken jaw.

title: National Briefing | West: California: More Surveillance On Freeways
description: Amid mounting concern about freeway shootings, the authorities in Southern California plan to set up video recorders to monitor vehicles and have asked state officials in Sacramento to help pay for increased surveillance. The federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives said that it had dispatched agents to patrol freeways and that it would set up mobile forensic laboratories to investigate shootings. Four drivers have died in less than two months, victims of apparently random shootings, and at least four others have been injured. The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors plans to vote next week on whether to give a $10,000 reward for information on the shootings. Nick Madigan (NYT)

title: The Arts, Briefly; Discord in Montreal
description: The management of the Montreal Symphony Orchestra announced that it was canceling the rest of the season until further notice after its musicians said that they would strike on Monday. The contract expired in August 2003. The union blamed management for refusing to budge on proposals for changes in work rules that the union said would overburden the musicians, and for offering an "insulting" wage package that provided for average raises of 0.9 percent through 2009. Management said that the changes would ensure a resumption of touring and recording contracts. At the root of the problem, as it has been at orchestras across North America in recent years, is a financial crunch. The Montreal Symphony said that it had a $2.7 million accumulated deficit and excessively high labor costs. The musicians accuse management of failing to raise enough money. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: A Tiffany Treasure Unmasked And Open to the Public

Along the proscenium and balconies, a Manhattan firm called the Finished Wall is using dental tools to exhume gilded and purple-blue glass tiles. "It's one of the finest Tiffany mosaics that's publicly accessible," said Tom Venturella, an expert in Tiffany restoration. The theater, completed in 1903, was a television studio after World War II, then a pornographic film theater, a nightclub and, starting in the late 1980's, an events venue. The Times Square Alliance has free tours that include the theater; www.timessquarenyc.org or (212)869-1890. EVE M. KAHN

She was also a member of the Cosmopolitan Club, the Colonial Dames of America, the Daughters of the Cincinnati and a women's flyfishing club. A graduate of New York University, he received his J.D. from New York Law School. George lived life to its fullest. He leaves his wife, Gunilla; his son, Peter; his daughter, Veronica; and his granddaughter, Rebecca. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, May 9th, 11:30 A.M. Entombment to follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Stem Cell Research Bill Passes

The bill passed 119 to 38 and will return to the Senate, which passed it last week, for one last procedural vote before landing on the desk of Gov. Mitt Romney. Mr. Romney opposes a type of research permitted in the bill and has said he will veto it. Based on the votes, both legislative chambers have the two-thirds majority necessary to override the veto. Katie Zezima (NYT)

Ruffles and a wide ribbon tied around one sleeve elevate the rainy day staple to a flirty frock. Saks Fifth Avenue was sold out of the coat, but you can get one without leaving home at shopbop.com, where the hard-to-find coats are available in limited sizes ($475). If you like the coat, you might want to check out L.A.M.B.'s taupe blazer. Taking a cue from the trench, it has a champagne-colored ribbon tied around the right sleeve ($365).

Mr. Harris was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. None of the students were injured, the police said. They said they were investigating whether the driver of the car had run a stop sign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANNIGAN, JOHN J.
description: HANNIGAN--John J., 85, of Lititz, PA, passed away on May 4, 2005. Born in New York City, NY, he formerly resided in Manhattan, Manhasset, Long Island and Honeybrook, PA. He was a member of St. James Catholic Church, Lititz, PA. John was a veteran of WW II, serving with the U.S. Army, 14th Division New 6th Army, in the China and India theatre. Formerly he was a New York City police officer and detective, and also worked for Pan Am Cargo. Survivors include his wife of 57 years, Mary K. Lennon Hannigan, daughter, Mary Anne Hannigan, and grandson, Sean Patrick H. Wernersbach, all of Lititz, and a sister, Mary Daly of Highland Lakes, NJ. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, May 7, 2005 10AM from St. James Catholic Church, 505 Woodcrest Ave., Lititz. Friends may call on Friday afternoon from 24PM and Friday evening from 7-9PM at Richard H. Heisey Funeral Home, 216 S. Broad St., Lititz, and Saturday morning from 9-10AM at the church. Interment will be private at the convenience of the family.

Andrew Thornton, a New York architect, and his wife, Jenny Argie, designed two versions in birch after their son was born, and both are now on the market. Some of those shown here can lose their trays and pull up to the table. One design, the Kinderzeat, is being used at the Modern, the new restaurant at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. All meet industry safety requirements for highchairs (there are no government rules) while answering a call for contemporary furnishings for every age group.

One thing stuck in my mind about his place, besides a pet mongoose I kept confusing for a member of his entourage. He had a Lucite staircase with a built-in fish tank, an aesthetic that I mocked at the time as drug-dealer modern but that I now look back on as visionary.

title: In the Spirit of Bobby Short, a Tribute Filled With Songs
description: More than 100 of Bobby Short's friends and musical colleagues packed the Cafe Carlyle on Tuesday evening to pay tribute to the singer and pianist who died March 21, leaving a gaping hole in the nightlife of Manhattan. Mr. Short, who was 80, would have opened his 37th spring season at the cafe on Tuesday. And the celebration, organized by the Carlyle Hotel with his friend Lisa Schiff, had the happy-sad atmosphere of an opening-night party whose ebullience was muted by the guest of honor's conspicuous absence.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Profit Surges At IAC/Interactive
description: IAC/InterActiveCorp, owner of the Expedia and LendingTree.com Web sites, said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 74 percent, helped by an increase in travel bookings and loan refinancing. Net income rose to $72.2 million, or 9 cents a share, from $41.5 million, or 5 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales at IAC, which also owns the HSN home-shopping network, climbed 14 percent, to $1.65 billion. The company, which is based in New York and is run by Barry Diller, said operating profit before interest, taxes, amortization and other costs increased 32 percent, to $168.5 million, at its travel unit.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES PLANS TO CLOSE A BAKERY AND CUT JOBS
description: Interstate Bakeries, the maker of Hostess Twinkies and Wonder Bread, said that it would close a bakery in Charlotte, N.C., and consolidate some routes and stores in the Carolinas and in Virginia, cutting about 950 jobs. Reducing operations in the Middle Atlantic region will cost the company about $17 million, including about $3 million in severance pay, Interstate said. The company, based in Kansas City, Mo., is trying to return to profitability by eliminating some operations and paring expenses. In September, Interstate Bakeries filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The closure and the consolidations are expected to be completed by July 23, subject to approval by the bankruptcy court.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Port To Require Criminal Checks
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey began requiring criminal background checks on all of its employees and contractors after a man who worked as a painter on the George Washington Bridge was arrested and turned over to federal immigration agents, a Port Authority spokesman said yesterday. The man, who was employed by a painting company, was stopped by the police yesterday afternoon for tailgating on Route 46 in Ridgefield Park, N.J., said Capt. Kevin Hartnett of the Bergen County police. His name and the name of his companion were on lists of immigrants whose visas had expired, said Steve Siegel, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Newark. The men, who were not suspected of any involvement in terrorism, were turned over to Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Mr. Siegel said. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

title: At the Derby, Zito's Horses Come From All Angles
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 - Nick Zito has rightly taken his bows for the remarkable achievement of bringing five 3-year-old colts to the Kentucky Derby this year. But after Wednesday's draw, the warm, fuzzy feeling of being only the second trainer to bring such an arsenal to America's greatest race, and the first to do so for five different owners, gave way to the inevitable pressure.

title: Togo tinderbox raises specter of civil war
Recipe for a Type-A Chef: Abracadabra, Just Add Iron
description: Cooktops for amateur chefs with less time than money will be out from Wolf this summer. Using induction, a technology popular in Europe, they boil water and sear steaks faster than any electric burner, said Al Wilkins, Wolf's chief operating officer. The surface remains cool (spills don't burn) because induction uses a magnetic field that comes alive only in contact with pots made of magnetic materials like iron. This unit is 15 by 21 inches. It's a miserly energy consumer, Mr. Wilkins said. And at $1,500, one would hope so. DEBORAH BALDWIN

title: Home Runs Wanted. No Questions Asked.
description: Philadelphia - ON the surface, the commissioner of baseball, Bud Selig, deserves hearty congratulations for his newly proposed policy on steroid use. title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Neo-Nazi Gets 7 Years For Bomb Plot
description: Martin Wiese, 29, the accused ringleader of a neo-Nazi group that plotted to bomb the site of a new Jewish cultural center in Munich in 2003, was sentenced to seven years in prison. He was tried separately from his five accomplices, who were convicted last month and sentenced to probation. Alexandra Walsh (NYT)

title: CIGNA SAYS ITS EARNINGS ROSE IN THE FIRST QUARTER
description: Cigna said yesterday that earnings for its first quarter rose to $436 million, or $3.28 a share, from $68 million, or 48 cents a share, helped by a gain on the sale of a retirement savings business and a slowdown in medical cost increases. Revenue fell 8 percent, to $4.35 billion. A $169 million gain from the sale of Cigna's retirement savings unit increased results in the quarter. Medical spending consumed about 84.3 percent of premiums in the first quarter and will account for 84 percent to 85 percent of premiums for the year, Cigna said. Medical costs increased by about 8 percent in the quarter, similar to increases reported in 2004.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARASZ, PETER

He led our firm with courage, energy and vision. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Marilyn, his children Alexandra, Andrew, Matthew and Valerie, and his sisters Zsuzsanna Karasz Lipsky and Fruzsina Marsh. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Computer Concern To Cut U.S. Jobs
description: The European computer services company Cap Gemini said its United States unit would return to profit by the end of the year as it cut jobs and office space. The reorganization may reduce revenue in the United States, the company said. Cap Gemini, based in Paris, expects to spend 127 million euros ($163.7 million) on a restructuring, which includes the elimination of 200 managers. "We are reshaping the pyramid, removing expensive people," the chief executive, Paul J. Hermelin, said. The company, which installs and runs corporate computer systems, said first-quarter sales rose 16 percent.

World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Second Case Of Polio Confirmed
description: A second case of polio was confirmed in Indonesia and more are expected, the Health Ministry said. About a half-dozen children with paralysis are being investigated in western Java, and the authorities are planning a vaccination drive to reach five million children in that region. Genetic tracing has shown that the strain of the polio virus found in the country this week originated in northern Nigeria and was probably picked up in Saudi Arabia by an Indonesian worker or a pilgrim returning from Mecca. Polio began spreading from northern Nigeria in 2003, after Muslims there refused the vaccine, fearing a plot to render Muslim girls infertile or spread AIDS. There has been no widespread resistance to the vaccine in Indonesia. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: At the Start, Lazard Shares May Face an Uphill Climb
description: BRUCE WASSERSTEIN won his battle to take Lazard public last night, raising $854.6 million from investors and ending the private control of one of the world's most fabled banking institutions.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Rises At Tobacco Concern

The company, based in London, said sales of four brands promoted internationally -- Kent, Dunhill, Lucky Strike and Pall Mall -- rose 2 percent, led by Kent, the best-selling premium cigarette brand in Russia. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Phillipsburg: Pollution Cleanup Announced
description: Atlantic States Cast Iron Pipe Company has agreed to spend $9.3 million to reduce mercury emissions from its Phillipsburg plant, Bradley M. Campbell, commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Protection, announced yesterday. The agreement will settle air and water pollution violations at the company since 2003, and improvements to the foundry are scheduled to be in place by January. The company will also pay a $51,520 fine and contribute $85,000 to a mercury monitoring project in Warren County. The new emissions reduction system is expected to reduce carbon monoxide pollution from the plant by 60 percent and reduce electricity consumption by about 25 percent. Tina Kelley (NYT)

The building, a landmark limestone mansion built in the 1920's, had been home to a branch of the Limited, and there was a jarring disconnect between the $8 hoop earrings sold there and the majestic environment.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Office Tower Sold
description: Citigroup, which announced last summer that it would move 1,600 jobs from Manhattan to New Jersey, has sold its 50-story office building in Long Island City. The company will maintain a 15-year lease on the building, One Court Square, which dominates the western Queens skyline. The 1.4-million-square-foot building was sold to Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, which controls 90 properties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. A Reckson official said the company believes that Long Island City will benefit from the success of Manhattan's office space market, which has one of the lowest rates of vacancy in the country. Citigroup officials have said that even though they are moving some technical jobs out of New York, the company intends to add more workers over the next several years. Last year, Citigroup announced plans to build another office tower across the street from One Court Square.

title: F.B.I. Will Exhume the Body of Emmett Till for an Autopsy

While no one fully understands these gyrations, we do know that markets become skittish when fundamentals are out of whack. There's arguably no more fundamental imbalance these days than the United States' low national savings -- the amount Americans save minus the amount the government borrows. But don't expect to hear our nation's leaders talk about it.

title: STRAYER SAYS 2ND-QUARTER PROFIT MAY NOT MEET ESTIMATES
description: Strayer Education said earnings for its second quarter would not rise as much as some analysts had expected. Strayer said it expected profit to increase to 82 cents to 84 cents in the period, below the 92 cents that was expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The company focused too heavily on issues such as bad debt expenses and management retention without paying enough attention to enrollment, Strayer's chief executive, Robert Silberman, told analysts on a conference call. The company, based in Arlington, Va., also said first-quarter net income rose 23 percent, to $14.1 million, as revenue rose 22 percent, to $56.2 million. (Bloomberg News)

Government officials said the requirement, part of a larger effort by American conservatives to attach moral conditions to foreign aid, was an unacceptable interference in Brazil's internal affairs and would reduce the effectiveness of programs to combat AIDS among prostitutes and drug users. title: A Better Way to Fight Poverty
description: Kenya has never seemed to be able to live up to the potential of its rich farmland and staggeringly beautiful valleys. Its government is corrupt. Its capital, Nairobi, has become a haven for street thieves and muggers. Some 56 percent of the population lives below the poverty level. Malaria, which could be as treatable as strep throat, kills one in five children every year because the government grossly shortchanges its public health system. All in all, it is a classic case of how African governments can squander foreign aid.

title: The Arts, Briefly; The Boss Edges 'Mimi'
description: Bruce Springsteen, below, narrowly beat Mariah Carey for the top spot on the Billboard album chart this week. His "Devils & Dust" (Columbia), released last week, sold 222,000 copies in the week that ended Sunday, about 25,000 more than Ms. Carey's "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island), according to Nielsen SoundScan. "Devils & Dust," released on the new DualDisc format -- one side CD, the other side DVD -- is Mr. Springsteen's second album in a row to debut at No. 1; "The Rising" reached the top spot three years ago, though it made a much bigger splash, selling 525,000 copies in its first week. Two new albums by R&B newcomers have made their debuts in the Top 5: Bobby Valentino, a protg of the rapper Ludacris, reached No.3 with "Disturbing Tha Peace Presents: Bobby Valentino" (DTP/Def Jam), his first album, and Amerie is at No. 5 with her second, "Touch" (Columbia). Last week's top seller, Rob Thomas's "Something to Be" (Atlantic), dropped to No.4, with 145,000 copies sold. BEN SISARIO

World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Charges Against Mayor Dropped
description: Mexico's new attorney general, Daniel Cabeza de Vaca, left, announced that his office would drop the charges that have threatened to keep Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador, the popular mayor of Mexico City, out of next year's presidential election. The decision had been expected since last week, when President Vicente Fox announced on television that he had accepted the resignation of the former attorney general, Rafael Macedo de la Concha, and ordered a review of the case against Mr. Lpez Obrador. In a statement, the attorney general's office indicated that it considered the mayor responsible for disobeying a court order in a minor land dispute, but said the charges were dropped because prosecutors were not clear on what sentence the mayor would face if convicted. Mr. Fox has scheduled a meeting with Mr. Lpez Obrador for tomorrow. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

description: Washington - NEARLY two years after Charles Taylor fled Monrovia under pressure from advancing rebels and a force of Marines on ships off Liberia, he sits exiled in Nigeria, plotting to undermine an international effort to rebuild the country he did so much to destroy. Although Mr. Taylor has been indicted on charges of fueling a brutal war in neighboring Sierra Leone, a deal brokered by Nigeria and the United States has kept him beyond the reach of justice.

World Briefing | Asia: Tens Of Thousands Still Missing In Tsunami
description: More than four months after the Indian Ocean tsunami killed more than 200,000 people, tens of thousands of people are listed as missing and thousands of the bodies that have been recovered have not been identified, experts said at a meeting sponsored by the World Health Organization in Phuket, Thailand. Although forensic scientists from 29 countries have collaborated to speed up identification of bodies, their work has been hampered by lack of medical records and information from relatives. In some parts of Indonesia, where 93,000 people are listed as missing, "entire villages including families and paperwork that could help identify bodies were swept away," said Dr. Luis Jorge Prez, a W.H.O. official. Many bodies were buried quickly for fear that they would start epidemics, despite repeated advice from the W.H.O. that dead bodies were not a health hazard. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: DELTA SAYS PENSION COSTS TOTAL $3.6 BILLION THROUGH 2008
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it expected to contribute a total of $3.6 billion to its employee pension plans in 2005 and the next three years. The airline said in a regulatory filing that it expected to provide $450 million to the plans this year, $600 million next year, $950 million in 2007 and $1.6 billion in 2008, under current funding rules. Also yesterday, Mesa Air Group, which conducts commuter flights for larger carriers, agreed to operate as many as 30 regional jets for Delta. Under a 12-year agreement, Mesa's Freedom Airlines unit will begin flights for Delta as soon as October. Mesa, based in Phoenix, also flies for America West, US Airways and United Airlines.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: Cancer Web Site In Spanish
description: Each year, 45,000 cases of cancer are diagnosed in New Jersey, and nearly 18,000 residents die of the disease, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey said yesterday in announcing creation of a Spanish language Web site for cancer patients. The site, operated by the Cancer Institute of New Jersey, will provide information on clinical trials. Patients or family members can register at the site, create a private home page, scan the roughly 400 clinical trials of cancer treatments under way at state hospitals, and receive e-mail notification of new trials. The site's Internet address is www.njctc.org/. Iver Peterson (NYT)

description: NORRIS--The Rev. Dr. Richard A. Jr. Noted theologian, priest and educator in the Episcopal Church, died at home on Saturday, April 23. He was 75. Ordained a priest in the Diocese of New York in 1955, he was a graduate of The General Theological Seminary, where he served on the faculty from 1964-1978. In 1978 he joined the faculty of Union Theological Seminary. He retired in 1996, being honored as Professor Emeritus. He also served as priest associate at the Church of St. Ignatius of Antioch in Manhattan from 1978 until his death. In 1990 he was made Honorary Canon Theologian to the Episcopal Bishop of New York. Dr. Norris was the author of many distinguished volumes in church history and theology. His most recent work was a large collection of translated commentaries on the "Song of Songs," from the early and medieval church. Earlier works included "Manhood and Christ" (1963), "God and World in Early Christian Theology" (1965), and "The Christological Controversy" (1980). Canon Norris is survived by his cousin Joan DeMoss of Silver Spring, MD, and by his aunt Ellie Richmond, of Gaithersburg, MD. A mass of the resurrection will be celebrated at 7 PM, Friday, May 6, at St. Ignatius Church, 552 West End Avenue. NORRIS--Richard A. Jr., Reverend Canon of the Episcopal Church. Clergy and parishioners of St. Ignatius of Antioch Church mourn the passing of teacher, scholar, priest and friend. Service at 7PM, May 6, St. Ignatius of Antioch Church, 552 West End Avenue.

title: The Listings: May 6-12; JACK GOLDSTEIN
description: Goldstein (1945-2003) was revered by the new Pop artists and theorists of the 80's. He manipulated mass media imagery with conceptually savvy elegance, and he was included in the famously influential "Pictures" exhibition at Artists Space in SoHo in 1977. In retrospect his achievement seems modest, but the wry lucidity of his sensibility and style is still compelling. Varying in length between 20 seconds and 5 minutes, the films from the early 70's on view at Mitchell-Innes & Nash have a deadpan quality that calls to mind William Wegman's early videos. In one, the MGM lion roars over and over. In "Shane," a trained German shepherd barks repeatedly on cue. In the elegiac "The Chair," colored feathers float down one by one onto a chair covered with sticky tar. On canvas, Goldstein airbrushed expansive, simplified pictures of celestial events -- some meteorological or astronomical, some suggesting fireworks or military gunfire (above). Among the best, examples of which are at Metro Pictures as well as Mitchell-Innes & Nash, are views of lightning storms as much as 12 feet wide in which jagged white lines haloed by intense pinks, greens and blues flare out from fields of nocturnal darkness. With their sensuous eggshell surfaces and visionary atmospherics, the pictures are cinematically thrilling. Like the landscapes of Ed Ruscha to whom they appear much indebted, Goldstein's paintings are a form of postmodern transcendentalism. He had a keen eye for the new, hypermediated sublime. (Metro Pictures, 519 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212)206-7100, through May 28. Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, between 78th and 79th Street, (212)744-7400, through June 11; both free.) KEN JOHNSON

title: The Listings: May 6-12; CONOR DONOVAN AND HARRY ZITTEL
description: The two brothers in Paul Weitz's play "Privilege" can make you forget where you are. As they bicker and joke in front of 299 people at the Second Stage Theater, it seems as if the audience is peeping through a keyhole into their room. What the performers manage to do is thoroughly persuade you that they are not the actors Conor Donovan, 14, and Harry Zittel, 18, but 12-year-old Charlie (he of the blue blazer) and 16-year-old Porter (note the vintage Clash T-shirt), who are dragged along for a very bumpy ride in 1987, when their wealthy father is accused of insider trading. Reviewers, mixed on the play, were of one voice in their praise for the young actors. Looking relaxed before last Saturday's matinee, the two talked at the theater about how a pair of strangers can appear as if they've known each other all their lives. Mr. Donovan (above left), a student at New Canaan High School in Connecticut, sounded practical: "We rehearsed for four weeks." Mr. Zittel, a senior at LaGuardia High School of the Performing Arts in Manhattan, offered a few details: "Conor's cool, so I don't mind hanging out with him. But there's something very natural about the writing, and both of us got used to it." In fact, Mr. Weitz does have a brother, Chris, with whom he sometimes works. For the record, Mr. Donovan, who appeared on Broadway in "Our Town" with Paul Newman, has a sister; Mr. Zittel, who played Adam Hughes for three years on "As the World Turns," has a sister and a brother. When the reviews came out, did they read them? Both actors grinned mischievously. Mr. Zittel took the bland route: "I read a couple, so I have some awareness of them." Mr. Donovan went further: "We're really not supposed to. If it's going well, you don't want to change it based on what they might say." (Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43rd Street, (212)246-4422.) ANDREA STEVENS

But these cultural revolutions, and the African-American milieu that spawned them, got no respect until Elvis died in 1977, and the city was inundated by grieving fans spending green money. Soon, Memphis began the urban-renewed version of Beale Street -- its answer to Bourbon Street, sans the nudie shows -- which over the years has become more like frat row. title: The Listings: May 6-12; NETA PULVERMACHER
description: She was born and raised in Kibbutz Lehavot Habashan in Israel. She came to the United States in the 1980's to train in dance at the Juilliard School, founding her own company in 1987, soon after graduation. She will soon choreograph Mira Nair's new film, "The Namesake." Ms. Pulvermacher drew on childhood memories for her 1993 "Five Beds/Children of the Dream," a signature dance that will be presented in a retrospective of her work this month at the Flea Theater. Her Jewish heritage also informs "Goodbye and Goodluck" (above), a dance about exhumed legends of the Lower East Side that was a collaboration with the composer Anthony Coleman and his SelfHaters, a band of six violinists. But the lyrical, sweeping physicality of Juilliard schooling has also always been present in her work, here in revivals of "Vivaldiana," a voluptuous yet formal duet for women that is called "Matildas,"and "Rainbow Girl," set in part to music by Schubert. Uncategorizable, perhaps, are the remaining two dances in the two-program repertory. "River of Orchids," set to music by the British rock band XTC, is an exceedingly whimsical bit of frivolity set in a psychedelic swamp of giant vinyl lily pads. And "A Song" was inspired by the vanishing language and heritage of the Tliglit people whom Ms. Pulvermacher met in residencies in Alaska. Of equal interest are the performers, who include the engaging Derry Swan, formerly with Merce Cunningham, and three eloquent founding members of the Pulvermacher company, Ani Udovicki, Stephanie Tooman and Kraig Patterson. ("Netro: A Neta Dance Company Retrospective" will be presented Wednesday through next Saturday (and May 18 to 21) at 7 p.m. and next Sunday at 3 p.m. The Flea Theater, 41 White Street, TriBeCa, (212)352-3101. Tickets: $20.) JENNIFER DUNNING

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Runaway Bride Apologizes
description: Jennifer Wilbanks, the Duluth woman who led law enforcement agencies on a three-day manhunt after disappearing days before her wedding, issued her first detailed statement, apologizing and saying she had been "running away from myself and from certain fears controlling my life." Mayor Shirley Lasseter said the city was still assessing the search costs and expected to ask Ms. Wilbanks for restitution and to perform community service. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Iraq's Violence Sweeps Away All the Norms
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 5 - The gardenias are blooming in Baghdad, but Hala is not allowed out in the garden to cut them. A 16-year-old high school student, Hala was kidnapped for a day in the middle of April and has not set foot outside her house since.

title: TBWA loses its British ad director
Jonathan Thomas, Artist, Dies at 59
description: Jonathan Thomas, a sculptor who exhibited widely in North America, died on Monday at his home in New York. He was 59.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Smarty Jones Still Draws a Crowd
description: MIDWAY, Ky., May 5 - Americans still love Smarty Jones. They visit his new home, Three Chimneys Farm, in droves. They just want to catch a glimpse of him or get a piece of something connected to him.

title: Husband of Prosecutor Says He's Suing Reputed Mobster
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 5 - Albert J. Pirro Jr., the husband of the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, said on Thursday that he had sued a reputed mob figure for slander for stating that he had tipped them about an investigation by his wife's office.

title: BLOCKBUSTER POSTS LOSS OF $57.5 MILLION FOR QUARTER
description: Blockbuster, the video rental chain, posted a first-quarter loss of $57.5 million, partly because it eliminated late fees and increased marketing to stem customer defections. The company said yesterday that the result meant a loss of 31 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $114.4 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 3 percent, to $1.55 billion. Advertising costs more than doubled to $119 million. Carl C. Icahn, the company's largest shareholder, said on a conference call yesterday that some initiatives had not worked out. He has nominated three candidates, including himself, for election to the board at Blockbuster's annual meeting on May 11.

title: Paris Hilton and Friends, Pursued by Maniacs With a Fondness for Wax
description: "House of Wax," the latest high-end frightener to be released by Warner Brothers under the Dark Castle label, begins with a creepy flashback to 1974. The date is fitting, because even though this movie is a loose remake -- a "reimagining," in the words of its publicity material -- of a 1953 horror classic starring Vincent Price, its more immediate sources of inspiration are the cheap, grisly and highly effective scare pictures of the 70's, a decade that saw the birth of the "Halloween" and "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" franchises.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Macao: Wynn Plans Casino Expansion
description: Wynn Resorts, the casino company headed by Stephen A. Wynn, added a $345 million wing to plans for its casino in Macao. Wynn Resorts was already spending $700 million to build the casino, set to open in the third quarter of 2006. The expansion will almost double casino space and add two restaurants and a theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRADLEY, ESTHER WEIGT
description: BRADLEY--Esther Weigt. A service of remembrance will be held on May 7, at 12 noon at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Route 25, Brookfield Center, Brookfield, CT.

title: Facing Surplus, Mayor Plans to Spread It Around
description: New York City will end the fiscal year with a record $3.3 billion surplus fueled in part by taxes from a superheated real estate market. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed an election-year budget yesterday that would spread that wealth around by cutting taxes and spending millions more on reducing class sizes, increasing garbage pickups and other measures sure to please voters.

title: Kremlin fires back at critics
Private Will Face New Charges Over Abuse of Prisoners in Iraq
description: KILLEEN, Tex., May 5 - The government will file new charges soon against Pfc. Lynndie R. England, whose guilty plea was thrown out and her court-martial canceled Wednesday over testimony by the convicted ringleader in the Abu Ghraib prison scandal, an Army defense lawyer said Thursday after meeting with military prosecutors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLAKE, FREDERICK H. JR.
description: BLAKE--Frederick H. Jr., on May 3, 2005. Husband of the late Lois Catherine Robinson. Previously deceased are his parents, Helen Avery and Frederick H. Blake. Also deceased are his sister, Avery B. Walker, and two brothers, Charles A. Blake and Dexter B. Blake. Surviving are four generations of nieces and nephews. Services will be private. Those who wish may contribute in his memory to the New Vernon First Aid Squad or the New Vernon Volunteer Fire Department, both located at PO Box 143 Village Road, New Vernon, New Jersey 07976.

title: Arts, Briefly; Spotlight on Comic Books
description: Tomorrow is Free Comic Book Day. In the fourth annual event, sponsored by comic book publishers, retailers and Diamond Comics Distributors are to give away more than two million comic books, featuring a range of characters including Batman, Spider-Man, the Simpsons and Betty and Veronica. The giveaways also include Impact University, a sampler of lessons on how to write and illustrate comics, and Wizards Top 100, a guide to the best comic book trade paperbacks. A list of participating stores and the availability of specific titles is at www.freecomicbookday.com. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 25 about the former Israeli president Ezer Weizman mischaracterized the affiliation of the secondary school he attended in Haifa. The Hareali Ha'ivri school was founded by Zionists in pre-World War I Palestine; it was not run by the British.

title: Seeking Adult Answers in Two Scarred Boyhoods
description: Based on a novel by Scott Heim, Gregg Araki's "Mysterious Skin" tells the parallel stories of two boys growing up in a small town in Kansas in the 1980's and early 90's. One, Brian Lackey (played first by George Webster and then in his late teenage years by Brady Corbet), believes that the nightmares and nosebleeds that afflict him throughout adolescence are results of an alien abduction that occurred in the summer of 1981, when he was a shy, frail 8-year-old. That same summer, Neil McCormick (Chase Ellison, and later, Joseph Gordon-Levitt) was molested by his Little League coach (Bill Sage).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENSINGER, ALYCE G.
description: ENSINGER--Alyce G., of Litchfield, CT, formerly of Eastchester, NY and Mill River, MA, died on April 29th at her home. Beloved wife of Lewis G. Ensinger; loving mother of Lynne, Carol and Lori; caring sister of Frederick Gurzeler and cherished sister of Ferd and Mary Ensinger. "God could not be everywhere, so he made mothers." Funeral service and burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Oliver Wolcott Library, P.O. Box 187, Litchfield, CT 06759 or the Charlotte Hungerford Hospital, Development Office, 540 Litchfield Street, Torrington, CT 06790.

title: Delay at Ground Zero, Bad Timing for Pataki
description: ALBANY, May 5 - More than any other official, Gov. George E. Pataki has sought to make the reconstruction of the World Trade Center site his legacy. But just as the governor is trying to chart his political future, the rebuilding effort has been bedeviled by a series of setbacks that could hardly have come at a worse time.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Flextronics Software Profit Rises 42%
description: Flextronics Software Systems, an Indian telecommunications and software maker owned by Flextronics International, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 42 percent as orders increased. Net income rose to 301 million rupees ($6.9 million), or 8.67 rupees a share, in the three months ended March 31, from 212 million rupees, or 6.23 rupees, a year earlier. The company, which is based in Gurgaon, near New Delhi, said sales rose to 1.3 billion rupees. Profit beat the 289 million-rupee estimate of seven analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News. Flextronics International, which is based in Singapore and already owns about 70 percent of the Indian unit, said Wednesday that it might buy the remaining shares in the subsidiary and delist the stock. Flextronics International offered to pay 575 rupees for each share. Shares of Flextronics Software, which surged 13 percent Wednesday, fell 9.6 rupees, or 1.5 percent, to 613.5 rupees in Mumbai yesterday.

title: 2 Witnesses Say They Shared Jackson's Bed and Were Never Molested
description: SANTA MARIA, Calif., May 5 - Two young men who said they shared a bed many times with Michael Jackson when they were boys said emphatically on Thursday that he had never molested them or touched them inappropriately.
