description: THROUGH the night and into the day, the roll call flowed on and on, a river of memory and pain.

title: A World Champion of Cabinetmaking
description: If, for fun, you equated America's top colonial cabinetmakers with today's major league baseball players, you could appreciate the fierce rivalries between various city teams -- Philadelphia and New York, say, or Boston and Newport, R.I. By the 1750's, Philadelphia was winning the World Series of cabinetmaking. In the 1760's and 1770's, however, the title often went to Newport.

title: Where No Fish Swim
description: Almost everyone who has taken the Harlem Line through the Bronx and Westchester County knows the look of the Bronx River. Anywhere else, it would be a wild river, just the right size for fishing, but this river looks too often like the derelict edge of human habitation. And yet things have changed for the river. It no longer looks like radiator fluid flowing past abandoned tires. It looks almost natural enough to harbor a population of trout.

title: Not Much Left to Say for Last-Place Yanks
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 5 - Derek Jeter remembers the glory days, an era in Yankees history that seems to be gone forever. The Yankees of that generation hardly resemble this team, a collection of faded stars who have crash-landed in the basement of the American League East.

title: States and Employers Duel Over Health Care
description: The relentless rise in health care costs is causing states and businesses to fight over whose job it is to insure workers. And nearly two dozen states, struggling with the growing burden of providing public assistance to people with jobs but no insurance, are looking to shift more of the financial burden onto the workers' employers.

title: Insurer Ex-Chief Is Called Target of Stock Inquiry
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have opened an investigation into whether Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chairman and chief executive of the insurance giant American International Group, orchestrated an effort to manipulate the company's stock price in his final weeks as chief, people officially briefed on the inquiry said yesterday.

title: Conservatives Fail in Bid to Topple Canada's Liberal Government
description: TORONTO, May 5 - The Conservative Party staged a surprise move to topple Prime Minister Paul Martin's government on Thursday and to call an immediate election, but the parliamentary maneuver failed when the speaker of the House of Commons, from Mr. Martin's Liberal Party, ruled it out of order.

description: For way too long, managers of sports arenas and museums were content to provide people with mediocre nibbles, never thinking to use food as a way to augment the experience, to burnish it.

By 6:15 a.m., his exercise rider, Salomon Diego, was on his back for a two-mile jog around the Churchill Downs oval. But his work was not over yet.

Sorenstam won the last five tournaments she played, including two in 2004, not five this year.

title: Chopping Off the Weakest Branch
description: LEADING evangelical conservatives are taking on the federal judiciary, which they see as hostile to religion, and they have much more in mind than simply putting an end to Senate filibusters against judicial nominees. Some have now proposed that Congress cut off federal financing for judges and even abolish some lower-level courts that they feel have issued decisions that mandate a secular, anti-Christian state. "We set up the courts," said the House majority leader, Tom DeLay, a key ally of the evangelicals. "We can unset the courts. We have the power of the purse."

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Treasurer To Rejoin Marines
description: State Treasurer Mike Coffman said he was rejoining the Marines for a nine-month stint in Iraq. Mr. Coffman, a Republican who retired as a major in 1994, said friends on active duty had told him his civilian experience was needed in Iraq. Mr. Coffman, 50, whose tenure as treasurer will end in 2006 because of term limits, said he would run for secretary of state upon his return. Gov. Bill Owens has not determined if he will appoint a temporary treasurer or a new one. Mindy Sink (NYT)

description: Dr. Robert N. Colwell, a forester and specialist in remote sensing who helped adapt the military's aerial image-reading techniques to forestry, mapmaking, land planning, agriculture and other fields, died on April 14 in a hospital in Walnut Creek, Calif. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAWRENCE, GWENDOLYN KNIGHT
description: LAWRENCE -- Gwendolyn Knight. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, May 7th, 2005 at 2 P.M., Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue at 112 St., NY, NY. All are welcome.

title: Chief Executive Quits at Merck; Insider Steps Up
description: Raymond V. Gilmartin resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of Merck, ending a troubled decade-long term during which Merck lost its place as the world's pre-eminent drug maker and was forced into a product recall that has clouded its future.

title: Fashion Victim
description: "FASHION is not art. It is a profession. It must be done with a lot of rigor," proclaimed Gabrielle Chanel, known to the world as Coco. Yet the new "Chanel" exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art recklessly disregards that dictum, elevating to artistic status not only Coco's designs but also the less celebrated oeuvre of Karl Lagerfeld, the current master of the House of Chanel.

title: A Modern Foray Into The Past
description: Blair McMillen is best known as a new-music pianist, both as a member of the contemporary music ensemble Counter)induction and as a soloist. But musicians as imaginative as Mr. McMillen tend to dislike being typecast, and perhaps the satisfyingly idiosyncratic recital on Wednesday at Casa Italiana at Columbia University was his way of showing the breadth of his interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TUCKER, N. GEORGE
description: TUCKER--N. George. Of Pompton Plains, N.J. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Devoted father of Edmond and Marie, and Laurence and Rise. Loving grandfather of Michelle and Paul Eisenberg. Services "Gutterman-Musicant", corner Park and Passaic Sts, Hackensack, Friday, 12:30PM. Donations may be made to ESL Program C/O River Vale Library, 412 River Vale Rd., River Vale, NJ 07675.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Posts Reward In Worker's Killing
description: New York's largest health care union has offered a $10,000 reward for information leading to a conviction in the death of an employee whose body was found on Sunday in Stockbridge, Mass. The authorities said the dead woman, Jan Stackhouse, was the first homicide victim there in years. Ms. Stackhouse, 52, was a director in the membership and dues department of the union, 1199/S.E.I.U. Yesterday, the union's president, Dennis Rivera, called her "a priceless asset" and said that the reward "was another way to bring forth justice swiftly." A spokesman for the Berkshire County district attorney said the investigation was continuing. James Barron (NYT)

title: New Intelligence Chief Announces 4 Top Aides
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 - The new director of national intelligence, John D. Negroponte, has provided the first concrete signs of his plans for reinventing American intelligence operations, naming four deputies to fill newly created posts, senior government officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Clothes Maker Plans Barbie Line
description: The Benetton Group, Italy's largest clothing maker, said it had reached an agreement with Mattel to make apparel for girls under the Barbie brand. The new line, to be called Barbie Loves Benetton, will be in stores by September, the company said. "Benetton Group sees co-branding with partners of a global level as strong business opportunities, and this agreement with Mattel is, I believe, the best example," Silvano Cassano, left, Benetton's chief executive, said. The agreement runs through 2006. Mattel is based in El Segundo, Calif.; Benetton is based in Treviso, Italy.

title: Arts, Briefly; Sweeps Update
description: ABC's Wednesday lineup -- new episodes of "Lost" and "Alias," along with the "Primetime Live" investigation into Fox's "American Idol" -- was No. 1 in the Nielsen estimates in both households and total viewers. "Lost," which gave viewers more about the pre-plane-crash life of Sayid (Naveen Andrews), attracted an audience of 16.53 million. But its ratings were low for an original episode, and "American Idol" drew a far larger crowd. Some 24.46 million viewers saw Scott Savol voted off the show. The numbers for that half-hour "Idol" gave Fox an overall victory among adults 18 to 49. Through six days of the May sweeps, CBS was in first place in households, viewers and in the 25-to-54 demographic. Fox was No. 1 in the two important younger age groups, 18 to 49 and 18 to 34. ABC has made double-digit percentage gains in every measure compared with last year. NBC was second in viewers and households but a dismal fourth among 18-to-49-year-olds. KATE AURTHUR

title: Giants Will Watch Miller and Wait Out the Market
description: In the week since the disclosure that Jim Miller, the Giants' backup quarterback, would miss at least three months with a hip injury, team officials have given more indications about what they will not do to address the absence than what they will do.

title: Ulster Vote Seen as a Victory for Hard-Liners on Both Sides
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 6 - Northern Irish voters delivered convincing victories to hard-line parties here in Britain's parliamentary elections this week, almost eliminating the moderates who had negotiated the landmark Belfast peace accord, and highlighting the province's sectarian divisions.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Rises At Medical Concern
description: Smith & Nephew, a British medical devices company, said its profit rose 13 percent in the first quarter as revenue increased 9 percent. Growth in the orthopedics and endoscopy units offset a weaker performance by the wound management division, the company said. Profit in the quarter, which ended April 2, rose to 48.9 million ($93 million) and revenue rose to 333.2 million ($633.7 million).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RADLER, RABBI EVAN C.
description: RADLER--Rabbi Evan C., 42, spiritual leader of Hillcrest Jewish Center, died suddenly late Sunday night. His funeral took place at the synagogue Tuesday. Burial was at New Montefiore Cemetery. Rabbi Radler who grew up in the New York area was ordained at Yeshiva University. The rabbi was an accomplished communicator, teacher and scholar. His sermons were always timely, interesting and distinguished by the fact that Rabbi Radler never used notes and could quote from a wide range of sources in his presentations. The rabbi's sense of humor was a mark of his very effective capacity to reach out to everyone he dealt with. Rabbi Radler is survived by his wife, Mindy, and his mother, Norma. Contributions may be made to the Rabbi Evan C. Radler Memorial Fund at Hillcrest Jewish Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERSH, STANLEY, DMP
description: HERSH--Stanley, DMP, 90, of Great Neck, NY, on May 4th, 2005. Beloved husband, father and grandfather.

title: Trade ministers agree on formula for tariffs
World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Russian Refuses Extradition To U.S.
description: Yevgeny Adamov, the former Russian atomic energy chief who was detained in Bern, the Swiss capital, this week after he was accused by the United States of stealing $9 million in Department of Energy funds intended for nuclear safety projects in Russia, has opposed his extradition to the United States, according to Swiss officials. His refusal leaves the United States 60 days to formally request extradition from the Swiss courts, meaning that a final decision could be delayed for months. Meanwhile, news agencies in the United States reported that a federal grand jury in Pittsburgh had indicted Mr. Adamov, 65, on charges of money laundering and fraud. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Disparate Ways and Means Converge on a Single Goal: The Jersey City Mayor's Office
description: JERSEY CITY, May 5 - The Healy signs are everywhere. They are in shop windows and on telephone poles, on the sides of buses and in front of apartment buildings. They make it clear that Mayor Jerramiah T. Healy, who won a special election to replace Mayor Glenn D. Cunningham, is serious about capturing a full term.

title: Around the World
Abbas's Allies Win Palestinian Elections
description: GAZA, Friday, May 6 - The Fatah movement of the Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas captured a clear majority of the more than 80 towns and villages that staged local elections, beating back a strong challenge by the Islamic movement Hamas, an election official said Friday morning.

title: The Listings: May 6-12; BAMBERG SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA
description: What's one way to hedge your bets when making your New York conducting debut? Bring along the commanding French pianist and new-music specialist Pierre-Laurent Aimard (above). The British conductor Jonathan Nott has done just that for his two performances in Avery Fisher Hall this weekend with this well-established German orchestra. At each concert, besides playing a Beethoven Piano Concerto (No. 4 tonight and No. 5 on Sunday), Mr. Aimard will perform six of the punishingly difficult and musically explosive tudes for solo piano by the eminent Hungarian composer Gyorgy Ligeti. Anyone who heard Mr. Aimard play these pieces at Tanglewood two summers ago probably still remembers the devastating power, precision and sweep of those performances. Mr. Nott himself is no stranger to Mr. Ligeti's music, having made a fine recording of the composer's orchestral works, including two pieces, "Lontano" and "Atmosphres," which he will lead again this weekend. In addition to the Beethoven and Ligeti, Mr. Nott will conduct works by a composer who helps link the two: Gustav Mahler. (Tonight at 8 and Sunday at 3, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212)721-6500., $35 to $68. A third performance (this time, all-Beethoven) will take place tomorrow at 8 p.m., Tilles Center, C. W. Post Campus, Long Island University, Route 65A, Brookville, (516)299-3100, $48 to $65.) JEREMY EICHLER

title: U.S. COURT BLOCKS SALE OF BRASIL TELECOM SHARES
description: Citigroup won a temporary restraining order blocking a deal that would allow Telecom Italia to gain greater control over Brasil Telecom Participaes, a Brazilian telephone company in which the bank is a controlling shareholder. The ruling, by a federal court in New York, stops Citigroup's former investment manager in Brazil, Daniel Dantas, from selling his shares in Brasil Telecom to Telecom Italia. Last week, the Italian group agreed to pay 341 million euros ($439.8 million) to end all legal disputes with Mr. Dantas and buy his stake. Citigroup, which shares control of Brasil Telecom with Brazilian state-run pension funds, contended that the deal violated a court order. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: For Classical Concertgoers, a Fourth B Is Budget
description: Nothing is more exasperating for those trying to foster interest in classical music -- concert presenters, artists and critics alike -- than the widespread perception that the high price of high culture makes it affordable only to those with disposable income. Yes, for many people, the top-tier New York institutions are prohibitively expensive. The priciest seats at the Metropolitan Opera now cost more than $200.

title: U.S. Vows to Help Bring Liberian to Justice
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 - The administration took a cautious stance on Thursday on the deposed Liberian leader Charles Taylor, pledging to help bring him to justice over war crimes but refusing to say whether President Bush would push to have him expelled from Nigeria, where he has been sheltered.

title: Gillette profit exceeds expectations

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been pilloried by critics who say his relentless push for a Jets stadium on the West Side of Manhattan has distracted him from other important projects, like the troubled rebuilding efforts at the World Trade Center site.

Andrew McGuinness, chief executive at TBWA London, and Bill Bungay, deputy creative director there, left with Mr. Beattie to form the new agency. Paul Bainsfair, president at TBWA Europe, assumes the additional posts of chairman and chief executive at TBWA London.

While Robert Lucid is the current one, a biography by Peter Manso, "Mailer: His Life and Times" (1985), was also authorized. Dr. Lucid has not yet published a Mailer biography.

title: Zimmer Expects the Worst if Slide Lasts
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 5 - Maybe it will be Brian Cashman, the general manager. Or maybe another executive will be fired, or a coach, or maybe, who knows, Manager Joe Torre. If the Yankees stay below .500, Don Zimmer said, that is inevitable.

title: Corrections

While the number fell by 2.3 million, to 21.7 million, from the figure in the period a year earlier, the drop was 549,000 from the previous quarter.

title: Grisly Discovery Near Train Tracks
description: Two bags containing what the police believe to be human remains were discovered yesterday afternoon next to a stairway leading to the Long Island Rail Road tracks near Ocean Avenue in Midwood, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: When your phone calls your car
An Epic Bloodletting Empowered by Faith
description: Near the end of "Kingdom of Heaven," a plaintive period epic from Ridley Scott about the bloody orgies of piety known as the Crusades, the camera pulls back from the tumult of battle. Perched on high, as if assuming the view of a passing bird or some divine being, the camera looks down on a medieval scene that condenses the barbarism that has consumed the previous two hours of screen time -- the impaled flesh, the crushed bone, the hollow and inflamed invocations of faith. From this great height, the Christian crusaders and Muslim warriors below no longer look like men, like warring armies of God, but bacteria under a microscope.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Minister Defends Garlic In Aids Care
description: Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, left, South Africa's outspoken health minister, said her advocacy of garlic as a treatment for AIDS had been vindicated by a World Health Organization report stating that good nutrition is a key factor in forestalling H.I.V.'s attack on the immune system. Speaking in Pretoria, she also repeated her warning that anti-retroviral drugs had potentially dangerous side effects. She said the ministry planned to determine how many of the South Africans who had enrolled in anti-retroviral programs had dropped out or died from side effects. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEPAUW, FR. GOMMAR
description: DePAUW -- Fr. Gommar, Founder-President of the Catholic Traditionalist Movement and US Citizen, was born October 11, 1918 in Stekene, Belgium to a distinguished family which included early American settlers. At the outbreak of WWII he fought as a combat medic and was taken prisoner at the battle of Dunkirk. After escaping from prison camp he returned to the seminary to complete his studies by special indult of the Holy See. He was ordained a priest in 1942 and served as a battle-field chaplain until the end of the war. After post-graduate studies at the University of Louvain, he earned a Bachelors in Canon Law and the triple major licentiate in Canon Law, Moral Theology and Church history. In 1949, Father DePauw came to the US and while serving as a parish priest in New York City, he prepared for his doctoral dissertation at The Catholic University of America where he was promoted to Doctor in Canon Law. In 1952 he accepted the Chair of Moral Theology in Canon Law at Mt. St. Mary's Seminary in Maryland which he held for 13 years. Between 1962 and 1965 Father DePauw participated in the Second Vatican Council as a personal expert and procurator. During this time he publicly launched the Catholic Traditionalist Movement in 1965. The Holy See placed him under the jurisdiction of the Bishop of Tivoli Rome so he could continue his leadership of the Catholic Traditionalist Movement. Father De Pauw has contributed to several well-known publications as well as publishing his own. Most notable among them his 'Quote Unquote' and "Peace through Strength." In 1968 he established the Ave Maria Chapel in Westbury, New York which became the first and only publicly functioning Traditionalist Catholic parish in the world. Besides being an influential voice in Church affairs, Father De Pauw was also influential in addressing issues facing the nation, culminating in meetings with President Reagan. Father DePauw was recognized by numerous international organizations for his leadership roles most notable among them Community Leaders of America and Who's Who in the World. Father passed to his well earned eternal reward on Friday May 6, 2005. Reposing Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Ave, Westbury on Saturday & Sunday from 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Service Monday 10AM at the Ave Maria Chapel, 210 Maple Avenue, Westbury, LI. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, LI.

description: The police in eight European countries detained dozens of people in raids this week in connection with a child pornography ring on the Internet. The total number was not available, but officials in France said that about 20 people had been arrested there, with 10 more placed under investigation. Besides France, hundreds of officers took part in raids in Denmark, Italy, Malta, Norway, Poland, Sweden and the Netherlands, seizing thousands of pornographic pictures and hundreds of videos. title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Poachers Kill All Of Reserve's Tigers
description: A government inquiry has found that not a single tiger remains in the famed Sariska national wildlife sanctuary in Rajasthan. "The entire population seemed to have become extinct, primarily because of poaching" the Forest Ministry said in a statement to Parliament. The inquiry was ordered after news reports about the park's plummeting tiger population. The last census, in 2002, turned up 22 tigers at the reserve. Conservationists have decried the slaughter in Sariska and are warning of similar poaching in other reserves. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Unilever Profits Up 24 Percent
description: Unilever, the owner of about 400 brands ranging from Lipton tea to Dove soap, said that its first-quarter profit climbed 24 percent as it reduced costs and sold assets. Unilever's shares had their biggest gain in more than a year and a half, as investors took the results as a sign that the company was turning a corner. Net income rose to 934 million euros ($1.21 billion) from 753 million euros a year earlier, the company said. Unilever, based in London and Rotterdam, the Netherlands, was expected to earn about 737 million euros, according to analysts surveyed by Bloomberg. Sales climbed 2.3 percent, to 9.27 billion euros.

title: Arts, Briefly; And Then There Were Two
description: For the first time in three seasons, "The Apprentice" has two female finalists: Tana Goertz and Kendra Todd. They were in the middle of their final challenge when Thursday's episode, which drew 12.76 million viewers, ended. The season finale is next week. But the show's ratings were not strong enough to pull NBC out of second place in Nielsen's estimates. The CBS lineup was No. 1 in total viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds, as it nearly always is on Thursday nights. Also typical was that the night's most-watched episode was CBS's "CSI," which brought in an audience of 25.89 million to a downbeat hour about the private life of Catherine (Marg Helgenberger) interfering with her work (and vice versa). ABC came in third in total viewers; and without any more revelations about "American Idol," the Thursday edition of "Primetime Live" attracted only 7.28 million. KATE AURTHUR

He is also a member of Federal Aviation Administration committee on air traffic services. He currently works as a technology consultant. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: JURY DECIDES AGAINST ALCON ON PATENTS
description: Alcon Inc., the world's largest maker of eye care products, must pay $94.8 million in damages to Advanced Medical Optics for infringing cataract surgery patents, a jury decided yesterday. The jury also ruled that the two patents at issue in the case were valid. The verdict came after a two-week trial in federal court in Wilmington, Del. Alcon, based in Hunenberg, Switzerland, is majority-owned by Nestl. Advanced Medical, based in Santa Ana, Calif., sued Alcon in 2003, contending it infringed patents awarded in 1997 and 2000 covering equipment and methods for removing clouded eye tissue through a suction needle.

title: Arts, Briefly; Without a Topic
description: CNBC has canceled "Topic A With Tina Brown." Ms. Brown said yesterday in an interview that she had instigated the cancellation on Thursday by telling her employers that she needed to devote her time to a book about Diana, Princess of Wales, to be published by Doubleday in 2007. "They were very nice about it," Ms. Brown said. "I just could not do everything at once. I was spinning like the kid in 'The Exorcist."' Mark Hoffman, president at CNBC, said in an e-mail message to employees that Ms. Brown, the former editor of Talk magazine and The New Yorker, had asked to relinquish her duties. "I have much respect for Tina and understand the amount of time she will need to dedicate to her new project," the message said, "so I am announcing to all of you that the last episode of 'Topic [A]' will air on Sunday, May 29." An average of 62,000 households tuned in to the 9 p.m. showing of "Topic A" each week this year, according to Nielsen Media Research, down from an average of 85,000 households last year. NAT IVES

title: DUPONT SETTLES U.S. ALLEGATIONS ON TEFLON INGREDIENT
description: The DuPont Company agreed yesterday to settle allegations by federal regulators that it failed for 20 years to disclose health data about an ingredient used to make Teflon nonstick coatings. DuPont said in a regulatory filing that it set aside $15 million in the first quarter as a result of a preliminary agreement with the Environmental Protection Agency. DuPont, based in Wilmington, Del., declined to say how much it would pay under the agreement. The E.P.A. said last July that DuPont failed to disclose that it knew in the 1980's that the ingredient, perfluorooctanoic acid, could pass from a mother to her fetus and that the acid was in water supplies near its plant in Parkersburg, W. Va.

Growth in full-time positions was particularly strong during April and the number of hours worked by Canadians grew by 1.4 percent during the first quarter of the year. title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: 2 Sentenced In Foiled ETA Train Plot
description: The National Court sentenced two members of the militant Basque separatist group ETA to a combined sentence of more than 5,000 years in prison for plotting to blow up a train in Madrid on Christmas Eve 2003. Although the explosion appeared set to occur after the train had completed its trip and released all its passengers, the court said that the defendants, Gorka Loran, 36, and Garikoitz Arruarte, left, 25, had intentionally put the passengers' lives at "very grave risk." Their sentences were 15 years in prison for each of the 184 passengers and rail workers the bomb could have killed, but they are more likely to serve 40 years. The plot was cited by the government of the former prime minister, Jos Mara Aznar, as justification for early declarations that ETA was responsible for the March 11, 2004, train bombings that killed 191 people in Madrid. Islamist radicals with ties to Al Qaeda later became the main suspects. Renwick McLean (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Guuam Loses A 'U'
description: Uzbekistan, the autocratic Central Asian state with close ties to the Kremlin, has withdrawn from the five-nation organization of post-Soviet states set up in 1997 and known by the acronym Guuam, for Georgia, Uzbekistan, Ukraine, Azerbaijan and Moldova. The once pro-Kremlin orientation of the bloc has shifted markedly westward since 2003, as the Communist Party in Moldova turned toward Europe, and popular uprisings unseated autocratic governments in Georgia and Ukraine. Russia has complained that Guuam has become an American tool to counter Russian influence in its former sphere. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Meningitis Outbreak
description: A rare strain of bacterial meningitis has killed 15 people in Delhi and landed 100 in local hospitals. The Indian government maintains that the cases do not represent an epidemic, and it has urged people to report to hospitals if they develop symptoms like nausea, severe headache or a skin rash. Last seen in India over a decade ago, the first cases of the new outbreak were reported from the densely packed walled city known as Old Delhi. They have since been reported from all over Delhi, a city of about 14 million highly mobile people. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

The teenage rapper Bow Wow stars in "Bow" (WB); in "The Show With AJ Calloway" (UPN), the host of BET's "106 & Park" sends up his own brand of talk show. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTIN, NATALIE ''MIMI''
description: MARTIN -- Natalie "Mimi". Passed away on April 25, 2005 from heart failure in Rancho Mirage, CA. She was 74. Born Natalie Powell Scott in Cedarhurst, NY, she graduated from the Oldfields School in Glencoe, MD, in 1949. She moved to New York City in the 1950's and worked for Jonai, a women's apparel retailer, and then for Saks Fifth Avenue as an assistant buyer. Natalie married Francis Martin, Jr., an advertising executive, in 1964 and they lived in Manhattan for 20 years. After Francis retired, they relocated to Reno, NV, and spent the winters in La Quinta, CA. She was an avid golfer, played bridge and backgammon, participated in community affairs and enjoyed traveling throughout the world. From 1979 to '86 and again in '88, Natalie kept official score cards for amateur, celebrity and professional golfers during the Bob Hope Desert Classic (now called the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic), a stop on the PGA tour. Rebounding from health problems in the early 1990's, Natalie won several tournaments and was named the Most Improved Golfer of 1996 by the La Quinta Country Club. She volunteered her time to several nonprofit associations, including the Braille Institute Associates of the Desert, Palm Springs Pathfinders and the Valley Partners with California State University. Known for her magnetic personality, endless energy, charm and quick wit, Natalie's network of friends was no less than amazing. Francis preceded Natalie in December 2003. She is survived by a son Scott Marshutz of Laguna Niguel, CA; stepdaughter Anne Rossman of Menlo Park, CA; stepson Francis III; and two step granddaughters, Eleanor and Grace, of Portland, OR. Friends are invited to attend a Celebration of Life reception on Thursday, June 9, 2005, from 4-6 pm at the Union Club, 101 East 69th St, NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association, 122 East 42nd St, NYC, 10168.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANDAU, BERNARD D. (BERNIE, SHIMMY, BDL.)
description: LANDAU--Bernard D. (Bernie, Shimmy, BDL.) Born November 20, 1930. A graduate of Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Law School, who pioneered the synthesis of law with computerization. Founding and senior partner of the national law firm of Hayt, Hayt & Landau, with 35 offices in eight states. Chairman and CEO of Professional Data Services. Recognized by the health care industry as the leader in so many dimensions of computerizing the needs of the hospital industry from their business offices to medical records. title: Missing Nuclear Leadership
description: Representatives of nearly 190 countries are currently meeting in New York to discuss ways of strengthening the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. It's a shame that neither President Bush nor Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice can find time to attend. Nuclear proliferation is the pre-eminent national security issue of our times. The nonproliferation treaty, signed in 1968, is the main reason John F. Kennedy's nightmare vision of 15 to 20 nuclear weapons states has been avoided. Instead, there are fewer than 10: the five that already had nuclear weapons when the treaty was signed, and Israel, India, Pakistan and probably North Korea, with Iran threatening to join that list in a few years' time.

title: 'Bad Day at Black Rock'
description: A few months after the end of World War II, the Southern Pacific Streamliner pulls into a dust pile of a California desert town where it hasn't stopped in four years. A one-armed stranger (Spencer Tracy) gets off the train asking about a local Japanese farmer. The film's 81 minutes, during which the locals try to question, intimidate and kill the stranger, are among the tautest, most expertly directed examples of Hollywood suspense. A hybrid of contemporary western and social problem picture, John Sturges's "Bad Day at Black Rock" (1955) is one of the most intelligent examinations of violence in American movies. Tracy's character has seen all the killing he wants to in the war. He resists the efforts of the local thugs, Ernest Borgnine and Lee Marvin, to needle him. They mistake this for weakness. Sturges uses the conventions of the vigilante picture to make us hungry for Tracy to take his revenge. When he inevitably does, Sturges makes us share Tracy's disgust at having to resort to violence. There's no visceral charge to that violence here, only ugliness and waste. Shooting in CinemaScope, Sturges and his photographer, William Mellor, find the moral darkness in the film's clean, spare, bright compositions (beautifully transferred to DVD). The blast of desert sunlight makes the growing menace feel even more sinister. And as Tracy's main nemesis, that great underrated actor Robert Ryan embodies D.H. Lawrence's characterization of the "essential American soul": "hard, isolate, stoic and a killer." (Warner Brothers, Tuesday) C.T.

title: Paperback Row

Toibin builds his novel around James at midlife, reeling from his failures as a dramatist in England in the late 1890's, yet on the brink of many of his richest literary achievements. An incident in each chapter triggers a memory, allowing Toibin to paint a detailed portrait of James's privileged Yankee childhood, his solitude and his deeply submerged sexuality. The Book Review named "The Master" one of the 10 best books of 2004; our reviewer, Daniel Mendelsohn, called it "unquestionably the work of a first-rate novelist."

Barbara Hall, the show's creator, said in a recent telephone interview that CBS bought the show in 2002 when public discourse about spirituality seemed more gentle: post-9/11 prayer services rather than heated debates over "The Passion of the Christ."

title: FILM
description: From ROBERT FLAHERTY'S "NANOOK OF THE NORTH" to the cavalry westerns of the Hollywood studio era, indigenous peoples have often been represented on movie screens, but rarely on their own terms. It is only recently, with works like LEE TAMAHORI'S "ONCE WERE WARRIORS" and ZACHARIAS KUNUK'S "ATANARJUAT: THE FAST RUNNER," that aboriginal cultures have begun to reflect their own situations on film. This Thursday, the MUSEUM OF MODERN ART begins an ambitious two-week series called "FIRST NATIONS/FIRST FEATURES," which presents 25 films , each announcing the birth of a national cinema at once brand new and age-old. Their geographic range -- from Lapland to Arizona, from Nunavut to New Zealand -- is matched by an impressive diversity of style and subject matter, from the documentary to social realist melodrama to Mr. Kunuk's grand, snowy epic. Roy and Nita Titus Theaters, 11 West 53rd Street, (212)708-9480, with screenings at various sites in Washington.

title: SUMMER MOVIES: Five Actors To Watch This Summer; Simon Abkarian
description: Simon Abkarian is a famous stage and film actor in France, but modest roles in "The Truth About Charlie" and Atom Egoyan's "Ararat" (both 2002) weren't enough to make audiences remember him here. Sally Potter's new film, "Yes" (June 24), should change that. Set in London, "Yes" stars Mr. Abkarian as the lover of an Irish-American scientist (Joan Allen) unhappily married to a philandering British politician (Sam Neill). Mr. Abkarian's character is a political immigrant, a Lebanese doctor who supports himself as a cook and catering worker. With his long, elegant body and lined, tragicomic face -- mournful eyes, a delicious smile under a canopy of dark mustache and a nose just short of Cyrano's, Mr. Abkarian is a visual feast. He's seldom still, his expressive features shifting from sad to sexy to sharply observant, and his loose-limbed body moving for the sheer pleasure of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERRY, LOREN C.
description: BERRY--Loren C. Lawyer, died at his home in Hilton Head S.C. on May 3, 2005 at the age of 93. He was the son of Gordon Lockwood and Katharine Dwight Berry. He graduated from the Choate School, Yale University (AB cum laude 1934), and Columbia University Law School, 1938. He became a member of the Bar in Mississippi in 1937 and New York in 1939. He practiced estates and trusts law at Rogers & Wells from 1939-1941, and 1945-1990 and was of counsel at Clifford Chance Rogers & Wells at the time of his death. During WW II he served as a lieutenant commander in a US Navy Scouting Squadron. He served as a director of Church & Dwight Co., Inc from 1961 to 1984, Councilman of the Town of Huntington 1953 to 1957, vice president of the Association of Towns of the State of New York 1957 to 1960, and delegate from the second senatorial district to the New York State Constitutional Convention 1967. He was a member of the Suffolk County Republican Committee from 1952 to 1985. He served on the vestry of St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor NY. He was a member of the Elks, the Union Club, and the Tahawus Club. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, Florence Bateson Berry, his daughters, Rosina B. Dixon (Richard W. Dixon), Lucinda B. Berry and five grandchildren, Erica H. Dixon, Douglas R. Dixon, Andrew D. Dixon, Ryan W. Berry, Jason T. Berry, and his sisters, Helen McClure Bluhm and Louise Berry Caldwell. He was preceded in death by his son, Roger Wolcott Berry, and his sister, Marion Berry Scott. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor NY on May 21, 2005 at 1:00 P.M. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to The First Presbyterian Church Hilton Head, 540 William Hilton Pkwy, Hilton Head SC 29928, St. John's Church, PO Box 266, Cold Spring Harbor NY 11724, or the charity of your choice.

title: 'Divorce, Italian Style'
description: Marcello Mastroianni's performance in "Divorce, Italian Style" (1961) is a feat of overstated understatement, a primer on how to shape a comic character by arching your eyebrows just so, or allowing your eyelids to droop at precisely the right angle. As a bored, spoiled Sicilian baron looking to do away with his fluttery, fawning wife so he can marry his virginal 16-year-old cousin (Stefania Sandrelli), Mastroianni is an insouciant, sleepy lizard: he saunters through the picture as if he were merely on his way to finding the right sunny rock. Mastroianni is so good-looking it almost hurts (and the velvety black-and-white of this beautifully restored version makes him look that much more scrumptious). But his slicked-back matinee-idol hair and "Don't hate me because I'm beautiful" mustache are part of the sendup: the careless elegance of the performance is what makes it so funny. And if the idea behind "Divorce, Italian Style" seems broad, the execution is anything but. Pietro Germi keeps the movie's dusky black humor perfectly calibrated and takes impish delight in puncturing old-time Italian macho values. When Mastroianni gazes upon Ms. Sandrelli's luscious, youthfully blank face, we know they're a match made in the shallower reaches ofheaven. (Criterion) S.Z.

title: A Brief History of the (Star Wars) Universe
description: When George Lucas's "Star Wars: Episode 3 -- Revenge of the Sith" arrives in theaters on May 19, the long saga will at last be complete. But will it be clear? Fans who began paying attention in 1977, when the series started, managed to wrap their brains around Wookiees, droids and the dusty planet Tatooine. But as each installment spilled new creatures, characters and planets into the Star Wars universe, events became harder to untangle.

title: SUMMER MOVIES: Five Actors To Watch This Summer; Natalie Press

Ms. Press plays the working-class half of a teenage odd couple who find each other at the start of an otherwise lonely summer in a poky Yorkshire town. Her partner in mischief, fantasy and the joys of exploratory sex is the rich, upper-class Tamsin (Emily Blunt), whose rhinestone sophistication Mona happily takes for diamonds.

title: THEhotel in Las Vegas

But the swankiest element of all is actually what's missing: slot machines. Unlike the typical resort on the Las Vegas Strip, where you must charge through the one-armed bandits to check in, the black-marble-and-chrome lobby is as serene as a futuristic wedding chapel.

After reaching an all-time high of $686,000 in the third quarter of 2004, the median was $615,000 for the quarter that ended in March, the same as it was for the previous quarter.

title: Freud and His Discontents
description: "CIVILIZATION AND ITS DISCONTENTS" first appeared in 1930, and on the occasion of its 75th anniversary has been reissued by Norton ($19.95). A new edition of a classic text of Western culture is a happy occasion, not least because it offers the opportunity to debate the book's effect on the way we see the world -- or whether it has any effect at all. "Classic" can mean that an intellectual work is indisputably definitive in its realm, or it can mean that its prestige has outlived its authority and influence. Being leatherbound is sometimes synonymous with being timebound.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the popularity of poker-related businesses referred incorrectly to the idea of having a camera show poker players' face-down cards to television audiences. While Steve Lipscomb, creator of "World Poker Tour," put a variant of it into practice, the idea was patented earlier by Henry Orenstein, creator of "Poker Superstars."

He arrived in New York in 1955, worked for several years in journalism and had a long and distinguished career as a college professor, both at CCNY and the University of Puerto Rico; he received his Ph.D. from Columbia in 1973. He is survived by his former wife Ila D. Little of Placitas, NM, and their two sons, Lorenzo and Sharon of Easton, PA, and Andrew and Kelly of Suwanee, GA;, a brother, Francesco of Italy; a sister, Rossana of Italy; nine grandchildren, and five nieces and nephews. title: 'The Diezmo'
description: I WAS AS WILD for glory as any of us. Before too much time had passed, we had all changed our minds, had given up on dreams of glory and were fighting only to win. And not too much longer after that, all that was on our minds was a good cool drink of water; and before it was over, all any of us wanted was simply to get back home.

title: SUMMER MOVIES: Five Actors To Watch This Summer; Tony Leung Chiu-wai
description: At 42, Tony Leung Chiu-wai is a huge star in Asia, with more than 60 movies to his credit. But it was just four years ago that "In the Mood for Love," Wong Kar-wai's meditation on loss and desire, introduced him to nonspecialized American audiences. As a figure of ravishing sadness, Mr. Leung's gentle newspaperman, Chow Mo Wan, has no equal. With the smallest gestures -- the tilt of his body, the lift of a hand, a quickly shuttered glance -- he conveys his intense but discreet yearning for the woman who ultimately refuses him. It's safe to say that some of the anticipation here for Mr. Wong's new film, "2046," a sequel to "In the Mood for Love," has to do with audiences' desire to see Mr. Leung's enchanting character again.

title: 3 Wall Street Agencies Enhance Suffolk Ratings

The house shown in the middle was at 210 Rugby Road; the one on the bottom was at 97 Marlborough Road. The listing also misstated the price for the house at 1305 Albermarle Road. It is $4.2 million, not $4 million.

title: Coming Soon
description: Sam Fuller's rough-hewn World War II masterpiece gets the full treatment in the two-disc "The Big Red One: The Reconstruction" (May 3). Javier Bardem is superb as a quadriplegic fighting for the right to end his life in Alejandro Amenbar's "Sea Inside" (May 17). Leonardo DiCaprio stars in Martin Scorsese's luxe version of the life of Howard Hughes, "The Aviator" (May 24). Invited guests sit around a dining-room table on toilets and excuse themselves to go to a cubicle to eat in Luis Buuel's late jape "The Phantom of Liberty" (May 24). Two of James Dean's three films -- "East of Eden" and "Rebel Without a Cause" -- are reissued in deluxe two-disc editions (May 31). "The Gary Cooper Collection" anthologizes five of the stoic one's films, including "Beau Geste," "Lives of a Bengal Lancer" and the gothic oddity "Peter Ibbetson" (May 31). Ernst Lubitsch's 1943 afterlife satire "Heaven Can Wait" (June 14) arrives in a Criterion edition, as does Anthony Asquith's film of Terence Rattigan's play "The Browning Version," starring Michael Redgrave. One of last year's most dazzling and underrated movies, the mystery/war drama/love story "A Very Long Engagement," is released in an edition that includes the director's commentary and deleted scenes (July 12). And though the title gave Bugs Bunny one of his best punch lines, it's tears that Dorothy McGuire inspires in Elia Kazan's 1945 film of Betty Smith's coming-of-age novel "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" (Aug. 9).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WINTER, MARVIN
description: WINTER -- Marvin. Loving and beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother. Cherished memories of your wisdom, humor and compassion fill our thoughts and hearts.

title: DEVELOPER ARRESTED
description: Anthony Spalliero, a developer whose companies have been behind much of the building boom in Marlboro Township in Monmouth County over the past decade, was arrested last Tuesday on federal charges of paying town and county officials more than $143,500 in bribes in exchange for favorable zoning rulings. Mr. Spalliero appeared before a federal magistrate judge, Ronald J. Hedges, and was released on a $250,000 bond pending further grand jury action. Ronald Smothers

title: Navy Outlines Errors Preceding Fatal Submarine Crash
description: APRA HARBOR, Guam, Sunday, May 8 - Navy investigators have found that a series of mistakes both at sea and in preparations onshore helped cause a nuclear submarine to crash into an undersea mountain in January, killing one sailor and injuring 97 others.

title: The Help A Phone Call Away

The victim was moaning that she was sick to her stomach. The caller reported that the airbag had activated but the victim seemed uninjured.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Lays Off 105, but Discord Grows Louder
description: Already facing upheaval and dissent from several union presidents, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. saw its problems escalate last week when the federation laid off about a fourth of its staff and the chairman of its public relations committee resigned in a fit of pique. Not only that, but four of the nation's largest unions demanded that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. remove their members' names from its master political list of 13 million workers because of a feud over sharing information.

title: Makes Them Want to Holler

But Luna Stage here has taken up the challenge, a doubly bold gamble given that in Luna's tiny house there is no buffer zone between actors and audience; if the performers fail, they fail a few feet from the front row.

title: THEATER

The performer otherwise known as JOHN EPPERSON has long been slicing, dicing and splicing together great moments in screen goddess history , so he's certainly dipped into the Crawford lexicon before. Indeed, Mr. Epperson as Lypsinka as FAYE DUNAWAY as Joan in "MOMMIE DEAREST" would probably top anyone's list of this performer's greatest hits.

title: Flamenco's Strange New Moves
description: JEREZ DE LA FRONTERA, Spain - SINCE 1994, the Jerez Flamenco Festival has drawn flamenco lovers, many of them American, to this small, pretty town in the heart of Andalusia. For 15 days, they see exhibits, master classes and performances by both new and established dancers and musicians. On a cold and rainy late winter night, a crowd of shivering festival patrons hurried into the Teatro Villamarta for a premiere from Mara Pags, a leading light of the flamenco revolution that has turned this traditional dance form into a hot show-biz commodity.

title: Chair of Senate Intelligence Committee Believes North Korea Is Preparing Nuclear Test
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 - The chairman of the Senate intelligence committee said today that he believed North Korea appeared to be preparing a nuclear test explosion, even as the head of the United Nations nuclear monitoring agency said he believed the North had five or six nuclear weapons in its possession.

title: The Supersizing of the School Play
description: New Albany, Ind. - PLUNKED down in front of an $18,000 mixing console, the two eighth-grade boys looked terrified. They had never run a sound board before, and suddenly here they were, one Monday last month, up in the balcony of the 900-seat auditorium at New Albany High School, desperately trying to tame the blinking, glowering, 40-channel behemoth. Reading dials and pushing slides, with a stage manager constantly calling cues in their earphones, they started to fumble and sweat as the cast of "Into the Woods," way down below on the stage, went through a tech rehearsal. Nothing seemed to work right. Hideous feedback alternated with thunderous explosions each time a word began with P. Microphones came on in midsentence or while the actors were still offstage discussing homework. And there were only three days left until opening night.

title: Social Conscience, Junior Division
description: JULIA CAPALINO and Janie Ostrager realized their social standing had risen in the eyes of other sophomores at the Spence School when Ms. Capalino's cellphone rang. The caller was Selby Drummond, who is such a fashion plate at Spence that she is listed as a contributor on the masthead of Teen Vogue and had her prom dress made personally by Zac Posen. Most impressive of all, she is a senior.

title: Hard-Liners in Northern Ireland Gain in British Voting, Leaving Peace Pact in Jeopardy
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 7 - Voters in Northern Ireland have delivered convincing victories to hard-line parties in Britain's parliamentary elections, stoking fears that a resumption of the suspended Northern Irish legislature, which is intended to provide power-sharing between Roman Catholic and Protestant groups, will be more difficult.

title: Playground on the Air
description: MY mother's from Puerto Rico and my father's from Boston. Starting from the time I was 8 or 9 my brother, two sisters and I would go down from Huntington, N.Y., to Puerto Rico for several weeks during the summer with my mother and stay at my Aunt Josie's house. She had a three-bedroom apartment in the Miramar section of San Juan, and my brother and I slept on an open-air porch, really a terrace.

description: GREEN--James Wilder. The Board of Directors, Artists and staff of The MacDowell Colony mourn the loss of our close friend James Wilder Green. title: Seeing Triple
description: Blue Man Group and Cirque du Soleil clone themselves; Broadway shows have touring companies. In the penny-pinching world of dance, however, a junior company like Ailey II has been about as far as it goes. That may be changing, as name-brand dance troupes take on the kind of multiplicity that has served other genres so well. Momix, based in Connecticut and known for its onstage illusions, has performed the neat trick of expanding into three touring units, with a total of 30 dancers. One of the three Momixes comes to the Joyce starting Tuesday.

title: Werner Herzog's New Direction
description: "EVERYBODY is the center of their universe," the Dalai Lama remarks in Werner Herzog's "Wheel of Time." If so, that's not the only thing this Buddhist holy man has in common with the British inventor of a one-man helium dirigible and a New Age naturalist devoured by a grizzly bear: each of them is the subject of a Werner Herzog film.

title: See Spot Sue
description: WHEN it comes to awarding damages for pain and suffering, loss of companionship or emotional distress in pet death and injury cases, New York judges have issued conflicting decisions. Essentially, some judges allow these damages; others don't.

title: Lifting the Flaps
description: Anybody who has tried to use the New York Freedom of Information Law knows just how free most government information isn't.

title: A River View That Comes With a Castle
description: TARRYTOWN - WITHIN the turreted walls of Castle on the Hudson, magnificent public rooms and long views of the lovely grounds that seem to tumble down to the Hudson River make dining here unmatched elsewhere in Westchester. The space is indeed over the top but so totally captivating that the food succeeds to the extent that it doesn't distract from that space. It never allows guests to forget for a moment that they're experiencing life in a castle, albeit one built only a century ago.

title: Beacons of the Past, and Present
description: WHETHER it is the history with tales of shipwrecks and eccentric keepers, or the beauty of simple structures that soar as high as 168 feet, something about lighthouses attracts dedicated buffs. Whatever it is, on May 14 and 15, the lighthouse faithful, some traveling from as far as Arizona and California, are expected to join local participants in this year's Long Island Lighthouse Challenge.

title: White Sox Show Their Manager Isn't All Talk
description: Find a spot to stand in the third-base dugout at U.S. Cellular Field in Chicago, train your eyes and ears on Ozzie Guillen for an interview and absorb 15 minutes with Ozzie. Or maybe 20 or 25. His words come fast, sometimes faster than his complete thoughts.

title: Wake Up. Wash Face. Do Routine. Now Paint.
description: CHRIS OFILI'S watercolors at the Studio Museum in Harlem, the spring art season's rapturous sleeper, are of imaginary heads. There are 181 of them, all the same size, of men and women in bright African garb, deliriously colored and intricately detailed. Mr. Ofili is, obviously, the British artist (lately transplanted to Trinidad) whose "Holy Virgin Mary," with elephant dung, caused a ruckus a few years back when the "Sensation" show was at the Brooklyn Museum. He is also adept at rather lovely, clever and not at all inflammatory art, including these silhouettes and straight-on portraits, which are titled "Afro-Muses."

title: Lots of Big Bodies at Giants' Rookie Minicamp
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 7 - At his introductory news conference as the Giants' coach in January 2004, Tom Coughlin was asked to describe his ideal player.

title: A Safety Net, Woven on the Web
description: WHEN you hear that a friend, neighbor or co-worker is facing a crisis, your instinct is to try to do something to help. But too often you're not sure what. I know I've taken casseroles to households coping with illness, only to see three others stacked on the countertop. Meanwhile, what I didn't know was that the laundry basket was overflowing and the car was awaiting pickup at the shop.

title: Buried Answers
description: You report the rate of missed diagnoses found on autopsies to be 25 to 40 percent. I suspect that malpractice lawyers might exploit the knowledge gained by performing more autopsies for their profit. Until we have malpractice tort reform, doctors will fear autopsies.

title: CAMDEN PROJECT DELAYED
description: The massive redevelopment of the Cramer Hill neighborhood in Camden was delayed again last week when a Superior Court judge ruled that area residents had not been given enough notice about the February public meeting where the project's plan was adopted. Camden City Council was given another 90 days to readopt a plan by Cherokee Investment Partners to build a golf course and 6,000 new homes in the working-class neighborhood. Judge Francis Orlando also upheld a restraining order blocking the city from condemnation proceedings against local businesses scheduled to be seized for the project through eminent domain. Jill P. Capuzzo

title: The (Mis)Directions of Emir Kusturica
description: Last year at the Cannes Film Festival, the Sarajevo-born director Emir Kusturica was taking questions from the press about his new movie. He was discussing the sorts of things he likes to discuss: why the cinema he loves is being ruined by an inhuman, mass-produced fast food coming out of Hollywood, for instance. Until, inevitably, he was visited with a mild version of the question reporters have never failed to ask him over the last decade: During the wars that destroyed Yugoslavia in the 1990's, why didn't he come out publicly against Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian leader who was ravaging his homeland?

Paid Notice: Deaths   O'NEIL, LOUISE WESTERGAARD
description: O'NEIL--Louise Westergaard. A Broadway producer and mother of four, died on May 6, at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. The cause of death was Leukemia, with which she was recently diagnosed. Mrs. O'Neil, who was known professionally as Louise Westergaard, produced or co-produced a number of shows both on and off Broadway, including the Tony Award-winning Sophisticated Ladies, the Erte version of Stardust featuring the lyrics of Mitchell Parish, the musical Dream featuring the lyrics of Johnny Mercer and most recently, the Tony Award-nominated Say Goodnight, Gracie. With the Royal Shakespeare Company, she produced Peter Nichol's Poppy in London. Her Off-Broadway credits include American Rhapsody, Joyce Carol Oates' Cry Me a River and Tovah: Out of her Mind, which was presented at the Jewish Repertory Theater. She also co-produced three feature films: The Orphan, Bad Timing and Take it from the Top. Her first book, Melanie, was made into a film with Walter Reade Sterling. Early in her career she was artistic director of Joseph Campbell and Jean Erdman's theater, The Open Eye. Mrs. O'Neil was born in New York City on September 2, 1937. She graduated from the Professional Childrens School and the University of Chicago. After her first marriage to John Westergaard, she was married to Stephen O'Neil. In addition to Mr. O'Neil, she is survived by two daughters and two sons from her first marriage, Emile, Cathrine, Kermit and Elizabeth, all of New York, and three grandchildren. The funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Inside the List
description: SCRATCHY, DRAWLY, BOOPY: Three new books -- Sarah Vowell's "Assassination Vacation," William Queen's "Under and Alone" and Phil Lesh's "Searching for the Sound" -- stride onto the hardcover nonfiction list this week. Queen is a former undercover A.T.F. agent whose superbly skanky memoir is about how he infiltrated a West Coast motorcycle gang; Lesh, of course, is the former bassist for the Grateful Dead. They're both first-time authors. "Assassination Vacation," on the other hand, is Vowell's fourth book, and her first to make the hardcover list. (Bruce Handy reviews it on Page 14.) Vowell has built a devoted audience through her performances on public radio's "This American Life," where she declaims her pieces in a scratchy voice that has, as Nick Hornby put it, a certain "drawly, Boopy, Lisa Simpsonesque quality." Last year Vowell lent that voice to Violet, the teenage superhero in "The Incredibles." It was a job she was prepared to turn down, she told Hornby, until she learned it was a Pixar movie. "They're the best at what they do, the most universally culturally revered. It's like if Nelson Mandela showed up asking for your help to fight racism. Maybe fighting racism isn't normally your thing. Maybe you're more of an armchair racism hater. But if Mandela was standing at your door asking you to get on the bus, you'd just start putting on your shoes, right?"

title: Up Front
description: Last month an era in American literary history came to an end when two important figures died just one day apart. The death, on April 5, of Saul Bellow, a giant of the modern novel, received a great deal of coverage; this newspaper printed, in addition to a long front-page obituary, appreciations by Michiko Kakutani, Ian McEwan, Edward Rothstein, A. O. Scott, Brent Staples and David Brooks. The second death, of Frank Conroy, on April 6, was recorded more quietly. But Conroy, too, was a major presence in American literature -- less through his own writing, though his memoir "Stop-Time" is a classic of the genre, than through the contribution he made as the longtime director of the Writers' Workshop at the University of Iowa. When a former teacher there, the novelist James Salter, asked the Book Review if he might write an appreciation of Conroy, we encouraged him to go ahead. Salter's essay, "The Writing Teacher," which appears on Page 31, evokes the spirit of Conroy ("tall, unflappable and urbane") and also of the program he ran, rigorously and lovingly, for 18 years. It helped keep Iowa City, a small Midwestern river town, at the center of the literary universe -- a place where Nobel laureates came to read, and writers like John Cheever, Philip Roth, Kurt Vonnegut and Joy Williams evaluated student work and continued the conversation at local bars. How did Conroy prevent this most venerable of writing programs from becoming a processing plant? To begin with, he kept a close watch on who got in. He "read every submission and made final decisions himself," Salter notes. "It was the way great cities of Europe were built, not by committee but by royal decree." The Editors

title: 'Jules and Jim'
description: How many films feel this fresh and free more than 40 years after their release? Franois Truffaut's story of love and indissoluble friendship between two men (Oskar Werner's Jules and Henri Serre's Jim) and a woman (Jeanne Moreau) -- based on Henri-Pierre Roch's novel -- is infused with such delicacy of feeling that you can watch it five times, or 20, and still not feel you've fully plumbed it. (This two-disc package comes with a passel of extras, including two audio commentaries, one of them by Jeanne Moreau and Truffaut's biographer Serge Toubiana.) As Catherine, the woman beloved by both men, Ms. Moreau is the movie's thrumming heart: in the most famous and most vivid sequence, the three friends run a footrace across a railroad bridge. She has disguised herself as a boy, with a penciled-on mustache -- in her plaid cap and baggy pants, she is the men's almost-equal. But in the way she's so petulantly and defiantly alive, she's their superior. She wins the race (she cheated, but who cares?), and she has already made us, the audience, her willing captives. Just before that race Mr. Serre, entranced not just by Ms. Moreau but by the fine-grained texture of the day around him, says, "Either it's raining or I'm dreaming." She answers, "It might be both." "Jules and Jim" is about remaking reality via the imagination, about finding the spot where raining and dreaming are one and the same. (Criterion, May 31) STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

title: The Fathers' Crusade
description: After tomorrow, I'll have done everything there is to do, "Jason Hatch said one night in February, staring wistfully into a near-finished glass of beer at a bar in Shrewsbury, England. Just a few hours earlier, he and some friends were enjoying a raucous, boisterous evening, all but driving out the other diners at a decorous French restaurant. Now, after several drinks at the bar, the lateness of the hour and the increasing proximity of Hatch's plans for the next day seemed to be catching up with him, and his mood took a turn toward the tense. By the following afternoon, Hatch, a 33-year-old former house painter and contractor, intended to scale a government office building near the prime minister's residence at 10 Downing Street. His friends, many of them co-conspirators, had gone home, the revelry had died down and he was clearly trying to regain some focus. Was he getting nervous? "The police say Jason doesn't have fear like other people," he said, speaking of himself in the third person, perhaps hoping they were right.

title: Xan Cassavetes: Treasure of the Indies
description: HOLLYWOOD - XAN CASSAVETES is a film geek's dream girl. She shudders with passion at the mere mention of Rainer Werner Fassbinder, pounds her fist on the table as she defends David Lynch's critically lampooned "Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me" and still laments the afternoon that she missed a screening of the four-hour uncut version of Luchino Visconti's "Ludwig." Then there's the hallowed lineage: her father, John Cassavetes, who died in 1989, is the patron saint of art house cinema, and her mother, Gena Rowlands, was the original "It" girl of independent film.

title: The Face That Says 'Glass Menagerie,' Frame by Frame
description: People, especially actors, who saw Laurette Taylor play Amanda Wingfield in the original production of "The Glass Menagerie" in 1945 typically say it was the best performance ever offered on the American stage. Tennessee Williams compared her radiance in the role (which he had based on his mother) to the "greatest lines of poetry" and mourned that her reputation would be limited to the "testimony and inspiration" of those who saw her. That's mostly true; Taylor appeared in only three films, all silent, and died shortly after leaving the road company of "Menagerie" in 1946. But something of what made her Amanda so memorable was captured by Eileen Darby (1916-2004), a photographer who worked Broadway from 1940 to 1964, producing some of the signal theatrical images of the period: Marlon Brando menacing a thrilled but terrified Jessica Tandy in "A Streetcar Named Desire"; Carol Channing, framed by a halo of hair and feathers, at the top of the Harmonia Gardens stairs in "Hello, Dolly!"

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Let's admit it: opera and instrumental-music fans inhabit different planets. For the instrument fans, a highlight this week is an installment of "THE ANDSNES PROJECT" on Monday, giving CARNEGIE HALL audiences a sampling of the kind of intriguing chamber music the Norwegian pianist LEIF OVE ANDSNES explores at his Risor Festival. 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, (212) 247-7800. But opera fans will wallow in the guilty pleasure of yet another "comeback recital" by MADAME VERA GALUPE-BORZKH on Wednesday. Some may sniff that Madame (who, by day, masquerades as the stage director, writer and vocal coach IRA SIFF) is not serious entertainment, to which you could answer: that's the whole point, or, honey, she knows more about opera than most serious singers have forgotten. Not that you have to know a thing about opera to enjoy it. 8 p.m., Thalia at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212)864-5400. But seriously: there is much ado about the 80th birthday of PIERRE BOULEZ, and the ENSEMBLE SOSPESO has an appropriate birthday present. Its tribute at Zankel Hall on Tuesday includes pieces other composers -- like JOHN ZORN, MARC-ANDR DALBAVIE, DJ SPOOKY -- have written in his honor, as well as Boulez's own MALLARM songs (sung by SUSAN NARUCKI) . 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, (212) 247-7800.Department of Less-Trodden Paths: the CENTRAL SYNAGOGUE, which installed a major new organ in 2002 (with stops marked "trompette shofar" and "klezmer clarinette"), has a concert series to show it off. Closing the season is JUSTIN BISCHOF, who will demonstrate his improvisation skills on Tuesday in the style of REGER, MESSIAEN and ADAMS. Mr. Bischof recently founded the MODUS OPERA COMPANY, proving that opera and keyboard are not always separate tastes. 12:30 p.m., Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, at 55th Street, (212)838-5122.

title: 'Love Me or Leave Me'
description: This backstage biography of the singer Ruth Etting must be the most unusual MGM musical of the 50's. On the surface, "Love Me or Leave Me" is a big, satisfying CinemaScope melodrama, with Doris Day starring, about Etting's rise from dime-a-dance girl to headliner. James Cagney is the small-time Chicago hood she uses, marries and then leaves for the man she really loves. But as directed, sharply, by Charles Vidor, the film is awash in the disturbing undercurrents that made Hollywood movies of the 50's both rich and unstable, made them, in Manny Farber's phrase, "termite art." In "Love Me or Leave Me" it is Ruth Etting we're supposed to root for. We can see how the strong-arm tactics that Cagney's Martin Snyder uses to advance her career hurt her when she moves beyond the speakeasies. Yet the movie shows us the calculation in Etting's obedience to Snyder, her willingness to use his muscle and the way, when he calls the bill due, she settles accounts by marrying him. This is Day, remember, the archetypal sweetheart. As in "The Man Who Knew Too Much," another film about a marriage held together by neuroses and need, Day proves a terrific dramatic actress. And Cagney is amazing, making us feel the naked need, the insecurity behind Snyder's bullying. We're both appalled by Snyder and hurt for him. In his review, Franois Truffaut said the sting of the film was sharpened by the surrounding genre perfection of the movie musical. This DVD transfer is lush. The picture still stings. (Warner Brothers) CHARLES TAYLOR

title: Box-Office Battles, Begun Long Ago and Far Away

But for movie distributors and marketers, who must jockey for the best opening days and manufacture buzz among those most likely to show up on those days, this summer has been in play for months -- in some cases, even years. From the start of production to the annual exhibitor conventions to the publicity campaigns, the studios are in a war for opening-day supremacy. Based on conversations with studio executives, this chronology follows the strategic maneuvering that has been going on since June 30, 2003, when "Star Wars: Episode III -- Revenge of the Sith" began principal photography.

When she is cracked open, a bit of towel is discovered next to her lung. The Korean-American surgery intern, Cristina Yang (Sandra Oh), is sent to Medical Records to find out who is at fault. It turns out that an attending surgeon, an African-American named Preston Burke (Isaiah Washington), accidentally left it there during the woman's last surgery, five years ago. Dr. Yang and Dr. Burke have been exchanging coffee and longing glances for quite some time. Will she turn him in? Will he confess?

title: Watching TV Makes You Smarter
description: Johnson says that watching TV can make you smarter. This flies in the face of everything I've lectured about in the last 10 years. I say this not as a neurologist but as an avid TV watcher, who could go toe to toe with Johnson about "The West Wing" or "E.R." Yes, I agree that TV plot lines have gotten increasingly complex and "multithreaded." But watching TV remains a sedentary, passive and essentially solitary activity. Johnson's essay reads like something a student cooked up when he realized his paper was due and he'd spent the entire semester watching TV (the pseudo graphs were a particularly clever touch). Sorry, Steve, nice try. TV is a great soporific, often much needed as an escape, but it isn't good for you.

title: An Unforgettable Cover
description: To the Editor:

title: He Didn't Write the Songs
description: EVEN when he was a successful child performer in his native Canada, Bob Ezrin had an inkling his true calling was on the other side of the studio microphones.

description: WAYLAND--George B., 80, of Charlottesville, VA. Died May 4. Pratt graduate, JC Penney designer. Burial in Virginia.

description: The plaintiffs in four lawsuits against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority each have their reasons for fighting the deal that gave the New York Jets development rights for a prime piece of real estate on Manhattan's West Side. description: DURING the Tiananmen Square protests 16 years ago, young Chinese demonstrators eager for democratic reforms raised a replica of the Statue of Liberty in the center of Beijing.

title: Germany Commemorates 60th Anniversary of the End of World War II
description: BERLIN, May 8 - Germany commemorated the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II today with church ceremonies and speeches in Parliament emphasizing German responsibility for a war that, as the country's president, Horst KAhler, put it, "turned all of Europe into a mass graveyard."

description: SALONICA, CITY OF GHOSTS Christians, Muslims and Jews, 1430-1950. By Mark Mazower. Illustrated. 490 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

description: Ashley Nicole Hudson and Charles Franklin Gray II were married in Memphis yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Edward Parker Jr., a Baptist minister, officiated at the Cadre Building, a space for special events. The Rev. Dr. Christopher Davis Sr., also a Baptist minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: 'Irresistible Empire': McEurope
description: IRRESISTIBLE EMPIRE America's Advance Through Twentieth-Century Europe. By Victoria de Grazia. Illustrated. 586 pp. The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $29.95.

title: The Cheat: So You Still Can't Get a Reservation at Babbo?
description: One of the singular pleasures of eating out in New York City in the early years of the new century is the arrival of a plate of steaming beef-cheek ravioli at Babbo, Mario Batali's flagship restaurant on Waverly Place in Greenwich Village.

title: A Surplus and a Smile
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg should have had balloons in one hand and a pin in the other as he outlined his budget for a year in which he asks to be re-elected. Blessed with a surplus of more than $3 billion, he offered a bag of goodies, including tax cuts and rebates and millions more dollars for education.

title: Workout Evangelism
description: At the Y.M.C.A. where I exercise, the Christian Emphasis Committee displays copies of the magazine Focus on the Family (from the "conservative politico" James Dobson's organization) on its bulletin board. I find it offensive -- it's clearly political -- and have twice asked the committee to remove it. It has refused. I have since started removing these magazines myself and disposing of them in the trash. Is this O.K.? Anonymous, Charlotte, N.C. At least you're not littering. But your actions, while tidy, are intemperate. Never mind having to burn down every newsstand that carries magazines expressing ideas you reject and pillage the local library if any of its books fails to merit your approval. Exhausting!

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: The Casting Kuchen
description: I GOT off the subway at 72nd Street. The stop was just a few blocks from my final destination, the ABC-TV studios. It was also near a bakery, which was an important part of the plan.

title: For Preston, a Final Push in Utopia Deal
description: TOWN leaders in Preston are expected to begin negotiations soon on the final land and development deals with Utopia Studios of New York, the investment firm proposing a $1.6 billion entertainment complex for the former Norwich State Hospital property.

description: THE DIEZMO By Rick Bass. 208 pp. Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.

title: Giacomo, the Unknown, Storms to Victory
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7 - George Steinbrenner had Bellamy Road, the Kentucky Derby favorite. Nick Zito had five horses, good ones, who accounted for a full quarter of the 20-horse field. But for 130 years, this has been a puzzling race; one in which big horses have shrunk and multiple-horse entries have guaranteed trainers nothing but headaches when it comes to pleasing different owners.

title: If Nimby Means Stay Away, Kimby Means Don't Leave
description: At the rounded, low-slung building that houses the Dyckman Job Center, which sits at the corner of Broadway and Sherman Avenue in Washington Heights, city employees cluster near the doorway taking smoking breaks while welfare and food-stamp recipients come and go. Most of them look down on their luck, although occasionally a client will step, incongruously, into an expensive-looking S.U.V.

title: The Perfect Picture Of an Urban Club
description: THE network of steel scaffolding now encasing the University Club at 54th Street and Fifth Avenue seems to offer a new sense of scale to the Italian Renaissance-style palace. Built in 1899, it remains one of New York's most majestic monuments.

title: Science, Religion And Kansas
description: To the Editor:

title: After Vote, Blair Confronts Debate His Tenure
description: LONDON, May 8 - It's not unusual in politics for an election victor to enjoy a honeymoon, however brief. But three days after a national vote in Britain that gave him a historic third term, Prime Minister Tony Blair confronted a widening debate about his tenure in office.

title: Marly Grana and Thomas Henry
description: Dr. Marly Maritza Grana, an internist, and Dr. Thomas Andrew Henry, an anesthesiologist, were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Ronald A. Franco, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul the Apostle Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAVEN, ANNE S. (NEE FREEDMAN)
description: RAVEN--Anne S. (nee Freedman). Beloved wife of the late Ben Raven. Loving mother of Pam Lippman of Manalapan, NJ, and Abbe Raven of Edgemont, NY. Cherished grandmother of Genna and Keri Lippman and David Tackel. Adored mother-in-law of Martin Tackel. Deeply devoted sister, aunt, great-aunt, cousin and friend. Resided in Clearbrook, NJ, after raising her family in Laurelton, NY. During her 85 years she was an educator, humanitarian, activist and volunteer with many organizations. She was beloved by her extended family and large circle of friends. She was an extraordinary woman who touched everyone she met. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services Monday, May 9, 10 am, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, Yonkers, NY. Memorial donations may be made to American Women's ORT-NJ Region or the Special Olympics.
