description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION
description: A chance to stare at JAMES DEAN, again, comes Wednesday night on "JAMES DEAN: SENSE MEMORIES," a presentation of AMERICAN MASTERS, on WNET. Dean looks -- how else? -- good, sauntering along his Boulevard of Broken Dreams, swaggering melancholically in that Coke-can-colored "Rebel" jacket.

title: Off-Street Dining
description: Sidewalk cafes are sprouting around the city these days, but "Sex and the City" notwithstanding, not everyone enjoys dining smack on the street, with the accompaniment of honking taxis. A few places, relative newcomers, offer outdoor dining that comes with a little seclusion.

title: Your Garbage, Our Backyard
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIENSTOCK, LIESL
description: BIENSTOCK--Liesl. Devoted mother of Michael and Reesa Bienstock, and Diane and Morton Setchen. Devoted wife of the late Ben Bienstock. Cherished grandmother of Marissa and Adam Bienstock, and Jason A. Setchen. A woman of intelligence, elegance and grace. For info, call WeinsteinGarlick - Kirschenbaum, phone 800-556-7799.

title: Letters
description: Our April 24 issue drew provocative mail. Some readers offered a risk-benefit analysis of autopsies (as diagnostic aids versus tools in the hands of malpractice lawyers). Others weighed in on cognitive workouts on prime-time TV, life in the Democratic Party and political correctness at PBS.

title: Buried Answers
description: I'm sorry to provide the economist's diagnosis for the disappearing autopsy, but at present there is no monetary incentive for a patient to consent to one. How about prefinancing your own autopsy -- perhaps with the additional incentive that your heirs would benefit from any malpractice awards for mistaken diagnoses? People might like to gain the certainty that if mistakes were made in their final days, someone would be held accountable.

title: Working for a Boss Who Bullies
description: DURING one summer break in college, I worked at a print shop. My days were spent collating and stapling -- and listening to the manager scream.

title: A Different Set of Chronicles
description: ON a perfect, sunny afternoon, Jakob Dylan sat not quite comfortably in the small recording studio he maintains on the grounds of his Los Angeles home. A single candle burned in the room, which was crowded with instruments and gear. The blue eyes that helped make him a '90s-era heartthrob shone, and his black hair, pushed back off his face, jutted this way and that in hip disarray. The Wallflowers, the band Mr. Dylan has led for 15 years, have a new album coming out, and that can mean only one thing: more questions about his dad.

title: Sri Lankan Maids Pay Dearly for Perilous Jobs Overseas
description: KEGALLA, Sri Lanka - The teacher held up an electric cake mixer and told the class of wide-eyed women before her to clean it properly. If it smells, "Mama," as the aspiring maids were instructed to call their female employers, "will be angry and she will hammer and beat you."

title: My Son, the Hairdresser
description: A lifetime of never worrying about your roots. That is, if you can get an appointment.

title: A Friar Speaks, and Lightning Strikes
description: THE REV. JOHN CELICHOWSKI, a Franciscan friar from Milwaukee, found out last week that corporate boards sometimes move in mysterious ways.

description: THE HOT KID By Elmore Leonard. 312 pp. William Morrow. $25.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRIMM, ELAINE, PHD.
description: GRIMM--Elaine, PhD. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute and Society mourn the loss of Elaine Grimm, PhD. An esteemed graduate, member of the Society Board, faculty member and a treasured colleague. Known for her generosity of spirit and for her sage, direct and straightforward manner, Elaine served successfully in many arenas with plucky vitality. She was much valued and will be sorely missed. Joerg Bose, MD, Institute Director Gurmeet Kanwal, MD Society President

title: Jockey Has Very Different Derby Experiences Aboard Father and Son
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7 - Mike Smith had been waiting 11 years for this, and he said he could actually feel it would be his day.

title: Golf Homes Attract Even Those Who Don't Play
description: IN the game of golf, a triple bogey -- three strokes over par on one hole -- is bad news.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "After 9/11, we had to show how committed we were by spending hugely greater amounts of money than ever before, as rapidly as possible. That brought us what we might expect, which is some expensive mistakes. This has been the difficult learning curve of the new discipline known as homeland security."

title: Dust-Up on Red Sox Island, or, the Rift at the Riviera
description: The night last October when the Red Sox won their first World Series in 86 years, hundreds of euphoric Boston fans spilled into Sheridan Square from the Riviera Cafe and Sports Bar in Greenwich Village, blocking traffic, cheering raucously and dancing, in some cases, until dawn.

title: How Everyone Jumped Aboard a Railroad to Nowhere
description: When the Friends of the High Line first banded together six years ago, their idea -- to turn a stretch of rusting rail into an oasis floating above the bustle of Chelsea -- seemed quixotic at best. At worst, it seemed like a folly, proof that the artists and celebrities involved had lost touch with real life in Giuliani-era New York. Against staggering odds, however, their daring vision has become city policy. Here's a look at how fancy photography, graphic design and celebrity serendipity trumped railroads, landlords and a swamp of government agencies.

title: The New Girl
description: I was in the third grade when my family moved from Indianapolis in the early 80's and I became the lone black kid in a little Iowa town. At first there were stares, followed by the standard questions: Why did I call it getting a perm if it actually made my hair straighter? Did it hurt that my legs were so dry? Other kids who were different, who were fat or ugly or handicapped in some way, were ridiculed. But somehow I was special.

title: Exiled General Back in Beirut, Promising a New Era
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 7 - Gen. Michel Aoun, a onetime nationalist Lebanese army commander who inspires support in the street among many Christians and unease among some of the long-entrenched elite, arrived in Beirut on Saturday after 15 years in exile, promising to remake the country's politics.

title: Showcasing Homes for Good Causes
description: LATE last month, Brian Pinkow easily maneuvered his wheelchair through a spacious hallway at the Lindens, a mansion in Muttontown, three days before the opening of a display of custom-designed rooms at the stately home.

title: The Economic Unit Called Supermom
description: IF you want to know how much the average food worker in the nation earns -- $8.31 an hour -- the Bureau of Labor Statistics has the answer. A hedge fund manager's salary can be inferred by the Jaguar in his driveway. But how to calculate the value on the 10 hours clocked last week at an elementary school book fair by the mom in the fetching cardigan?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PEYRELONGUE, LUCILE
description: PEYRELONGUE -- Lucile. Memorial service for Lucile Peyrelongue on Tuesday, May 17 at St. Thomas More Church at 4 PM, 65 East 89 Street, New York City.

title: Candidate Criticizes the Mayor for the Delays at Ground Zero
description: Escalating his criticism of delays in the reconstruction of ground zero, Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker and a Democratic candidate for mayor, is challenging Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to push for greater control over the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan.

title: On the Stage of the Blind
description: Extreme method acting alert: in the Vortex Theater Company's production of "The Blind," Maurice Maeterlinck's 1890 play about sightless people in a forest waiting for their caretaker to return, the three actors wear opaque contact lenses that make them unable to see. Newly adapted by Bathsheba Doran, the play runs at the Classic Stage Company from Wednesday to next Sunday. Zachary Pincus-Roth talked to the company about learning to walk, talk and act blind.

title: Meet Grandma Moses With an Attitude
description: A JERSEY CITY artist showing in New York City is nothing new, but what the painter Amy Wilson has assembled at Bellwether Gallery in Manhattan is worth more than a passing nod of approval. The exhibition, which coincides with her inclusion in the "Greater New York 2005" show at P.S. 1 in Long Island City, features more than 75 of her disarmingly nave yet sharp, politically-attuned drawings and paintings.

title: Emily Fox and Peter Scott
description: Emily Joy Fox, the daughter of Victoria Fox and Lawrence Fox, both of Philadelphia, was married last evening to Peter Edward Scott, a son of Ronnie and William Scott of Hingham, Mass. Judge Barbara M.G. Lynn of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas officiated at Cicada, a restaurant in Los Angeles.

title: Wang Hao, 16, Has No Title, but He Has a Victory in Dubai
description: These days there are so many young players performing spectacular feats that we may become blas and take them for granted. There were 149 entrants at the Seventh Dubai Open Chess Championship, held from April 3 to 13, and only about a dozen were not grandmasters. Yet the winner turned 16 during the event and held no title at all. Wang Hao of China is no grandmaster, no international master, not even a FIDE master. But he scored 7-2 in the nine-round Swiss-system competition, something no one else did.

title: Molto New Jersey
description: Welcome to the merry month of Mario Batali, the celebrity chef whose sizzling affair with the culinary life started simmering when he was a student at Rutgers. Mr. Batali has a new book just out, received the James Beard Foundation's 2005 award for outstanding chef last Monday and is scheduled to deliver the Rutgers commencement address on May 19. Not bad for a guy who took a job at the Stuff Yer Face sandwich shop in New Brunswick when he was a college student because "it was where all the pretty girls hung out."

title: Fairfield's Piece of the Pie
description: THE year is 2020. You are cruising in your hovercraft through Pennsylvania to visit relatives in Ohio when you start to get hungry. At the nearest exit, you pull off, pass McDonald's and pull into a place called Pepe's, where the clam pizza is always fresh and the line is out the door.

title: DataBank; Market Has a Good Week Despite Bad News
description: The stock market rallied last week, despite epochal news that was, on the face, mostly negative. General Motors and Ford, two bulwarks of the American economy, had their bond ratings cut to junk status on Thursday. Standard & Poor's said the action reflected the carmakers' long-term "competitive disadvantages."

title: Stir the Noodles, Lace the Running Shoes, Collect the Children
description: ORI MUNSON seems most at rest when she is in motion. Shortly after teaching yoga in her loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on a recent afternoon, she was already suited up in running clothes and whipping up noodles for her 3-year-old daughter, Sasha Ray. One eye on the clock, Ms. Munson gracefully maneuvered her daughter into pink sweatpants and out the door, where she strapped the drowsy girl into a red jogging stroller.

title: Distant Musical Pilgrimages, Recorded on the Run
description: IT was the Bach year that keeps on giving. One of the most notable commemorations of the 250th anniversary of Bach's death in 2000 was a yearlong pilgrimage in which Sir John Eliot Gardiner and his early-music ensembles presented all of Bach's surviving sacred cantatas in churches throughout Europe and in the United States on the appropriate liturgical feast days. It began on Christmas, 1999, in Weimar, Germany, and ended on New Year's Eve, 2000, at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York.

title: Whoops! We Seem to Have Misplaced Your Identity
description: THE diesel-powered utility van is the unappreciated speed demon of the digital age. Even lumbering along city streets in stop-and-go traffic, it can move a trillion bytes of corporate data across town far faster than if they were sent across the Internet.

title: On to Detroit Now, Where the Brawl Is Not Forgotten
description: BOSTON, May 7 - The team that fisticuffs, suspensions, mayhem and misfortune could not destroy took another spectacularly improbable leap forward Saturday night. The Indiana Pacers' reward now is to return to the very place that nearly wrecked them all those months ago.

title: Clear the Way, Fellows. The Yellow Brick Road Is Coming Through.
description: SALINA, N.Y. - IN this corner we have what's certain to become the greatest thing to hit upstate since the Erie Canal: DestiNY USA, the developer Robert Congel's ever-elastic field of dreams. To be picky, three years after construction was to begin, it doesn't yet exist. Still, at the moment it promises the biggest, greenest most enviro-friendly mall and entertainment project in the galaxy and the first 21st century "technology cluster," which will be to this century what Silicon Valley was to the last one: 250,000 jobs! $65 billion in taxes created over 30 years! 100 percent fossil-fuel free! "The most visited single leisure destination on earth!"

title: One Kenmare Square: There Is No There There
description: One Kenmare Square is the latest address in SoHo.

title: Hospital Finds Health in Alliances
description: SLEEPY HOLLOW - KENDAL on Hudson, a retirement community, sits on a slope between the Hudson River and Phelps Memorial Hospital Center here, and what makes this setting unusual is that it is property leased from the hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DOSIK, SHERRY
description: DOSIK--Sherry. On Mother's Day and every day we remember and love you. Morty, Jon and Jill

title: Smart? Fine, but Do You Know What to Do With the Olive Pits?
description: At the annual senior etiquette dinner at Salve Regina University in Newport, R.I., in February, one student, Jennifer Bladykas, was surprised to learn that reaching for the salt before tasting her entree tells people she is prone to rash decisions. She also learned where to put the spoon after stirring her coffee, and in what direction to pass bread.

title: At Spas, Color Therapy Replaces Heavy Machinery
Paid Notice: Deaths   BRILL, DR. NORMAN
description: BRILL--Dr. Norman. Beloved brother, uncle and friend. Sadly passed away on April 14th at the age of 75.

title: BOUNTY ON A FUGITIVE
description: The state attorney general's office has raised the reward for the capture of a woman convicted of killing a state police trooper. Attorney General Peter C. Harvey said last Monday that the state would award $1 million to anyone who turns in Joanne Chesimard, classified as a federal fugitive, for killing New Jersey State Trooper Werner Foerster on May 2, 1973. According to the police, Ms. Chesimard, 57, a member of the Black Liberation Army, was with two accomplices when they had a shootout with the state police. Trooper Foerster was severely wounded in the gun battle, before being executed by Ms. Chesimard. She was tried and convicted on murder charges, but later escaped. Mr. Harvey said she is living in Cuba under the name Assata Shakur. John Holl

title: For Parks in a Tangle, a Plan to Tame
description: IF they hadn't been wearing blue shirts with New York City Parks Department patches on the sleeves, the two women and two men in combat boots could have been mistaken for privates in a zany version of Army boot camp. They perched warily in the concrete bleachers of the amphitheater in Echo Park, near the Grand Concourse and East Tremont Avenue, in a part of the Bronx where people guard their homes with razor wire and big dogs.

title: The Pope and AIDS
description: SO PAULO, Brazil - Let's hope that Pope Benedict XVI quickly realizes that the worst sex scandal in the Catholic Church doesn't involve predatory priests. Rather, it involves the Vatican's hostility to condoms, which is creating more AIDS orphans every day.

title: Big Homes for Town Founded by Slaves
description: LAWNSIDE, a haven for African Americans since the days of the Underground Railroad, when former slaves secretly built homes there on land made available by a Quaker from the adjacent settlement of Haddonfield, is now reaching out to higher-income home buyers with a new development of 25 spacious homes.

title: Corrections
description: A pop/jazz entry last Sunday in the Tours section of the Summer Stages listing misidentified the instrument played by Trey Anastasio, with the Zooma tour. It is guitar, not bass.

title: Amid Claims of Rising Prostitution, Complaints, Followed by Arrests
description: Along Third Avenue in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, warehouses, grocery stores and residential buildings are interspersed with sex shops adorned with green, red and blue neon. Business with names like Pleasure, Blue Door and Bachelor Party openly display X-rated videos and sex paraphernalia as mothers walks past pushing strollers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YANUCK, SHERMAN
description: YANUCK--Sherman on May 4, 2005, peacefully at home in Palm Beach Gardens, FL, formerly of Huntington, L.I. Beloved and loving husband of Anita and the late Lyn. He will be missed by his adoring children Bob and Robin, Beth and Jerry, Scott and Barbara; stepchildren Andrew and Elizabeth, Judith and David. Grandpa to Mollie, Michael, Andrew, Margot, Sam, Joshua, Brian, Lauren, Jacob, Benjamin and Eli. Loving brother of Mel, Barbara and Gloria. He proudly served as a radio officer in the Navy during World War II and later became a pioneer builder/developer on Long Island. Above all else, he prized his family and the simple fundamental values of life.

title: On the Cover; Acting Like a King
description: THE lives of Elvis Presley and Jonathan Rhys Meyers overlapped by only 20 days, but this week they will be fused as Mr. Meyers plays the rock 'n' roll legend in "Elvis," a four-hour film on CBS. Mr. Meyers, who was born July 27, 1977, not quite three weeks before Presley's death on Aug. 16, may not have experienced the Elvis phenomenon first-hand, but he knows that playing someone millions of people already think they know is a double-edged sword. "It is an actor's best dream and his worst nightmare all rolled into one," he said. "I've always accepted that all I can do for any role is my best, and so there are people who are going to like it and people who are not."

title: FEB. 26, 2005, PUNTA TOMBO NATURAL RESERVE
description: Yvonne van Anrooy, 41, a teacher from Alphen aan den Rijn, the Netherlands. "I found it amazing that these penguins live in the warm climate. They were under bushes, searching for shade, digging holes and lying in them. The young penguins were running toward the sea, ready to take their first swimming lessons. You see them running across the road, and you let them go first, because they have the right of way. My camera was making noises that the penguins didn't recognize. They reacted by turning their heads to the left and right. They are used to human beings. You can talk and you can walk, but they didn't recognize the motor of the camera. They were moving in such a way, wiggling and diggling, that -- how do you call it in English? -- they were sweet. And the smell was also not bad. I also went to a sea lion colony, and they smelled very badly. But the penguins didn't." As told to Seth Kugel

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   EDLUND, RICHARD HARDING
description: EDLUND--Richard Harding. You are forever remembered, especially today. Loving thoughts from us all.

title: In Two Lively Districts in Lisbon, Every Night Is a Block Party
description: LISBON has no idea how cool it is. The city lives in the shadow of Europe's superstar capitals, unaware of its own modern charms. It is not uncommon to hear people talk about surviving dictatorship, the earthquake of 1755 and the loss of empire as though these were recent concerns, not events that happened some 30, 250 and 400 years ago.

title: A Mayor's Secret Life Jolts a Northwest City
description: SPOKANE, Wash., May 6 - Over the last three months, Mayor James E. West of Spokane, one of the most powerful politicians in this state, carried on an online exchange -- full of mutual compliments and often overtly sexual -- with someone who said he was a 17-year-old high school senior. In time, the mayor, 54, revealed his identity, and said he had lots of sports memorabilia he could give the boy from his office. As they prepared to meet for the first time, the mayor professed his nervousness, and his caution.

title: Buried Answers
description: As interns at Presbyterian Hospital in the late 1940's, we were very proud of our high success rate in obtaining permission for post-mortem examinations from patients' responsible relatives (David Dobbs, April 24). We spent considerable time with them to explain the value and importance of the autopsy. The current political and economic climate has made it extremely difficult for physicians to take the time to discuss the matter with the relatives. The pressure to see as many patients as possible to generate revenue makes it even harder to carry out this necessary effort.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WASSERMAN, AL
description: WASSERMAN--Al. Memorial to be held Tuesday, May 10th at 4PM, Channel 13, 450 West 33rd Street, 6th Fl, NYC.

title: Seeking a New South Beach Standard
description: When can $1,000 a night for a hotel suite be considered a bargain? When it's about to go up to $2,000 a night.

title: Who Scares the Rest? (See Bottom Left)
description: MAYBE North Korea really is preparing to make the ground shake, to prove that its 50-year quest to acquire a nuclear arsenal has succeeded.

title: 'Jaws'
description: For everything that has been said and written about how Steven Spielberg's "Jaws" began the reign of the Hollywood blockbuster and spelled the end of the golden age of American filmmaking in the early 70's, "Jaws" belongs more to the adult era that preceded it than to the infantile one that followed. Pauline Kael called the movie a grand joke on masculinity, with Robert Shaw's macho shark hunter Quint set up as the target for Roy Scheider's pragmatic sheriff and Richard Dreyfuss's brainy ichthyologist to score off. "Jaws" is the American comedy that grew out of the divisions of the Vietnam years, years in which men who didn't affirm what was considered the traditional masculine role had their manhood questioned. When Robert Shaw starts chewing the scenery, bragging of some fishy exploit, it's easy to hear the braggadocio of some vets who used their own combat experiences to question the bravery of those who opposed the war. Which is why when Quint gets the danger he seeks and is swallowed whole by the shark, it's the funniest consummation in movie history. This 30th-anniversary DVD set includes all the extras you'd expect -- making-of documentary, outtakes, deleted scenes, etc. But the true attraction, as it always has been, is Mr. Spielberg's ingenious, malevolent filmmaking. Without any of the Cuisinart editing, whipping camera movements or computer-generated effects that have rendered today's commercial blockbusters visually incoherent, using only camera placement, perspective and editing, Mr. Spielberg succeeds in completely shredding any sense of safety in the viewer. His craft dovetails beautifully with that of his heroes, who defeat the shark through brains and not brawn. "Jaws" is Mr. Spielberg's "Revenge of the Nerds." (Universal, June 14) C.T.

title: A Blog Revolution? Get a Grip

description: Five years after he retired as the chairman of Citrix Systems, Edward Iacobucci is planning to become a highflier again -- this time with a regional charter jet service.

description: SINCE he became president, George W. Bush has made charity an important part of his political platform. Time and again, he has suggested that charitable groups, especially those with religious affiliations, could take over social services traditionally offered by the government.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHATTAN, BO AND MIMI
description: SHATTAN--Bo and Mimi. In memory of our parents who died one year ago. The fact that they passed on one day apart was symbolic of their extraordinary devotion and connection to each other. Their family and friends cherish the wonderful memories of them. Buzz and Tom

title: Editors' Choice
McMansions or Bash-and-Builds, Some Towns Have Had Enough
description: AFTER her husband died, Barbara Wirkus decided it was time to sell the house in Union where they had lived for 38 years and raised four sons. She moved into bungalow, "a lovely little home" on a cul-de-sac in Kenilworth, a town the 72-year-old widow describes six years later as "a town that time forgot." She planted a garden and made friends with her neighbors.

title: After a Fire, a Family in Turmoil
description: WITH up to $4,000 a month to spend on a temporary rental for her family -- two adults, two children, two pets -- Larissa Phillips figured that finding a place would be a snap. "I thought I would have something by the end of the day," she said.

title: The Nazis and Coco
description: Coco Chanel was a superb businesswoman and, not coincidentally, a superb liar: she lied about her date of birth and her childhood; she stole details from novels and friends' lives to weave a more melodramatic account of her life. She was candid -- for example, about her many lovers -- only as far as it helped drive up the price of her dresses.

title: Gliding Along the Water in the Land of the Eternal Sky
description: ONE thing to keep in mind if you ever go to Mongolia: Watch what you say about Genghis Kahn. Westerners may think of him as a marauding savage (albeit the ruler of one of the largest empires the world has ever known), but to the people of Mongolia he is a visionary leader who created international law, abolished torture, granted religious freedom and developed the first and a highly efficient international postal system. A brilliant military strategist, his innovative fighting techniques were still being studied well into the 20th century, more than 800 years after he was born.

title: Arty, Twangy and Carey
description: Since dissolving his ironically named trio Ben Folds Five in 2000, Ben Folds has continued to ply his brand of piano-driven pop on his own. In April, Mr. Folds released his second solo album, "Songs for Silverman" (Epic), and he performs tonight at the 9:30 Club in Washington and on Tuesday at Town Hall in New York. Speaking recently with Joel Topcik, Mr. Folds discussed what he's been listening to and why.

title: 'Perfectly Reasonable Deviations From the Beaten Track': A Word From the Wise
description: PERFECTLY REASONABLE DEVIATIONS FROM THE BEATEN TRACK The Letters of Richard P. Feynman. Edited by Michelle Feynman. Foreword by Timothy Ferris. Illustrated. 486 pp. Basic Books. $26.

description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLANK, JOHN N.
description: PLANK--John N., 81, resident of Storrs, CT. Died April 30, 2005. He was Emeritus Professor of Polital Science at the University of Connecticut. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II in the North African and European campaigns. He received his B.A. and Ph.D. degrees from Harvard University where he was a member of the Government faculty from 1959-62.He was Director of the Office of Research and Analysis for American Republics in the Bureau of Intelligence and Research, U.S. Department of State during the Kennedy Administration and a Senior Fellow at the Brookings Instition from 196470. He joined the faculty at the University of Connecticut in 1970, retiring in 1985. A convinced Quaker, he was an active member of the Storrs Friends Meeting. He is survived by his wife, Eleanor, brother Stephen, children David, Margeret and Geoffrey and many devoted grandchildren, nieces, nephews and friends. Contributions in his memory can be made to the American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry St, Philadelphia, PA. 19102-1403.

title: Bridget Janairo and Charles Best
description: Bridget M. Janairo, a daughter of Elizabeth M. Janairo and Antonio R. Janairo of Dover, Del., was married yesterday to Charles Best, a son of Suzanne Best and Geoffry Best of New York. The Rev. Joseph Lorenzo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Anthony of Padua Church in New York.

description: In 15th-century Italy, double-entry bookkeeping was invented, and that system of balancing income and expenses has provided the iron logic of money management for businesses and governments ever since.

description: WHAT with the pollen count now over 6,000 and trees and flowers in bloom everywhere, winter in the Northeast is fast becoming a distant memory -- and yet, not so distant as to forget it all, especially if you had problems with your heating, as we did.

title: Nowhere to Run and Nowhere to Call Home
description: WHEN Tammy Krol and her partner, Patty Langan, heard that the Plainfield Greyhound Park was closing, they quickly arranged to adopt one of the track's greyhounds. When they brought it home late last month, the dog, whose racing name was Twilight Arthur, paced throughout their West Haven home all that night. So the couple's two teenagers, Mike Blodgett, 15, and Sarah Blodgett, 14, christened him Pacey.

title: Benefits
description: Sale to Aid the Blind WEDNESDAY -- The annual sale of designer clothing as well as home furnishings and beauty products at Lighthouse International, 110 East 60th Street, will aid its programs for blind and visually impaired people. The preview begins at 5 with cocktails, hors d'oeuvres and the shopping, and concludes at 9. Tickets, $225, or $125 for entry at 6, from (212)821-9445.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, LAUREN A.
description: LEVY--Lauren A. The Horace Mann School is deeply saddened by the tragic passing of a cherished and beloved alumna, Lauren Levy '99. Her sense of humor, warmth and gentle spirit filled the halls of HM. Lauren's courage and devotion to family and friends will remain with us forever. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to her parents, Wendy and Larry A. Levy and to the rest of her family. Dr. Eileen Mullady Head of School Robert J. Katz '65 Chair, Board of Trustees

title: Of Two Minds
description: The human brain is mysterious -- and, in a way, that is a good thing. The less that is known about how the brain works, the more secure the zone of privacy that surrounds the self. But that zone seems to be shrinking. A couple of weeks ago, two scientists revealed that they had found a way to peer directly into your brain and tell what you are looking at, even when you yourself are not yet aware of what you have seen. So much for the comforting notion that each of us has privileged access to his own mind.

title: The Sporting Life; Southwestern Art Oasis
In Keeping With Trend, Beltran Personally Delivers a Victory for Martnez

title: Keeping Aging Bodies Moving Smoothly
description: ARNOLD HORWITZ, 67, of Melville is an avid tennis player. He used to play singles two or three times a week. But for the last few years, he has been spending more time at the physical therapist's office than on the tennis court.

title: The Writing Teacher
description: Iowa City, along its river, is a beautiful town. There are brick-lined streets in a neighborhood called Goosetown, once Czech, where geese were kept in the deep backyards. Ample old houses remain and huge trees. Downtown there are wide streets, restaurants, shops and a wonderful bookstore, Prairie Lights, but the chief business is really the University of Iowa, within which, small but renowned, lies its jewel, the Writers' Workshop. Originally established in 1936, the workshop is the pre-eminent writing school in the country, although it is almost universally believed that writing cannot be taught, and in fact it is not really taught there; it is practiced. Kurt Vonnegut, one in the long list of famous writers who have been on the workshop's faculty, liked to say he couldn't teach people to write but, like an old golf pro, he could go around with them and perhaps take a few strokes off their game.

description: Why does this page look this way?

title: SUMMER MOVIES: Five Actors To Watch This Summer; Elizabeth Banks
description: In "Heights" (June 10), an ingenious puzzle of love and deception among New York's haute bohemia, Elizabeth Banks plays the bland exception. Her character, Isabel, is the stubbornly conventional daughter of a larger-than-life superstar stage actress (Glenn Close). Although Isabel has her own ambition to be a photojournalist, she sidelines it with a job working for a wedding photographer. With her beige clothes, well-behaved blond hair and emotions to match, she could be a day-tripper from deepest Connecticut, which is where she plans to retreat after marrying her fianc (James Marsden).

But for 44 sixth graders from St. Christopher's School in Baldwin, a recent field trip ended traumatically when their school bus overturned. The accident, which resulted in minor injuries for a number of the children and a fractured shoulder for the driver, has again focused attention on bus safety and the qualifications of school bus drivers.

title: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week

title: Immigrants in Tennessee Issued Certificates to Drive

The translation, Ms. King explained in Spanish, was not exact enough. It would have to be redone.

The pageantry and heroic movement in two pieces Ms. Chen presented Saturday night at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College are familiar attributes of that modern-dance company's repertory, as is the Expressionist tinge of Ms. Chen's work. But a little more sense of narrative or context -- and concision -- would have been welcome.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: West Islip: Girls On Bicycle Hit By Car
description: Two young girls riding a bicycle together were seriously injured yesterday when they rode into an intersection and were struck by a pizza deliveryman's car, the police said. The accident happened about 3:40 p.m. when the girls, Valerie McCarthy, 14, of West Islip, and Frances Jedlicka, 8, of Lindenhurst, rode into the intersection of Hunter Avenue and Toomey Road. Frances was taken to Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center in West Islip, where she was in critical condition. Valerie was airlifted to Stony Brook University Hospital, where she was in stable condition. The police issued a summons to the deliveryman, whom they identified as Stephen F. Carrasso, 20. They said that he had been driving with a suspended license and that his car had been impounded for a safety check. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

Before the Flood
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. - ONE of the paradoxes of global warming is that developing countries, which were not responsible for most of the greenhouse gas emissions that are changing the climate and did not reap the benefits of industrialization, will bear the brunt of the consequences. One of these consequences will be rising seas, which in turn will generate a surge of "climate exiles" who have been flooded out of their homes in poor countries. How should those of us in rich countries deal with this wave of immigrants? The fairest solution: allowing the phased immigration of people living in vulnerable regions according to a formula that is tied to the host country's cumulative contributions to global warming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'NEIL, LOUISE WESTERGAARD
description: O'NEIL--Louise Westergaard. A Broadway producer and mother of four, died on May 6, at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. The cause of death was Leukemia, with which she was recently diagnosed. Mrs. O'Neil, who was known professionally as Louise Westergaard, produced or co-produced a number of shows both on and off Broadway, including the Tony Award-winning Sophisticated Ladies, the Erte version of Stardust featuring the lyrics of Mitchell Parish, the musical Dream featuring the lyrics of Johnny Mercer and most recently, the Tony Award-nominated Say Goodnight, Gracie. With the Royal Shakespeare Company, she produced Peter Nichol's Poppy in London. Her Off-Broadway credits include American Rhapsody, Joyce Carol Oates' Cry Me a River and Tovah: Out of her Mind, which was presented at the Jewish Repertory Theater. She also co-produced three feature films: The Orphan, Bad Timing and Take it from the Top. Her first book, Melanie, was made into a film with Walter Reade Sterling. Early in her career she was artistic director of Joseph Campbell and Jean Erdman's theater, The Open Eye. Mrs. O'Neil was born in New York City on September 2, 1937. She graduated from the Professional Childrens School and the University of Chicago. After her first marriage to John Westergaard, she was married to Stephen O'Neil. In addition to Mr. O'Neil, she is survived by two daughters and two sons from her first marriage, Emile, Cathrine, Kermit and Elizabeth, all of New York, and three grandchildren. The funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

description: BAUER--Theodore J., MD, 95 of Wyckoff on May 6, 2005 at home. Beloved husband of 66 years of Helen Lucy (nee Mattes). Cherished father of Jane Gray of Marietta, GA, Virginia Biedron of Clarksville, MD, Martha Bauer of Saddle River, and the late Mary L. Bauer in 1977. Loving grandfather of nine grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren. Ted was born in Iowa City, IA and graduated from the University of Iowa Medical School in 1933. He served in the United States Public Health Services for 29 years where he was Chief of the Division of Venereal Disease in Washington, DC, Chief of the CDC, Atlanta, GA and Assistant Surgeon General. Upon retirement he joined Becton Dickinson in 1962 as Senior Vice-President for Research and Medical Affairs. He also served on Becton Dickinson's Board of Directors from 1965-1985. He was a member of numerous expert committees for the World Health Organization, the AMA, the Wyckoff Board of Health, the planning board for Hackensack Medical Center, and the Governor's Health Care Administration Board. He received the University of Iowa Alumni Achievement Award in 1997. In 2002 he was inducted into the Immaculate Heart Academy Hall of Fame. He was a parishioner of St. Elizabeth RC Church, Wyckoff. He also was a member of High Mountain Golf Club, the Wyckoff YMCA and Activities Unlimited. Contact the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, Wyckoff, NJ, 201-891-3400. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mary Bauer Memorial Scholarship Fund, Immaculate Heart Academy, 500 Van Emburgh Avenue, Washington Township, NJ 07676. www.vanderplaatfuneralhome.com

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Distributes Nicotine Patches
description: For the second time, New York City is making nicotine patches available free to city residents who want to stop smoking. Since the program was announced on Thursday, the city's 311 hot line has received more than 28,000 calls about the patches, health officials said yesterday, a daily increase of about 25 percent. The number of calls to 311 averages 35,000 per day. "These numbers -- over 28,000 calls so far -- demonstrate what we've always said: many people who smoke want to quit," said Thomas R. Frieden, the city health commissioner, above. Officials said a similar but smaller program in 2003 had been a rousing success, helping 11,000 people quit. This year, the city is providing patches for 45,000 people on a first-come-first-served basis. The patches can be obtained by calling 311 or by going to one of the Health and Hospitals Corporation's stop-smoking clinics. Pfizer donated the patches, valued at $8 million. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

"Gladiator," also directed by Sir Ridley, took in $47 million over its first weekend, in May 2000, and "Troy," released last May, made $35 million in its first week. ("Kingdom of Heaven" did better than last year's "Alexander," however, which made just $13 million in its debut weekend.) This week's No. 2 film was "House of Wax" (Warner Brothers), a remake of the 1953 Vincent Price classic with Paris Hilton in her first feature film role; it opened with $12.2 million in ticket sales. "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy" (Buena Vista), last week's No. 1, dropped to No. 3 with $9.1 million. Paul Haggis's "Crash" (Lions Gate) is at No. 4 with $9.1 million, and "The Interpreter" (Universal), starring Nicole Kidman and Sean Penn, made $7.5 million in its third week, landing at No. 5, with cumulative sales of just over $54 million. To secure the title, Gilad Altschuler and David Birman from Israel and Piotr Bizon and Michal Kwiecien from Poland had to win by 3 international match points over Roy Welland and Bjorn Fallenius of Manhattan, Bobby Levin of the Bronx and Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y.

title: Preserving Our Readers' Trust
description: Last fall, roughly a year after your acceptance of the Siegal Committee recommendations on our newsroom's culture, you asked us to take a fresh look at some of the steps we had taken to increase readers' confidence in The Times. You asked about anonymous sources and whether the paper had done everything possible to minimize their occurrence and maximize our candor when using them. You asked whether we could cut our error rate by a significant amount and thereby give readers greater confidence in our reliability. You asked us to look beyond our walls and investigate our industry's best practices: Are other leading papers taking steps that we should adopt to reinforce our readers' trust in us? And you were notably concerned about the din of outside criticism, about what seemed to be an unceasing drumfire from both left and right, amplified by the passions of the presidential election campaign and the wondrous reach of the Internet. Was it any longer possible to stand silent and stoic under fire?

title: 100 Rebels Killed in U.S. Offensive in Western Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 9 - A Marine task force swept through a wide area of western Iraq near the Syrian border, killing 100 insurgents and raiding desert outposts and city safe houses belonging to insurgents who have used the area to import cars, money, weapons, and foreigners to fight United States and Iraqi forces in Baghdad, Mosul and other cities, American military officials said Monday.

title: GLENAYRE IN DEAL FOR CD AND DVD UNIT OF UNIVERSAL MUSIC
description: Glenayre Technologies, which develops wireless communications equipment, agreed to buy the Universal Music Group's CD and DVD manufacturing operations for about $122 million to enter the entertainment business. Glenayre said it would acquire manufacturing and distribution assets in Hanover, Germany; Kings Mountain, N.C.; Fishers, Ind.; Reno, Nev.; and Wilkes-Barre, Pa. Universal Music, the world's largest music company, is a unit of Vivendi Universal of Paris. The acquisition is expected to be completed May 31. The new unit will employ about 1,900 people, a Glenayre spokeswoman, Stacy Adams, said. The acquisition lets Glenayre "become a significant participant in the manufacture and distribution of entertainment products," Glenayre's chairman, Clarke Bailey, said in a statement. Glenayre is based in Duluth, Ga.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: McDonald's Japan Profit Rises
description: Net profit for the Japanese unit of the McDonald's Corporation more than tripled, to 1.92 billion yen ($18.23 million), for the quarter that ended March 31, from 560 million yen in the same quarter a year earlier, as it increased sales in new and existing restaurants. The Japanese unit, McDonald's Holdings (Japan) said revenue rose 8.8 percent, to 82.14 billion yen, for the quarter, helped in part by a simplified pricing system and new breakfast menu items. The McDonald's Corporation of the United States owns 50 percent of the Japanese unit, which is the biggest fast-food chain in the nation. The unit kept its full-year profit forecast unchanged at 5.17 billion yen. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: CREDITORS OF UNITED AIRLINES CAN REPOSSESS PLANES
description: Aircraft creditors of United Airlines have the right under federal bankruptcy law to repossess 14 planes from the carrier, a federal appeals court in Chicago ruled, reversing a November decision by a bankruptcy judge. United, which has not been making payments on the planes, has given up six of them, so only eight are subject to repossession, an airline spokeswoman, Jean Medina, said yesterday. United, owned by the UAL Corporation, has been negotiating with the aircraft creditors, which own bonds secured by the planes, since UAL entered Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in December 2002. United has said that an agreement on the leases is one of the few remaining obstacles to an exit from bankruptcy later this year.

title: Silver Producer Posts Loss

Mr. Lpez Obrador, of the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party, leads all national polls ahead of next year's election. His popularity soared even as the federal government sought to prosecute him over a minor land dispute. It dropped the charges last week. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

description: A group led by Apax Partners Worldwide and a media entrepreneur, Haim Saban, made the winning bid for a 30 percent stake in Bezeq, Israel's largest telephone company, offering 4.24 billion shekels ($971 million). The Apax-Saban group outbid the only other participant in the auction, a group led by Beny Alagem, the Israeli-born founder of the personal computer maker Packard Bell Electronics, the Israeli Finance Ministry said. The winning group includes Moshe Arkin, vice chairman of the Perrigo Company, a maker of nonprescription store-branded drugs based in the United States.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Sun To Buy Programs From Procom Technology
description: Sun Microsystems said yesterday that it had agreed to buy for about $50 million the rights to use software from Procom Technology that operates storage computers. The rights cover programs for storage servers sold to small- and medium-sized businesses, known as attached storage products. The purchase will help cut costs and speed production, Sun said. The market for attached storage is expected to grow 15 percent a year, to $3.1 billion in 2008, the researcher IDC has estimated. Sun is seeking to increase storage sales amid tougher competition from Dell. Sun is the world's fifth-biggest maker of storage computers and last year its share of that market fell to 6.2 percent, from 6.8 percent, IDC said on March 4. Shares of Sun Microsystems, based in Santa Clara, Calif., fell 1 cent, to $3.85. Shares of Procom, based in Irvine, Calif., rose 65 cents, or 42 percent, to $2.20.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
SUNOCO LOGISTICS ACQUIRES PIPELINES FROM EXXON MOBIL
description: Sunoco Logistics Partners , an owner and operator of oil terminals and pipelines, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a storage site and pipeline from the Exxon Mobil Corporation for $100 million to expand its Texas network. Sunoco Logistics said it was buying a 197-mile, 16-inch pipeline that carries 125,000 barrels of crude oil a day from Corsicana to Wichita Falls. It will also get an idle 104-mile, 12-inch pipeline from Kilgore to Corsicana, and a storage operation in Corsicana that can hold about 2.9 million barrels. Sunoco Logistics, based in Philadelphia, plans to build an $18 million, 20-mile pipeline to connect the West Texas Gulf Pipeline with the Corsicana terminal, it said, allowing American refiners to process crude oil from foreign sources and the Gulf of Mexico.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Measures To Combat Drought
description: After six months of exceptionally dry weather, the government has begun restricting water use in preparation for the first major drought in 10 years, an official at the Environmental Ministry said. Average precipitation across Spain this winter measured less than 3 inches, or 35 percent of typical levels. Forecasts show few signs that rainfall will increase significantly over the summer. The restrictions apply so far just to water used for irrigating crops. Officials in the agricultural industry, particularly in the olive and cereal sectors, have warned that their crops could be seriously damaged by the restrictions. Renwick McLean (NYT)

Rexair, which makes Rainbow vacuum cleaners, had about $104.8 million in sales and $27.3 million in operating income in the fiscal year ended Oct. 2. He was a member of the New York Bar Association. He was predeceased by three children, Christine, David and Deirdre Goss. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DWYER, CORNELIUS J., JR.
description: DWYER--Cornelius J., Jr. Age 61. Died suddenly of a heart attack at his weekend home in Germantown, N.Y. on May 7, 2005. Casey, as he was known, graduated from Yale University and Harvard Law School, and practice law for 35 years at Shearman & Sterling in New York City, where he was a partner. Upon his retirement, he became a four-day-a-week school volunteer at P.S. 36 in Harlem. He also took up the study of the Irish language. He is survived by his wife June, a professor at Manhattan College, and his two sons, Quetzal, who built and runs Parque Reptilandia, a reptile zoo in Domenical, Costa Rica and Colin, a veterinarian with The Humane Society of New York. He also leaves a brother Michael, who lives with his wife and two daughters in Le Mans, France, and a sister, Rosemary, who lives in Monson, MA. with her husband, two sons and a daughter. A mid-summer memorial is planned.

description: It must have seemed like a good idea at the time, to create a charming musical about an early chapter in F. Scott Fitzgerald's life -- his college romance with Ginevra King, a prominent Chicago debutante -- and his meeting with her many years later. (She inspired a character in his first novel, "This Side of Paradise.") But the Prospect Theater Company has thrown everything but the kitchen sink into "The Pursuit of Persephone," jamming the two-and-a-half--hour-long evening with enough musical numbers and drag routines to sustain several musicals.

description: TBILISI, Georgia, May 10 - President Bush told tens of thousands of cheering Georgians packed into the city's Freedom Square today that the United States would stand with the former Soviet republic as it built its young democracy, and then pointedly warned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia that the sovereignty of Georgia "must be respected by all nations."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Father Avoids Death Sentence In Murder
description: A federal jury in Manhattan decided yesterday that Elijah Bobby Williams, 49, who was convicted Friday of the murders of three men in a crack cocaine deal that turned violent, would not face the death penalty. But the jurors decided that Mr. Williams's son Michael, 33, also convicted of the murders, would remain on trial so they could determine if he should be sentenced to death. Elijah Bobby Williams and his son, both Bronx-based drug dealers, were convicted of the Feb. 18, 1996, shootings in Wilkinsburg, Pa., of Timothy Moore, a cousin, Joel Moore, and Robert James. After deliberating for less than two hours, the jury concluded there was persuasive evidence that Michael Williams -- but not his father -- had planned the killings. Michael Williams's sentencing trial, with the same jury, will begin today. His father will go to prison for life without parole. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYER, HILDE
description: MEYER--Hilde. The worldwide family of Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem extends its heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Irma Haas on the loss of her beloved sister. A softspoken and gentle person her smile radiated kindness, warmth, inner beauty and peace of mind. She lived her life fulfilling countless acts of tzedekah and chesed which touched the lives of thousands, thus following the dictum of the Ethics of the Fathers to "say little but do much". From the ashes of the Shoah she came to this country where she rebuilt her life together with her late husband, Dr. Nathan Meyer. The people of Jerusalem were blessed to have Mrs. Meyer as a cherished and deeply caring friend. As a Diamond Founder of the Medical Center together with Mrs. Haas, the two worked together side by side generously supporting every event of the American Committee and every facet of the Hospital's work -from the expansion of our synagogue to equipping the Jesselson Heart Center and supporting our Well Baby Nursery and Maternity Department. We will always remember with deep respect and affection this remarkable and special woman. May her memory remain a blessing. Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Dr. Jonathan Halevy, Director General Sidney Adler, Treasurer Lee Weinbach, President, Nat'l Women's Division Michael S. Strauss, Chair, New York Board American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem

title: Most City 8th Graders Miss State Norm in Social Studies
description: More than 80 percent of New York City's eighth graders failed to meet state standards in social studies last year, a decline of nearly 20 percentage points since 2002, school officials acknowledged yesterday at a hearing of the City Council Education Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   APRIL, IRA
description: APRIL--Ira. Age 74. Of Summit, N.J., formerly of Livingston, on May 8, 2005. Beloved husband of Rigie. Devoted father of Sheryl and Mike. Adoring grandfather of Marni, Austin, Robbie and Jessie. Dear brother of David April and Barbara Saltzman, and brother-in-law of Marion April and Bob Saltzman. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Lung Association, or the American Cancer Society.

title: Arts, Briefly; Invigorated Tonic
description: In February the Lower East Side club Tonic, which presents rock, jazz and all kinds of unclassifiable avant-garde music, began a series of benefit concerts to raise $100,000 to avoid eviction. Things looked grim, but its fund-raising efforts worked. The club has raised $80,000 and persuaded its landlord to cover a $20,000 outstanding plumbing bill, the owners say, bringing Tonic back into the black. The club celebrates at 9 tonight with a free concert featuring the band Slavic Soul Party. BEN SISARIO

title: For Giambi, Timing, Not Time, Is Essential
description: In some ways, teams still fear Jason Giambi. They still bring in left-handed specialists to face him, and Giambi still draws a lot of walks.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Cardinal Sentenced For Radio Waves
description: A Rome court found a Roman Catholic cardinal and a priest who heads Vatican Radio guilty of polluting the atmosphere with electromagnetic waves from the station's transmitters, in an area north of Rome where a government study found elevated levels of leukemia. The two, Cardinal Roberto Tucci, the former chief of the management committee of Vatican Radio, the broadcasting station of the Holy See, and the Rev. Pasquale Borgomeo, the general director, were given 10-day suspended sentences. They said they would appeal. The convictions came after a trial in 2002 was halted when a judge ruled that the Vatican was a separate nation and that Italian law did not apply. That ruling was later overturned. The Vatican contends that its station meets safety standards. Ian Fisher (NYT)

description: In a conference call with Morgan Stanley employees yesterday, Stephen S. Crawford and Zoe Cruz, the firm's new co-presidents, cited a fresh batch of deals in Europe as evidence that the firm was thriving.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Governor Expands Records Access
description: Citing a recent government report exposing problems in the construction industry, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey signed an executive order yesterday to expand public information about building contractors. The order instructs the State Department of Community Affairs to create a Web site where the public can find information on builders, including legal claims against them, as well as housing-code and building-inspection information. The Web site, which does not yet have an address, is to open in three to four weeks, a spokesman for the Department of Community Affairs said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Friday about Col. David H. Hackworth, a war hero and later a critic of the Vietnam War, misidentified two units he commanded and the helicopters used by American forces in Vietnam. The Wolfhound Raiders were a platoon he led in Korea, not a regiment. In Vietnam, he commanded a battalion of the 101st Airborne Division, not an air cavalry brigade; that battalion flew Huey helicopters, not Black Hawks.

description: Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum endorsed Manhattan's district attorney, Robert Morgenthau, for re-election yesterday. The endorsement of Mr. Morgenthau, 85, who was first elected district attorney in 1974 and has not faced a primary challenge in two decades, came on the eve of the formal announcement by Leslie Crocker Snyder, a former State Supreme Court justice, that she is running against Mr. Morgenthau for the Democratic nomination. title: World Business Briefing | Brazil: Bank's Profit Surges
description: Brazil's largest private sector bank, Banco Bradesco, said its profit nearly doubled in the first quarter, citing an increase in lending and higher revenue from insurance, pension and savings plans. The bank posted net income of 1.2 billion reais ($489.4 million) in the quarter, up from a profit of 609 million reais a year earlier. Its credit portfolio expanded 22.3 percent from a year earlier, to 75 billion reais, a result of the growing demand for loans among individual clients and small and midsize companies. Revenue from insurance, pension and savings products more than doubled, to 427 million reais, accounting for 35 percent of the bank's earnings. The bank, which is based in So Paulo, finished the quarter with 191 billion reais in assets, up 19 percent from a year earlier. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Reverses Loss
description: The largest airline in Japan, the Japan Airlines Corporation, rebounded to a net profit of 30.1 billion yen ($285 million) for the fiscal year that ended March 31, from a loss of 88.6 billion yen a year earlier, on an increase in flights abroad. The airline, however, forecast that its profit would drop 43 percent, to 17 billion yen, this year because of rising fuel costs. Separately, the airline said its chairman, Isao Kaneko, above, would resign after a recent string of safety mishaps. Just a day earlier, a Japan Airlines flight from New York to Tokyo made an emergency landing in northern Japan after cabin pressure in the jumbo jet dropped suddenly. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Fire Chief Challenges New York Emergency Plan
description: The chief of the New York City Fire Department directly criticized the Bloomberg administration's decision to give the police initial control at hazardous materials emergencies, telling a packed City Council chamber yesterday that it "makes no sense" and risks endangering firefighters and the public.

Without a Conductor, a Different Sound
description: For an orchestra like Orpheus, playing without a conductor is a test, almost an athletic event. The game is to get the better of true ensemble playing with one useful arm tied behind one's back. European music is non-metronomic ebb and flow. Conductors exercise unilateral executive decisions in the name of unity, whether every orchestra member believes in them or not. The contest for Orpheus is how well 37 musicians will make identical adjustments and still play musically.

Books of photographs by Ms. Meiselas, the recipient of a 1992 MacArthur grant, include "Carnival Strippers" (1976) and "Nicaragua" (1981). title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Linen Supplier Admits Secret Deals
description: The owner of a company that provides tablecloths, chefs' uniforms and other linens to New York City restaurants pleaded guilty yesterday to federal charges of suppressing competition by dividing up customers with other linen supply companies. The owner, Stanley Olan, admitted in Federal District Court in Manhattan that he and his company, Sea Crest Linen Supply, agreed secretly with competitors not to fight for customers in New York City, parts of New Jersey and Fairfield County, Conn. Three other linen companies have been convicted of related charges in a business that generated $500 million in revenue in eight years. Mr. Olan, who also pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice, faces a maximum of three years in prison and fines of $350,000 or more, and Sea Crest could be fined as much as $10 million. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: Passport Chips to Be Encrypted
description: PASSPORT CHIPS TO BE ENCRYPTED -- After protests from business travel representatives, the State Department modified its plan to issue new passports embedded with tiny radio chips that transmit information to electronic devices at customs and immigration stations. The main objection was that the chips could put travelers in danger abroad by transmitting easy-to-intercept data identifying American nationality and other personal information. The State Department said it would modify the chips, called radio frequency identification tags, with encryption technology to greatly reduce the potential for eavesdropping. At its annual meeting last week in Vancouver, the Association of Corporate Travel Executives, which represents corporate travel managers, welcomed the move. But it said it would not endorse the proposed passports until the government demonstrated that the chips could not identify United States citizens at any distance from a passport reader and that "any encryption technology used to code traveler information is virtually foolproof."

title: Cocaine Users Face Greater Risk of Aneurysm
description: Cocaine users face a newly discovered and possibly fatal risk: coronary aneurysms, a ballooning of the walls of coronary arteries. The condition increases the chance of suffering a heart attack, even years after users stop the drug, researchers in Minnesota are reporting.

title: AAIPHARMA WILL SEEK BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: AaiPharma Inc., a pharmaceutical maker, said yesterday that it planned to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection this month and that it had agreed to sell its pharmaceuticals division for $170 million. AaiPharma said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it would provide manufacturing and other support services to the buyer of the pharmaceuticals unit. The buyer was not identified. AaiPharma shares were delisted by the Nasdaq Stock Market last month after the company failed to file its annual report on time, and it had to restate its third-quarter loss. AaiPharma is based in Wilmington, N.C.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 9 - The head of Afghanistan's peace and reconciliation commission offered an amnesty on Monday for all rebels fighting American and government forces, and even extended the offer to two of the most wanted Afghan terrorism suspects: the Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar and the renegade warlord Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. However, an American military spokesman seemed to suggest that the two suspects could not be included in the program.

title: The Line Between Life and Death
description: LATE last month, New York's major newspapers reported that a 13-year-old boy had "died" after he was taken off "life support." That assertion reflected a fundamental misunderstanding of death as defined by the laws of all 50 states. In fact, the boy had died more than a week earlier -- from a severe brain infection -- after transfer to the hospital where we work. In the interim, advanced medical technology supported his organs, not his life.

title: Gershwin: Bringing It All Back Home
description: During its 50th-anniversary season, the Brooklyn Philharmonic has been paying tribute to the Brooklyn community, which has rallied to its support, especially during the orchestra's recent years of dynamic growth. For Saturday night's anniversary concert, the program offered the best-known works by the Brooklyn-born George Gershwin: "Rhapsody in Blue," "An American in Paris" and a deftly conceived arrangement of arias, songs and choruses from "Porgy and Bess" prepared by Lorin Maazel. The performers included an appealing neighborhood chorus, the Total Praise Choir of Emmanuel Baptist Church. Making his debut with the Philharmonic was the conductor Chelsea Tipton II, currently the resident conductor of the Toledo Symphony Orchestra, substituting for Robert Spano, who was ill.

title: Chemical Time Bombs
description: A small stretch of northern New Jersey running between Newark Airport and Port Elizabeth has been called the most dangerous two miles in America by terrorism experts, and for good reason. It holds a chlorine plant that could threaten some 12 million people, and it has more than a dozen other chemical plants, two port complexes and a plethora of oil storage tanks, refineries and pipelines, intermingled with rail and highway links that provide easy access to more than 100 potential targets in all.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Amnesty For Migrants
description: More than 85 percent of the 800,000 immigrants estimated to be working illegally in Spain applied for residency under a three-month amnesty program that ended on Saturday, the Labor Ministry said. Almost all are expected to be approved, the ministry said. The program allowed illegal immigrants already living in Spain to apply for residency papers if they did not have a criminal record and if their employers agreed to provide them with a written contract to work for at least six months. The government said the program was necessary to satisfy the economy's demand for workers and to increase government revenues by adding the migrants to the tax rolls. Illegal immigrants have been pouring into Spain over the last five years, drawn mostly by jobs produced by the country's growing economy. Since 2001, their numbers have more then tripled. Renwick McLean (NYT)

Part 1 of the CBS mini-series about Elvis Presley (Jonathan Rhys Meyers, right), placed a distant second behind those two ABC hits, drawing 13.85 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates for Sunday. "Desperate Housewives" had nearly double that, with an audience of 26.2 million. And "Grey's Anatomy" (19.34 million) had its best ratings yet. The combination of the two shows resulted in an easy win for ABC in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49 for the night. CBS was second in total viewers, but it trailed Fox among adults 18 to 49. Fox continued to perform well with its animation block, which included new episodes of "Family Guy" (9.71 million) and "American Dad" (8.23 million). title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEROSE, JAMES F.
description: DeROSE--James F. Died on May 7, 2005. He was 71 years of age and left a rich legacy, both professional and personal. Almost immediately after graduating from Akron High School in 1950, he joined IBM, and in his 30 years with that organization, worked on projects ranging from SAGE I (New York Air Defense Sector, the IBM 3600, the Gemini/ Apollo Space Launches, New York Stock Exchange floor trading system, to the precursors of the ATM and an early hand-held commercial data radio terminal. In 1979, he received a Sloan Fellowship to complete his MA in Business from Stanford University. After retiring from IBM, he published four editions of "The Wireless Data Handbook". A lifetime of interest in things nautical, which included sailing, lead to his authorship of "Unrestricted Warfare", an account of the early years of submarine warfare in World War II. His work--and his gift for telling a good story--led to an appearance on a documentary on submarines, still being shown on the History Channel. His first wife, Nancy Fisher, predeceased him. He is survived by his wife Judith, his mother Helen, his daughters Linda DeRose Primavera, Jane DeRose Evans, Margaret DeRose Douglas and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the American Cancer Society.

He is the third city jail inmate to kill himself this year, and the fifth in the last 10 months. Mr. Labanca had no record of mental health problems at the jail, Mr. Antenen said. title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: U.S. Backs Fight Against Rebels
description: Less than two weeks after suspending emergency rule, King Gyanendra got a nod of support from two of his most important allies. India announced that it would resume military aid, suspended since the king dismissed the government on Feb. 1 and took direct power, and the United States said it backed him against the country's Maoist insurgency. The American support came on a visit by the assistant secretary of state for South Asia, Christina Rocca, above. She is the highest ranking American official to visit since the royal takeover, and she urged the palace to free political prisoners, reinstate civil liberties and reach out to political parties. The United States also cut military aid, and she did not say when it might be restored. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

description: Hudson County authorities continued to search yesterday for an illegal immigrant suspected of killing one man and stabbing two others in an apartment building. Investigators said that Ofelio Rojas Herrera, 29, entered the building, at 568 West Side Avenue, through a third-floor window on Monday morning and stabbed Crispin Lucero Flores, 23, as he slept. Mr. Herrera then stabbed two other men, one of them his cousin, before fleeing the apartment, said the Hudson County prosecutor, Edward J. De Fazio. Witnesses told the police that Mr. Herrera seemed intoxicated and that he had recently been fired from his job at a local car wash. Mr. De Fazio said that several hours after the attack, Mr. Herrera tried to board a flight for Mexico , but was turned away because he lacked proper identification. John Holl (NYT)

The rest of us, parents and friends, sat quietly enchanted by their youth and innocence.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Chief Rabbi Questioned
description: Shlomo Amar, the Sephardic chief rabbi, was questioned by the police about the kidnapping and beating of the boyfriend of his 18-year-old daughter. In a statement, the rabbi, who had just returned from a trip to Thailand, denied knowing about the assault and blamed his estranged son, Meir, 31, who is in custody. The rabbi's wife and daughter are under house arrest, under suspicion of involvement in the assault, which the police said was intended to frighten the boyfriend into ending the relationship. The announcement comes just as American intelligence agencies are trying to determine whether North Korea is preparing for a nuclear test.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Abuse Suit Forces Sale Of Churches
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of St. George's, in Newfoundland, is appealing to its 32,000 parishioners for donations to help it buy back some of the 150 properties it says it must sell to cover compensation payments of $10.5 million to 36 victims of a pedophile priest. Last year, the Supreme Court of Canada upheld lower court rulings against the diocese, and this year it became the first Catholic diocese in Canada to seek bankruptcy protection. It says it must sell its assets, including all of its churches, missions and parish houses. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: 13 Years In Cannibal Killing
description: A 41-year-old man who said he was driven by cannibal fantasies to kill and dismember a gay lover he met over the Internet was sentenced to 13 years in prison by a Berlin court. The man, identified only as Ralf M., 41, stored some of the organs of his 33-year-old victim, a music teacher, in his refrigerator, but in the end could not eat them. The case has drawn much attention in Germany after the spectacular trial of the admitted cannibal Armin Meiwes, who was convicted of manslaughter after killing and eating a willing victim last year. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBIN, BETTY (BESSIE)
description: RUBIN--Betty (Bessie) in her 95th year, on Mother's Day, May 8, 2005. Beloved and devoted mother of Enid Mindich, Jeffrey and daughter-in-law Susan. Precious Nanny of Aaron, Spencer Mindich (Samantha), Lauren, Jamie Klasfeld (Marc) and Diana, and great grandmother of Skylar Reese Mindich. Was married for 26 years to her cherished husband, A. Michael Rubin who died in 1966. Born on the Lower East Side on September 26, 1910 to Russian immigrant parents, she was the youngest of eight children, all now deceased. Her passing marks the end of an era. A true matriarch. She was a great classic Jewish mother with inexhaustible energy. Her unconditional and selfless love for her family played an integral role in their lives. She was a force of life who will be missed dearly. Graveside services at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, Wednesday, May 11 at 11 AM.

title: AIDS Now Compels Africa to Challenge Widows' 'Cleansing'

Instead, she hid in his sister's hut, hoping that the rest of her in-laws would not find her.

title: And to Badge Central
Dontrelle Willis, Please Phone Home
description: ALAMEDA, Calif., May 4 - If Joyce Harris were to ever watch her son pitch, she would notice the same things everyone else does. His corkscrew windup. His enthusiasm. The boyish way he slaps his mitt after a strikeout, bounding toward the dugout without touching his cleats to the first-base line, his jaw working a wad of gum the size of a fish filet.

After all, three of the firefighters who attended are a living reminder of Jan. 23, 2005, the Fire Department's deadliest day since Sept. 11, 2001. On Jan. 23, three of the department's members were killed battling two separate fires, one in Brooklyn and the other in the Bronx. Three recovering injured firefighters from that day -- Joseph P. DiBernardo, Jeffrey Cool and Brendan K. Cawley -- were at the ceremony.

title: Heart From the Heartland: Peace Corps Is Special Tradition at Wisconsin

This particular day in November 1967, the mail carried news about his college campus and hometown, the University of Wisconsin in Madison. There had been a protest against the Vietnam War, specifically a blockade against recruiters for the company that made napalm, and it had ended with tear gas, billy clubs, arrests and demonstrators taunting cops with cries of "Sieg heil!"

Sonny Perdue has signed a bill that requires abortion providers to tell patients at least 24 hours before the procedure of the risks of abortion and childbirth, the fetus's gestational age, and that medical assistance may be available for prenatal care and childbirth should the woman decide against abortion. The conversation may take place over the telephone. The patient must also be told that she can view a Web site describing her fetus and containing "information on fetal pain." Wheeler School in Providence, Milton Academy, and the University of Berlin. She lived in Old Westbury, NY until 1998 when she moved permanently to Narragansett where she had spent every Summer as a child and as an adult. Mrs. Milburn leaves six children, Devereux of Long Beach, CA, John of Williamsburg, VA, Frank and Nancy of New York City, Elizabeth Morris of Boxford, MA and Michael of Hamden, CT, as well as nine grandchildren. She was the sister of the late Anita Hovey, Francesca Pell, Gladys Porter, and Frank L. Hinckley, Jr. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Animal Rescue League, Curtis Corner Road, Peacedale, RI 02883 or Home and Hospice Care of Rhode Island, 169 George St, Pawtucket, RI 02860.
