description: "Spamalot," the decidedly goofy musical adaptation of the 1975 cult film "Monty Python and the Holy Grail," led all productions yesterday, as it bagged 14 Tony Award nominations, including nods for best musical; its director, Mike Nichols; and five of its actors.

title: New Credit Card Spots Show Fierce Competition for High-End Consumers
description: WHEN MasterCard rolled out its new Willy Wonka-themed television ads last night, it was aiming for the credit card industry's sweetest spot: the highly profitable "new affluent" consumer who spends several times what the average cardholder does and expects a cornucopia of rewards.

title: Egypt expected to adopt multicandidate elections
Chanel at the Met
description: To the Editor:

title: BAUSCH & LOMB DEBT IS UPGRADED BY MOODY'S
description: The debt rating of Bausch & Lomb, the eye care company, was raised to investment grade by Moody's Investors Service yesterday. Bausch & Lomb's senior unsecured rating was upgraded to Baa3 from Ba1, Moody's said. Bausch & Lomb, based in Rochester, has improved its performance in recent years, and short- to medium-term earnings are expected to remain solid while industry trends are favorable, Moody's said. The company has ample liquidity, with about $500 million in cash and "well-staggered debt maturities," Moody's said. Once $100 million in debt is repaid in August, the next larger maturity does not come due until 2007, Moody's said.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Profit Up At Budget Airline
description: The Brazilian budget airline Gol Linhas Areas Inteligentes said its profit rose 44.6 percent in the first quarter on increased revenue and market share. The airline, which started operating in 2001, posted net income of 131.1 million reais ($53.6 million) for the quarter, up from a profit of 90.7 million reais a year earlier. Revenue climbed 36 percent, to 589.2 million reais, as the carrier added three Boeing 737's to its fleet. According to data released last week, Gol finished April with 27.8 percent of the Brazilian aviation market, surpassing Varig, the unofficial flag carrier, to become the country's No. 2 airline in passenger traffic behind TAM Linhas Areas. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Before the flood
Mix-and-Match Retailers for the Eclectic Shopper
description: Retailers in New York used to gravitate toward certain streets or neighborhoods depending on the types of shoppers they were trying to reach, but in recent years the city's retail dynamics have changed, many real estate brokers say. More and more, seemingly incompatible types of retailers are intermingling on a single block or street.

title: Wider Net Cast in Saks Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has expanded its investigation of Saks Fifth Avenue to include chargebacks -- the deductions merchants take on payments to apparel makers for supposedly defective or unwanted goods, according to a person briefed on the investigation.

title: At Least 79 Are Killed in New Round of Attacks in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 11 - Insurgents struck in northern and central Iraq today in a series of bloody bombing attacks that killed at least 79 people in three cities, and wounded at least 120 others, according to figures provided by police and hospital officials. The attacks appeared to signify an intensification of attempts by Sunni Arab militants to disrupt Iraq's newly formed Shiite majority government.

title: 24-hour strike expected to hobble all sectors
World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Glacier In Coveralls
description: A ski resort in central Andermatt has wrapped part of the shrinking Gurschen glacier in a layer of reflective foil to protect it from melting. The cover, which is made of synthetic fibers, cost $83,000 and covers as much as 4,000 square yards, will protect natural access to the runs on the glacier. Urs Elmiger, a board member of the ski lift company behind the project, told Reuters that the retreat of Alpine glaciers due to global warming meant it would become "common practice to cover parts of the glaciers." John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: U.S. Provides Rules to States for Testing Special Pupils
description: Secretary of Education Margaret Spellings announced guidelines yesterday for states that plan to take advantage of new, short-term flexibility in the way special-education students are tested under the federal education law, No Child Left Behind.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Televisa's Chief Leaves Univision Board
description: Emilio Azcrraga, the chief executive of the Mexican media company Televisa, and his top executive, Alfonso de Angoitia, resigned from the board of Univision, the fast-growing Hispanic television network based in the United States. The move deepens a rift between Mr. Azcrraga and Univision's chief executive, A. Jerrold Perenchio. Televisa, a minority shareholder in Univision, said last month that Univision had cut some royalties paid to Televisa, which supplies most of Univision's programming. In response, Televisa filed a lawsuit contending that Univision breached the licensing agreement between the companies. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Soldier's Palestinian Father Can Stay
description: A Palestinian who was married to an Israeli Jew and whose son served in the Israeli Army has been granted residency in Israel after years of failed applications. The Palestinian, Adel Hussein, left, and his wife, Stella Peretz, divorced in the late 1990's after 30 years of marriage so she could take the boy, Muhammad, then 16, to the relative safety of Israel. There he was called Yossi Peretz and was drafted into the army. Mr. Hussein told his son to do his job as a soldier, even to stop him at a checkpoint. Harassed by Palestinians and his home attacked, the father fled to Israel, where he worked illegally and was deported several times. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: The Password to a Japanese Secret
description: JUST off the bustle of Second Avenue, where 41st Street heads uphill toward Tudor City, there's a billboard plastered with posters for the hip-hop album du jour, and, next to it, a black awning that juts out over a sturdy door. For years there was no indication of what lay beyond, until the owners recently added the name Tsukushi to the awning in little white letters.

title: Long Skull, Narrow Face: Tut Gets New Look
description: Artists and scientists drawing on a detailed examination of King Tut's mummy have reconstructed the face of the young ruler as he might have looked in life: an unusually elongated skull, a narrow face, pronounced lips and possibly a receding chin.

title: Chinese rule out sanctions on North Korea
Congress Adopts Restriction on Treatment of Detainees
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 - Congress barred the government on Tuesday from using any money in a newly passed emergency spending bill to subject anyone in American custody to torture or "cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment" that is forbidden by the Constitution.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Shippers Discuss Merger
description: The world's biggest container-shipping company, A.P. Moeller-Maersk, is negotiating to buy a rival, Royal P&O Nedlloyd. News of the talks set off a 21 percent rise in the share price of Nedlloyd, which is based in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. The talks are being held between Nedlloyd and Maersk Sealand of Copenhagen, a unit of Moeller. After the rally on its shares, Nedlloyd has a market value of about $2.6 billion. A.P. Moeller operates about 400 container ships, controlling 12 percent of the global market.

title: India to release shipment of arms to Nepal's army
Paid Notice: Deaths   PINCHUK, SINDY P.
description: PINCHUK--Sindy P. 68, of Cinnaminson, NJ on May 9. "Wonderful" mother to Nancy & (Joe Frank), Robert & (Anne) and Steven. Loving companion to Bruce Foster. Cherished grandmother to Audrey, Julia, Abbey, Helena & Benjamin. Daughter of the late Leon & Diane Schoenfeld of Flushing, NY, and sister of Gerald. A devoted aunt, cousin, friend and co-worker to countless others and former wife of William. Born in Forest Hills, NY, Sindy will be remembered by all who knew her as intelligent, loving, caring, genuine and sincere and a dedicated champion of the environment who proudly served for 25 years in the NJ Dept. of Environmental Protection. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Sindy's memory to Pastoral Care Library Fund, Fox Chase Cancer Center, 333 Cottman Ave, Phila, PA 19111. A private celebration of Sindy's life will be held on Saturday, May 14, details available through family members or stevepinchuk@hotmail.com

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Man Faces Omagh Charges
description: A prosecutor said in the Belfast High Court that a 35-year-old electrician, Sean Gerard Hoey, would face trial on charges of murder for the 29 people killed in the 1998 car-bomb attack in Omagh, the single worst atrocity in Northern Ireland. Besides the 29 killed, more than 300 people were injured. Mr. Hoey is already in custody on terrorist charges related to other attacks. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: A Producer Who Loved Both Art and Ribaldry
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10 - From his sprawling perch in Holmby Hills, the Hollywood producer Ray Stark amassed a collection of paintings and sculpture that was as notorious as it was illustrious, though perhaps no more notorious than the producer himself, whose estate bequeathed 28 of the sculptures to the J. Paul Getty Trust last month.

title: Hedge Fund Rumors Rattle Markets
description: Long-simmering worries about the growing influence of hedge funds erupted yesterday in a wave of nervous selling on world stock markets after talk that hedge funds had suffered large losses tied to the debt of General Motors. Shares of banks with connections to hedge funds fell sharply, even though the rumors could not be substantiated.

title: Plane Prompts Brief Evacuation of White House and Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 - A small plane flew into restricted airspace over the nation's capital today, causing a scare that prompted evacuation of the Capitol building, the White House, the Supreme Court and other government sites.

title: Putin's sour mood darkens Russia-EU accord
Bronx Renaissance for Martinez and Yanks
description: When Tino Martinez hits at Yankee Stadium, the fans transport themselves to a time when championships seemed assured. Martinez was fiery, dependable and occasionally transcendent, and the fans still revere him.

title: Coaches Are the Pawns in Steinbrenner's Game
description: THE sheet of paper is a page from a small yellow pad, 5 inches by 8 inches. I have been writing on it for years, and maybe I'll offer it to the Hall of Fame someday. I don't want to be or sound pretentious, but that small sheet of paper has history written all over it. It might be the only record in existence of all of the Yankees' pitching coaches and hitting coaches during the 33-year reign of George Steinbrenner as the Yankees' principal owner.

title: College Graduates for a Year, Hoping for Chances in the Throes of Reality
description: IT has been a year since members of the class of 2004 donned caps and gowns, hugged friends goodbye and left the campuses where they had been for four years.

title: A Pair of Rising Stars Opts Out of Manhattan
description: THE night before Allison Vines and her future husband Slade Rushing left the South for Manhattan four years ago, they went out gambling at Harrah's in New Orleans. The couple plunked $20 on the roulette table and rather miraculously won $700.

title: Tennis Adds to Summer Series Leading Up to the U.S. Open
description: The United States Tennis Association has created a combined men's and women's tournament leading into the United States Open to bolster the summer series it began last year as a warm-up to the Open.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Candidate To Lead Parade
description: Having tossed his signature black cowboy hat in the ring for the 2006 race for governor, Kinky Friedman, Texas' most famous Jewish country singer, mystery writer and gadfly, chose Houston as his first campaign stop. He will be grand marshal of the Art Car Parade on Saturday, an annual folk art regatta of fantastically decorated creations on wheels. Mr. Friedman, who needs to collect enough signatures as an independent to challenge the Republican incumbent, Rick Perry, picked the state's largest city for his kickoff tour in part because, his campaign said, "He just likes the darn cars." Ralph Blumenthal (NYT)

title: WENDY'S TO GIVE AWAY MILKSHAKES IN WEEKEND PROMOTION
description: Wendy's, the fast-food chain, said yesterday that it planned to give away Junior Frosty milkshakes at stores nationwide this weekend. The company has said its sales have been hurt by the publicity surrounding the claims of a woman that she found a severed finger in March in a bowl of chili at a Wendy's in San Jose, Calif. The police later deemed the accusation a hoax, and the woman, Anna Ayala, 39, faces charges of attempted larceny. Wendy's said yesterday that it expected to give away 14 million milkshakes during the three-day promotion, from Friday through Sunday. Wendy's is advertising the giveaway in a national print and television campaign. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Snyder, Admitted Underdog, Opens Campaign Against Morgenthau
description: Leslie Crocker Snyder, a former judge who has never run for public office, officially announced her candidacy for Manhattan district attorney yesterday before a roomful of enthusiastic supporters and donors.

title: ARVINMERITOR DOWNGRADED BY S.&P. AS G.M. SCALES BACK
description: The credit rating of ArvinMeritor was downgraded by Standard & Poor's yesterday because of operating inefficiencies and reduced demand for auto parts from companies like General Motors. S.&P. said that it had lowered ArvinMeritor's rating from BB+ to BB, or two levels below junk status. The downgrading affects about $1.5 billion in debt for the company, the world's largest maker of vehicle exhaust systems. G.M., ArvinMeritor's second-largest customer, plans to cut North American vehicle production by more than 10 percent in the first half of this year from a year earlier.

description: WHITE PLAINS, May 10 - It might have been an innocent request for directions. But against a backdrop of heightened anxiety in Westchester County over the safety of children, the encounter set in motion a panicked plea for help from a 10-year-old girl, a chase by a nearby phone technician, a burst of news media attention and extra police presence.

description: RAMKHALAWAN -- Seeper sad. The entire Abraham Joshua Heschel School community mourns the loss of our devoted and respected employee Seepersad Ramkhalawan, his wife Maldaye and his daughter Sarah in a tragic fire. "Ram" has been part of our building staff since 2002. Our heartfelt sympathies go to his extended family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President Roanna Shorofsky, Head of School

title: Suozzi Calls for 'Common Ground' on Cutting Pregnancies

Jersey City Mayor Wins; Hoboken Heads for Runoff
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., May 10 - The mayor of Jersey City cruised to re-election on Tuesday night, though his ally and fellow incumbent in Hoboken failed to get enough votes to avoid a runoff.

title: L.I. Students Arrested Over Gun Threat
description: A 17-year-old boy threatened to shoot a Long Island high school student yesterday, then, carrying a loaded semi-automatic rifle, followed the school bus carrying the student to a track meet, the authorities said.

title: Arts, Briefly; Just for Fun
description: Steve Martin was named yesterday to receive this year's Kennedy Center Mark Twain Prize for American Humor. Mr. Martin, left, walked away from a successful career as a comic in the late 1970's to broaden his repertory. Since then, he has written plays and films and starred in offbeat movies like "Pennies From Heaven," "Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid" and "The Man with Two Brains," as well as box-office successes like "Parenthood" and "Father of the Bride" (and its sequel). Mr. Martin, 59, has also published two novellas and a collection of comic pieces. The center said that Mr. Martin, learning that he had won the prize, which will be awarded on Oct. 23, responded, "I think Mark Twain is a great guy, and I can't wait to meet him." JOHN FILES

title: Revlon Awards Almay To Arnell Agency
description: Revlon Inc. in New York has expanded its agency roster by naming the Arnell Group in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle the creative and media planning duties for its Almay brand of cosmetics. Spending was estimated at $40 million.

title: Endorsements Announced by Mayoral Candidates
description: New York City's mayoral candidates announced several endorsements yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: West Islip: Girl Hit By Car Dies
description: An 8-year-old Lindenhurst girl who was critically injured by a pizza delivery car on Sunday while bicycle riding died of her injuries yesterday, the Suffolk County police said. On Sunday the girl, Frances Jedlicka, and Valerie McCarthy, 14, riding the same bicycle in West Islip, rode into the intersection of Hunter Avenue and Toomey Road and were struck by the car, driven by Stephen F. Carrasso, 20. Francis was taken to Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center. Valerie was airlifted to Stony Brook University Hospital and was reported in stable condition that night. Mr. Carrasso was driving with a suspended license, the police said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Some straight science for the feds
VISTEON FINDS ACCOUNTING ERRORS AND DELAYS FILING
description: The Visteon Corporation, an auto parts maker, said yesterday that it would delay its regulatory filing for the first quarter because of accounting errors. The company also said it lacked the cash to cover some expenses and would have to borrow money this year. Visteon, of Van Buren, Mich., said its audit committee had delayed the filing after management found errors in costs associated with about $31 million in freight and material surcharges before the end of 2004. Visteon said it could not determine if these errors or other adjustments would require the restatement of financial results.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Woman Sentenced In Hammer Attack
description: A Queens woman was sentenced yesterday to seven years in prison for a hammer assault that left her husband brain damaged and partly paralyzed. District Attorney Richard A. Brown said the sentence was warranted by "the terrible physical damage the defendant inflicted by her violent and brutal conduct." Gina Guillen, 26, a nightclub waitress from Elmhurst, was convicted last month of assault for repeatedly striking her husband, Felipe Herrera, 35, on the head with the hammer in April 2003. Mr. Herrera suffered a fractured skull and spent several days in a coma, prosecutors said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Hurt In Uptown Slashings
description: A man and a woman were injured in separate attacks yesterday in the Upper Manhattan neighborhood of Fort George by a young man who slashed them with a blade and fled, the police said. Neither victim was robbed, and both were reported in stable condition. The first attack occurred about 2:30 a.m. as the woman, 25, was walking home on West 189th Street. The attacker, described as being about 17, cut her ear, the police said. About eight minutes later, a 47-year-old man was attacked in a similar manner, at 190th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Bush, in Georgia, aims talk at Putin
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Camera Maker To Cut Jobs
description: The Olympus Corporation, a leading seller of digital cameras, plans to cut 30 percent of the work force this year at its camera unit, with most of the cuts in China, as it tries to return to a profit. Olympus expects to cut costs by 13 billion yen ($123 million) in the year ending March 2006. That figure includes 3 billion yen that the company will save by cutting 4,000 jobs, the company's president, Tsuyoshi Kikukawa, left, said at a news conference. Olympus was overtaken last year by the Eastman Kodak Company as the third-biggest seller of digital cameras in a market led by Canon Inc. and the Sony Corporation, according to researcher IDC.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: United Airlines Is Allowed To Terminate Pension Plans United Airlines received court permission to terminate its four employee pension plans, bringing about the largest pension default in the three decades that the government has guaranteed pensions.

title: United Air Wins Right to Default on Its Employee Pension Plans
description: United Airlines, which is operating in bankruptcy protection, received court permission yesterday to terminate its four employee pension plans, setting off the largest pension default in the three decades that the government has guaranteed pensions.

description: Correction Appended

title: Congress Rekindles Battle on Mandatory Sentences
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 - Just months after the Supreme Court struck down federal sentencing formulas, the House is moving to institute new mandatory minimum sentences, beginning with a sweeping bill to fight street gangs.

description: In what could prove to be one of the first major drugs to emerge from the human genome project, a chemical that singles out a specific gene thought to increase the risk of heart attacks has shown promising results in a preliminary test.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARSHALL, NINA B.
description: MARSHALL--Nina B. The painter and printmaker, Nina B. Marshall, died on May 9, 2005, of cancer. Born in Brooklyn in 1953, she grew up in Jersey City. After teaching art in high school in Irvington, New Jersey, she took a MFA at Texas Tech University. She taught painting at Southern Utah State College, and then at Ball State University, in Indiana, from 1985 until shortly before her death. She received artist fellowships, awards, and prizes from the Indiana Arts Commission, Mary Anderson Center, BSU, and the sponsors of numerous competitions and exhibitions. Her work was presented in journals and books including New American Paintings and The Art of Encaustic Painting. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Thomas Koontz; her mother, Dr. Ethel Lawner; her sister, Dr. Sydne Marshall Chazanow; nieces and nephews, and stepdaughters and grandchildren. She was preceded in death by her father, Dr. Irving Marshall and her sister, Madeline.

title: The Tipping Point
description: LONDON - JOHN BOLTON, President Bush's nominee to be ambassador to the United Nations, has been described as dogmatic, abusive to his subordinates and a bully. Yet Mr. Bush has said that John Bolton is the right man at the right time. Can these seemingly contradictory statements both be accurate? Yes. The reality is that sometimes the characteristics that make someone successful in business or government can render them unpleasant personally. What's more astonishing is that those characteristics when exaggerated are the same ones often found in criminals.

title: Meanwhile: Will you still need me?
Chief Auditor Quits at Ace
description: Ace Ltd., one of more than a dozen insurers that have received subpoenas from regulators investigating reinsurance accounting, said yesterday that its chief auditor, Jeanette Hughes, had left the company.

title: Arts, Briefly; The Stones Prepare to Roll Again
description: With characteristically ragged pomp and at least one sparkly costume change, the Rolling Stones announced a yearlong world tour yesterday at a news conference in front of the Juilliard School at Lincoln Center, below. Appearing on a stage built on the balcony walk above 65th Street, with banners of the band's lips-and-tongue emblem flying beside the school's name, the Stones played three numbers: "Start Me Up," "Brown Sugar" and "Oh No, Not You Again," a song the band said would be on a new album that is "85 percent done," Sir Mick Jagger said. Representatives said it was the first time the group had performed at a press event since 1975, when the band sang atop a flatbed truck rolling down Fifth Avenue. The tour, to begin Aug. 21 at Fenway Park in Boston, will go to stadiums and arenas in 35 cities in North America through Dec. 1, including a stop at Giants Stadium on Sept. 15. The band will continue the tour in January 2006, the tour manager said, going to South America, Japan and possibly China (where plans to play in 2003 fell apart) and then to Europe, through summer 2006. Asked if the tour would be the group's last, Sir Mick scoffed and said: "We don't think about it. We take each tour as it comes." The Stones' last tour, in 2002-3, grossed almost $300 million. BEN SISARIO

description: TORONTO, May 10 - Parliament narrowly voted Tuesday to force Prime Minister Paul Martin to resign but the governing Liberals said they would not accept the no-confidence vote as binding.

title: Perspectives From Pianist With Interest in Eclectic
description: In a program note for the Andsnes Project, Leif Ove Andsnes wrote that he wanted his contribution to the Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall to be eclectic. That makes sense, although it's hardly a novel approach: nearly all the musicians who have taken part in the series have explored interests well beyond their usual concert routines. So far, the high water mark for eclecticism was a 2001 Perspectives concert programmed by Maurizio Pollini that included ancient Greek chant, Monteverdi madrigals and avant-garde works by Luciano Berio.

title: U.S. presses raids near Syria border
Clinton Link to Fund-Raiser Adds Spice to Mundane Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10 - As the criminal trial of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's former chief fund-raiser began here Tuesday in Federal District Court, about 60 potential jurors were asked whether they have "such strong feelings one way or another" about the senator that it would be difficult for them "to impartially consider this case? (If so, please explain.)"

description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, owner of the A.&P. supermarket chain, said yesterday that it might sell its Canadian unit.

description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., May 10 - Reggie Miller does not have to be reminded that imitation is the sincerest form of flattery.

title: Pentagon Is Asking Congress to Loosen Environmental Laws
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 - After three unsuccessful tries, the Pentagon is asking Congress again this year to loosen major environmental laws to allow military training exercises around the country to proceed unimpeded.

description: Gentlemen may prefer blondes, but a brunette was worth twice as much last night at Sotheby's sale of contemporary art. Andy Warhol's famous image of Elizabeth Taylor and a Roy Lichtenstein painting of a sexy blond nude -- both classic Pop Art images -- became the stars of an otherwise lackluster sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTWEIN, DONALD
description: ROTWEIN--Donald. The Officers, Trustees and Members of the Hollywood Golf Club note with sorrow the passing of their longtime friend and member, Donald Rotwein. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family. Jeffrey J. Siegel, Pres. Solomon S. Greenspan, Secy.

VERTEX SHARES GAIN ON TRIAL SUCCESS FOR HEPATITIS DRUG
description: Vertex Pharmaceuticals, a developer of medicine for cancer and viral disorders, said its oral drug for the liver disease hepatitis C had reduced virus activity in an early clinical trial. The shares gained 20 percent. Geoffrey Purges, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said the study produced "remarkably positive data and exceeded our expectations and is likely to set a new standard for the treatment of hepatitis C," should the drug succeed in further testing. In the two-week study, the amount of hepatitis C virus in the blood of 28 patients given the drug VX-950 decreased by a factor of 10,000, the company said. The drug is in the first of three stages of human testing generally required for federal approval.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Huntington: Boy, 13, Is Shot To Death
description: A 13-year-old boy died last night after being shot in a house here, the Suffolk County police said. The shooting, at 53 Sherwood Drive, was reported in a 911 call at 7:52 p.m.. The police said that the caller referred to the shooting as accidental. Detective Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick of the Suffolk County police said that the boy and a friend, also 13, had been alone in the house with a loaded rifle. The boy was struck with a single bullet and was pronounced dead in the house, the police said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Nepalese troops kill rebels
Democrats Reject a Compromise on Judicial Nominees
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 - Senator Bill Frist, the majority leader, said Tuesday that a confrontation over judicial nominations could reach a climax next week, while his Democratic counterpart dismissed a Republican offer of compromise and made clear that his party was ready for the fight.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Peacock Alley, the restaurant in the Waldorf-Astoria that closed in late September 2001, is to reopen Nov. 1. Renovations are under way, though a chef has not been named, said Eric Long, the hotel's general manager. Laurent Gras, the chef who earned Peacock Alley three stars in The New York Times in 1998, is back in New York after cooking in San Francisco, and plans to open his own restaurant.

title: Art, Money and Power
description: We had "Sensation" at the Brooklyn Museum, a gift to Charles Saatchi, whose collection it advertised, and shows at the Whitney of artists (Robert Rauschenberg and Agnes Martin come to mind) virtually packaged by the gallery that represents them. The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has been renting its Monets to a casino in Las Vegas, while the Guggenheim, which gave us the atrocious "Armani," an even more egregious paid advertisement, is spending resources shopping itself around the globe while canceling shows here at home.

title: Whimsical Ways to Tempt the Finicky
description: Zoo Sticks and Fish Sticks, colorful plastic chopsticks joined at one end, bring some fun to children's dinnertime. These sturdy, dishwasher-safe implements come in eight animal or sea-creature shapes. title: United Nations Of Hot Dogs
description: Hot dogs that represent a tour of the United States and a bit of Europe are a suitable snack opposite the United Nations, at First Avenue and 47th Street. The Patio, a large kiosk with outdoor tables in Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, serves snappy foot-long hot dogs topped, Coney Island style, with chili, mustard and chopped onions; Chicago style with pickles, onions, tomato, mustard and celery salt; Pacific Coast style, with chili, cheese, onions and tomatoes; and German, with sauerkraut and spicy mustard, all $4.75. Sandwiches, coffee, beer, wine and cocktails complete the picture of this oasis owned by Mark Grossich, who also owns the World Bar in the Trump Tower nearby, and the Campbell Apartment in Grand Central Terminal.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Global Crossing Loss Narrows
description: Global Crossing, which runs a high-speed fiber optic network for sending telephone calls and data, said yesterday that its first-quarter loss narrowed as costs to connect calls declined. The company, which is based in Bermuda, said it lost $107 million in the quarter, compared with $109 million a year earlier. Sales fell 21 percent, to $526 million, while expenses to connect calls declined 33 percent, to $320 million. Global Crossing, after exiting bankruptcy in December 2003, has been shifting its focus in an effort to win more contracts to handle services, like managing networks, for big companies. Falling demand for long-distance calls cut sales at its wholesale voice unit by 38 percent, to $219 million, last quarter. Since shifting to the data services market, Global Crossing said its gross margin rose to 39 percent last quarter, from 28 percent a year earlier. "In a market where others are seeing declines, we have growth," the chief executive, John J. Legere, said in a conference call with analysts yesterday. Shares of Global Crossing rose 58 cents, or 5 percent, to $11.82.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Raymond' Is Pivotal
description: "Everybody Loves Raymond" helped CBS win Monday's Nielsen competition in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49: an estimated audience of 19.35 million watched the next-to-last original episode of the popular sitcom. (The final episode will be broadcast next week.) "CSI: Miami" on CBS was the night's most-watched show, with an audience of 19.71 million and a higher rating among viewers 18 to 49 than "Raymond" had. The NBC lineup -- "Fear Factor," 8.35 million; "Las Vegas," 10.88 million; and "Medium," 12.75 million -- was second to CBS for the night. At 10 p.m., opposite both "CSI: Miami" and "Medium," ABC broadcast "Extreme Makeover: Wedding Edition," yet another variation on the popular home redecorating show. It fared poorly, bringing in only 5.58 million viewers. ABC placed fourth in this sweeps night, behind Fox in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. KATE AURTHUR

title: National Briefing | West: California: Shooting By Deputies To Be Investigated
description: The Los Angeles County sheriff promised a full investigation into why 10 deputies fired 120 shots into a vehicle, wounding the unarmed driver after he led them on a chase. The shooting Monday night in Compton injured the suspect, Winston Hayes, 44, and a deputy, Edward Clark, who has been on the force for six years. A number of bullets struck nearby homes. The sheriff, Lee Baca, said that for the next five days, the deputies involved would be temporarily reassigned and face psychological counseling and interviews from investigators and six independent civil rights lawyers in the Sheriff's Independent Review office. "We also plan to go into the community and explain everything we know as to what occurred and offer to assist residents," Sheriff Baca said. Chris Dixon (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Satellite Bidders Consider Joint Offer
description: The two groups bidding for the contract to run Europe's Galileo satellite navigation program are considering joining forces, a European Commission spokesman said. The spokesman, Stefan de Rynck, said that to be accepted a combined bid would have to be better than either of the individual bids. The commission and the European Space Agency set up an agency to select a contractor for the 2.1 billion euro ($2.7 billion) project two years ago, but so far it has failed to choose a winner. The project is intended to have 30 satellites in orbit by 2008 to compete with the global positioning system operated by the United States. The competing groups are led by Alcatel, the French telecommunications company, and by the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the aircraft manufacturer. Paul Meller (NYT)

At the Steve Madden store in SoHo last Thursday the crowd skewed young, and the shoes skewed open-toed, as customers tried on sparkly espadrilles, rainbow wedges and shiny silver flip-flops. Mr. Madden was not on hand; presumably he was in the Bronx halfway house where he is spending 60 days after serving 30 months in a federal prison for securities fraud. But before reaching the top, she began choking on a ball of peppermint candy her sister had given her, and was dead a few minutes later, relatives said yesterday.

title: COURT ALLOWS FOOTSTAR TO CONTINUE SALES IN KMART
description: Footstar, which is operating under bankruptcy protection, may continue to sell its shoes in Kmart stores, the source of 95 percent of its revenue, a judge ruled. Sears Holdings, which owns Kmart, had asked a judge to release it from a contract allowing Footstar to sell shoes in outlets in Kmart stores, saying that Footstar violated agreements. Judge Adlai Hardin of United States Bankruptcy Court denied the request, ruling that ending the contract would frustrate Footstar's attempt to exit bankruptcy protection. Footstar has made the contract the centerpiece of a plan to repay creditors. Judge Hardin has not ruled on a request by Sears to remove Footstar's products from Kmart stores that Sears is renaming.

title: Mirrors, Prisms and Light Turn a House Into 3-D Art
description: In Pasadena, Calif., the artist Olafur Eliasson has transformed a private neomodernist house, designed by the Los Angeles firm Escher GuneWardena, into a public art project. Titled "Meant to Be Lived In," the installation uses projectors, prisms, mirrors and other devices, including a hanging lamp of woven wood wrapped in light-filtering glass (below), to cast otherworldly patterns in each room. "A house can be an extroverted thing that you look out of," said Mr. Eliasson, an Icelandic Dane who lives in Berlin and worked on the project with Emi Fontana, a gallerist who represents him in Milan. "But here I tried to make a house in which you could look into yourself." The house, at 1472 Inverness Drive, is open Thursdays through Saturdays through May 29; information: (310)666-0767. Hundreds of historians and archaeologists, and the government's cultural advisers, have campaigned against the roadway's path, and its planners would have been forced to explore an alternative route if Mr. Roche had withheld the licenses. title: CAESARS WILL SELL RENO HILTON FOR $150 MILLION
description: Caesars Entertainment agreed to sell the Reno Hilton to the Grand Sierra Resort Corporation for $150 million. The Reno Hilton in Nevada has almost 2,000 hotel rooms, 10 restaurants and a 107,000-square-foot casino. Caesars, based in Las Vegas, has been selling resorts ahead of its acquisition by Harrah's Entertainment in a $5.18 billion deal that will create the world's largest casino company. Caesars and Harrah's sold four casinos to Colony Capital for $1.24 billion last month, and Caesars has said it may sell a casino at Lake Tahoe in Nevada. Grand Sierra, a closely held company based in Nevada, said it would add an indoor water park to the Reno resort.

title: DELCATH GETS SPECIAL STATUS FOR CHEMOTHERAPY SYSTEM
description: Delcath Systems received fast-track status from the Food and Drug Administration for a system to deliver chemotherapy to specific organs and regions of the body. The F.D.A. accepted the faster review because the system has the potential to treat an illness that lacks adequate therapy. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., said the designation covers delivery of melphan to treat metastatic melanoma in the liver. The F.D.A. based its decision on results presented by researchers from the National Cancer Institute of a trial that Delcath sponsored. The trial was not aimed at proving effectiveness and had too few subjects to make a statistical claim, but tumors did shrink in some patients who used the system, the company said.

Ms. Boone, of course, is no teenager. Twenty-five years and four children ago she married Gabriel Ferrer, the middle of Ms. Clooney's three sons. The short distance of the island, Italy's southernmost territory, to the coasts of Libya and Tunisia and the relatively calm waters of the spring and summer months lead thousands of illegal migrants to crowd onto rickety boats and risk the journey every year. Technology Briefing | Internet: Amazon.com To Cut Number Of Merchants
description: Amazon.com, the largest Internet retailer, is cutting the number of merchants that offer digital cameras, televisions and computers for sale on its site, saying it wants to give buyers a more trusted shopping environment. Only merchants preapproved for certain top-selling electronics, software and computers will be allowed to list the products on its site, Amazon.com said in a Web posting to sellers. The company is now notifying vendors whether they will be allowed to list, said Patty Smith, a spokeswoman. Amazon.com, based in Seattle, has fostered a reputation for above-average customer service since starting sales in July 1995. The company's satisfaction rating slipped to 84 from 88 in the American Customer Satisfaction Index report in February. The change in Amazon.com's policy was first reported yesterday by AuctionBytes, an online newsletter.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Chicago Regulates Cellphone Use
description: Chicago City Council approved an ordinance making it illegal to use a hand-held cellphone while driving. Starting in July, drivers could be fined $50 or up to $200 for a violation tied to a car accident. The law does not apply to drivers who are using a hands-free phone or are calling emergency numbers. New York, New Jersey and Washington, D.C., have similar bans. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

All our sympathy and love to your husband, Steve and all your children and grandchildren. Your loving friends, Ildiko Butler, Francoise Edwards, Jane Maynard, Edwina Sandys.

title: The Pirate Kingdom
description: Washington - CHINA is the global epicenter of pirating and counterfeiting. By its government's own estimate, China's domestic trade in bogus goods accounts for $19 billion to $24 billion annually. That is undoubtedly a significant understatement, and it doesn't even include the stolen technologies and phony brands China exports to the rest of the world. Since welcoming China into the World Trade Organization in 2001, the United States has had a historic opportunity to stop the Chinese piracy trade. So far, the Bush administration has failed to seize it.

title: Off-Course Plane Prompts Brief Evacuation in the Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 - A single-engine plane bearing down on Washington without clearance prompted a frantic evacuation of the Capitol, the Supreme Court and the White House on Wednesday. President Bush was not told of the threat until he finished a bicycle ride at a Maryland wildlife center, nearly 40 minutes after the plane had been forced to turn away, administration officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer Posts Profit
description: Aegon NV, the Dutch insurer, said first-quarter profit rose 5 percent as gains on investments made up for a decline in insurance earnings. Net income rose to 666 million euros ($857 million), or 42 cents a share, from 633 million euros, or 41 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Profit from traditional life insurance fell 4 percent to 121 million euros. Earnings from fixed annuities fell 50 percent and profit from variable annuities dropped 26 percent. Quarterly profit from accident and health insurance rose 6 percent to 87 million euros. Aegon's gain on investments, which include equities, bonds and real estate, rose 57 percent to 302 million euros

description: For an orchestra like Orpheus, playing without a conductor is a test, almost an athletic event. The point of the game is to get the better of true ensemble playing with one useful arm tied behind one's back. European music is nonmetronomic ebb and flow: conductors exercise unilateral executive decisions in the name of unity, whether every orchestra member believes in them or not. The contest for Orpheus is how well 37 musicians will make identical adjustments and still play musically.

title: THOMAS H. LEE PARTNERS TO SELL ITS STAKE IN AXIS CAPITAL
description: The buyout firm Thomas H. Lee Partners will sell its stake in the insurer Axis Capital Holdings for about $302 million. Morgan Stanley will buy about 11.6 million Axis shares from Thomas H. Lee for $26.05 a share, Axis said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Morgan Stanley will resell the shares to investors, Axis said. Thomas H. Lee, which has been an investor in Axis since the insurer was founded in 2001, is selling its entire stake, Axis said. Thomas H. Lee, based in Boston, declined to comment further.

description: Louis Graham, the DeKalb County police chief, announced the formation of a five-member cold-case squad whose first task will be to reinvestigate five of the Atlanta child killings that terrified the city from 1979 to 1981. Investigators said they would also look into the disappearance of a sixth victim who was found in Fulton County. Chief Graham reopened the case to try to determine whether Wayne Williams, a 23-year-old music promoter who was sentenced to life for two of the killings, was responsible for at least 22 others. Most of the victims were African-American boys. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: When Time Softens Fury of a Piano Man Scorned
description: Kindliness can creep up on a guy. A decade ago, Ben Folds was a piano-man and songwriter who sang about being snubbed in high school, dumped by girlfriends or kicked out of his own band. He was the nerd who had made it through but hadn't forgotten a single slight, and he pounded his frustrations into songs full of big splashy chords and rippling arpeggios, with the bass and drums of the Ben Folds Five socking along with every left-hand chord.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Ithaca: Body Found Near Cornell
description: A man's body was found in a creek near the Cornell University campus on Tuesday, 17 days after a student was reported missing. Daniel A. Pirfo, 19, a freshman from Washington, D.C., was reported missing on April 25, when the local and campus police began a five-day search of the campus and nearby areas. Ten days after the search ended, three fishermen found the body downstream from a gorge on campus. A medical examiner in Albany is expected to release the identity of the body today, said Simeon Moss, director of the Cornell University press office. Katherine Boas (NYT)

title: That's Our Will. Always an Eye for the Girls.
description: WILL ROGERS, the Oklahoman humorist, spent a fair amount of time in New York City, since he was a vaudeville star in the Ziegfeld Follies before he turned to motion pictures. From 1922 until his death in 1935, he occasionally wrote for The New York Times on politics, world events and life's little absurdities. But it was hard for him to ignore the stage full of chorus girls who flashed skin around him each night. Here, in honor of the Tony Award nominations, are some of his views on his co-stars from his Times writings.

title: Geneticists Link Modern Humans to Single Band Out of Africa
description: A team of geneticists believe they have shed light on many aspects of how modern humans emigrated from Africa by analyzing the DNA of the Orang Asli, the original inhabitants of Malaysia. Because the Orang Asli appear to be directly descended from the first emigrants from Africa, they have provided valuable new clues about that momentous event in early human history.

title: Terror Suspects Sent to Egypt by the Dozens, Panel Reports
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 - The United States and other countries have forcibly sent dozens of terror suspects to Egypt, according to a report released Wednesday by Human Rights Watch. The rights group and the State Department have both said Egypt regularly uses extreme interrogation methods on detainees.

title: National Briefing | Science and Health: Bechtel To Bid On Los Alamos Contract
description: The Bechtel Group Inc., the world's largest construction and engineering company, said it would join the University of California to bid on a federal contract to manage Los Alamos National Laboratory, which has been plagued in recent years by reports of security lapses. Since its creation in 1943, Los Alamos has been managed by the university. Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman, two of the largest military contractors, had already said they would submit bids to manage the laboratory, the birthplace of the atomic bomb.

title: Democrats Seek to Rally Forces for Showdown Over Judicial Nominees
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 - Digging in for a showdown over judicial confirmations, Democrats are trying to rally party loyalists with an online advertising campaign and planning a rally on Thursday with sympathetic Princeton students.

title: Study Leaves Athletes With Bottles Half-Full
description: KAREN McGLADE, a 37-year-old schoolteacher from Kent, N.Y., says she has always tried to drink enough water to stay ahead of feeling thirsty when she exercises. But after a study published in The New England Journal of Medicine last month found that drinking too much water can be dangerous, even deadly, Ms. McGlade now wonders if she's on the right course. "I went for an hourlong run the other day, and as soon as I got back to my car, I started guzzling water," she said. "Then I started to think, should I be drinking so much?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELLINWOOD, GEORGE WEBSTER, JR.
description: ELLINWOOD--George Webster, Jr. an international private banker, died peacefully on May 10, 2005 at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, FL., following a long illness. He was 71. The son of George W. Ellinwood and Doris (Green) Ellinwood, he was born in Providence, R.I. He graduated from Providence Country Day School and Colby College. Prior to his retirement in 1992, Mr. Ellinwood had been a Vice President of Citibank, where he worked for 36 years. At the time of his promotion to Vice President in 1968, he was the youngest employee ever appointed to this rank at Citibank. He headed Citibank's trust activities in the Bahamas and the Cayman Islands in the 1970s. He served the bank's clients most capably with professionalism and a personal touch remembered by many. For many years, Mr. Ellinwood lived in West Palm Beach, FL., New York and Lakeville, CT. Mr. Ellinwood leaves his dear companion, Hugh L. Harrison, three sons, Peter of Concord, N.H., Craig of Westport, CT., and David of Shrewsbury, MA., and a sister, Grace E. Wilson, of Bristol, R.I. He had seven grandsons, Gordon, Pierce, Sam, Wyatt, Tate, Jack and Hayden, a granddaughter, Lydia, and a step granddaughter, Natalie, whom he adored and visited with frequently. Besides his cherished family, he occupied his time with a variety of interests including serving on the Board of Directors of the Humane Society of New York, world travel and spending time on the water. A memorial service is scheduled for Saturday, May 21st at 10AM in the Chapel at Swan Point Cemetery in Providence, R.I. Mr. Ellinwood was a member of Bethesda-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Palm Beach, where a second service will be held in his memory next winter. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to the Humane Society of New York, 306 E. 59 St., New York, N.Y. 10022.

title: 79 Die in Attacks as Rebels in Iraq Intensify Fight
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 11 - Insurgents struck in northern and central Iraq on Wednesday in a series of bloody attacks that killed at least 79 people in three cities, and wounded at least 120 others, according to figures provided by the police and hospital officials. The attacks were a further intensification of a two-week-old onslaught by Sunni Arab insurgents who appear intent on destabilizing Iraq's newly formed Shiite-majority government.

title: Amtrak Official Outlines Roots of Acela Problems
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 - The Acela Express trains were far closer to a serious accident than Amtrak officials believed, with many more cracks in their brake spokes, when all 20 of the trains were abruptly taken out of service on April 15, an Amtrak official testified on Wednesday before a House subcommittee.

title: 2 Families, 2 Very Different Cultures and the Little Girl Between Them
description: LEBANON, Tenn., May 10 - For 11-year-old Linda Berrera Cano, life changed with the stroke of a judge's pen. Lifted out of a crowded trailer where meals might consist of nothing but tortillas, she now lives in a brick ranch house with a basketball hoop in the driveway, a swimming pool in the backyard, and her own twin bed and wooden vanity.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Increases Its Reported Profit
description: The Intel Corporation increased its reported first-quarter profit by $24 million yesterday, saying its tax bill was smaller than expected. Net income for the period was $2.18 billion, or 35 cents a share, compared with $2.15 billion, or 34 cents, originally reported April 19, Intel said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Intel added back to profit $24 million set aside to pay taxes after an adjustment reduced its tax rate to 30.9 percent from 32 percent a year ago. Intel, whose chips run more than 80 percent of the world's personal computers, reorganized in January into five business units from two. That was part of a plan by Paul S. Otellini, who will take over as chief executive later this month, to find new markets. A new mobility group, which includes the Centrino laptop product, had operating income of $1.1 billion in the first quarter, compared with $405 million a year earlier, Intel said. Shares of Intel rose 10 cents, to $24.77.

title: Hussein Gave Oil to French and British Officials, Senate Panel Says

Cappellini's latest collection, New Antique, by the Dutch designer Marcel Wanders, is a takeoff on period furniture. The loveseat, top, is $1,900; tables with round glass tops, above, start at $2,300. The store interior is bright red, which Giulio Cappellini, the company's art director, said will enhance the furniture's often riotous colors.
