Spas and the Man: Mars Goes to Venus
description: TECATE, Mexico - ROBERT LUKE is not one to look a gift horse in the mouth. So when his in-laws organized a family trip to a spa here, he didn't let on that a week of organic vegetables, Feldenkrais and loofah salt scrubs was hardly a dream vacation for a hard-driving trial lawyer with a hearty appetite, a love of competitive sports and a belief that being pampered is a waste of time.

title: A Celebration of Romantic and Comedic Joy
description: "Harlequinade" has a new Harlequin. Joaquin De Luz has taken over the lead male role in Balanchine's sweetly silly romantic fantasy. And on Sunday afternoon he gave an ingratiating performance in the New York City Ballet's production at the New York State Theater.

title: Rounding a Square's Edges
description: Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village has its own special character, its own special characters. There are always musicians trying out riffs -- the heirs of Bob Dylan and Pete Seeger, who once played nearby. Masters at superspeed chess glower at anyone whose mind moves at a mere mortal's pace. The police have cleared up the drug markets, although there is occasionally still somebody whispering offers of "weed" or worse. Now the city has devised a plan to tidy up Washington Square, to update its 60's seediness the way an old-school barber would whack off an adult's graying ponytail.

title: Cub Conquers the Wind and the Mets
description: CHICAGO, May 11 - The chilling wind howled into Wrigley Field all afternoon, making every pop-up an adventure and preventing any well-hit fly ball from reaching the bleachers. But in the 10th inning, when the fastball from Mets pitcher Heath Bell cut back over the plate and Derrek Lee drove it toward left-center field, Bell understood instantly that the wind could not help him.

title: United's Pension Debacle
description: On Tuesday, when it received a federal bankruptcy court's permission to terminate its pension plans, United Airlines became the biggest pension defaulter in the history of corporate America. Analysts fear that Delta may also default, as well as other ailing airlines, followed by auto parts companies and perhaps even, in five years or so, the carmakers themselves.

title: Berra, 80, Transcends the Test of Time
description: Little Falls, N.J. - ON the stucco building at the far end of the Montclair State campus, Yogi Berra's large signature precedes the words "Museum and Learning Center." Seldom have any words fit anyone's name so well. As a folk hero and philosopher, Yogi Berra is a living, walking museum. And whenever you're around him, you learn something, either about him or about the world. Such as his reaction to turning 80 today.

title: The Stakes in the Vote on Bolton
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwan visitor stresses cooperation
Funds in Brief: Asia is next destination for global hedge funds
Anarchists in Athens set hostages free
Atom Agency May Be Asked to Meet if Iran Resumes Uranium Work
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 - Leading European nations may call an emergency meeting of the International Atomic Energy Agency next week to act against Iran if it resumes some nuclear activities it has suspended, European diplomats said Wednesday.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Sondheim Sings Sondheim

title: HILLENBRAND SAYS ITS CHIEF EXECUTIVE HAS RETIRED
description: Hillenbrand Industries, a maker of products including coffins and hospital beds, said its chief executive, Frederick W. Rockwood, retired two days after the company reduced a profit forecast. Mr. Rockwood, 57, was the first chief executive who was not a member of the Hillenbrand family. He had been an employee for 28 years, the company said. The vice chairman, Rolf A. Classon, was named interim chief executive while the company seeks a successor, a spokeswoman, Wendy Wilson, said. Mr. Rockwood's departure was not related to the reduced forecast, Ms. Wilson said. On May 9, Hillenbrand lowered its forecast for 2005, citing increased costs of wood and steel.

title: As the cookie crumbles, winners galore in lottery
Bluetooth, Uniting Computer and Printer
description: A Bluetooth Path To the Printer

title: Checking Out That Man With a Van
description: MAN with a van -- or man with a scam? Sometimes it's hard to tell.

title: Briefly: UN pulls camp workers after 5 are wounded
Retail Sales Surged in April
description: High gasoline prices failed to keep consumers away from restaurants and shopping malls last month, fueling the best advance in food and retail sales since September, the government said today.

title: Betty Talmadge, Ex-Wife of Georgia Senator, Dies at 81
description: Betty Talmadge, a former first lady of Georgia and a prominent Washington hostess who had a second career as a businesswoman, restaurateur and cookbook author after her divorce from Senator Herman E. Talmadge, died on Saturday in Atlanta. She was 81.

title: Judge Indicted on Charge of Taking Aunt's Money
description: A Brooklyn judge accused of siphoning money from his elderly aunt's assets has been indicted on charges of grand larceny and forgery, a law enforcement official said yesterday.

title: New Panel Will Study Medicaid With Eyes Toward Big Changes
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 - The Bush administration will create an advisory panel to recommend big changes in Medicaid eligibility and benefits and in the financing of the program, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Keeping Little Touches While Growing Big
description: Retailing start-ups like corner cafes and mom-and-pop bookstores can get a lot of mileage out of their antiestablishment aura. Customers love the idiosyncratic touches that set small shops apart from the chains, not to mention the allusions to third world cooperatives and the Amazon rain forest.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Seek Bank Robber
description: The police are requesting help in tracking down a man suspected in two bank robberies in Queens and two in Manhattan in the past year. The suspect, described as Hispanic, in his 30's, 5-foot-5 to 5-foot-7, 170 pounds, with salt-and-pepper hair, passed a note demanding money to a teller at the Chase Bank branch at 3515 Broadway on April 25, and got away with about $800. No one was injured. The police suspect that the same man robbed a Chase Bank branch on 86th Street last year and the same Marathon Bank branch, at 31-04 Broadway in Queens, in April and May. In all three earlier robberies, a note was passed and no one was injured, the police said.

title: Searching for profit in networking Web sites
Plan for Bergen Train Service Is Put Off
description: New Jersey Transit's plan to revive passenger train service on tracks in Bergen County that could eventually connect all the way to Manhattan ran into an unexpected delay yesterday.

title: A better memorial
Senate Panel Is Set to Vote onBolton Nomination Today
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 - With a vote scheduled Thursday on his contested nomination as ambassador to the United Nations, John R. Bolton has told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that a policy maker should maintain the right to "state his own reading of the intelligence" even when it differs from that of intelligence agencies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer Attacked By Dog
description: A police officer was attacked by a dog and bitten several times as he patrolled a Bushwick housing project last night, the police said. The attack occurred around 11 p.m. as the officer, who works in the Housing Bureau and whose name was not released, was walking in a stairwell with his partner at 140 Menahan Street near Central Avenue. They encountered the dog, which lunged at the officer. A police spokesman said the dog, which was unattended, appeared to be a pit bull mix. The officer drew his weapon and shot the dog several times, and it was finally subdued with a dart gun. The officer was taken to Wyckoff Heights Medical Center. The police said they did not know his condition. The dog, which was alive last night, was taken by the A.S.P.C.A., a police spokesman said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERMAN, STANLEY H.
description: SILVERMAN--Stanley H., 90, of Sarasota, formerly of Manhattan died May 9, 2005 peacefully in his home.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Lawmakers Back Putin Bill, On Second Try
description: The normally routine enactment of Kremlin legislation hit an unexpected bump. The upper house of Parliament, the Federation Council, failed -- for a while -- to approve President Vladimir V. Putin's proposal to end direct elections of parliamentary deputies from local districts. Under the proposal, they would instead be elected on party lists, a step that has been criticized as anti-democratic. But the council vote fell 5 short of the required majority of 91, stunning the council's pro-Putin leadership. Within two and half hours and after appeals from Mr. Putin's aides, though, a second vote was held, ostensibly on the procedural ground that not all deputies had been present the first time. And this time 96 voted in favor. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: 2 Top Lawyers for Hollywood Stars Join Forces
description: LOS ANGELES, May 11 - Two of the best-known litigators in Hollywood are joining forces, as Howard L. Weitzman -- whose clients have included Michael Jackson, O.J. Simpson, Madonna and Courtney Love -- is leaving the Proskauer Rose law firm in New York to join the Los Angeles firm of Bertram H. Fields.

title: Army to Spend Day Retraining Recruiters
description: Responding to reports about widespread abuses of the rules for recruitment, Army officials said yesterday that they would suspend all recruiting on May 20 and use the day to retrain its personnel in military ethics and the laws that govern what can and cannot be done to enlist an applicant.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Saturday about the Yankees' 6-3 loss to Oakland used an incorrect given name in some copies for the player for whom Jorge Posada pinch-hit. He is Tony Womack, not Bobby.

title: Species extinctions may not be forever
Warner Music Shares Fall After Public Offer
description: Shares of the Warner Music Group fell 3.5 percent yesterday after the company raised $554.2 million in an initial public offering on Tuesday.

title: Entr'acte: EU cultural elite learn to love the constitution
World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Profit Declines At Airline
description: Singapore Airlines posted its first profit decline in eight quarters as fuel prices surged and an increase in the number of low-fare competitors caused ticket prices to fall. Net income in the three months that ended March 31 fell 38 percent, to 297.8 million Singapore dollars ($181 million) from 477.9 million Singapore dollars a year earlier, the airline said.

title: The Stakes in the Vote on Bolton
description: To the Editor:

title: When Pavano Implodes, Yankees' Bats Explode
description: The giant line score that looms above the left-center-field bleachers is out of view from the home bullpen at Yankee Stadium. The relievers did not have to see it yesterday to feel the numbers changing.

title: Crazy 'Bout a Sharp-Dressed Man
description: SOME men are shoppers; others are not. Before I married, I dated a Shopper. His cufflinks matched his watch. Which matched his pen. Which matched his lighter. He had a cashmere sweater for every day of the month. The Shopper made me feel inadequate.

title: The Roads Are Paved With Pork
description: An immense pork-laden highway spending bill is trundling through Congress like some surreal demonstration vehicle for the nation's skewed values. The Senate is busy angling to balloon the plan beyond the $284 billion maximum approved by the House, prompting the Bush administration to threaten a veto and gruffly lecture lawmakers against resorting to "accounting gimmicks" that promise "to spend money that doesn't exist." But lawmakers, who have heard those veto threats before, are greedily ignoring lessons in fiscal prudence from a White House that rewrote the book on runaway tax cuts and deficit spending.

title: Operator of Sprint Canada Gets a Bid
description: OTTAWA, May 11 - Rogers Communications, Canada's biggest cable television company and a leading wireless provider, made a stock-swap bid Wednesday for Call-Net Enterprises, which operates under the Sprint Canada name, that values the company at 330 million Canadian dollars ($267 million).

title: MOLINA HEALTHCARE LOSES TWO CONTRACTS IN CALIFORNIA
description: Molina Healthcare, which arranges health care services for Medicaid recipients, said it lost contracts with two California counties worth a combined $111 million in annual revenue. The California Department of Health Services will give the contracts for Riverside and San Bernardino Counties to another health care manager, Molina said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Molina said it expected a start-up operation in Indiana, higher interest income and the acquisition of about 70,000 members in San Diego to make up for the lost revenue. Molina said it planned to appeal the decision. The contracts, which cover 96,492 members, expire March 31, 2006.

title: America's hired guns: A pot of gold or death
World Briefings
description: AMERICAS

title: Gaza pullout will permit better border, Israeli says
Garca May Have Crashed, but He's Not Burned Up
description: IRVING, Tex., May 11 - In the hours since Sergio Garca rinsed his golf ball in a Carolina lake, drowning the remnants of a robust six-shot lead, the stubble that dots his chin has thickened.

title: The Stakes in the Vote on Bolton
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about two books on John F. Kennedy's inaugural address misstated the position of one regarding the history of the line that begins "Ask not what your country can do for you." The book, "Sounding the Trumpet," by Richard J. Tofel, does not agree with previous assertions by scholars, including Thurston Clarke, the author of "Ask Not," that the phrase echoes one frequently used by a former headmaster at Choate, the prep school Kennedy attended. Seeking to refute that account, Mr. Tofel quotes the author of the school's official history as saying it is "wishful thinking at best."

title: Henry Hudson Parkway Is Buried After Hillside Gives Way
description: A sizable section of retaining wall collapsed onto the Henry Hudson Parkway in hilly northern Manhattan this afternoon, sending tons of dirt, rock and trees onto the roadway, snarling traffic for miles around and leading to the evacuation of nearby buildings.

title: Tech Brief: Real buys Finnish games firm
VISTEON PROPOSAL APPROVED OVER OPPOSITION OF BOARD
description: Visteon shareholders voted yesterday in favor of a nonbinding proposal that directors of the company, which makes auto parts, be elected annually, a measure opposed by the board. The vote was 85 percent for the proposal, the company said at its annual shareholders' meeting in Wilmington, Del. Also at the meeting, the board elected the chief executive, Michael Johnston, to succeed Peter Pestillo as chairman on June 1. The vote came a day after Visteon said it would delay filing a quarterly report because of accounting errors, prompting Moody's and Standard & Poor's to cut Visteon's debt ratings.

title: Few Republicans in House Are Expected at DeLay Event
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 - When 900 conservatives gather at a downtown Hilton hotel on Thursday night to pay tribute to Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority leader who is caught up in a swirl of accusations over his fund-raising and ties to lobbyists, only about three dozen House Republicans will be there.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Surgeons Protest On The English Seaside
description: About 350 French surgeons have gone off for a week to Camber Sands, a beach resort in southeast England, to demand higher operating fees and to protest rising insurance premiums in France. French health care has long been the envy of the British, who complain of long waits to see a doctor and of poor hospital conditions. But the French surgeons, who plan to continue the protest until tomorrow, say those who provide lesser medical services, like radiologists, are often better paid. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Old Atomic Reactor Is Kaputt
description: After nearly 37 years in operation, Germany's oldest atomic reactor was shut down. The reactor, in southwestern Obrigheim, is the second of 19 to be disconnected as a result of national legislation approved in 2000 to phase out nuclear energy. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: U.S. Tycoon Buys Big Chunk of Manchester United
description: LONDON, May 12 - Malcolm Glazer, owner of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers football team, is expected to gain control of the Manchester United soccer club after buying up a big chunk of the company's shares today.

title: Pacers Undermanned, but Not Outplayed
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., May 11 - After one quarter at the Palace of Auburn Hills on Wednesday night, the undermanned Indiana Pacers were staring at a 15-point deficit and appeared headed to going down by two games to none in their Eastern Conference semifinal series with the Detroit Pistons.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Race' vs. 'Idol'
description: Sometimes Internet leaks turn out to be right. In Tuesday's season finale, Uchenna and Joyce Agu, the rumored winners, came in first in "The Amazing Race." The formerly hard-luck couple -- he had worked at Enron, she at WorldCom -- beat the "Survivor" villains Rob Mariano and Amber Brkich, as well as another team, Ron Young and Kelly McCorkle, for the million-dollar prize. CBS reaped rewards, also. The show drew 16 million viewers, making it the most-watched episode of the seven-season series and helping to make the seventh edition of "The Amazing Race" its most popular. Was this big finish enough to come in first in Nielsen's estimates on Tuesday? On "American Idol" night it was good only for second place. Fox was No.1, as "Idol" attracted 23.98 million viewers, and "House" yielded its best ratings of the season. KATE AURTHUR

title: The Stakes in the Vote on Bolton
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BADER, NATHAN
description: BADER--Nathan. I miss you more and more each day. Good night sweet prince. All my love, Ann

title: Boston's Catholic Archdiocese May Cut Priests' Pensions
description: Seeking to save money, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston is proposing cuts in its pension benefits for priests.

title: A Backyard Fountain Like None Before
description: RICHMOND HILL, Ontario - The Euser family has something in their backyard, sitting on the patio out by the tarp-covered swimming pool, that a wounded city 350 miles away has been waiting a long time to see.

title: New York: 'Little' Films Grow Big
description: When the Cannes Film Festival opened yesterday, the first of what could be a long stream of distribution deals was announced: "Transamerica," a comedic road movie starring Felicity Huffman of "Desperate Housewives," will be coming to a screen near you soon. The film is a New York project from beginning to end, written, directed and partly shot in a city that has carved out its own place in the film industry -- a place that only occasionally intersects with what Hollywood likes to call "the movie business."

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Surges
description: Inflation in Brazil in April was at its fastest pace in nine months, pushed higher by an increase in pharmaceutical prices and a drought in the southern part of the country that drove up food costs. The government's statistics agency said its consumer price index, the central bank's main gauge in setting interest rates, rose 0.87 percent last month after climbing 0.61 percent in March. That lifted the accumulated inflation rate over the last 12 months to 8.07 percent, well ahead of the government's year-end inflation target of 5.1 percent. To curb the price increases, the central bank has raised its benchmark lending rate eight times since September, to 19.5 percent. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: News Analysis: Unemployment casts pall over Chirac's 10 years
On the Seine, Haut Baroque
description: PARIS - BACK in the 1930's and 40's, the French design world thrilled to artists who made modern objects that combined up-to-the-minute allure with the authenticity of traditional crafts: hand-wrought bronze, layers of painstakingly applied lacquer, meticulously matched and polished wood.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Vote On The Government Next Week
description: Prime Minister Paul Martin said that Parliament would hold a vote on his budget plan next Thursday and that he would regard it as a vote of confidence in his government. If the budget is defeated, he said he will dissolve Parliament, forcing a national election. Mr. Martin was forced to set a date for the much anticipated vote after the Conservative Party and the separatist Bloc Qubcois narrowly passed a motion on Tuesday calling on his minority Liberal government to resign. The Liberals discounted the vote as procedural, but after an emergency cabinet meeting, Mr. Martin conceded that the question of confidence "must be settled soon, clearly, and definitely." Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: An Easy-to-Use Graphics Program Made for Those Who Don't Always Get the Picture (or Can't Afford To)
description: Corefx Three Level is a simple, powerful graphics program for those who can't afford or can't master Photoshop. The drawing palette offers 12 types of art tools, in any color or tip size. You can scribble with waxy crayons -- the harder you press, the darker the line -- or let watercolors bleed into a silky parchment.

title: Briefly: United allowed to dump pensions
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Trade Deficit Declines To Lowest Level in 6 Months The United States trade deficit unexpectedly narrowed in March to its lowest point in six months, as consumers cut back on purchases of imports and as businesses and farmers increased their sales in foreign markets.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times column on Monday, about "Against Depression" by Peter D. Kramer, misstated Dr. Kramer's opinion of "Darkness Visible," a book about depression by William Styron. He said he admires it; he does not find anything about it outrageous.

title: Panel Declines to Recommend Bolton but Sends Vote to Senate
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 - John R. Bolton suffered a setback in his quest to become ambassador to the United Nations today when the Senate Foreign Relations Committee declined to recommend him even as it voted to send the nomination to the full Senate for consideration.

title: Court clears Pinault, but his firm is guilty
Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Beaten With Baseball Bats
description: Rafael Pica, 21, of the Bronx, was in critical condition yesterday after six or seven men beat him with baseball bats, the police said. The beating occurred shortly after 8 p.m. on Tuesday in front of 179 East 205th Street in the Norwood section. Mr. Pica was standing near a bodega when the men got out of a dark S.U.V. and kicked, punched and beat him with bats, fracturing his skull, before fleeing, the police said. The motive for the attack was unclear, but investigators said witnesses told them that Mr. Pica knew the men. Mr. Pica was in "extremely critical" condition at St. Barnabas Hospital, a hospital spokesman said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLICKMAN, JENNIE LEVIN
description: GLICKMAN--Jennie Levin. Died in New Rochelle, NY on April 19, 2005 at the age of 98. Jennie taught the piano for 78 years, before closing her studio in Brooklyn at 94 years of age. Jennie was married to Eli Glickman until his death in 1976. She is survived by her children, Ellen Highstein and Stephen Glickman; her grandchildren, Gustav and Nathaniel Highstein, and Matthew and Lauren Glickman; her great-grandchildren, Eli and Isaac Glickman; her sonin-law, Virgil Blackwell and daughter-in-law Krista Glickman; and her sisters, Alice Goldfeld and Pauline Ring. Jennie's optimistic and vibrant presence will be missed by all who came in contact with her.

title: Leaving Out What Will Be Skipped
description: DETROIT, May 9 - Elmore Leonard is about talked out. The stories about the craft of America's premier crime novelist have become clichs waiting their turn.

title: Is Woody Allen Back?
White House and Capitol evacuated in plane scare
Times Editor Is Named to Post at Herald Tribune
description: The International Herald Tribune announced yesterday that Michael Oreskes, deputy managing editor of The New York Times, would become its executive editor.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (BBC America) SHAMELESS -- There's a lot going on in the season finale. Frank Gallagher (David Threlfall, above), the useless, alcoholic, on-the-dole patriarch of Chatsworth Estate, fakes his death to escape his creditors. His agoraphobic neighbor, Sheila (Maggie O'Neill), accidentally goes outdoors. The house next door goes up in flames.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: 3 On Trial For Helping 'Shoe' Bomber
description: Two French nationals and a Pakistani have gone on trial in Paris, accused of having helped Richard C. Reid, the so-called shoe bomber from Britain, in his unsuccessful attempt to blow up a Paris-to-Miami flight in 2001. The three men have been charged with criminal association with regard to a terrorist enterprise and face up to 10 years in prison if convicted. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Gingrich and Clinton Agree: Let's Share
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 - In the early 1990's, Newt Gingrich was behind many of the harshest Republican attacks on Hillary Rodham Clinton's ambitious plan to overhaul health care, comparing it to Soviet Communism at one point.

title: Five Awards for Excellence In the Classical Tradition
description: The Arthur Ross Awards, which recognize contributions to classical design, were won this year by the landscape designer Deborah Nevins; the architect Demetri Porphyrios; John Benson, an artisan; Dover Publications; and, for stewardship, the Biltmore Estate in Asheville, N.C. They are presented by the Institute of Classical Architecture and Classical America, an educational organization and publisher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, KATHERINE DUSAK
description: MILLER--Katherine Dusak. Age 61. Widow of Nobel Laureate, Merton Miller, died May 6, 2005 in Chicago. Katherine was Merton's constant companion and advisor on research papers, books and speeches. After Merton's death, she became his literary executor responsible for the publication of the "Selected Works of Merton H. Miller". Katherine earned an A.B. from the Uniersity of Chicago, and an M.B.A. & Ph.D. from the University's Graduate School of Business. She taught at Northwestern University and was Treasurer of Sanwa Bank of Chicago, where she was one of the first female American financial executives to hold a senior position in a Japanese company. She is survived by stepdaughters Pamela Miller Chwedyk, Margot Miller Horn and Louise Miller Lorber, step grandsons Andrew Horn and Eric Horn, and cousins Amy Peters, Peter Goodwin, Carol Hall and Susan Lakosil. Donations may be made to Palliative Care Center & Hospice, 3420 West Vollmer Rd., Olympia Fields, IL. 60461.

title: Cambodia's Garment Makers Hold Off a Vast Chinese Challenge
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia - At the close of a long, hot day sewing men's shirts, hundreds of young Cambodian women waited anxiously as their British boss jumped onto a cutting table with a bullhorn, worried that he would tell them they had lost their jobs.

title: Moeller makes a bid for rival shipper
Global Giant in Container Shipping to Buy Rival
description: A.P. Moeller-Maersk, the world's biggest container-shipping company, has agreed to buy Royal P&O Nedlloyd for 2.3 billion euros ($3 billion) as a four-year surge in freight rates has led to record backlogs at shipyards.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: President Rejects Energy Law
description: Worried that a steep new tax would drive away investors, the Bolivian president, Carlos Mesa, has refused to sign an energy bill into law and called on Congress to make modifications. Mr. Mesa said the new 32 percent nondeductible tax on production of natural gas would further divide a country roiled by protests. The bill, passed by Congress last Thursday, was a response to a widespread public opinion that multinational companies are plundering Bolivia's resources. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: For Petals and Peat, A Host of New Materials
description: THIS season's outdoor planters include a cast of fabulous fakes and colorful characters, in new materials like molded silicone and tinted fiberglass. More important than the material, gardeners say, is having a hole for drainage. If there isn't one, drill one or drop a conventional terra cotta pot into the new one.

title: A Visitor From Another Genre Stars in Christie's Sale of Postwar Art
description: When the spring auction season is over, Christie's sale of postwar and contemporary art last night is the one the art world will remember. Not just because records were set for artists including Edward Hopper, Franz Kline, Arshile Gorky, Joseph Cornell and Sigmar Polke, but also because the enthusiasm throughout the evening was matched by bidders' reaching into deep pockets.

title: Calendar
description: Not Just to the Trade

title: Highway plans approved despite a storied site
In Seoul, fears return of foreign investors
Buildings Farther From Ground Zero to Be Tested for Contaminated Dust
description: In order to determine how far the choking dust cloud spread from ground zero after the World Trade Center collapsed, federal officials are planning, for the first time, to look for a telltale sign of the dust in apartment buildings and workplaces along part of the Brooklyn waterfront and as far north as Houston Street in Lower Manhattan.

title: Henry A. Kissinger: Realists vs. idealists
Protests continue against Koran abuse report
In Texas, a Foolish Move to Regulate Cheerleaders
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; An Architect's Brickbats
description: The architect Robert A.M. Stern, below, challenged the chairman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday night to explain why he did not hold a hearing on 2 Columbus Circle, designed by Edward Durell Stone as Huntington Hartford's Gallery of Modern Art but never designated a landmark. The building is to be reconstructed as the Museum of Arts and Design. "Not to preserve the building is shocking, but not to hear it is criminal," Mr. Stern said during a panel discussion at the 92nd Street Y, addressing Robert B. Tierney, the chairman. Mr. Tierney did not directly respond except to say that the commission had decided in 1996 not to hold a hearing on the building and that he had chosen not to revisit the decision. The panel, which discussed the effects of 40 years of landmarks regulation on architecture in New York, also included the architects Hugh Hardy and James Stewart Polshek. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: Kodak's President to Become Chief Executive on June 1
description: Correction Appended

title: Forced Labor Said to Bind 12.3 Million People Around the World
description: At least 12.3 million people worldwide work as slaves or in other forms of forced labor, the International Labor Organization, the labor arm of the United Nations, said in a report issued yesterday.

title: The Moviegoer: For Some, the Thrill Is Gone
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Oddball Rodent' Is Called New to Science
description: They live in the forests and limestone outcrops of Laos. With long whiskers, stubby legs and a long, furry tail, they are rodents but unlike any seen before by wildlife scientists. They are definitely not rats or squirrels, and are only vaguely like a guinea pig or a chinchilla. And they often show up in Laotian outdoor markets being sold as food.

title: Blair Endorses Going to U.N. if Iran Proceeds on Nuclear Plan
description: LONDON, May 12 - Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that Britain would support American moves to invoke the United Nations Security Council "if Iran breaches its obligations and undertakings."

But it finds its most virulent expression in rap music, which started out with a broad palette of themes but has increasingly evolved into a medium for worshipping misogyny, materialism and murder.

The incident began at 10:30 a.m. yesterday when two female students left the school grounds with Eguardo Alvarez and another male student, the police said. The four bought beer and went to the home of the unidentified male student in North Bellmore, the police said. They drank the beer, then Mr. Alvarez raped the 16-year-old, according to the police. When she returned to school, she notified a member of the staff, who called the police. In 2003, three Mepham junior varsity football players were sexually attacked by varsity players on a team trip. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LESCHNITZER, MARIA E.
description: LESCHNITZER--Maria E. on May 11, 2005. Beloved and devoted mother of Michael Lesch and daughter-in-law Judith. Adored Granny of Sara and Benjamin and their spouses Gabriel and Ali, and great grandmother of Ana Maria Mesa. Was married for 43 years to Adolf F. Leschnitzer who died in 1980. Born on August 22, 1909 in Berlin Germany, she was among the last Jewish women to receive a Ph.D. from the University of Berlin in Nazi Germany. Emmigrated from Germany in March 1939 and, after a stay in England, arrived in the U.S. in May 1940. Here she and her husband established the American Institute of Foreign Languages where hundreds of fellow immigrants learned English. In later years, she taught at Hunter and Queens Colleges and was actively involved in the Leo Baeck Institute. Graveside service Friday, May 13, 2pm at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY.

description: CNN has decided to replace the afternoon shoutfest "Crossfire" with news programming led by a host who is decidedly more low-key: Wolf Blitzer, right, the former Pentagon and White House correspondent who is currently the host of an afternoon program ("Wolf Blitzer Reports") and a Sunday talk show ("Late Edition"). In an internal memorandum sent late Tuesday, Jonathan Klein, president of CNN's domestic cable networks, said that Mr. Blitzer would lead a three-hour block of programming each weekday afternoon, from 3 to 6. The as-yet-untitled program, which will originate in Washington, is to begin this summer. Besides "Wolf Blitzer Reports" and "Crossfire," it will replace "Inside Politics," whose anchor, Judy Woodruff, had announced she would leave the network next month when her contract expires. Mr. Klein had said in January that he intended to cancel "Crossfire" because he wanted to move away from what he described as "head-butting debate shows." Mr. Blitzer will continue to be the host of "Late Edition" on Sundays. JACQUES STEINBERG

Tallahassee proves the point - nearly 500 miles from Miami, but only about 20 miles from the Georgia border, it is a city of verandahs and live oaks dripping with Spanish moss. Lately, it has become a backdrop for newscasters reporting on contentious cases (Bush v. Gore and the Terri Schiavo case) but most of the time, the focus is on learning: Florida State University, and Florida Agricultural & Mechanical University bring more than 40,000 students a year to this city of 153,000. Tallahassee is not as thrillingly unspoiled as Charleston, S.C.; it is more like Savannah, Ga. - where despite some ill-conceived redevelopment, a lot of Southern charm still oozes through.

title: Op-Chart; The Good News You Missed
description: As the old newsroom saying goes, "If it bleeds, it leads." And while it is understandable that newspapers like to report stories about violence, crime, conflict and mayhem, it means that good news is often relegated to the back pages, if reported at all. This happens the world over, be it in Boston, Berlin -- or Baghdad. People who live in Boston or Berlin know, of course, that the bad news is never the whole story. Baghdad, on the other hand, is far away, and Westerners have no choice but to rely on reporters to tell us everything that is happening there. And while there's no denying that there is much bad news -- and the recent spate of audacious attacks by the insurgents is a prime example -- the international press has been so focused on the setbacks that few readers are likely know about the daily parade of small triumphs that mark slow but steady progress. Consider a month's worth of such stories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LESCHNITZER, MARIA E.
description: LESCHNITZER--Maria E. on May 11, 2005. Beloved and devoted mother of Michael Lesch and daughter-in-law Judith. Adored Granny of Sara and Benjamin and their spouses Gabriel and Ali, and great grandmother of Ana Maria Mesa. Was married for 43 years to Adolf F. Leschnitzer who died in 1980. Born on August 22, 1909 in Berlin Germany, she was among the last Jewish women to receive a Ph.D. from the University of Berlin in Nazi Germany. Emmigrated from Germany in March 1939 and, after a stay in England, arrived in the U.S. in May 1940. Here she and her husband established the American Institute of Foreign Languages where hundreds of fellow immigrants learned English. In later years, she taught at Hunter and Queens Colleges and was actively involved in the Leo Baeck Institute. Graveside service Friday, May 13, 2pm at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY.

title: JUDGE SETS ASIDE DIET DRUG VERDICT AND ORDERS RETRIAL
description: A court in Philadelphia set aside last November's jury verdict and ordered a new trial in a liability case against Wyeth over its diet drugs, the company said yesterday. The plaintiffs contended that they suffered heart damage by taking Wyeth's Pondimin and Redux pills, which made up half of the fen-phen diet drug. Wyeth took the diet drug off the market in September 1997. Wyeth said that the Court of Common Pleas judge set aside a verdict that awarded the plaintiffs, three women from Utah, $1.36 million in compensatory damages. The company said that its motion for a new trial was granted after Judge Mark I. Bernstein ruled that the testimony of the plaintiffs' lone liability specialist was inadequate and violated Pennsylvania's rules of evidence. Wyeth is based in Madison, N.J.

title: Arts, Briefly; Philadelphia Orchestra President to Leave
description: Joseph H. Kluger plans to step down as president of the Philadelphia Orchestra on Aug. 31. Mr. Kluger, 50, said on Wednesday that he felt he had accomplished enough after 16 years as the orchestra's top executive and was leaving it in sound condition. He plans to join an arts consulting concern. Although he said that he and the orchestra had begun planning a transition three years ago, a search committee to find a new president will not begin work until after June 8. The next season opens on Sept. 21. Mr. Kluger said that he had no worries about the short notice: "If you show me an organization that can't survive a short-term period of leadership transition, then it's an organization that is not in good shape." DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Tallahassee, Fla.
description: IT is often said that southern Florida is in the North, and northern Florida is in the South. Tallahassee proves the point -- nearly 500 miles from Miami, but only about 20 miles from the Georgia border, it is a city of verandahs and live oaks dripping with Spanish moss. Lately, it has become a backdrop for newscasters reporting on contentious cases (Bush v. Gore and the Terri Schiavo case) but most of the time, the focus is on learning: Florida State University, and Florida Agricultural & Mechanical University bring more than 40,000 students a year to this city of 153,000. Tallahassee is not as thrillingly unspoiled as Charleston, S.C.; it is more like Savannah, Ga. -- where despite some ill-conceived redevelopment, a lot of Southern charm still oozes through. FRED A. BERNSTEIN

title: The Listings: May 13-May 19; 'RECEPTACLE: AFRICAN CONTAINERS'
description: Sometimes a receptacle is just a receptacle, but usually it is much more: an instrument of ritual, an expression of communal aesthetics, an ingenious use of material or an occasion for surface decoration. All conditions apply in full to "Receptacle: African Containers," a stunning exhibition at the Axis Gallery in Chelsea. This nearly continental survey excludes ceramic vessels to concentrate on containers made of natural materials, especially gourds -- and on man-made objects transformed through decoration. The latter include a Ndebele diviner's bottle that is a glass jug encased in beading and a Mpondo canister, beaded in red, ochre and yellow that gives new life to a discarded paint can and lid. The show includes four Zulu beer baskets with woven bands of zig-zags or diamond shapes, whose grasses swell when wet, forming a watertight seal and an effective cooling system. Some techniques create illusions. The gleaming, swelling surfaces of five Yatura ceremonial wedding gourds from Tanzania might be glazed ceramic or worked leather; they have been stained dark red and decorated with staccato incisions and geometric and zoomorphic motifs in black. A tall Gurunsi gourd from Burkina Faso, golden in color and incised with a grid of x's, suggests ivory. Two small Kwere medicine gourds with carved finial heads have matte black surfaces suggestive of basalt. Meanwhile, a rose-tinted tsonga diviner's gourd (above) gets its power not only from its fierce finial head, but also from the gourd's protruding pustule-like bumps. Also made from gourds are the large lightweight bowls, or calabashes made by the nomadic Fulani of the Sahara region and two ceremonial vessels with woven-grass coverings that suggest colossal wine jugs. Closer to its natural state is a bark Fang container that almost might be freshly cut from the trunk of a slender young tree. An unexpected bonus is a scintillating display of snuff containers that reiterates the show's variety and quality in miniature. An invaluable lesson: the prevailing sense of economy and respect for nature, two things in disastrously short supply these days. (Axis Gallery, 453 West 17th Street, (212)741-2582, through June 18; free.) ROBERTA SMITH

description: Many ghosts of Broadway past owe a serious debt to Mr. Fisher, who has been the conductor and music director of the beloved Encores! concert series since it began matching up stars with forgotten musicals 12 years ago. He finishes his illustrious run with a production of the Jerry Bock and Sheldon Harnick musical "The Apple Tree," which was originally directed by Mike Nichols in the 1966 Broadway production. (The respected conductor Paul Gemiginani will take over next season.) The concert stars Kristin Chenoweth, Malcolm Gets and Michael Cerveris and runs through Monday. After 32 productions, Mr. Fisher, 52 (above), who still sounds like a chipper professor eager for his students to love the material he's teaching as much as he does, says he wants to pursue a more diverse variety of projects (although he wouldn't get more specific than that). "There's still plenty of old shows that people don't know about that I think they will love, and I will continue to find ways to bring them to the public," he says. "That is my lot in life." Not only has Mr. Fisher rescued shows that have fallen off the radar, but he has reconstructed many of them from fragmentary snatches of sheet music and recordings. Such scholarly persistence has earned him good will from the theater community and enviable attention from the press; Encores! has one of the best rave-to-pan ratios of any company in town. So, if things are going so well, why leave now? "I'm used to shows closing and then moving on," Mr. Fisher says. "Twelve years is a long time." title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELLINWOOD, GEORGE WEBSTER, JR.
description: ELLINWOOD--George Webster, Jr. an international private banker, died peacefully on May 10, 2005 at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, FL., following a long illness. He was 71. The son of George W. Ellinwood and Doris (Green) Ellinwood, he was born in Providence, R.I. He graduated from Providence Country Day School and Colby College. Prior to his retirement in 1992, Mr. Ellinwood had been a Vice President of Citibank, where he worked for 36 years. At the time of his promotion to Vice President in 1968, he was the youngest employee ever appointed to this rank at Citibank. He headed Citibank's trust activities in the Bahamas and the Cayman Islands in the 1970s. He served the bank's clients most capably with professionalism and a personal touch remembered by many. For many years, Mr. Ellinwood lived in West Palm Beach, FL., New York and Lakeville, CT. Mr. Ellinwood leaves his dear companion, Hugh L. Harrison, three sons, Peter of Concord, N.H., Craig of Westport, CT., and David of Shrewsbury, MA., and a sister, Grace E. Wilson, of Bristol, R.I. He had seven grandsons, Gordon, Pierce, Sam, Wyatt, Tate, Jack and Hayden, a granddaughter, Lydia, and a step granddaughter, Natalie, whom he adored and visited with frequently. Besides his cherished family, he occupied his time with a variety of interests including serving on the Board of Directors of the Humane Society of New York, world travel and spending time on the water. A memorial service is scheduled for Saturday, May 21st at 10AM in the Chapel at Swan Point Cemetery in Providence, R.I. Mr. Ellinwood was a member of Bethesda-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Palm Beach, where a second service will be held in his memory next winter. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to the Humane Society of New York, 306 E. 59 St., New York, N.Y. 10022. ELLINWOOD--George. We extend our deepest sympathies to Hugh, Peter, Craig, David and the entire Ellinwood family. George's quiet charm, gentle manner, and wry sense of humor warmed our hearts. His integrity, loyalty and friendship made us better people. George touched all who knew him and we will miss him greatly. Beth, Rosita, Peter and Larry

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: U.S. Must Wait For Qaeda Suspect

"Until all the issues are cleared, there is no question of him being handed over to anyone else," he said. "Anything relevant to American security is being shared." Pakistan announced the arrest last week. Mr. Libbi is suspected of orchestrating two assassination attempts on Pakistan's president and of heading a plot to kill its prime minister. A number of arrests followed the seizure of Mr. Libbi near Peshawar, and officials say the army has stepped up the hunt for Osama bin Laden. If he is alive, Mr. Kasuri speculated, he is probably continually moving between the tribal areas of Pakistan and Afghanistan, and not with a large group of people, "otherwise he'd be detected." title: The Listings: May 13-May 19; NINE INCH NAILS
description: Trent Reznor, the only voting member of the long-running synth-punk act Nine Inch Nails, turns 40 on Tuesday. In the days before his birthday, he is to play a couple of concerts at Hammerstein Ballroom, and if you're expecting him to seem a bit old, a bit rusty, or a bit tired, then you haven't been following his career very closely. Mr. Reznor, above, long ago perfected his own ridiculous (but never tongue-in-cheek) act, and during a recent performance at the Coachella festival, he proved that he hasn't lost a step: he can still grab a microphone and snarl about what he wants to do to you (here's a hint: he wants to do it "like an animal") without cracking a smile. The new Nine Inch Nails album is "With Teeth" (Interscope), and it's a reminder of just how influential Mr. Reznor has been. His serrated tantrums and menacing ballads inspired some of the 1990's best-selling acts, from Marilyn Manson to Korn, and if Nine Inch Nails has outlasted nearly all of them, that's in large part because Mr. Reznor's rather risible lyrical preoccupations (insects, rotting stuff, things eating other things) don't prevent him from writing big, sturdy songs with big sturdy hooks. For these two concerts, Mr. Reznor will be joined by a well-chosen opening act: the Dresden Dolls, a theatrical piano-and-drums duo (they call their act "Brechtian punk cabaret") with a catalog full of clever, angular songs; show up early, if only to see if Mr. Reznor's fans are as broad-minded as he is. ( Sunday and Monday at 8 p.m., Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, Manhattan, (212)279-7740, sold out; returns may be available.) KELEFA SANNEH

title: The Listings: May 13-May 19; 'CYRANO DE BERGERAC'
description: You've seen the movie, or the play, or the musical. The tale of the large-nosed hero -- who actually lived in the 17th century -- has been the stuff of adaptation at least since Edmond Rostand wrote his famous play in 1897. Jos Ferrer won a Tony and an Academy Award as Cyrano in 1947 and 1950; Christopher Plummer took a Tony for a Broadway musical version in 1974; and Grard Depardieu's film version won him a best actor at Cannes in 1990. Now, the opera tenors are taking Cyrano on. Franco Alfano, a verismo composer best known for completing Puccini's "Turandot," wrote a "Cyrano" opera in 1936; tonight, the Metropolitan Opera is staging it for the first time as a vehicle for Plcido Domingo (above right, with Raymond Very and Sondra Radvanovsky). Meanwhile, this week saw the release of a new DVD of the same opera starring Roberto Alagna (DGG). It may not be great opera -- Alfano tempered his flamboyant verismo tendencies with a soupon of French modernism and a big dash of conservatism -- but it's fun theater, with a big meaty tenor part, and Mr. Domingo's presence has ensured that the run of three performances is already officially sold out. (Tonight and Tuesday, 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212)362-6000; returns may be available at the box office.) ANNE MIDGETTE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCORMICK, LAWRENCE P. (''MAC'' OR ''LARRY'')
description: McCORMICK--Lawrence P. ("Mac" or "Larry"), died on 6 May 2005 in Brooklyn, NY. He was 84; born on 17 November 1920 in Manhattan, NY. Mac McCormick was a retired technical director with ABC news where he worked for years in the production of both ABC's national and local TV news programs. He learned his profession while serving in US Navy's long forgotten Asiatic Fleet in the 1930's as a radioman. In NY, he employed his skills first as a dispatcher of FDNY fireboats. He then work in the heyday of radio in NY with WOR Radio and eventually contributing to the early days of live TV before moving to ABC. Mac earned a BS in physics from Columbia University in the City of New York. Among his many accomplishments was successfully fighting for our civil rights in US Federal Court. The case regarded the First Amendment to the Constitution of the US. While not an attorney, his court victory was reported on the front page of the Wall Street Journal. Mac McCormick was a great mentor to many of his friends and relatives and will be sorely missed. He is survived by his sister Nora Brandt of Clifton Park, NY, 10 nieces and nephews, 21 grand-nieces and grand-nephews, one great grand-niece and his life-long companion Grecia McCormick of Manhattan, NY. He was preceded in death by his parents, Joseph and Mary (Hunt) McCormick, and two younger sisters, Margaret "Peggy" Albers and Annamay Modruson. Friends may call on Sunday, May 15th from 2 to 4pm at the Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Ave, Westbury, NY (phone 516-333-0615). A funeral mass will be held Monday May 16th at 11:00 am in St. Brigids Church, Westbury, NY. Interment will follow at the Calverton National Cemetery.

description: MCI, the long-distance carrier, won court approval to pay $118.2 million to settle a $1 billion Mississippi lawsuit over back taxes the state claimed were owned by its predecessor company, WorldCom. Judge Arthur Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court approved the accord at a hearing yesterday in New York. WorldCom filed for bankruptcy in July 2002 after revealing an $11 billion accounting fraud. It emerged from court protection in April 2004 as MCI. The tax disputes stem from more than $20 billion in royalties paid by WorldCom subsidiaries to the parent corporation. Under the terms of the settlement, MCI will pay Mississippi $114 million in cash, including $14 million for legal fees. MCI will make an additional $4.2 million payment to the Children's Justice Center of Mississippi and turn over its property in Jackson, Miss.

World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Holiday For Hirohito
description: Japanese lawmakers overwhelmingly voted to honor Emperor Hirohito by renaming a national holiday to be celebrated in his honor starting in 2007. Showa Day, as it will be called, will be held on Hirohito's birthday, April 29, which is now a holiday called Green Day. Hirohito, whose rule lasted from 1926 until his death in 1989, is regarded by most Asians and some Japanese as a symbol of Japanese militarism and aggression in Asia, and he is still a revered figure for Japanese nationalists. But most Japanese now associate him with the postwar years of the Showa era, during which Japan rebuilt itself and became the world's No.2 economy. Two previous attempts to rename the holiday, in 2000 and 2002, were shelved in consideration of Asian sensitivities, but growing nationalism allowed the law's enactment this time. The holiday had been known as Emperor's Day before Hirohito's death, but was changed to Green Day to avoid an Asian reaction and to honor the emperor's interest in nature. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: MOODY'S MAY CUT RATING ON LIBERTY MEDIA
description: The Liberty Media Corporation's debt was placed under review for a possible downgrading by Moody's Investors Service yesterday after the company said it might seek acquisitions or return equity to shareholders. Liberty, controlled by the cable television entrepreneur John C. Malone, has about $10 billion in long-term unsecured debt that is rated Baa3, the lowest investment-grade level. Liberty's plan to raise up to $2 billion of bank debt at its QVC television shopping business "contributes to the credit pressure," Moody's said. The review will focus on the company's long-term strategy and its ability to meet financial obligations, Moody's said. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rise
description: Orders for machinery unexpectedly rose in March, paced by orders from electronics companies and automakers, according to Japan's cabinet office. Machinery orders, excluding those from shipping and utility companies, rose 1.9 percent in March from February for the second consecutive month of gains after a 4.9 percent increase for February. Economists had predicted a decline. The cabinet office forecast, however, that machinery orders would fall 3.1 percent in the second quarter of this year from the first quarter, damping hopes that corporate spending would provide a long-lasting boost for the economy. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Abbey Theater Shakeup
description: The managing and artistic directors of the Abbey, Ireland's national theater, resigned on Thursday after revelations that faulty accounting procedures masked the organization's $2.34-million budget deficit in 2004. The deficit is more than double earlier estimates, which were already large enough to prompt angry playwrights and actors to rebel last fall against the managing director, Brian Jackson, and the artistic director, Ben Barnes. Instead of taking over in December, the new artistic director, Fiach MacConghail, will assume his post immediately and oversee the Abbey's long-delayed move to a new site, probably the financial district by Dublin's dockyards. The government-sponsored theater, founded in 1904, still suffers from a "Victorian" style of management, said the government arts minister, John O'Donoghue. The Abbey will receive nearly $9 million in state money this year to produce new Irish works, in addition to revivals of "A Doll's House," "The Importance of Being Earnest" and "Hamlet." BRIAN LAVERY

A spokeswoman for the Georgia Technology Authority, Joyce Goldberg, said investigators were still trying to determine how the files had been downloaded, whether any had Social Security numbers and if the information had been used. The programmer, Asif Siddiqui, 43, is charged with two counts of computer intrusion and one count of computer theft. A spokeswoman for the Georgia Bureau of Investigation said several computers were seized at Mr. Siddiqui's home in Cobb County after his arrest on April 28. Ariel Hart (NYT)

Last year, academy officials promised to do something about widespread complaints of unconstitutional proselytizing of academy students by evangelists whose efforts were blessed by authority figures in the chain of command. title: Barcelona: Casa Camper
description: THE BASICS You've walked in the shoe; now sleep in the hotel! That could well be the slogan for Casa Camper, which is not merely a place to stay but a sensibility, a philosophy - or in other, more cynical words, an exercise in brand extension by Camper, the Spain-based maker of hip, moderately priced and aggressively comfortable footwear. This hip, moderately priced and debatably comfortable hotel is the company's first, and it opened in Barcelona early this year a few paces from a Camper boutique. It embodies the apparent Camper spirit - "we believe that the secret to true luxury lies in simplicity," says the hotel's Web site - by presenting an odd hybrid of indulgence and asceticism that feels like a splurge for the crunchy granola set: Ian Schrager meets Lonely Planet.

title: The Remix; Don't Cry For Me/Oil of Ole
description: Malbec isn't the only tasty thing being bottled in Argentina. The country's olive oil has recently come into its own, with boutique versions widely available. Now no restaurant table in Buenos Aires is complete without a bottle of a bright and fruity local aceite de oliva. Olive trees first arrived in Argentina nearly 500 years ago, but the oil was exported until the Spanish Civil War disrupted trade in the 1930's. Afterward, Argentine oil was thought to be iffy stuff. But since the 1990's, quality has skyrocketed, following the same trajectory as the local wines. Many of the oils are organic or biodynamic, with the best coming from small producers in the winemaking regions of Mendoza, San Juan and Catamarca. Connoisseurs differentiate oils by region and by variety. There's fiery farga, peppery frantoio and good, all-purpose arauco. These delicious olive oils can be purchased outside the wine regions, too. In Buenos Aires, most wine shops carry a small selection. Or pick some up at Valenti (www.valenti.com.ar), which is the city's equivalent of Dean & Deluca. OLIVER SCHWANER-ALBRIGHT

description: My grandfather served on a hospital boat in the Pacific during World War II, and so he was a preferred applicant for one of the 8,756 new rent-regulated apartments in Stuyvesant Town when it opened in 1947. The massive redbrick complex, which lies just north of the East Village in New York, was built by Metropolitan Life with the political help of Robert Moses and Fiorello La Guardia, who were anxious about where to put returning veterans and eager to clear away the vicious Gashouse district. It was modeled on the European concept, then modish, of towers in a park. In Stuyvesant Town and its slightly more upscale counterpart, Peter Cooper Village, there are 110 apartment buildings, from 13 to 15 stories each, housing more than 25,000 people on the equivalent of 27 Manhattan blocks.

title: Democratic Moral Values?
description: Matt Bai's suggestion that the 1960's antiwar movement grew out of the "counterculture" only shows again how rapidly that period is receding into the domain of myth (The Way We Live Now, April 24). The antiwar movement did not emerge from the so-called counterculture, although the counterculture contributed to its ethos. It grew out of a more general movement called the New Left. Its base was academic, and its signature creation was the teach-in, which originated at the University of Michigan in 1965. Its primary organization was Students for a Democratic Society.

title: The Nicest Place You'll Never Go
description: Fifteen minutes by car down the Malecn, Havana's coastal boulevard, sits the private beach club Nautico, where the wealthiest, best-looking and most idle capitalists once sunned their pampered, prerevolutionary bodies. Built in the 1920's and redesigned by the renowned Cuban architect Max Borges Recio in 1953, it is one of the most perfect futuristic constructions in Latin America (despite an uncanny resemblance to Terminal 4 at Kennedy International Airport). The exquisite portico and vaulted ceiling have survived without a crack. But unfortunately, most Americans will never get to sip mojitos poolside. Those lucky enough to wrangle a visa will run into Castro's recent ban on dollars. (He has imposed a maddening 10 percent surtax on the now-mandatory exchange for "peso convertibles.") Even if you manage to cut through all the Communist red tape, you still probably won't make it past the guards. Invitations are rare unless you've got juice with a former Olympian or one of the high-ranking party members who dominate the current list. Then again, you can always put some of those extra peso convertibles to use. CHRISTOPHER ISENBERG

title: The Ticket; Handball Wizards
description: "This is like the Old West out here," Adolfo Vzquez says. "The fastest hands win." The handball courts at Houston Street and First Avenue in downtown Manhattan are packed. A gang of Chinese teenagers is gathered along one wall, playing cards and flirting with girlfriends. On the opposite side of the court, a group of Hispanics are clustered quietly, adjusting bandannas on their heads and hoping for another game before it's too dark to play. Nearby, Justin Sullivan (shown left), a filmmaker who made a documentary about New York City handball called "Big Blue" in 2001, is calling it a day. Vzquez and his friend Cruz are teamed up against a pair of Chinese kids, and despite being old enough to be their grandfathers, they are beating them easily. "My doctor is pleased with my vascular system," says Vzquez, 59, who has been playing the game for 30 years. "He says he's never seen such a force in a man my age."

title: The Remix; Call of the Wild
description: Travelers seeking the next bit of African exotica can now roam the 45,000-acre Lewa Wildlife Conservancy in northern Kenya in the company of rhinos and zebras. Lewa is the setting for the BBC documentary "Cheetahs: Fast Track to Freedom," by the wildlife filmmakers Simon King and Marguerite Smits van Oyen, to be shown in the United States on Animal Planet in August. It traces the lives of two 3-week-old orphan cheetah cubs. Until a year ago, only donors to the conservancy could vacation there, but the group now rents its primary property, the grand, colonial-African-style Lewa House, to guests. Parties of up to 12 can enjoy the private verandas, indoor and outdoor dining, game viewing (Prince William rhino-spots here), the swimming pool looking out on Mount Kenya and the full staff with chef. "Every single day is different here," says Gustavo D. Romano Oliveira, Lewa's business-development manager. "This morning a male elephant woke me up at 5 a.m. when he decided to have a tree that was six feet from my bedroom window for breakfast." Lewa House is $840 a night, and the food (full board, with drinks) is $120 per guest a night. MARK JACOBS

title: The Ticket; The Hills Have Arrived/Five-Star Hikes

These hotels offer accommodations as lofty as the mountain treks that preceded them. Lake Placid Lodge A concierge doles out trail maps (or arranges guided hikes) and picnic lunches, including a blanket and a bottle of wine, for some of the nearly 50 4,000-foot-high peaks that dot this area of the Adirondacks. Don't miss Noonmark Mountain; the views of Lake Champlain are breathtaking. Go to www.lakeplacidlodge.com. Twin Farms Rooms start at a cool $1,050 a night in this luxe Vermont inn. There are five miles of private beginner and intermediate trails on the 300-acre property. But the hiking is more challenging in the surrounding area -- try Camel's Hump, Mount Ascutney or the Appalachian Trail. Go to www.twinfarms.com. Riffelalp Resort With views of the Matterhorn, this Swiss resort sits 7,290 feet above sea level and borders a pine forest. The Zermatt Alpine Center arranges six-hour glacier tours and "four-thousander" (4,000-meter) ascents. Less ambitious hikers can have trains deposit them at higher-altitude rambling areas, a great way to visit nearby mountain huts for home-cooked meals. Go to www.zermatt.ch/riffelalp. ALEXANDRA ZISSU

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: ALTERNATIVE ATLANTA. By Marshall Boswell. (Delacorte, $22.) "Is it so wrong, wanting to be at home with your record collection?" That was the question Nick Hornby posed in his 1995 novel, "High Fidelity," and a similar argument is raised in "Alternative Atlanta," Boswell's likable but fairly weightless first novel. His narrator, 30-year-old Gerald Brinkman, is a music critic for an alternative weekly newspaper in Atlanta who'd rather stay home cranking his free review copies of CD's than deal with the mess his life has become. "Alternative Atlanta" opens with Gerald attending the wedding of his ex-girlfriend, Nora, a k a the One Who Got Away. Gerald broke up with her several years earlier, even though she was perfect for him. That's what happens when your life lessons come to you through your stereo receiver: "Rock has taught him all he cares to know about integrity, aesthetic form and love. Don't sell out, don't overstay your welcome, don't grow up: those are the three lessons of rock." Gerald's preprogrammed playlist gets scrambled when his father, a minister turned disillusioned eccentric by the death of Gerald's mother when Gerald was 7, arrives at his doorstep. Then Nora proceeds to drop a bomb of her own, entangling Gerald in her messy marriage. Boswell uses the 1996 Summer Olympic Games as a backdrop, so some actual explosives figure in the plot as well, catapulting Gerald into adult responsibility faster than he can say, "Hope I die before I get old."

title: Paperback Row
description: ARC OF JUSTICE: A Saga of Race, Civil Rights, and Murder in the Jazz Age, by Kevin Boyle. (Owl/Holt, $15.) A National Book Award winner last year, "Arc of Justice" is a cogent account of the racially charged trial of Ossian Sweet, a young black doctor who breached Detroit's color line in 1925 by moving his family into a white middle-class neighborhood. When a mob attacked the house, someone inside shot and killed a white man in the crowd. Sweet and several friends and relatives who had come to his defense were charged with murder. The Ku Klux Klan and a nascent N.A.A.C.P. both seized on the sensational trial, which featured the legendary Clarence Darrow leading the defense. Mixing biography, social history and courtroom drama, "Boyle vividly recreates the energy and menace of Detroit in 1925," Robert F. Worth wrote in the Book Review.

But those of us on the hunt for movies that can stir both the senses and the mind in the meantime might also consider a couple of documentaries, part of a lively and growing genre in a so-far depressingly dull movie year. "MAD HOT BALLROOM" was the subject of a bidding war at the SUNDANCE -- whoops, make that the rival SLAMDANCE -- Film Festival in January. The movie tells a very uncynical tale of fourth and fifth graders in the New York public school system, most from humble backgrounds, who are transformed by ballroom dance lessons. title: Rescuing Modernism
description: In 2002, the Los Angeles architect Richard Neutra's landmark 1963 Palm Springs Modern Maslon House was bought for $2.45 million, then bulldozed within a week by its new owner. Mies van der Rohe's iconic glass-fronted Villa Tugendhat, completed in 1930, was restored in the mid-80's, but the restoration did more harm than good. Alvar Aalto's 1964 Kaufmann Conference Center, near the United Nations, narrowly escaped gutting by its Japanese owners, who hoped to turn the building into offices. And in Beirut, some of the midcentury towers along the formerly glamorous Corniche are still in disrepair. Modern architects dreamed of a radiant future, but their buildings have become an increasingly fragile record of the past. Is Modernism disappearing from the landscape it made?

title: THE POLL RESULTS

It found differences in the views of rich and poor in some areas, including the likelihood of achieving the American dream. The poll was followed by interviews with respondents, including the four people pictured above, chosen to represent different economic groups. MARJORIE CONNELLY

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: May 15-21; ART
description: In an effort to show the work of more living artists, the METROPOLITAN MUSEUM has organized an exhibition of two installations by the New York artist TONY OURSLER, which opens on Tuesday. The first, called "Climaxed," is a floating fireball hanging in midair that continually explodes. The second originated last fall, when Mr. Oursler was asked by the MUSE D'ORSAY to choose something in its collection and create a work of art in response to it. The result is "STUDIO: SEVEN MONTHS OF MY AESTHETIC EDUCATION (PLUS SOME,)" inspired by COURBET'S 1855 painting "THE ARTIST'S STUDIO: A REAL ALLEGORY OF A SEVEN YEAR PHASE IN MY ARTISTIC AND MORAL LIFE." "The tradition of studio paintings has always interested me," Mr. Oursler said. So he decided to create an artist's studio for the 21st century, with modern-day trappings like electronics, e-mail and surveillance. Just as Courbet's painting incorporated a host of people, Mr. Oursler's work does as well: A surveillance camera captures museum visitors and puts them in the installation. There are also inspirational objects like a model by the Rotterdam architect REM KOOLHAAS, and works by Mr. Oursler's wife, JACQUELINE HUMPHRIES, who is also an artist. "Courbet always said his painting was unfinished so he gave me the license to make this organic," Mr. Oursler said. "It keeps growing." Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212)535-7710.

But by the time they learned that it was the only Le Corbusier house in Belgium, commissioned by the artist Ren Guiette in 1925, they were in love with it. Guiette's daughter sold it to the young couple in 1983 for "very little money." They had to tape up the windows to keep the rain out, but "good architecture makes a beautiful ruin," Demeulemeester points out. "The house is a poem of light and space." On the centennial of Le Corbusier's birth, the Belgian government agreed to help restore it. Demeulemeester is limited in what she can do dcor-wise, but no matter. "It's not necessary to change a thing," she says. "It's so beautiful, and it keeps on surprising me." Alix Browne

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RYAN, DONALD HILLSDON, ''MISTER MINIT''
description: RYAN -- Donald Hillsdon, "Mister Minit". September 23, 1925--May 9, 2005. The co-founder and former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Minit International died at his home in London, England on Monday, May 9. He and his partner virtually invented the rapid-service industry and the idea for the company while at Harvard Business School. They were anxious to do something very challenging commercially and would sit and talk about the "sleepers", the small craft industries, which were established businesses providing something everyone needed but without any real organization or capital behind them, and which no one seemed to be trying to industrialize or commercialize. After working five years for Procter and Gamble in the US and Europe, Mr. Ryan co-founded the Minit Corporation in 1957 with the opening of a small "while-you-wait" heel repair bar in Brussels' Bon Marche department store. He bought out his partner and built a global network of shops and services in 30 countries. The business provided quick service for everything from the original heel and shoe repair, to key duplication, photo development, watch repair, knife and skate sharpening, engraving, name tapes, rubber stamps, and retailing of travel goods, personalized gifts, cutlery, wigs and jewelry. The company also manufactured key blanks, shoe materials, machinery, fixtures and signs for its shops worldwide. Born in Petersburg, Virginia, Mr. Ryan started his first business at age 12, raising birds and rabbits for sale to small markets and delivering newspapers. He attended the Virginia Military Institute before serving in the Infantry in WWII and in Berlin during the occupation, where he was responsible for the allocation of German transportation assets throughout the US zone. He graduated from The College of William and Mary (AB) where he later funded the Ryan Professorship of Business Policy, and received his MBA from the Harvard Business School in 1952. He received honorary Doctor of Laws degrees from the American College Of Switzerland and from the College of William and Mary. He was given the prestigious honour of Commander of the Order of Leopold II by the King of Belgium. Mr. Ryan was chairman of the Swiss Romande Harvard Alumni Association for many years, was international senior vicepresident of the Young President's Organization and international chairman of the Chief Executive's Organization. He has been quoted as comparing leadership to the yeti--"You never see him, but his footprints are everywhere in the snow." Mr. Ryan was a resident of The Bahamas and of London, England. He is survived by his wife, Gail, and by his four daughters--Kristina, Shelly, Kim and Alexandra, and seven grandchildren. Graveside services will be held at the Highgate Cemetery in London on Monday, May 16.

title: The City He Built
description: It is hard to imagine a crueler fate for an urban planner than seeing his country taken over by a regime with a murderous hatred of cities. As Cambodia's pre-eminent architect and chief urban planner during the 1960's, Vann Molyvann laid out significant portions of Phnom Penh and designed dozens of landmark structures fusing High Modernist design with classical Khmer elements, including the Corbusier-influenced Independence Monument, the stacked-block minimalist Front du Bassac housing development and the National Sports Complex. Then, in 1975, the Khmer Rouge marched into the capital and evacuated its entire population. They used the stadium for political meetings and mass rallies. In the southern port of Sihanoukville, they tried to blow up Vann's National Bank of Cambodia building (having abolished money) but gave up when the vaults proved too strong.

And despite the strictures of Islam, women are starting to choose work over marriage. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HECHT, KAL
description: HECHT--Kal, died in peace on May 13, 2005 at his daughter's home in Miami. These are his own words: "I graduated from Lafayette College in June of 1941. As Salutatorian of my class, I gave a speech at our commencement exercises urging that the United States enter World War II on the side of Great Britain. I entered the US Navy a few days later. When the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor, I was a newly commissioned ensign serving aboard the USS President Adams. Eventually, I participated in the invasion of Guadalcanal. After the war, I received an MS degree from the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University and worked as a reporter and editor of newspapers in Pennsylvania and Connecticut. Then I went to Europe. I studied French and Spanish, fell in love with Europe, and stayed there for the next 30 years. I live in a building bordering the sea in Fort Lauderdale. Each day I look out to sea as I did 60 years ago on islands in the Pacific." Kal remains in the hearts of daughter Lisa Hecht-Cronstedt, sister Florence Savin, niece Irene Hecht and cousin William Troy and Susan Troy. May your brilliance shine on your final voyage. Fare well.

title: Inside the List
description: REBEL ZELL: There was a time when Zell Miller, the former Democratic senator from Georgia, was a uniting kind of guy, not a dividing one. On the cover of his 1997 book, "Corps Values: Everything You Need to Know I Learned in the Marines," there were blurbs by (from the right) Newt Gingrich and Mary Matalin and (from the left) Max Cleland and James Carville. Consensus, however, doesn't sell books. It's only since Miller forcefully spurned his party that he's begun to move units. His 2003 book, "A National Party No More: The Conscience of a Conservative Democrat," made the Times hardcover nonfiction list for nine weeks, rising as high as No. 4. And Miller's new volume, "A Deficit of Decency," which arrives in the wake of his vein-popping keynote address at the 2004 Republican National Convention, enters the hardcover list this week at No. 9. "A Deficit of Decency" is a tough book to get a handle on. On the one hand, there's an introduction by Sean Hannity of Fox News, and Miller zeroes in on predictable conservative targets -- the "useless nuisance" of the United Nations, the liberal media and hip-hop. (Miller blows a gasket over the Nelly video in which the rapper "swipes a credit card through a young woman's backside.") On the other hand, he has nice things to say about Hillary Rodham Clinton and her chances in 2008. (Miller calls her a "warrior.") Miller's literate and often likable book also includes encomiums to Waylon Jennings, the Carter Family, Ray Charles, George Jones and Loretta Lynn -- proving he's still a uniter on one issue: he's got beautiful taste in music.

But has the typical sandwich become too dull? Perhaps one of the most interesting and new takes on the sandwich comes not from our own country, but from South America -- Brazil to be exact.

description: Lighten up, Daphne. We pet lovers may be besotted fools, but don't lump us all in with Hitler, the loonies from PETA and people who keep tigers in their backyards. We're just trying to express what our animals mean to us. Misguided, perhaps, but "depraved"? I hope that someday you do get your dream dog. I'll bet you anything that that pooch will be sleeping in a velvet-lined basket next to your bed in no time.

title: Let the Fur Fly
description: Daphne Merkin is right on target. I see more behavior problems in dogs today compared with just 10 years ago. Many cases involve separation anxiety, a condition in which dogs become nervous and destructive when left alone, even for short periods. Many veterinary behaviorists believe that not allowing puppies to build confidence on their own is at least partly responsible. It's tough to develop confidence when you are being carried under someone's arm. So common is this disorder that Novartis is marketing a drug specifically for it.
