title: Preserving the Global AIDS Fund
description: The world has two big programs that fight AIDS in poor countries. One, created by President Bush, will spend more than a billion dollars in 15 hard-hit nations this year. It is a very important lifesaving initiative, but it could do even more. The pharmaceutical industry has kept it from buying cheap generic versions of AIDS medicines. And the religious right has pushed it toward abstinence-only programs and away from the people most likely to become infected: prostitutes, gays and intravenous-drug users. Fortunately, there is also the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, which has been free to do the work America shuns. But its ability to continue to do so is at risk.

title: Miramax Founders in Deal to Distribute Video Programs
description: LOS ANGELES, May 18 - Seven weeks after negotiating their exit from the Walt Disney Company with talk of building a "fully integrated media company," Harvey and Bob Weinstein, the brothers who founded Miramax Films, have made their first strategic deal -- an acquisition fund and distribution arrangement with Rainbow Media Holdings, the programming subsidiary of Cablevision Systems Corporation.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Blackstone to Invest $1 Billion
description: The Blackstone Group, the New York private equity firm, said that it would invest more than $1 billion in India's infrastructure and real estate. The group said that it might also set up its own back-office outsourcing company. "We are bullish on India," Blackstone's president, Hamilton E. James, told reporters in New Delhi. "The fundamentals of the future of the economy are very promising." Foreign companies have invested about $10 billion in the Indian stock markets in the past year. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: A Senior Official To Retire
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan announced that Sir Kieran Prendergast, 62, a veteran British diplomat and the United Nations under secretary general for political affairs since 1997, was retiring. He will leave his post in June but will remain on staff until the end of the year while taking up a Harvard University fellowship to compile a report on how the United Nations can contribute to conflict resolution. A knowledgeable and influential official, Sir Kieran, left, was identified as an opponent of the war in Iraq by Washington, which successfully discouraged his ambition to become the United Nations envoy to the Middle East, a post that was given this month to the Peruvian diplomat lvaro de Soto. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Jury Tallies Morgan's Total at $1.45 Billion
description: Morgan Stanley suffered another legal setback yesterday as a Florida jury ordered it to pay $850 million in punitive damages to the financier Ronald O. Perelman, who contended he was defrauded by the investment bank in a 1998 deal.

World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Border Is Set
description: Russia and Estonia signed a border treaty more than 13 years after the collapse of the Soviet Union divided them. The legal uncertainty over the border complicated Russia's relations with the European Union, which Estonia joined last year. Russia has yet to agree on a similar treaty with another new European Union nation, Latvia, which President Vladimir V. Putin criticized last week for reviving historical border disputes. Estonia and Russia agreed to the boundaries drawn after the Soviet Union absorbed the Baltic states after World War II. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Supremacist Group Dissolved
description: France has dissolved a white supremacist group, Elsass Korps, based in eastern Alsace near the German border. The group, which had about 30 members, was suspected of desecrating a number of Jewish and Muslim cemeteries in eastern France last year. In February, Interior Minister Dominique de Villepin pledged to crack down on neo-Nazi groups, estimating that about 3,000 people took part in their activities in France. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Molson Halts Cash to Kaiser
description: The Molson Coors Brewing Company has stopped injecting cash into its money-losing Brazilian subsidiary, Cervejarias Kaiser, Molson said in a statement. W. Leo Kiely III, Molson's chief executive, left, said the decision to operate Kaiser at "at least a cash break-even pace" was intended to minimize financial risk to the parent company. Kaiser was acquired by Molson about two years ago and has suffered, in part, because of a price war in Brazil. In the last quarter, Kaiser lost $3 million, compared with losses of $22 million during the same period a year earlier. Despite its decision to end financial support of Kaiser, Molson Coors said that it still believed Brazil had long-term potential for the company. Molson Coors is based in Golden, Colo. Ian Austen (NYT)

World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Rabbi's Wife And Son Indicted
description: An Israeli court indicted the wife and son of Israel's chief Sephardic rabbi in connection with the suspected beating of a teenage boy who was dating the rabbi's daughter, Ayala. The rabbi, Shlomo Amar, was questioned by the police but is not a suspect in the case. His wife, Mazal, and their son, Meir, along with two Arab accomplices, face charges that include kidnapping, assault and wrongful imprisonment, according to the Justice Ministry. The indictment alleges that the assault took place after the young man refused to stop seeing 18-year-old Ayala. Greg Myre (NYT)

Metro Briefing | New York: New High For Gas On Price Index
description: A gallon of gasoline cost New Yorkers more last month than at any time in nearly three decades, pushing up transportation and other costs in the region, the United States Department of Labor said yesterday. While the Consumer Price Index in the New York region was flat in April, the average price of a gallon of gas, as measured by the index, was $2.261, the highest since the department began recording prices in 1978. That was a 9.8 percent increase over March; the department's gasoline index is now 23 percent higher than a year ago. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Fire At Chemical Weapons Arsenal
description: A small fire broke out last week for about two minutes in the explosive containment room where the Army is destroying chemical weapons at the Pine Bluff Arsenal, the Army said. The work, which began in March, was shut down for two days while workers investigated. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Recycled T-Shirts That Your Comforter Can Wear
description: If you're done wearing your old T-shirts, you can start sleeping with them. Scott Cronick, owner of Cronick Valentine in the East Village, turns T-shirts into pillows ($30) and duvet covers ($175 to $210), above. Mr. Cronick, 27, came up with the idea after working for an entertainment news announcer who loved to wear vintage T-shirts, but only once. He developed a way to fuse the shirts to fabric for pillow covers. Further experiments led to a material stiffened with felt, used for more structured items like bags. Cronick Valentine, 324 East Ninth Street (First Avenue), was designed by Gold Wood & Daisies. Borrowing from the architect Shigeru Ban, the store uses cardboard tubes to frame artists' work, on left. description: The latest twist on the old white refrigerator is a four-door Samsung model scheduled to land in stores in September. The $3,000 fridge reflects demand for distinct storage areas, said Maria Kim, Samsung's product planning manager for home appliances. To keep odors from spreading, each compartment has its own fan, and two drawers can be separately set from minus 13 degrees to 50 degrees. title: Arts, Briefly; Country Surprises
description: Kenny Chesney predictably captured entertainer of the year, the top prize at Tuesday's Academy of Country Music Awards, but the "Redneck Woman" singer Gretchen Wilson, right, and the Australian Keith Urban were surprise winners as the top female and male vocalist, respectively. Ms. Wilson, who ended Martina McBride's three-year run as the best female singer, also was named the top new artist at the awards. Mr. Urban received top album kudos for "Be Here," while Tim McGraw's "Live Like You Were Dying" was honored as the year's best song and best single. Garth Brooks, who has been living in semiretirement in Oklahoma, received a standing ovation when he returned to announce that the Pioneer Award had been given posthumously to his mentor, Chris LeDoux, the former rodeo champion and singer who died on March 9. PHIL SWEETLAND

As the post-position draw for the 130th running of the Preakness Stakes unfolded Wednesday, Shirreffs had to pull from all three disciplines to get his Kentucky Derby winner, Giacomo, into a suitable gate and defend the horse's honor.

title: A Chandelier That Glitters In an Unlikely East Side Spot
description: Can anyone help solve the mystery of the incongruous crystal chandelier in the lobby of the Arsenal, headquarters for New York's Department of Parks and Recreation, in Central Park at East 64th Street? The eight-foot fixture, unsigned, was installed in the 1930's when the department took over the building, an 1851 former munitions warehouse. Could the rumor be true that Robert Moses took the fixture to the office in the trunk of his car?

title: Who's Your Daddy?
description: Washington - TWENTY-FIVE years ago, a peculiar little sperm bank called the Repository for Germinal Choice began offering its product -- the seed of Nobel Prize winners and other outstanding men -- to the public. The "Nobel Prize sperm bank" was jeered for its elitism and self-importance. Some critics proposed that the government ban it. But clients were undeterred. Women from across the country inundated the sperm bank, in Southern California, with applications for its special sperm.

title: Conceived by an Innkeeper, Apartments With Amenities

As part of his overhaul of the storied 1924 Gramercy Park Hotel in New York, Mr. Schrager, above on left, is creating 23 apartments designed by the London architect John Pawson, above on right. "I saw an opportunity to storm the market and have the same impact there that I had with hotels and nightclubs," Mr. Schrager said.

For over 30 years, she was Executive Vice President of the Realty Foundation of NY, which is the philanthropic arm of the real estate industry in NY. description: A high-profile battle over the ownership of six Gustav Klimt paintings once looted by the Nazis was settled out of court yesterday, with the parties handing the matter to a three-member panel in Austria. The decision ends the possibility of a protracted legal fight in a case so complex that some issues were settled by the United States Supreme Court.

title: Witness Says She Was Told to Cut Clinton Gala Charge

Rosen, who was the national finance director for Hillary Rodham Clinton's 2000 Senate race, a witness testified here today.

title: With U2, the Ideals Fly Along With Lights and Chords
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 17 - High-mindedness may be the toughest thing for a rock band to pull off in concert. Lust, anger, cockiness or humor are easy by comparison. Yet U2, whose "Vertigo" tour made its first local stop on Tuesday night at the Continental Airlines Arena here, is an old hand at equating great big chords with great big ideals. Its concert made virtue seem not just dutiful, but joyful.

title: The Personal Evolution of a Civil Rights Giant
description: In the 1940's, Malcolm Little aka Detroit Red (and, later, aka Malcolm X, aka El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz) wanted to impress co-conspirators in petty crime with his ruthlessness and daring. He loaded his pistol with a single bullet, twirled the cylinder, put the muzzle to his head and fired. The gesture demonstrated that he was unafraid of death and therefore not afraid of much else. And when he recounts the story in his 1965 autobiography ("as told to" Alex Haley), the reader is also impressed -- though evidence of his brilliance, fury and self-destructiveness is, by then, hardly necessary.

National Briefing | South: Georgia: Scouting Membership Investigated
description: The United Way of Metropolitan Atlanta voted to suspend $945,000 of its annual donation to the local Boy Scouts while a law firm hired by the scouting group investigates whether it inflated membership numbers. Local scouting leaders have accused the Scouts' Atlanta Area Council of inventing thousands of African-American scouts in order to increase donations to the group. A United Way spokesman, Mark Dvorak, said that in the Scouts' financing application this year, filed after the controversy arose, the group claimed 15,000 African-American members, 7,000 fewer than last year. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Chauvinism at the Battlefront
description: Female soldiers are barred by national policy from direct ground combat in Iraq, but that has not saved the lives of 34 American women killed so far in that lethal battlefield bereft of front lines. In a remedy steeped more in misplaced gallantry than wisdom, House Republicans ran into Pentagon opposition this week with a sudden proposal to protect women by cutting back the jobs they could hold in support units stationed to the rear of ground combat soldiers. The net effect, Army leaders properly warned, would hurt women's careers by shutting them out of more than 20,000 vital support jobs in a military effort that is already hard-pressed to keep its ranks filled with fresh volunteers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Emergency Room Decontaminated
description: Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Bushwick began decontaminating its emergency room last night after a woman carrying an envelope containing a white powder arrived complaining of flulike symptoms. The envelope, which the woman said she had received from California four days earlier, raised concerns that she had been exposed to a lethal substance, perhaps anthrax, and set off the decontamination effort. Officials diverted ambulances to other hospitals while they quarantined the woman and two friends who had accompanied her in a section of the emergency room, said Bill Green, the hospital's vice president of external affairs. The envelope was taken to the Health Department for analysis, a police spokesman said. Mr. Green said last night that there was no indication the powdery substance was anthrax, and that the woman and her friends, who arrived around 7:20 p.m., were expected to be held for several hours. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Roommates, When Dead, Know How to Keep Quiet
description: Beginning with an obeisance to the cruelties of fate and ending with a quote by Truman Capote, the Thai director Pen-ek Ratanaruang's splatter comedy "6ixtynin9" rejoices in a plot as tricky as its spelling. Made five years before the critical success of his "Last Life in the Universe" (2004), "6ixtynin9" offers an intriguing glimpse of themes that would blossom to stunning effect in the later film, for example, the deployment of fantasy as an emotional safety valve and the problems of a protagonist forced to share living quarters with decomposing corpses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REASENBERG, LILLIAN (NEE GERBER)
description: REASENBERG--Lillian (nee Gerber). Died peacefully at home May 17, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Julian Reasenberg, loving and devoted mother to Robert (Wendy) Reasenberg, Paul (Terry Lesser) Reasenberg and Margie (Tony) Pye. Adored grandmother of Suzanne, David and the late Michael Reasenberg and Lorien, Matthew, Karen and Jeremy Pye. Sister of the late Howard Gerber. A Brooklynite for most of her life, she was a Home Economics teacher in the public schools. A teacher at Brooklyn College and president of the Brooklyn Mineralogical Society, she was an avid mineral collector along with her late husband Julie, traveling the world trading minerals with museums and collecting specimens. In 1986 she moved to South Orange, New Jersey and became active in the JCC of West Orange. But her first and most passionate life's work was raising her three children. She will live on always in the hearts of all those who knew her.

The 'M' Word
description: t's funny that Mr. Scott has brought up the "M" word  i.e., masterpiece. I don't think or perhaps don't yet know if Hou Hsiao-hsien's "Three Times" is a masterpiece, but it's quite wonderful. I've been thinking about the M word a lot recently because critics really tend to lose all sense of perspective at Cannes, especially as the festival wears on. Some critics have complained that there are no masterpieces at the festival (others, meanwhile have found a rather startling number of masterpieces), when there are, in fact, a handful of exceptional films in the program. As one magazine editor said to me today, there are enough films here to carry the cover of his publication several times in the coming year. At the top of my list are the Hou, his best film since "Flowers of Shanghai," along with the Cronenberg, the Dardennes and the Haneke. I like a handful of other titles, as well, and even films I feel mixed about are of a high quality. Nonetheless, a friend who usually admires Mr. Hou doesn't believe that "Three Times" rates a "good," which slightly blows my mind. My take on my friend's parsimoniousness is that he's disappointed that Mr. Hou has not made yet another masterpiece. I guess the director's flawless mise-en-scene and ravishing-looking palette, along with his ability to pull wrenching emotions out of seemingly simple situations are just not enough. Thank goodness we will soon return home where we can begin wading through the usual junk.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Managing Job Losses

The Women for Fields, who included State Senator Ruth Hassell-Thompson of the Bronx and Westchester County and Assemblywoman Annette Robinson of Brooklyn, stood on the steps of City Hall, at one point chanting "Madame Mayor." Ms. Fields, the Manhattan borough president, who broke into dance amid the cheering, said she would pay particular attention to the needs of women, working to improve their health care and economic opportunities, while addressing the wider concerns of city residents. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, AMBASSADOR MILTON A. PHD.
description: WOLF--Ambassador Milton A. PhD. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) are deeply sorrowed by the passing of our esteemed former President (1993-1996), Ambassador Milton A. Wolf. His distinguished term as U.S. Ambassador to Austria and his continuing involvement in economic policy making and diplomatic affairs, gave Ambassador Wolf the special skills needed to lead JDC during a period of intensive activity and growth. With Ambassador Wolf at the helm, JDC was able to capitilize on a host of new opportunities to serve critical Jewish needs in a post Cold War world. Joined by his beloved life partner, the late Roslyn Zehman Wolf, Ambassador Wolf traveled the world on behalf of JDC and the Jewish people, leading our first mission to Cuba, inagurating the first Jewish community welfare center established in the former Soviet Union-the prototype for a Hesed network that now numbers over 170, and presiding over rescue operations from Sarajevo, Syria, and Yemen. Above all, Ambassordor Wolf was determined to help the Jews of the former Soviet Union reclaim their heritage and "return to the worldwide Jewish people." "Future generations will never forgive us" he said, "if we neglect to meet this challenge." A past President of the Jewish Community Federation of Cleveland, an officer and trustee of several distinguished universities and a civic leader, Ambassordor Wolf has been honored for his service to his country, his community, and the Jewish people. On behalf of the hundreds of thousands of people benefitting today from the programs he helped bring to fruition, we mourn his untimely loss. We extend our deepest sympathy to his children, including our devoted Board member, Caryn Wolf Wechsler. We will miss his wise counsel and unswerving support. May his memory be for a blessing. Judge Ellen M. Heller, President Eugene J. Ribakoff, Chairman of the Board Steven Schwager, Executive Vice President

description: Euro Disney, the operator of two money-losing theme parks east of Paris, abruptly replaced its chief executive, Andr Lacroix, installing Karl Holz, a German who had previously been a senior executive at Walt Disney's theme parks in Florida. Mr. Holz, 54, who became chief operating officer of Euro Disney in September, will take over as chief immediately, the company said. The company said Mr. Lacroix, 45, was leaving to pursue other opportunities and quoted him as saying, "I am confident in the future of Disneyland Resort Paris." Mr. Lacroix, who had been chief since 2003, put in place a financial restructuring that involved delaying the payment of fees owed to Walt Disney, the American parent, as well as delaying interest payments on some debt. Attendance at the two theme parks the company operates has not lived up to forecasts, and the company has been through two reorganizations. title: Cleveland
description: THE Cleveland of "American Splendor," the 2003 Oscar-nominated movie, is a dreary 1980's town of thrift stores and shambling eccentrics, a place where you'd barely care to spend two hours, let alone a weekend. Today, Cleveland hardly feels like the same place. In the 1990's, public-private enterprise replaced center-city blight with new sports stadiums and the lakefront Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum. Meanwhile, downtown's revival spurred gentrification into forgotten enclaves along the Cuyahoga River. There's a thriving art scene in Tremont, and the retooled Warehouse District has become a place to be, rather than flee, after dark. Clevelanders remain, by nature, a self-deprecating lot. But before long, calling their town hip, cosmopolitan -- even splendid -- won't sound so ironic. MICHAEL GOLLUST

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: East-West Tug Of War
description: Russia formally asked Switzerland to extradite Yevgeny O. Adamov, the former Russian atomic energy chief who was arrested in Bern this month on a warrant from the United States. American prosecutors accuse him of stealing up to $9 million from the Department of Energy, and a federal grand jury indicted him on charges of fraud and money laundering on May 5. The United States has not yet made a formal request for his extradition. The Swiss Justice Ministry said the Russian request was based on a Russian arrest warrant of May 14. Russian prosecutors are investigating Mr. Adamov in connection with accusations of fraud committed while he was in government. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MITTELMAN, EUGENE
description: MITTELMAN--Eugene. After a brave battle with cancer, Eugene Mittelman died on May 19 at Beth Israel Medical Center, surrounded by family and friends. He was born in 1935 in New York. He received his BA degree from Bard College and his law degree, as a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar, from Columbia University. From 1967 until the mid-1970's he served as Minority Counsel to the US Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee, appointed by Jacob K. Javits. During those years he helped to shape major pieces of progressive labor legislation. Subsequently, he entered private practice, specializing in labor issues and litigation in Washington, DC and New York City, most recently with the firm of Maidman and Mittelman. He lived his life with great passion, and he will be sorely missed. He is survived by his wife Frances, daughters Karen and Deborah, his mother Marion Banks, cousin Jim Blue, and grandson Jacob Mittelman. Funeral services will be held at 10AM on Sunday at Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard.

But most of the credit goes to the Board of Regents, which vaulted the state to the front of the national standards movement when it beefed up graduation requirements, strengthened teacher training and introduced tests to make sure students were progressing. Critics predicted mass failures and civic disaster, but the reforms are bearing fruit.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Seeking To Pressure Sudanese Government
description: The General Assembly passed a bill prohibiting the state from doing business with companies that do business in Sudan. The legislation, which passed both houses on Tuesday and which is the first of its kind in the nation, bars the state treasurer, retirement systems and pension funds from contracting with, lending to or investing in companies that work in Sudan. The bill seeks to pressure the Sudanese government to end genocide and terrorism in the Darfur region, said State Senator Jacqueline Y. Collins, Democrat of Chicago, a co-sponsor. Two of the state's five pension systems have about $1 billion invested in 32 companies that work in Sudan, Ms. Collins said. Similar legislation has been proposed in six other states. title: Arts, Briefly; Some Large Canvases
description: In recent years, summer in New York has usually meant bumping into a public sculpture exhibition on almost every other corner. But public art in the form of painting has been rare. Creative Time, a nonprofit group that oversees art projects around the city, is now trying to remedy that situation by commissioning three painters to create works on three huge billboards above Lower Manhattan. The project, underwritten by the United Technologies Corporation, a longtime arts patron, recently chose Alex Katz, Gary Hume and Lisa Sanditz, an emerging young artist, to make the paintings, for billboards as high as 60 feet on Canal Street, Houston Street and near the Bowery. The works, to be unveiled in early September, will -- because of insurance concerns and union rules -- be painted not directly by the artists but by professional sign painters under their supervision. "I think this is a cool idea," said George David, the chairman of United Technologies. "I'm looking forward to seeing it myself, just as an individual." RANDY KENNEDY

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx-Whitestone Bridge Work Begins May 31
description: A one-year, $136 million project to replace the 66-year-old roadway deck of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge will begin on May 31, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has announced. One of the six lanes will be closed at all times during the project. A temporary movable barrier will provide three lanes for Bronx-bound traffic during the morning rush and reverse the flow during the evening rush, with three lanes open to Queens. "There is no way to make it painless, but we believe this design will reduce congestion as much as possible," said Michael C. Ascher, president of M.T.A. Bridges and Tunnels. Traffic enforcement agents will be posted at intersections on the Queens side every day from 3 p.m. to 10 p.m. to direct traffic in residential areas near the approach to the bridge. In the project's first phase, two Queens-bound lanes and one Bronx-bound lane will be replaced by Thanksgiving. The second phase is scheduled to begin in March and be completed by September 2006. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: A Divided Iraq

title: The Listings: May 20-May 26; STURTEVANT: 'PUSH AND SHOVE'
description: Sturtevant, who eschews her given name Elaine, began copying works by artists like Warhol, Johns and Lichtenstein in the mid-60's, to the annoyance of some in the art world who failed to see the point of her attack on the romance of originality. She went on to replicate works by Joseph Beuys, Felix Gonzalez-Torres and Robert Gober, among others. Now in her mid 70's and living in Paris (they love her in Europe), Sturtevant is having her first New York solo in almost 10 years. (A retrospective called "The Brutal Truth" is currently at the List Visual Arts Center at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.) The cavernous installation in Rubenstein's 23rd Street gallery features her rendition of Marcel Duchamp's 1,200 burlap coal bags hanging overhead like so many giant scrotums -- an effect the ribald punster Duchamp surely intended. Spotlighted around the gallery are her found versions of his readymades, including the bicycle wheel, the snow shovel, the urinal (above) and the bottle rack. Also there is a brief Cubist film of a live female nude descending a staircase. (Most works are dated between the late 60's and the early 90's.) Meanwhile, Rubenstein's 24th Street pocket gallery presents a recent seven-channel video, in part of which Sturtevant impersonates Paul McCarthy's demented Abstract Expressionist clown. If you like to philosophize about art and creativity, Sturtevant is for you. (Perry Rubenstein, 527 West 23rd Street and 526 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 627-8000, through June 18; free.) KEN JOHNSON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGAN, CLAUDIA BUR GHARDT
description: MORGAN -- Claudia Bur ghardt. July 23rd, 1939-April 14th, 2005. A graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, she earned a BA from Harvard in 1961, and an MA in Urban Planning, 1965, University of Cincinnati. Her career in urban planning was cut short by her increasing disability from multiple sclerosis. Subsequent volunteer work included the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center, the MTA Committee for Disability Transport, the NYC Harvard Admissions Committee, and the Community College Chorus of CCNY. She impressed all with her courage and commitment to focus on her abilities, not her disabilities. She completed the 2000 NYC Marathon in a wheelchair. Survivors in sorrow include husband, John P. Morgan, M.D.; children, Jennifer Lyle Morgan and Zachary Ross Morgan; son-in-law, Herman L. Bennett; mother, Ethel Carter; grandchildren, Carl J. Fraley and Emma Lee Morgan-Bennett; aunt and uncle, E.G. and Teena Spaulding; cousin, Kenneth Spaulding, M.D.; and loving caregiver of 20 years, Willie Mae Bryant. A memorial service will take place on Saturday, May 21st, at 2 PM, at the NYC Riverside Church. Donations may be made in her name to support stem cell or multiple sclerosis research at Mt. The Listings: May 20-May 26; MATHIEU AMALRIC
description: In Arnaud Desplechin's sprawling, tumultuous melodrama "Kings and Queen," Mr. Amalric (above right, with Valentin Lelong) gives a brilliantly comic performance as a manic violist who is committed to an asylum against his will. Mr. Amalric, who won a 2005 Csar award for Best Actor for the role, has been called "the Jean-Pierre Laud of the 90's," and just as that actor became Franois Truffaut's nervous muse in a series of films spanning decades, Mr. Amalric seems destined to continue into the 21st century as Mr. Desplechin's filmic alter ego. In their last collaboration, "My Sex Life, or How I Got Into an Argument" (1996), Mr. Amalric played a doctoral candidate in philosophy who has a nervous breakdown while writing his thesis; somehow, he managed to make writer's block both suspenseful and slyly funny. Mr. Amalric, like Mr. Laud (with whom he has appeared twice, in "Diary of a Seducer" and "L'Affaire Marcorelle"), specializes in playing a distinctly French kind of hero: an intellectual paralyzed by his own introspection, simultaneously antic and morose. Mr. Amalric, 39, may have a genetic predisposition toward such roles; his father is an editor of the French left-wing newspaper Liberation, while his mother is a literary critic for Le Monde. In addition to writing and directing three films of his own, he's also taught at La Femis, the Parisian film school associated with the so-called New New Wave of French filmmaking (exemplified by such directors as Mr. Desplechin and Oliver Assayas, who cast Mr. Amalric as the irresolute hero of "Late August, Early September" in 1998.) Mr. Amalric can currently be seen at Cannes in "Le Moustache," the first feature film directed by the novelist Emmanuel Carrre, in which he again plays opposite Emmanuelle Devos, the formidable female lead of both "My Sex Life" and "Kings and Queen." (Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, Broadway near 63rd Street, (212)757-2280; Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, (212)924-3363.) DANA STEVENS

title: The Listings: May 20-May 26; TYLER MAYNARD
description: The sweetly irreverent new musical "Altar Boyz," about a boy band singing Jesus's praises over a funky bass line, gives all five of its proselytizing pretty boys a chance to twinkle in the spotlight. But none grabs it quite as ferociously as Tyler Maynard, above. The whippet-thin, toothy Mr. Maynard plays Mark, the ingratiatingly peppy band member who has a not-so-secret, dogmatically incorrect crush on Matthew, the band's slickly hunky lead singer. Mark's looks of puppyish adoration grow more fierce as the musical proceeds, and his claws come out when Matthew aims a sincere serenade to a girl in the audience. Mark also performs the show's single funniest song, a rousing anthem in which he comes out -- as a Catholic. Mr. Maynard's deliciously overwrought performance is both an affectionate tribute to and a parody of "American Idol"-style vocal histrionics. It typifies the sly manner in which the musical manages to exploit the appeal of the pop genre it's parodying even as it accentuates its silliness. title: The Listings: May 20-May 26; CHUNKY MOVE
description: Expect choreographic adventures. Contemporary Australian dance companies are known for their heartiness, and this one from Melbourne is considered especially bold. It's appearing here in the New York premiere of "Tense Dave" (above), which promises to be a dance-theater piece that travels through a strange and fractured world of fears, paranoia and unfulfilled fantasies. The journey is being guided by a team headed by Gideon Obarzanek, the company's artistic director; Lucy Guerin, a prominent Australian choreographer; and Michael Kantor, a theater director trained in Melbourne and Paris. "Tense Dave" is set on a continually revolving stage in which spaces are revealed and then obscured as the protagonist is drawn into emotional dramas and confusions filled with images of obsession, isolation, manipulation and collisions. Psychological intrigues are rife. Encounters are wild. And what appears to be reality is deceptive. Five dancers create the turbulence, and original music by Franc Tetaz helps make this theatrical odyssey quite a trip. Chunky Move seeks to explore the myriad possibilities of contemporary dance in Australia, and its productions try to be diverse in both form and content. "Tense Dave" is considered the most theatrically elaborate work to date by this company founded by Mr. Obarzanek in 1995. (Opens Wednesday, through June 11, at 7:30 p.m., Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212)924-0077 or www.dtw.org, $23, $14 students and 65+. The company repeats "Tense Dave" at the American Dance Festival, Durham, N.C., June 20 to 22, and the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, Becket, Mass., June 30 to July 3.) JACK ANDERSON

description: Time Warner, having pared its debt by $11 billion in three years, plans to start paying the company's first quarterly dividend since it was acquired by America Online four years ago. The company has considered selling a stake in AOL to the public and has concluded that the move is not currently necessary, the chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, said at Time Warner's annual meeting in New York. The dividend, 5 cents a share, will start in September and will yield 1.1 percent for shareholders. The company has not paid a dividend since December 2000.

title: Big-Band Music Without the Weight of Nostalgia
description: You have to work a little at understanding Thad Jones, the trumpeter and composer. He arrived in New York in 1954, a decade after bebop exploded. He spent nine years playing and arranging with the Count Basie band, and made some lovely but generally overlooked small-group records under his own name. In the mid-1960's, when so much jazz was open-ended, small-group expressionism, he directed all his energies toward an immaculately sculptured big band.

title: The Yuan Diversion
description: The get-tough-on-China talk got tougher this week when Treasury Secretary John Snow announced that China risks being branded a currency manipulator -- and thus subject to sanctions -- unless it acts soon to increase the fixed exchange rate between its currency, the yuan, and the United States dollar. Mr. Snow was echoing American manufacturers and some members of Congress who complain that China is undervaluing the yuan to artificially depress its export prices. But his aim is only partly to prod China. By demanding action, he is also trying to defuse growing anti-Chinese sentiment, as evidenced by the Senate's threat last month to slap punitive tariffs on Chinese goods unless the yuan is revalued.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Girl, 16, Held In 'Happy Slap' Attack
description: A 16-year-old girl was arrested and charged with being part of a group of youths that attacked another girl in Manchester while filming the incident on a mobile telephone. The victim, 16-year-old Becky Smith, was briefly knocked out and spent two days in the hospital with head injuries. The assault was the latest example of an apparent British craze known as "happy slapping," in which youths randomly attack passers-by and then use their mobile phones to circulate pictures of the victims. Miss Smith's mother, Georgina, said that video phones should be banned from schools. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; 'CSI' Buries 'Apprentice'
description: On Thursday night, CBS was No.1 in all of the crucial Nielsen estimates and drew more than twice as many viewers as NBC, its closest competition. CBS's two-hour season finale of "CSI," directed by Quentin Tarantino, above right, brought in an average audience of 30.05 million, and its viewership grew in every half-hour: from 9:30 to 10 p.m., 35.15 million were watching "CSI." Notably, those people were not watching the finale of NBC's "Apprentice," which brought in 13.7 million viewers. Among adults 18 to 49, the hiring of Kendra Todd drew 22 percent fewer viewers than the second season's finale, and 55 percent fewer than the conclusion of Season 1. The departure of Dr. Carter (Noah Wyle) on "ER" brought NBC its only victory on Thursday; it was No.1 for its hour among 18- to 49-year-olds. KATE AURTHUR

title: World Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: 'Condor' Charges For Ex-Leader
description: A prosecutor filed charges of murder against former President Juan Mara Bordaberry and his foreign minister, Juan Carlos Blanco, in the 1976 killings of two prominent political leaders then in exile in Argentina. Their bodies, along with those of two members of the left-wing Tupamaro guerrilla group, were found after they were abducted from their homes in Buenos Aires in what is believed to be one of the earliest actions undertaken by Operation Condor, the name given to cooperative efforts by the secret police of six South American dictatorships to eliminate one another's exiled political opponents. Leavitt, the secretary of health and human services, will appoint up to 15 voting members of the commission, including current or former governors and state Medicaid directors. description: Johnson & Johnson, the drug maker, said federal regulators rejected its application to market the antipsychotic drug Risperdal as an autism treatment. The Food and Drug Administration sent the company a "not approvable" letter in response to the application, Johnson & Johnson said. Risperdal is Johnson & Johnson's second-best-selling drug after the Procrit treatment for anemia in cancer patients. A company spokesman, Doug Arbesfeld, said the company would decide on its next step after it finished evaluating the letter.

title: On the 'Nuclear' Brink
description: The judicial nominations debate reached a new low this week when a Republican senator compared his Democratic colleagues to Hitler. This rampage by the Republican majority, driven by a zeal to eliminate the Democrats' voice in the appointment of judges, poses a real danger of permanently damaging the system of checks and balances at the heart of American democracy. It is encouraging that moderates from both parties are trying to work out a compromise. But they should agree only to one that does not make unacceptable concessions on Senate procedures and does not lead to the appointment of unqualified, ideologically extreme judges.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: De Klerk Protests 'Tshwane'
description: A long-running furor over plans to change the name of the capital, Pretoria, to Tshwane boiled over after F.W. de Klerk, the last president under apartheid, called on the government to abandon the renaming. Mr. de Klerk, who won the 1993 Nobel Peace Prize with Nelson Mandela for his role in ending apartheid, said that the name Pretoria had "a central and honorable place in our history," reflecting South Africans' triumph against British colonialism. Pretoria was named for Andries Pretorius, a prominent Afrikaner figure. But he is best known for the 1838 Battle of Blood River, so named because a river ran red with Zulu blood. The city council voted in March to rename the city Tshwane, after a chief who ruled in the area in the 1800's. Michael Wines (NYT)

Arts, Briefly; Indictment on Antiquities
description: Two years after Marion True, the curator of antiquities at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, was indicted in Rome on charges of receiving stolen antiquities for the Getty, the Italian authorities have ordered her to stand trial on July 18. The case grew out of a 10-year investigation into the trafficking of ancient artifacts. Both Dr. True and the museum deny the charges. A statement released by the museum yesterday said: "The Getty has cooperated fully with Italian authorities in this matter. During the course of the Italian authorities' preliminary investigation, the Getty reviewed and provided to the prosecutors thousands of pages and documents from our files. We trust that this trial will result in her exoneration and end further damage to the personal and professional reputation of Dr. True." Dr. True is traveling in Greece and could not be reached for comment. CAROL VOGEL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMMER, EMANUEL F., PH.D.
description: HAMMER -- Emanuel F., Ph.D., on May 18th, 2005. Distinguished psychologist, author and teacher. An innovative thinker in the field of Projective Drawing Technique, Dr. Hammer made multi-faceted contributions to the field of psychology through his authorship of 15 books, numerous publications and his therapeutic practice over more than 50 years with diverse populations from children, to prisoners and other institutionalized people, to the many clients who came through his door for individual therapy. Among his many accomplishments, Dr. Hammer was known as: Diplomate in Clinical Psychology, Fellow of the American Psychological Association, Supervisor at the New York University School of Arts and Sciences, Faculty Member and Training Analyst at the National Association for Psychoanalysis, creator of the Institute for Projective Drawings and as a psychoanalyst in private practice. Dr. Hammer's expertise in, and sensitive understanding of, the nuanced use of the expressive tools of personality assessment influenced several generations of clinicians and therapists, most recently in the field of Art Therapy. He leaves behind his cherished family including his wife, Lila, his children, Diane and Cary, his daughter-in-law, Nadine, his grandchildren, Milo and Kirby, and his daughter - in - law, Patty. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, May 22nd, at 11:15 AM, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Beloved aunt of Thomas Lally, Jr., Karen Lally Colfer, Peter Lally, Dennis Lally, Richard Lally, Martin Lally and the late Maureen Lally. Winifred was a former Asst. Administrator and Commissioner in the N.Y.C. Human Resources Administration for many years. She was a graduate and member of The Hall of Fame for Hunter College and the Fordham Graduate School of Social Services. She carried a major responsibility for the establishment of the first child abuse registry in the City. Commissioner Lally also served for many years at Catholic Charities, both in Child Welfare and Adult Services. She was well known in American public welfare and served on the Advisory Board of its journal, as well as Vice Chairman of the N.Y.C. Committee on Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Substance Abuse. Winifred was a gentle and loving person who touched the lives of many people. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, (at 20th St) Monday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10AM at Epiphany Church, 2nd Ave and 22nd St. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery, Queens, N.Y.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: State Repeals Indian Ban
description: The state has formally repealed a law that made it illegal for Indians to enter Boston. The Massachusetts General Court enacted the law, the Indian Imprisonment Act, in 1675, during King Philip's War, a conflict between Indians and settlers. It has not been enforced for centuries. Mayor Thomas M. Menino filed a petition to repeal it last fall. The legislature and Gov. Mitt Romney acted on the issue this week after Unity, a minority journalists group, threatened to withdraw Boston from its list of potential sites for its 2008 convention. Katie Zezima (NYT)

The festival is also negotiating with the city for land adjacent to the theater, where it hopes to build a headquarters. title: Business Briefs | Former Energy Trader Pleads Guilty in Price Conspiracy
description: Brion S. McKenna, a former energy trader at the Williams Companies, pleaded guilty to manipulating natural gas prices in 2001 by submitting false pricing information to a trade publication. At a hearing in San Francisco, Mr. McKenna told Judge Susan Illston of Federal District Court that he conspired to drive up gas prices by reporting false trading data to Inside FERC Gas Market Report, a power industry publication. He pleaded guilty to one count of manipulating the price of a commodity. Mr. McKenna faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $500,000 fine.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Archdiocese Settles With Insurer
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston has reached an $8.5 million settlement with a former insurance carrier over the settlement of sexual abuse claims against members of the clergy. The company, St. Paul Travelers, which covered the archdiocese in the 1980's, also agreed to waive premiums the archdiocese would have owed. Some of the claims involved were part of an $85 million settlement the archdiocese brokered in 2003 with more than 540 people who say they were abused by priests. The archdiocese settled with another former insurer, Lumbermen's Mutual Casualty Company, for $20 million in March. Katie Zezima (NYT)

description: Military rescue teams that have been searching for more than 40 soldiers, inexperienced conscripts missing in the Andes since Wednesday in a blizzard, remain hampered by what Gen. Juan Emilio Cheyre, the armed forces commander, called a "snow tsunami." The military recovered the bodies of at least five soldiers who froze to death, and the missing soldiers are most probably dead, the general said. Responding to mounting public criticism, Minister of Defense Jaime Ravinet blamed bad judgment by military field officers and promised an investigation to name and punish those responsible. title: Amid Distortion, Notes of Wistful Clarity
description: It was a big night for reverb on Wednesday at Webster Hall, where Doves, from Manchester, England, and Mercury Rev, from Kingston, N.Y., shared a double bill. Clouds of resonance surrounded their instruments and voices, making the songs larger than life, haloed in consonance. The echoey recesses of the songs could suggest both sanctuaries and lost paradises; they also opened up in vast, dramatic surges.

title: Discovering unexpected gems
World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 4 Fired In Antelope Slaughter
description: Four laborers at the famed Kruger National Park were arrested and then fired after luring at least six impala antelopes into a park laundry and beating the animals to death, park officials said. The workers skinned the animals, apparently intending to harvest their meat for consumption or sale. The park's executive director, Bandile Mkhize, said in a statement that he was horrified by the "intense cruelty" of the incident. The men have been charged with poaching and may also face charges under national animal cruelty laws. Big-game poaching is rare in South Africa, but poaching of small game for meat remains a problem. Michael Wines (NYT)

Before undergoing a risky operation in Lyon, he wrote an anxious letter to his son, Pierre, insisting, "I love my family, truly, dearly and profoundly." He left another letter, to be delivered in the event of his death, making peace with Amlie.

title: Islam Can Vote, if We Let It
description: Cairo - IN last month's Saudi Arabian municipal elections, the nation's first experiment in real democracy, many were worried because Islamic activists dominated their secular rivals. Indeed, we have seen a similar trend in Turkey, Morocco and Iraq in the last few years; and we can expect it in the coming Lebanese, Palestinian and Egyptian elections. Yet, while this Islamic trend can no longer be ignored, neither should it be a source of panic to Western policy makers and pundits.

title: A Doctor -Lawyer-Gadfly v. Canada's Medical System

title: You Really Can't Be Too Rich
description: WAS there always this much pressure to get rich? Achieving wealth has long been part of the American dream, but now you're expected to want to marry a millionaire, be a "Survivor," win "American Idol" -- or at least look as if you know people who know Paris Hilton. Even personal finance books, which once just explained how to manage money, now insist that you do whatever it takes to get rich.

Celanese's biggest minority shareholder, Paulson & Company, an investment firm based in New York, wanted a higher price.

title: Code Pink for Pork
description: The public can be cheered by the House's approval of a bill aimed at the five-alarm homeland confusion that's unleashed every time the government resorts to its antiterrorism color code. The code is a running joke, not an informative gauge of risk, and the House is directing that future alerts be tailored more to specific intelligence warnings for the cities and regions most affected. Would that Congress would take the same approach with the $2-billion-plus homeland security budget and direct the money to the cities and regions most threatened, rather than passing it around to places like Martha's Vineyard.

title: Business Briefs | Jury Awards $128 Million in Wireless Patent Case
description: Cingular Wireless, the mobile phone carrier, and the Boston Communications Group were ordered by a jury to pay $128 million in damages for infringing a patent owned by Freedom Wireless. The verdict, reached in the United States District Court in Boston, named Cingular, its AT&T Wireless unit, Boston Communications, Western Wireless and CMT Partners. The closely held Freedom Wireless sued Boston Communications and cellular carriers in 2000, claiming Boston Communications' prepaid wireless services infringed two patents. The dispute is over prepaid services that let consumers pay for calls upfront, rather than sign up for a monthly plan, and then use the calling minutes without having to enter a pass code. A Cingular spokesman, Mark Siegel, said the company intended to appeal.

Mr. Hazel and another trustee also suggested that the Corcoran's president and director, David C. Levy, resign, The Post reported. Mr. Levy declined but said he would step aside if the dispute became rancorous. After more than two years of design and program development with Mr. Gehry, the Corcoran board approved plans to build a second and final wing in 1999 that would add about 140,000 square feet. Business Briefs | Bank of Japan Makes Subtle Shift in Reserve Control
description: The Bank of Japan held interest rates just a fraction above zero yesterday and maintained the target for reserves it makes available to banks. But the bank also said it would allow those reserves to fall short of its target under certain circumstances. The change comes just a few days after the government said the economy grew at a faster-than-expected annual pace of 5.3 percent in the first quarter, the strongest growth in a year. Some economists said the move could mean the Bank of Japan realizes that a tighter monetary policy is likely in the near future. "This is very symbolic in a sense that this is a turning point," Masaaki Kanno, a former Bank of Japan official and chief economist at JP Morgan Securities Asia, told Reuters. "At the same time, it will take more than a year to see the end" of the current policy. The central bank governor, Toshihiko Fukui, above, emphasized that the change was technical and did not reflect a new direction for monetary policy. Todd Zaun (NYT)

Hotel Victor in Miami Beach
description: THE BASICS Can the Victor bring the heat back to Ocean Drive? Twenty years ago, when South Beach was being revitalized by model agencies looking for cheap digs and young New Yorkers flocking there for weekend getaways, most people stayed at the refurbished Art Deco hotels that lined Ocean Drive. But since then, the action has largely shifted north, to the glittering hotel row on Collins Avenue, home to the Delano, the Raleigh and, most recently, the Setai - leaving Ocean Drive to the rowdy partygoers cruising the street in their Hummers, their sound systems jacked up to ear-splitting levels. The Victor, which opened in February (with a highly publicized party that drew the ire of animal rights activists protesting the gimmick of having penguins in the hotel pool), bucks that migration by offering a lushly designed haven - the first hotel project in the United States by the Parisian decorator Jacques Garcia, of Htel Costes fame - for guests who want to feel like reverse pioneers.

title: TBR: Inside the List
description: ROAD TO WELLVILLE: Michael F. Roizen and Mehmet C. Oz's new book, "You: The Owner's Manual," enters the hardcover advice list this week at No. 1 -- with not a little help from Oprah Winfrey, who invited the authors on her program for an hourlong wellness pep rally. "Health is it, baby," Oprah said at the outset. "Health is everything. Health beats shoes." Roizen and Oz are both doctors (Oz is also the host of a medical show on the Discovery Channel), and their book is a jargon-free, if mildly corny, assortment of health advice and trivia. (Typical sentence: "Gallstones and the Rolling Stones aren't the only stones that can change your life.") "You: The Owner's Manual" covers the waterfront, body-wise, but on Oprah's show a good deal of the talk was about keeping your colon healthy -- "I never thought I'd be discussing this on TV," Oprah exclaimed. Oz was involved with the team at New York-Presbyterian Hospital that performed the recent quadruple bypass operation on former President Bill Clinton, and Clinton made a taped guest appearance on the show. "He's the president of the United States," Oz said, "and he's as well tested as you can be . . . you cannot test for safety. You've got to live to be safe." Along the way, Oprah tossed out 12 words that put the post-Atkins-diet book industry on full alert. "Whole grains," she explained, "are going to become what the carb craze has been."

title: Night Moves
description: For 10 years, the photographer Elinor Carucci has moonlighted as a Middle Eastern dancer. She has performed several nights a week, as many as six or seven times a night, shuttling from weddings to anniversary celebrations, bar mitzvahs to birthday parties. The venues, throughout New York City and parts of New Jersey, range from high-end restaurants to dance halls to dives; the audiences are American, Arab, Greek, Turkish, Chinese, Indian. Carucci, a 33-year-old native Israeli, began studying belly dancing when she was 20. Last August, she gave birth to twins and has now resumed dancing. From 2000 to 2003, Carucci photographed her night job. She initially used a 35-millimeter camera for small, narrowly composed shots, typically of her preparations -- in restrooms, on the subway -- for her next performance. Eventually she added a panoramic camera, which allowed her to capture the often raucous and carnival-like atmosphere of her evenings.

description: Claudine Froger, a retired university administrator from Paris. But, in fact, I wasn't scared at all, which was pretty surprising, because at times they were very close to the boat. Our guide, Ramn, was used to it. He had been born on the reserve, had lived there for 70 years, so we felt very confident around him. At one point, using a fishing line, he caught a piranha. Then he dangled it over the water so we could get a photo when a crocodile sprang from the water with its jaws open to catch the fish. Maybe he did that every day. I don't know. title: Unsettling In

Although it is the middle of the night, light from the street has bathed my room in hazy half dawn, so at first I am disoriented, unclear of where I am, or who or what is causing the racket. For a moment, I think I'm still in North Fork, the town in the Sierra Nevada foothills in California I left three months before with both my 10-year marriage and my writing career in shambles. But at this moment I am unsure of where I am. I imagine a clear night under a full moon, and there's a raccoon in the yellow pine outside the window snarling at some foe. Maybe a bear has come down from the high country in search of food. It has been a dry year, and forage is scarce. Then the voices from outside the window jolt me awake.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: HOLY SKIRTS. By Ren Steinke. (Morrow, $24.95.) In her second novel, Steinke has resurrected a genuine Personality, a stylish eccentric who might have been a staple of the tabloid gossip columns, had they existed a century ago. Elsa von Freytag-Loringhoven was a real-life German migr turned baroness; in Steinke's fiction, her adventures begin in 1904 when she's an impoverished naf working as a "living statue" at the Wintergarten Cabaret in Berlin. After many lovers, two marriages and a tempestuous union with the penniless Baron von Freytag-Loringhoven, Elsa finds herself alone in a jail cell in Greenwich Village. Undaunted, she goes on to become the Courtney Love of her time: hanging out with Marcel Duchamp, composing poems that are like "small explosions" for The Little Review, parading through the streets in outrageous costumes (a car's blinking tail light for a bustle, a dress covered with bits of newspaper) -- and trying not to succumb to the madness that destroyed her mother. All this is presented in the kind of detail that might easily seem precious but is redeemed by Steinke's talent for description. Unapologetic and unabashed, her Baroness Elsa is a woman who does what she has to do -- and doesn't always mind doing -- to survive.

title: Can You Catch Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder?
description: To suffer from obsessive-compulsive disorder, many patients say, is to "know you are crazy." Other forms of psychosis may envelop the sufferers until they inhabit the delusion. Part of the torture of O.C.D. is, as patients describe it, watching as if from the outside as they act out their obsessions -- knowing that they are being irrational, but not being able to stop. They describe thoughts crowding their minds, nattering at them incessantly -- anxious thoughts, sexual thoughts, violent thoughts, sometimes all at the same time. Is the front door locked? Are there germs on my hands? Am I a murderer if I step on an ant? And they describe increasingly elaborate rituals to assuage those thoughts -- checking and rechecking door locks, washing and rewashing hands, walking carefully, slowly and in bizarre patterns to avoid stepping on anything. They feel driven to do things they know make no sense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MITTELMAN, EUGENE
description: MITTELMAN--Eugene. After a brave battle with cancer, Eugene Mittelman died on May 19 at Beth Israel Medical Center, surrounded by family and friends. He was born in 1935 in New York. He received his BA degree from Bard College and his law degree, as a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar, from Columbia University. From 1967 until the mid-1970's he served as Minority Counsel to the US Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee, appointed by Jacob K. Javits. During those years he helped to shape major pieces of progressive labor legislation. Subsequently, he entered private practice, specializing in labor issues and litigation in Washington, DC and New York City, most recently with the firm of Maidman and Mittelman. He lived his life with great passion, and he will be sorely missed. He is survived by his wife Frances, daughters Karen and Deborah, his mother Marion Banks, cousin Jim Blue, and grandson Jacob Mittelman. Depending on your political persuasion, that meant liberating the Senate, and the people's will, from an obstructionist minority or, on the other side, damaging the Senate and threatening one of the nation's fundamental protections against the tyranny of the majority.

title: DREAM PRODUCTIONS

In a society of extreme makeovers that values looks over talent and packaging over content, a reminder that true beauty and substance lie within is long overdue. Robin Williams would be my choice for Cyrano. He possesses all the wit, poetry and panache for the role. (When was the last time you met someone with panache?) title: The Fathers' Crusade
description: Dominus's insightful article highlights how current family law rewards custodial parents who maximize conflict. One thing on which all the social scientists agree is that parental conflict is bad for children in divorced families. If, instead, family-court judges created financial or other incentives linked to each parent's willingness to work together, high-conflict divorce might largely disappear -- to the benefit of the children, the parents and the courts.

title: Hotel Victor in Miami Beach
description: THE BASICS -- Can the Victor bring the heat back to Ocean Drive? Twenty years ago, when South Beach was being revitalized by model agencies looking for cheap digs and young New Yorkers flocking there for weekend getaways, most people stayed at the refurbished Art Deco hotels that lined Ocean Drive. But since then, the action has largely shifted north, to the glittering hotel row on Collins Avenue, home to the Delano, the Raleigh and, most recently, the Setai -- leaving Ocean Drive to the rowdy partygoers cruising the street in their Hummers, their sound systems jacked up to ear-splitting levels. The Victor, which opened in February (with a highly publicized party that drew the ire of animal rights activists protesting the gimmick of having penguins in the hotel pool), bucks that migration by offering a lushly designed haven -- the first hotel project in the United States by the Parisian decorator Jacques Garcia, of Htel Costes fame-- for guests who want to feel like reverse pioneers.

title: Is Le Marche the Next Tuscany?
description: "I BRING you a taste of my verdicchio," says our host as my friend Laurie and I sit down to dinner beside a murmuring fire. We're in the timber-and-stone dining room of a 250-year-old farmhouse whose owners, Mario and Mara Boria have converted into a casual, eight-room agriturismo outside the small Italian town of Castelraimondo. Mario brings a liter of a pale white wine, and places it on the table, beaming.

title: Queen of the Hamlet
description: Supersuccessful entrepreneurs may differ in personality, but they all have one trait in common: a striking lack of self-doubt. Where the dreams and goals of others become immobilized by too much analysis and worry, the enterprising businesswoman (or -man) lives in a state of blue-sky possibility. "It's true," said Marilyn Lewis, over a lunch of raw oysters at Kate Mantilini's, the Beverly Hills restaurant she owns with her husband, Harry. "I've never had doubt." At 73, Lewis, who is tall and willowy and has almost orange hair, has had several lives -- restaurateur, fashion designer, movie producer -- all of which required talent, hard work and extraordinary instinct. "I just know when something seems right," she said, glancing around the large, highly designed room, which has exposed metal beams and angular postmodern architectural elements mixed with an almost Deco-diner-like quality. "This was once a bank," she continued. "And when we opened Kate Mantilini's in the 80's, everyone was doing things in aquamarine and serving fish. I said, 'I want a long counter, and I want comfort food.' Harry said, 'I don't know."' Lewis smiles. "Well, one day we were out at the beach, and I saw this oxidized door on the front of a restaurant called 72 Market Street. I said: 'Who did that door? We have to get him to design the new restaurant.' I found out it was Thom Mayne, and he said, yes, he would design the restaurant. Now it's 20 years later, and he just won the Pritzker Prize."

title: 'A Church That Can and Cannot Change'
description: The inventor of the idea that Christian doctrinedevelops is John Henry Newman. Ignoring the boast ofBossuet that doctrine is unchanging, escaping the thintheorizing that would restrict development to amovement from the implicit to the explicit, Newmanpointed to transformations of doctrine as tangible andas organic, as many-sided and complex and real, as thepassage from childhood to adulthood. An Anglicanarguing his way into the Catholic Church, Newman sawthat the anomalies and novelties of his new spiritualhome were the marks of vigor, of maturity, of beingalive. What Newman noticed and defended were changesin the ways that piety was expressed, in the rulesguiding the governance of the Church, in theunderstanding of the nature of Christ. What he spentno time in either enumerating or explaining werechanges in the rules of moral conduct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMMER, EMANUEL F., PH.D.
description: HAMMER -- Emanuel F., Ph.D., on May 18th, 2005. Distinguished psychologist, author and teacher. An innovative thinker in the field of Projective Drawing Technique, Dr. Hammer made multi-faceted contributions to the field of psychology through his authorship of 15 books, numerous publications and his therapeutic practice over more than 50 years with diverse populations from children, to prisoners and other institutionalized people, to the many clients who came through his door for individual therapy. Among his many accomplishments, Dr. Hammer was known as: Diplomate in Clinical Psychology, Fellow of the American Psychological Association, Supervisor at the New York University School of Arts and Sciences, Faculty Member and Training Analyst at the National Association for Psychoanalysis, creator of the Institute for Projective Drawings and as a psychoanalyst in private practice. Dr. Hammer's expertise in, and sensitive understanding of, the nuanced use of the expressive tools of personality assessment influenced several generations of clinicians and therapists, most recently in the field of Art Therapy. He leaves behind his cherished family including his wife, Lila, his children, Diane and Cary, his daughter-in-law, Nadine, his grandchildren, Milo and Kirby, and his daughter - in - law, Patty. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, May 22nd, at 11:15 AM, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: 'The Good, the Bad, and Me'
description: UNION STREET was a wide main artery running from Prospect Park past Park Slope down to the docks of the East River. Number 166 housed Bertha's, a small toy, candy, and stationery store named for my mother. A long glass counter ran the length of the store. There was an icebox for soda pop and a pay telephone. On the back wall of the store were shelves, which held toys, big jars of Indian nuts, and cigarettes. The store was always busy in the late afternoons, when longshoremen would drop in after a day of unloading ships' cargo. Over their shoulders, many of them would carry big crooked iron hooks, which seemed to be part of their uniform. They'd drink sodas, make phone calls, buy cigarettes, eat the tiny Indian nuts, then spit the shells all over the floor.

description: The Kimpton Hotel Group has expanded its Gay Pride celebration packages this summer to include properties in 14 cities across North America -- up from nine in 2004. The packages, available at 24 hotels, will include gifts like spa treatments in Chicago, $50 dining certificates in Seattle and free cocktails in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAYLOR, HARRY
description: TAYLOR--Harry. May 20, 1905-May 18, 2005. Born in Montreal, resided in Middle Village and Bayside, Queens for 70 years and Deerfield Beach, FL for 30 years. Husband to the late Jeanne for 64 years. Survived by sons, Arthur of NY and Bruce of Ohio, and five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Legacy of honesty, strength, dedication and self-reliance. Services Parkside Memorial, Forest Hills, Sunday 11:30AM.
