description: Correction Appended

title: 'Against Depression': Anatomy of Severe Melancholy
description: AGAINST DEPRESSION By Peter D. Kramer. 353 pp. Viking. $25.95.

title: Gargoyles and Glockenspiel
description: AS the Cielo, a 28-story condominium, neared completion at York Avenue and East 83rd Street, Jules Demchick, the project's developer, heard more and more complaints about the view directly across from the new lobby: a graffiti-scarred tenement wall.

title: The Goodspeed Squeeze: Small Space, Big Productions
description: THE Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam holds a little jewel box of a theater on the fourth floor. The 1877 theater, listed for three decades on the National Register of Historic Places, has long been lauded for its charm, which means it is smaller than just about any professional stage.

title: From a Palace of Spectacles to an Edifice of Offices
description: Correction Appended

title: Miraculous Recovery Isn't Really a Shock
description: BALTIMORE, May 21 - In Afleet Alex's short life, he has already been part of two touching stories. He is credited with helping keep alive the spirit of a girl who died of cancer and with inspiring a breeder who is fighting cancer.

title: The Check? It's Lost. It's in the Mail. Maybe the Dog Ate It.
description: When a bill payment is late, the check, of course, is in the mail. (Where else?) But the more profound question is where on earth that bill was in the first place, and it is this cosmic issue that Visa USA tackles in a new survey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, ARNOLD
description: GREENBERG--Arnold. Beloved husband of Jane. Adored father of Steven Greenberg, Jeffrey Greenberg and Melinda and David Morris. Dear brother of Beverly and George Paul. He will be greatly missed. Services at Gutterman's in Woodbury on Sunday, May 22, noon.

title: Making Art Amid The Ruins
description: ASBURY PARK - THIS city of about 17,000 people is best known as a crumbling shore town that time, race riots and poverty have left in disrepair, if not despair. But these days it is also home to Robert Melee, a well-known artist who made a tidy sum -- he declined to say how much -- from a sale of his artwork to the British collector Charles Saatchi. (Mr. Saatchi is the guy who recently resold Damien Hirst's famous 14-foot tiger shark encased in formaldehyde to an American collector for $10 million.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 1 about Mustique, in the Caribbean, referred incorrectly to a meal included in the room rate of the Cotton House, the island's one hotel. It is afternoon tea. (High tea, served chiefly in Britain, is a more substantial early-evening meal.)

title: Albany's Duty on Birth Control
description: Bowing to the political and religious right, the Food and Drug Administration continues to dawdle over granting women over-the-counter access to the morning-after emergency contraceptive known as Plan B. This triumph of ideology over science is the impetus for important legislation pending in Albany that would permit pharmacists in New York State to dispense emergency contraception.

title: How Fourth Graders Fared on the State English Test
description: Many more New York City fourth graders passed the state's English Language Arts test this year than last year, representing the single biggest one-year increase since the test was first given in 1999. In all, 59.5 percent of them met the state reading and writing standards, up 9.9 percentage points from last year (chart on this page and Page 15).

title: TOPSY-TURVY
description: Making beds and picking up dirty towels is darned hard work. Just ask Jonathan Tisch.

title: Now Playing at Wesleyan
description: BY the late-1990's, Wesleyan's film department had gained national renown, as several of its graduates made it big in Hollywood.

title: 630 Symbols of Infinity
description: ARE diamonds really forever?

title: Going to Dubai
description: To the Editor: I wonder why Mr. Sherwood would omit the important information for the many Jewish readers of the New York Times that visas to visit Dubai are not granted to anybody with Israel stamps in their passport.

title: 'Follies': The Goddess of Small Things
description: FOLLIES New Stories. By Ann Beattie. 305 pp. Scribner. $25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYERS, RUTH
description: MEYERS--Ruth. Died peacefully on May 19, 2005. Devoted wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt and friend. Loving, kind and generous. Born in Brooklyn, a graduate of CCNY, she was a practicing CPA for over 50 years. Ruth will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to your favorite charity.

title: First, Know Where to Dig
description: I GREW up on Long Island. My father was a homicide cop who retired as a detective captain. I met a number of F.B.I. agents through his work, and for a while I was interested in becoming one. Back then you needed an accounting degree or a law degree. I was ready to get my career started, so I stuck with my business major.

title: DREAM PRODUCTIONS
description: August Wilson's "Fences" starring Denzel Washington. He's old enough to play that now, and I think he's a brilliant stage actor. Of course, Denzel will be busy for the next few years and August would never let me direct it anyway, but you did say "dream" play, didn't you?

title: It's All Newsweek's Fault
description: IN the immediate aftermath of 9/11, Fareed Zakaria wrote a 6,791-word cover story for Newsweek titled "Why Do They Hate Us?" Think how much effort he could have saved if he'd waited a few years. As we learned last week, the question of why they hate us can now be answered in just one word: Newsweek.

title: Hot Stuff: Tuner Cars Turn Up All Over
description: NEW-CAR showrooms are full of special editions, models that carry the logos of clothing designers, outdoor outfitters or cartoon characters, or that commemorate pivotal moments in history like the Ironman triathlon or a made-for-television racing series. It is not unreasonable to wonder how low an automaker will stoop to persuade shoppers that a "limited edition" is genuinely special.

title: 'Maps for Lost Lovers'
Paid Notice: Deaths   SLATTERY, FRANCES H.
description: SLATTERY--Frances H. On May 20, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Gerald. Loving mother of Gerald (Adrianne) and Letitia (Kevin). Adored grandmother of Gerald, Tara, Moira, Greer, Robert and Ryan. Cherished great-grandmother and godmother of Matthew. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave (at 20th St) Monday, May 23, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 11am at Epiphany Church (2nd Ave at 22th St). Interment to follow at Long Island National Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Visiting Nurse Service or The Epiphany School Foundation, 234 East 22 St, NYC 10010.

title: He Helped Put the Blue in Blue Note
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS - IT is one of the cathedrals of jazz, Rudy Van Gelder's studio here, a sacred acoustic space where some of the music's giants and near giants have done their finest work: Sonny Rollins and Horace Silver, Art Blakey and Herbie Hancock, Antonio Carlos Jobim and George Benson and hundreds of others.

title: Normalizing Torture on '24'
description: THE acclaimed Fox series "24" has received a lot of attention over its four successful seasons: for its innovative real-time format, its braided storylines, its heady brew of national security and sentimentality, and its uncanny topicality. From Balkan nationalist revenge to rogue agents with biological weapons, wars on and of terror have been portrayed in exacting detail, shaping entertainment out of headlines that often stretch the imagination.

title: Battle in the Sound
description: The chorus of local opposition to a floating, Queen-Mary-size natural gas operation in the middle of Long Island Sound grew even louder last week, when the Suffolk County Legislature voted overwhelmingly to oppose the project and hire lawyers to fight it.

title: Recognizing Problems In the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: More Room To Grow Creatively
description: NORWALK, at the mouth of the Norwalk River, is best known as an old farming, manufacturing and oystering town abutting some of the most affluent ZIP codes in the country. Although there is a nascent arts district in the old downtown, the city is not well known as a refuge for artists. Yet it is home to Joe Fig, a 37-year-old New York City artist who sought to escape the punishing cycle of ever-rising rents and the monotonous grisaille of city buildings.

title: Nature as Muse and Siren
description: A few years ago, when I was writing a weekly column about the outdoors, I spent about 15 minutes on my hands and knees watching and photographing a beetle. That was when I really began to think about how nature influences art.

title: Safe and Sound
description: The long, halting campaign to protect and revitalize the shoreline and waters of Long Island Sound will get a welcome boost if Westchester County's Board of Legislators now commits the county to putting new effort and money into finally cleaning up Davids Island, the tarnished 78-acre jewel off New Rochelle.

title: Leonid Khachiyan Is Dead at 52; Advanced Computer Math
description: Leonid Khachiyan, a Russian-born mathematician who helped to advance the field of linear programming, which is used by computer scientists to schedule complex rosters of airline flights and to solve problems in finance and industry, died on April 29 at his home in South Brunswick, N.J. He was 52.

title: The Old And the Restless
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EASTMAN, MONIQUE DE T.
description: EASTMAN--Monique de T. The Board of Directors mourns the death of Monique de T. Eastman. Mrs. Eastman was a longtime supporter of CR & T and showed great concern for finding better and more complete treatments for cancer. As a cancer survivor herself, she gave encouragement and understanding through her support and participation in educational and research opportunities that addressed the needs of all people with the disease. She was taken too soon from her friends and family who will miss her smile and her grace even during troubling times. Cancer Research & Treatment Fund

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POWERS, HELEN WHITECOTTON
description: POWERS--Helen Whitecotton. Formerly of Cold Spring Harbor and Oyster Bay, NY died unexpectedly at her home in Chester, CT on May 17. She was 80 years old. She was the loving mother of 6 children: Diana, Flip, Arthur, Brian, Elizabeth and Christopher and grandmother of eight. Helen will be missed by her former husband Francis C. Powers of Manhattan. Daughter of Helen and Jay Arthur Whitecotton, of Southport and Paris, France, Helen was educated at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, NY and Barnard College. A memorial service is scheduled for July 30, 10:30 AM, St. Johns Church, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Johns Church.

title: Letters
description: Self-Publish or Perish

title: Needy Wetlands
description: While we're on the subject of enhancing the environment, we'd like to remind the State Senate -- and Gov. George Pataki -- of some unfinished legislative business. Before the Senate is a bill identical to one approved by the Assembly last year. It would provide important new protections to New York State's wetlands, including those in Westchester and Putnam Counties that are particularly crucial to the integrity and cleanliness of the watershed and thus New York City's drinking water supply.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit in The Metro Section last Sunday with an article about 32 newly discovered works said to be by Jackson Pollock was published in error. As the article said, the Pollock-Krasner Foundation has asked that its name not be attached to images of those paintings because it has not authenticated them. It says it is reserving judgment. (Go to Article)

title: In Nascar, the Bigger the Space the Better
description: MOORESVILLE, N.C., May 18 - Roger Penske could park a 747 in the race shop of his new team headquarters in North Carolina's Nascar hub. The garage area alone is longer than a football field.

title: Stem Cell Researchers Feel the Pull of the Golden State
description: Up and down the East Coast, stem cell researchers are feeling the tug of a powerful, invisible force. It is a wave of recruiting calls from institutions in California seeking to expand their research programs with help from Proposition 71, the state's $3 billion stem cell initiative.

title: The Incredibles . . .
description: Correction Appended

title: A Lost Mexican Wine
description: To the Editor: "In Tequila's Home, a Wine Region Comes of Age," by Janelle Brown (May 1), reminded me of when I was on assignment in Tampico, Mexico, in 1970. Contrary to the article's statement that "Mexican wine was notoriously bad," I found vino Hidalgo (I believe from Monterrey), both the tinto, but especially the blanco, to be pleasant to drink.

title: 'Red Star Over Hollywood': A Fine Old Conflict
description: Correction Appended

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Voters have been fed a steady diet of Terri Schiavo, judicial wrangling and basic bickering. It is a pox on both of them."

title: First Victim in Judicial Fight: Congress's Image
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 - With the Senate filibuster fight approaching its climax, one of the biggest questions on Capitol Hill is: who's winning? At the moment, the answer appears to be no one -- at least from a political perspective.

title: Self-Publish or Perish
description: To the Editor:

title: Fourth and Eighth Graders Improve in State English Tests
description: SCORES in Westchester on fourth- and eighth-grade state English tests advanced strongly this year, more than making up for a slight drop in fourth-grade tests last year.

title: Katherine Henneman and Jonathan Kastellec
description: Katherine Lee Henneman, the daughter of Charlotte A. Henneman and Robert L. Henneman of Erie, Colo., was married yesterday in Manhattan to Jonathan Philip Kastellec, a son of Justice Megan Tallmer and Rick Kastellec of Manhattan. Justice Troy Karen Webber of State Supreme Court in the Bronx performed the civil ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia.

title: Gigi's Novel Life
description: "Write down that I actually eat bread. And butter."

title: Sunni Arabs Are Uniting to Compete With Shiites
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 21 - In a stark reversal from earlier this year, when Sunni Arabs boycotted national elections here, a broad gathering of Sunni sheiks, clerics and political leaders formed a political alliance on Saturday, seeking to win back the political ground they had lost to Shiites.

title: Eddie Barclay, Recording Magnate, Dies at 84
description: Eddie Barclay, who for three decades after World War II was arguably the most powerful music mogul in Europe and inarguably the most flamboyant, died on May 13 in Paris. He was 84.

title: The Fathers' Crusade
description: A 50-50 arrangement may seem fair by adult standards, but it can be physically taxing and emotionally draining for a child. Think of the ordeal of shifting homes every three to four days, of attending two schools and having two sets of playmates, sports and activities schedules, etc. Even in the best of circumstances, where the divorced parents get along (which is rare), children still have to meet two sets of expectations, negotiate perhaps two opposing sets of values, lifestyles, work schedules and so forth.

title: The Urbane Suburbanite
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of the Darkroom Age
description: AT the Westchester Art Workshop's photography seminar this spring, among the several dozen students were undergraduates with multiple piercings and retirees with none. That those students attended was nothing new; they have always been among the photographers who have traditionally been the workshop's bread and butter. It is the position that they are in that has changed.

title: Carol Campbell and Bill Boggs
description: Carol Edmunds Campbell, a publishing executive, and Bill Boggs, a television host, were married yesterday by the Rev. James L. Burns at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RISEMAN, CATHERINE E.
description: RISEMAN--Catherine E. On May 18, 2005 with grace and courage at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Devoted daughter of the late Mervin and Elaine Riseman. Beloved and loving sister of Margaret Bernstein. Cherished sister-in-law of James H. Bernstein. Adored aunt of Emily & Rebecca Bernstein. Family will receive friends on Sunday 2-5 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st St. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her memory to the Mt. Sinai Medical Center-Cardiovascular Institute, POB 1049, 1 Gustave Levy Pl., NY, NY 10029.

title: Want Your Letter to Stand Out? Here's a Tip: Write It Yourself
description: What makes a cover letter stand out from the hundreds that can inundate a hiring manager for even the lowest-paying entry-level positions? Some say a compelling first paragraph or an original way of expressing an idea can cut through the clutter.

title: Czannes of the Kitchen on the Art of the Plate
description: IT can be said that we all like a nice plate, but Maricel Presilla really likes plates. She likes plates in the way that Imelda Marcos likes shoes. Ms. Presilla was buying serene square plates and rectangular plates from a Japanese restaurant-supply store long before they became cool. Ms. Presilla likes plates so much, she says, that when she decided to open a couple of restaurants in northern New Jersey, her husband was mostly just relieved that her bags and boxes and packages of plates would stop coming to the house.

title: Paperback Row
Paid Notice: Deaths   ARNO, ALAN MARK
description: ARNO--Alan Mark. 67 years old, died on May 18, 2005. Beloved husband of Maxine E. Arno (nee Manoff). Devoted father of Michelle and Glenn Ward, Michael Arno and Elissa Miko. Loving son of Esther and the late Max E. Arno. Cherished brother of Susan and Murray Vogel. Dear brother-in-law of Jill and Jacob M. Gordon, adored uncle of Debbie and Don Martin, Richard and Pam Vogel, Jay and Sari Vogel, Amy Gordon and Matthew Gordon. Services Sunday, 2:30 PM at Temple Beth El of Boca Raton, 333 S.W. 4th Avenue, Boca Raton, FL.

title: Full Circle
description: The modernist California fashion designer Rudi Gernreich, visiting New York in 1970, remarked, "They are wearing their evening dresses during the day." Today full-tiered skirts are again sweeping Fifth Avenue. Designer versions are popping up at spring parties, below and left, some worn with wide leather belts, echoing the 1940's Mexican fiesta look.

title: An Australian Dance Troupe Learns Spin Control
description: NOBODY ever said the creative process is painless. But the dancers of Chunky Move, an Australian troupe known for its muscular style, have taken it on the chin. Working conditions got so tough during rehearsals for "Tense Dave," a haunting character study poised for a six-week American tour, that cast members experienced headaches, dizzy spells and bouts of nausea.

title: Back to College, Still in the Fray
description: Correction Appended

title: Buy! Sell! Hollywood Hand-Me-Downs
description: LOS ANGELES - WITH its white Spanish colonial facade, splashy window display and cool, airy interior, Decades Two on Melrose Avenue seems an unlikely gathering place for the obsessed. Yet here on a hot, sunny Saturday, shod in Jimmy Choos, Blue Cult jeans and Chlo tops, they are drawn to satisfy their desires.

title: There Ought to Be a Law?
description: Nineteen-year-old Kerry McLaughlin has received more than 100 complaints about the loud parties she has held in her apartment near Newcastle, England, over the past 18 months. It has been said that she invites 10-year-olds to get drunk, smashes windows and heaves trash cans at cars. But it was only after she roped a male acquaintance naked to a nearby lamppost and left him there that British tabloids started calling her an "ASBO queen."

title: Is It Worth It?
description: IT'S a springtime ritual: Like pollen shaking loose from the trees, many young Manhattan families are preparing to scatter toward the suburbs and a new phase of life. Others are merely thinking about it, wondering about the tradeoffs, and the psychic toll.

title: DANCE
description: Productions of "DON QUIXOTE" seem to be lurking behind every proscenium arch. AMERICAN BALLET THEATER gets the ball rolling on Tuesday with four performances staged by the company director KEVIN MCKENZIE and the ballet master SUSAN JONES. Then comes a much-talked-about revival of George Balanchine's darker "Don Quixote" staged by SUZANNE FARRELL for her company at the KENNEDY CENTER in Washington next month. Finally, the BOLSHOI BALLET -- where it all began in 1869 -- will weigh in with a new version by ALEKSEI FADEYECHEV that opens at the METROPOLITAN OPERA on July 18.

title: Emergency Measures
description: The Suffolk County Legislature took a good first step last week toward improving ambulance response times. It passed a bill to require local agencies to report data on emergency calls to the county every month, a perfectly sensible move that could help Suffolk fix the kinks in its balkanized, sprawling, often criticized all-volunteer ambulance system.

title: North Korean Ships Arrive in South Korea to Pick Up Fertilizer
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 22 - North Korean cargo ships docked in South Korean ports today for the first time in two decades to take home fertilizer urgently needed for crops to ease chronic food shortages.

title: Politics in Motion
description: THE six dancers of the Judy Dworin Performance Ensemble were improvising one rainy morning in early spring for their new dance piece, "Timeout," while Ms. Dworin sat on a folding chair against the wall of a hall at Trinity College in Hartford, calling out images of time to the dancers as they moved about the floor. The creator of the company, she no longer gets up to dance.

title: 'A Church That Can and Cannot Change': Dogma
description: A CHURCH THAT CAN AND CANNOT CHANGE The Development of Catholic Moral Teaching. By John T. Noonan Jr. 297 pp. A John W. Kluge Center Book/ University of Notre Dame Press. $30.

title: The Summer Sound
description: Here is a sampling of some Connecticut hip-hop acts performing this summer.

title: Annuities and Wolves
description: To the Editor:

title: Let the Fur Fly
description: It is strange that Daphne Merkin, while criticizing animal lovers, admits she would consider getting a dog to help her meet men (The Way We Live Now, May 1). The canine capability she is hoping to exploit, that of drawing people out of their shells, has long been recognized not only by urban divorcees but also by doctors treating everything from autism to depression to Alzheimer's. That is why you often see dogs in hospitals these days, and it is just one reason why so many humans admire them.

title: Not Just a Bunch of Yuppies
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   REICH, GILBERT AND THELMA
description: REICH--Gilbert and Thelma. Beloved parents. 10 years have passed as if in the blink of an eye, but time has not diminished the amount that I miss you. You are always in my thoughts and in my heart. Love, Nancy

title: The Fathers' Crusade
description: Thanks for Susan Dominus's important article (May 8). Divorced or separated fathers are routinely forced to the fringes of their children's lives and demoted to the role of visitor and wallet. I know. I'm one of them, and I will be joining Fathers 4 Justice when they launch here.

title: Dead Merchant of Venice
description: The Christmas lights are up and shoppers are thronging the busy outdoor market at Campo Santo Stefano in Donna Leon's BLOOD FROM A STONE (Atlantic Monthly, $23). But there is nothing festive about the wintry views of Venice in Leon's bleakly beautiful story, which opens with the brazen murder of an African street peddler and closes with a cynical shrug at the hopelessly corrupt state of Italian government.

title: Hoping the Good News Holds, El Paso Prepares for Major Growth at Fort Bliss
description: EL PASO, May 17 - "It's a great day to be a soldier," proclaims the big sign at El Paso International Airport.

title: U.S. Memo Faults Afghan Leader on Heroin Fight
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 - United States officials warned this month in an internal memo that an American-financed poppy eradication program aimed at curtailing Afghanistan's huge heroin trade had been ineffective, in part because President Hamid Karzai "has been unwilling to assert strong leadership."

title: 'Maps for Lost Lovers': Little Murders
description: MAPS FOR LOST LOVERS By Nadeem Aslam. 379 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: The Mayor's Mad Money
description: There are times in New York when government by the people becomes government by the very few, and that is dangerous. Take Mayor Michael Bloomberg's plan to help the Jets build a new football stadium on the West Side.

title: Implant Maker Hid Defects, Workers Said
description: Two former employees of a major manufacturer of silicone breast implants said in sworn depositions in 2003 that the company for years made defective implants that were prone to rupture and hid this information from customers and federal regulators.

title: Sandbagger or Slugger? Only Koo Can Say for Sure
description: OUT of totally nowhere, Dae Sung Koo stunned an entire ballpark yesterday, most notably his own teammates.

title: Jennifer Ho and Albert Kim
description: Dr. Jennifer En-Sian Ho and Dr. Albert Myung Kim are to be married today in the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Mark D.W. Edington, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate.

title: Crew From Queens Outslugs Boys From Bronx
description: The so-called rivalry between the Yankees and the Mets plays out more often in boardrooms than on diamonds. The two organizations claw each other year-round for advertisers, airtime and the almighty entertainment dollar, but rarely for an actual baseball game.

title: A Cover-Up, And a Mop-Up
description: Sarongs, the beach or poolside wrap-around of choice, have become requisite accessories in hot weather, but now they have been slightly reinvented with a practical twist. Atuttotondo's new collection of sarongs is made of rustic striped cotton with a knotted string fringe; the difference lies in a supple terrycloth lining that allows the wearer to dry off without having to search for a towel. The sarongs ($75 at Calypso Home in New York, 212-925-6200), which come in sorbet colors, make leaving the water and getting dry a matter of seconds.

title: Mongolia votes for new president
Uneasy Asian Rivals Relax by Going to Separate Islands
description: After China's anti-Japanese riots last month, can Asia's two ancient rivals unwind together on the beach?

title: The Playwright as Pen Pal
description: "It's a play that people want to talk about," John Patrick Shanley said of "Doubt," his Pulitzer Prize-winning, Tony Award-nominated drama. "They talk about it to the ushers." Never mind the ushers: they can talk about it to the playwright -- and he'll talk back. Mr. Shanley gives his e-mail address in the Playbill for "Doubt"; he said he gets about 15 messages a day and responds to each one. Don't believe him? Write to shanleysmoney@aol.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOORE, REV. JOHN PATRICK
description: MOORE--Rev. John Patrick on May 18, 2005. Son of the late John and Mary Anne Moore. Loving brother of Anne (William) Moore Buchan and the late Maureen (Daniel) Moore Sozzo. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, grandnieces, grand-nephews, cousins and friends. Devoted cousin of Marie Feeney. Father Moore was ordained on June 2, 1956. His first assignment was St. James Church in Carmel, N.Y. He later moved on to St. Monica's, NYC; St. Joseph's in Millbrook, N.Y.; Epiphany Church, NYC; St. Columba's Church, NYC. Former Chaplain of St. Kateri Tegawitha Residence. He concluded his career at St. Joseph's Church, NYC and finally, Immaculate Conception Church, NYC. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue, (20th Street), NYC, Saturday and Sunday 2-4, 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, May 23, 10:30AM at Immaculate Conception Church, 414 East 14th Street, NYC. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery, Queens, New York. Contributions in his memory may be made to St. Patrick's Home, 66 Van Cortlandt Park South, Bronx, New York 10463.

title: Bush Urges Graduates to Volunteer in Community
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 21 - President Bush told graduates of Calvin College in western Michigan on Saturday that the "public good depends on private character" and that they should embrace the American traditions of volunteerism and community service as they set out into the world.

title: A Surprising Leap on Cloning
description: South Korean scientists stunned their rivals around the world last week by announcing that they had produced the first human embryos that were genetic matches for diseased or injured patients, and had done so by a highly efficient method that could bring further rapid advances in cloning. It was sobering evidence that leadership in "therapeutic cloning" has shifted abroad while American scientists, hamstrung by political and religious opposition, make do with private or state funds in the absence of federal support.

title: Chauvinism Lives
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fatal Attraction for the Ring?
description: For those who have not seen "Million Dollar Baby," which won best picture at this year's Academy Awards, women's boxing is riding a wave of popularity, and not just as an excellent form of exercise and competition, but also as a vogue activity. Demand is increasing for women to take advantage of their drawing power in a male-dominated sport.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: SUMMER WEEKENDS IN NEW YORK -- As an alternative to renting a summer house, the Flatotel, at 135 West 52nd Street, offers studios or suites to share from Memorial Day through Labor Day. Minimum stay is four weekends (Friday and Saturday nights). Two people could share a 750-square-foot studio (one king bed; optional cot) for as low as $149 a person a night; up to four people could share a 1,100- to 1,800-square-foot suite (king and Murphy beds) for an average of about $99 per person per night over 10 weekends; both have kitchenettes. Taxes are not included. For details, call (800) 352-8683 or see www.flatotel.com.

title: 'Everything Bad Is Good for You': The Couch Potato Path to a Higher I.Q.
description: EVERYTHING BAD IS GOOD FOR YOU How Today's Popular Culture Is Actually Making Us Smarter. By Steven Johnson. 238 pp. Riverhead Books. $23.95.

title: With a Flashlight and a Stopwatch
description: ARIANNE COHEN is a woman in a hurry. She quailed at the thought of spending months looking for an apartment, as she had seen friends and colleagues do. "They didn't seem upset that they were wasting years of their lives, languishing away on seemingly permanent hunts for apartments that would be somewhat transitory," she said.

title: 'The Sad Truth About Happiness'

title: Acceptable Knockoffs
description: A friend tells me I must stop buying handbags from street vendors on Fifth Avenue in Midtown. I never buy bags with logos on them -- Kate Spade, Louis Vuitton, etc. -- just the nice generic ones. They're so much cheaper than the ones in the stores. Must I stop? Valerie Brett, Monmouth Beach, N.J. You are right to shun counterfeit handbags, but you may buy knockoffs, which are not the same thing. A knockoff apes the appearance of the original but does not present itself as other than what it is. It is not built around fraud (and probably not skillfully hand-stitched fine leather either). Nor does a knockoff run afoul of trademark law. Drawing on other people's work -- in fashion, in art, in literature -- is how ideas spread through the culture. (Is Eric Clapton a knockoff Robert Johnson? Is that a bad thing? Would absorbing the styles of three or four additional guitar greats make him more virtuous?) Besides, if absolute originality were the summum bonum, how would we get along without network television? More potent arguments could be made against unlicensed street vendors -- their sometimes lighthearted attitude toward paying taxes, your difficulty getting a refund from a merchant who is vigorously nomadic -- but neither these nor your fear for the well-being of Louis Vuitton compels you to eschew them.

title: Up Front
description: Jonathan Miles, the author of this week's cover essay on Nascar racing, has been a contributor to the Book Review since 1999, and this is the first time one of his reviews has made our cover. Earlier this year, Miles got a close look at a different kind of racing world: along with a partner, he drove a car in the 2005 Dakar Rally, a 5,566-mile race from Barcelona, Spain, to Dakar, Senegal. The 17-day event is considered by many to be the most dangerous and grueling race in the world; half the competitors don't finish. (Miles's team came in 64th.) "The most obvious difference between the Dakar and a Nascar race is that it's impossible to get lost on a Nascar track," Miles said in a telephone interview. "And Nascar drivers never have to worry about land mines."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BURGUIERES, CHERYL COURREGE
description: BURGUIERES--Cheryl Courrege. In the early evening of May 9, 2005, Cheryl Courrege Burguieres, devoted wife and mother, peacefully passed away at home surrounded by her family after a bravely fought 15 year battle with breast cancer. Her memorial service was officiated by Archbishop Joseph Fiorenza at St. Anne Catholic Church in Houston, TX. Burial service took place at St. Helen Cemetery, Florence Plantation, LA. Cheryl was born in New Iberia, LA, on August 23, 1944, the second of four children born to Irene LeBlanc Courrege and Emile John Courrege. She graduated from Our Lady of Mt. Carmel High School in New Iberia, and the University of Louisiana, where she was a member of Alpha Omicron Pi sorority. On August 21, 1965, she married Philip Burguieres, her sweetheart throughout high school and college. The young couple moved to Virginia Beach, Virginia, where Cheryl taught History and Government. After living in Philadelphia where she worked at the University of Pennsylvania, and Edinburgh, Scotland she moved to Houston, TX. In 1999, her book, One Centimeter, was published, relating the autobiographical story of a young woman's interactions with her doctor upon learning that she has breast cancer. The book raised over $100,000, all of which has been donated in support of the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center. Cheryl was a member of the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation and served on the Board of Directors of the Homes of St. Mark. She was active in her adopted Houston community as a volunteer for the United Way of the Gulf Coast, the Museum of Fine Arts, the Heritage Society, and the Houston Symphony and was dedicated in her support of Baylor Research Advocates for Student Scientists. Cheryl was also an owner of the Houston Texans. Together with her husband in 1999, she was honored as one of the Cancer League's Pacesetter Couples of the Year. In 2004, she was recognized by the Samaritan Center and most recently received, along with her husband Philip, the Smithsonian Institute?s Woodrow Wilson award for Public Service. Beyond the considerable talents Cheryl shared publicly, she was so much more to her family and friends. In addition to being a wonderful wife, mother, daughter, sister and friend, Cheryl was a history lover, a devout Catholic, and wise counsel to those she loved. Memorial gifts may be made to the St. Helen's Cemetery Fund, P. O. Box 333, Franklin, LA 70538.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, FREDERICK D.
description: GOLDBERG -- Frederick D. The Board of Directors of the Day Care Council of New York is deeply saddened by the sudden passing on May 16, 2005 of Frederick Goldberg, a staunch advocate for and practitioner of early childhood education and a Board member for 30 years. Mr. Goldberg graduated from Suffolk University in 1952 with a B.A. and Bank Street Graduate College of Education in 1952 with an M.S. in Early Childhood Education. From 1949-1952 he was an Assistant in the Vocational Guidance Dept. of Suffolk University. He taught as a nursery school teacher at the Educational Alliance from 1953-1959 and served as Educational Director of Breukelen Recreation Rooms from 1959-1962. From 1962 until his retirement in 1992 he was Director of the Child Care Program and Goddard Riverside Neighborhood House in N.Y. He was a member of the Professional Association of Day Care Directors and the Retirees Association of Day Care Directors. He leaves a brother, Dr. Alan Goldberg of Delmar, NY, many nephews, nieces, grand-nieces and a host of close friends who loved him. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Day Care Council of N.Y., 12 West 21 St., 3rd Floor, NYC, NY 10010. Memorial services will be announced later by the Council. Private graveside services will be held in Massachusetts.

title: The Baedeker, the Boots and the Bifocals
description: Actors use all sorts of techniques to help them prepare for a role: Stanislavski, Strasberg, Hagen, Grotowski, Improvisation, Subpersonality Work and more. But amid these and other intellectual approaches, one far more practical factor is frequently overlooked: props. We usually think of props as tools for the audience -- to help them suspend their disbelief, to make it easier for them to situate the action. But long before any audience members enter the theater, actors use them as keys to unlock their characters. Slipping on a pair of glasses or grasping a photograph can trigger that eureka moment, when actors are suddenly able to fully inhabit their roles. Melena Z. Ryzik spoke to several actors on Broadway this season about how an object unexpectedly helped them. Just don't expect to hear glasses, capes, or boots thanked in this year's Tony acceptance speeches.

ART
description: The origins of modern life and art are viewed through a British lens in two museum exhibitions opening this week. "ALL THE MIGHTY WORLD: THE PHOTOGRAPHS OF ROGER FENTON, 1852-1860," at the METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART (starting Tuesday) is the first major American survey of one of the founders of British photography, best known for his stark images of the battlefields of the Crimean War. But Fenton (1819-1869) was a full-service photographer with an instinct for majestic compositions, technical clarity and superb uses of light. His subjects included the Thames, Salisbury Cathedral, the brooding Welsh landscape, sundry stately homes and river views, the royal family and, in one especially abstract instance, Queen Victoria's target -- suggesting startlingly good marksmanship. A selection of photographs owned by Fenton's descendants can be seen at Hans P. Kraus Jr. 25 East 77th Street, (212)794-2064, through June 10.

title: The Believer
description: Rick Santorum, the boyish-looking 47-year-old senator from Pennsylvania, could not, in more decorous political times, have risen to a position of much power in Congress. He has been impatient and sometimes impertinent -- the political equivalent of the too-rough kid on the playground who either doesn't know the rules of the game or just doesn't care to follow them. In the House in the early 1990's, he fell in with a band of junior Republicans (nicknamed the Gang of Seven) who pushed aggressive investigations of both Democrats and Republicans. Elected to the more mannered Senate in 1994, Santorum took to the floor just months into his tenure displaying a sign for several days that read "Where's Bill?" to spotlight what he perceived as President Clinton's lack of leadership on balancing the federal budget. (Senator Robert Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, commented that the young senator's style seemed more appropriate for "an alehouse or beer tavern.") In a much-publicized interview in 2003, he argued that the Supreme Court should not overturn state sodomy laws that ban homosexual sex and suggested that such a ruling would create a justification for bigamy, polygamy and incest. At one point, he even raised the specter of bestiality, using the phrase "man on dog."

title: Sorry, the Jedi Won't Return

But what will the "Star Wars" faithful do now that the series is ending? The novels, cartoons and games will continue, and there's talk of a live-action television series, but the films -- the original "Star Wars" scripture -- will halt. title: The Fashion Curator
description: When asked to come up with a design for the Chanel exhibition at the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Olivier Saillard envisioned a microcosm of Manhattan. The result is a series of cubes arranged in a grid, set against black walls, carpet and ceiling. Video projections of Chanel emblems like camellias, pearls and lace float across many of the displays. Mr. Saillard, 38, who oversees exhibitions at the Muse de la Mode et du Textile in Paris, said, "I like the idea of placing clothes and products in space." Professionally, Mr. Saillard lives in fashion flux: He recently staged a Yohji Yamamoto retrospective and before that designed a show on the history of handbags. His own wardrobe is firmly rooted in one era and aesthetic. "I love the 1950's for men's fashion, and the idea of l'habit du dimanche," he said, translating the phrase as roughly "your Sunday best." Here he wears khakis and a denim blazer by Dsquared, a vintage shirt and tie, Paul Smith glasses and Helmut Lang shoes. Three chains hang at his waist: one is a gift from his friend Christian Lacroix, and another, in silver leather, is by Mr. Yamamoto. Mr. Saillard's other staples include dark, stiff jeans by A.P.C. and Helmut Lang, which he wears with very wide cuffs. He wore a Viktor & Rolf suit to the recent Costume Institute gala, but wouldn't mind switching to couture. "I'm dreaming of having a suit made from very exceptional fabrics, and having five for life," he said. "I've spoken to Christian Lacroix about making them for me." JENNIFER TUNG

In "Gaspara Stampa," the 16th-century Italian poet reflects on her agonizing love affairs and the art she makes of them. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RASMUSSEN, DR. HOWARD
description: RASMUSSEN--Dr. Howard. Founding Director of the Institute of Molecular Medicine and Genetics, Medical College of Georgia, Augusta, GA, died on April 20, 2005, after a prolonged illness. He was formerly Chair of the Department of Biochemistry at the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, and Professor and Chief of Endocrinology and Metabolism at the School of Medicine, Yale University, New Haven. Dr. Rasmussen is remembered for his many scientific accomplishments and his pivotal role in the establishment of the Institute at MCG. Born on March 1, 1925, Dr. Rasmussen grew up on a dairy farm in Pennsylvania with his five brothers. His young adult years were spent as a soldier on the front lines of the European Theater of Operations. He was twice wounded, earning him a purple heart with oak leaf clusters. Through the G.I. bill, he attended Gettysburg College and graduated Magna cum Laude with a Bachelor of Science in 1948. From there he went to the medical school at Harvard University, again graduating Magna cum Laude in 1952. Dr. Rasmussen completed his post-graduate medical training in Internal Medicine at Massachusetts General Hospital before pursuing a research fellowship at University College in London (England). He was among the first to isolate parathyroid hormone before returning to the US and earning a doctoral degree in 1959 in Biochemistry and Physiology from Rockefeller University. He then obtained an Assistant Professorship at Rockefeller, where he remained until 1961, when he accepted a position as Associate Professor at the University of Wisconsin, Madison. He was then recruited as the Benjamin Rush Professor and Chairman of Biochemistry to the University of Pennsylvania. With research focused on parathyroid hormone, vitamin D, calcitonin and aldosterone action, Dr. Rasmussen was one of the first scientists to appreciate the importance of calcium as a signaling molecule at a time when most research concentrated on cyclic AMP as second messenger. In 1976 Dr. Rasmussen accepted a position as Professor of Medicine and Cell Biology and Chief of the Endocrinology and Metabolism section at Yale Medical School. His research in aldosterone and insulin secretion and vascular smooth muscle contraction resulted in hundreds of publications in prestigious scientific journals, large amounts of federal funding, multiple awards and honors. In 1993, Dr. Rasmussen accepted the challenge to establish and direct a new Institute of Molecular Medicine and Genetics at MCG. He retired in 2000. His wife, Jane Spence, whom he married in 1952 and who remained by his side until her death in 1999, predeceased Dr. Rasmussen. He has four children: Gail, Paul, Jane, and Craig. He is sorely missed by his family and academic offsprings.

title: Can You Catch Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder?
description: To suffer from obsessive-compulsive disorder, many patients say, is to ''know you are crazy.'' Other forms of psychosis may envelop the sufferers until they inhabit the delusion. Part of the torture of O.C.D. is, as patients describe it, watching as if from the outside as they act out their obsessions -- knowing that they are being irrational, but not being able to stop. They describe thoughts crowding their minds, nattering at them incessantly -- anxious thoughts, sexual thoughts, violent thoughts, sometimes all at the same time. Is the front door locked? Are there germs on my hands? Am I a murderer if I step on an ant? And they describe increasingly elaborate rituals to assuage those thoughts -- checking and rechecking door locks, washing and rewashing hands, walking carefully, slowly and in bizarre patterns to avoid stepping on anything. They feel driven to do things they know make no sense.

The measure, proposed in May 2004, would have banned people from photographing, videotaping or filming inside subway cars and stations; the press and businesses or individuals with permits would have been exempt. After public comment and discussions with the New York Civil Liberties Union, the police considered a partial ban on photos of tunnels, control booths and other areas closed to the public, but decided against it, said Christopher Dunn, the associate legal director of the civil liberties group. "From the outset, we have believed that a total ban would unnecessarily infringe on First Amendment rights," he said. The decision was first reported in The Daily News yesterday. Paul J. Browne, a police spokesman, said, "We don't feel the broad ban is necessary, and as a practical matter is unenforceable." People taking photos of areas deemed sensitive will still be questioned, Mr. Browne said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

"The same machine that wrecked the county is threatening the future of that town," he said. His Republican opponent, Gregory Peterson, a former Hempstead town supervisor, has criticized Mr. Suozzi for raising taxes in his first year and has warned of big budget gaps. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, MILTON A.
description: WOLF--Milton A. The Board and staff of the Ameican Austrian Foundation deeply mourn the passing of Ambassador Milton A. Wolf, who had worked so tirelessly for many years as our Chairman. Milton Wolf was the consummate diplomat. His distinguished service as the United States Ambassador to Austria established his international reputation for wise counsel and courageous decisions. He was a gentleman of great learning and intellect, a patriot who served his country in war and peace, a brilliant businessman, and a philanthropist whose generosity touched the world. Through the American Austrian Foundation, he helped establish the Salzburg Seminar Medical Programs in which the faculty of the Weill Cornell Medical College of Cornell University and leading physicians of the major hospitals in New York, Philadelphia and Duke University, with the support of the Soros Open Society Institute and the Austrian government, have given seminars and extended instruction to over 6,000 doctors from Central and Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. It has beeen said that these programs are the most important contributions to the health and well being of the peoples of that part of the world since the collapse of the Iron Curtain. Ambassador Wolf established a program for young Austrian journalists in partnership with the Sanford School of Public Policy at Duke University. The seminar program in his name on Media and Diplomacy has been hailed for its impact by its host, the Vienna Diplomatic Academy. He also initiated an intern program for graduate students at Case Western Reserve University in cooperation with Austrian financial institutions. He welcomed creative ideas, constructive discussion, and never stopped encouraging young people to consider public service as the highest calling. We share the sorrow of his children, Nancy, Caryn, Sherri and Leslie. On July 25, we will dedicate a park in Salzburg, Austria, that Ambassador Wolf gave in memory of his beloved wife, Roslyn. Milton Wolf brought honor to every aspect of his extraordinary life. His memory will be cherished always. Wiliam J. vanden Heuvel Vice Chair Thomas J. McGrath President Dr. Wolfgang Aulitzky Medical Director

description: It is perhaps understandable that the new designs for a cultural center at the former World Trade Center site are being treated with some wariness. After swooning over the original master plan by Daniel Libeskind and applauding the original Freedom Tower design by David Childs, we now recognize how these seductive proposals offer hope more than a final contract for exactly what will be built on this crucial site. Thus, it is easy to say the proposal for a dual-museum complex unveiled last Thursday by the respected Norwegian architectural firm Snohetta looks promising in almost every way. State environmental regulators have scheduled a public hearing for today on whether the station's owner, Radiac, should receive a renewal of a nuclear storage permit from the state, the senator said. Critics have said that Williamsburg is not an appropriate site for the station, which stores hazardous waste and low-level nuclear waste from medical devices. "The bottom line is that this facility is not essential and should not be located in a populated, and increasingly popular, Brooklyn community," Mr. Schumer said. He said a fire at the site could threaten 130,000 people who live within a mile. Radiac officials said yesterday that the levels of waste at the site were too low to pose a risk even after an accident. John Tekin, Radiac's operations manager, said the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had concluded that "the radioactive materials we store are below areas of concern and a radiological release would have no health and safety consequences." He that said 85 percent of the material at the station came from hospitals and schools in the New York City area.

Paid Notice: Deaths   PRICE, VIRGINIA A.
description: PRICE--Virginia A. After graduating from Zanesville High School, Gena Price attended nearby Muskingum College in southeastern Ohio. She spent her junior year abroad in Aix-en-Provence and graduated from Muskingum with degrees in both French and Psychology. In 1966 Gina joined IBM, where she worked as a marketing representative, a software instructor, and executive consultant. In 1973 Gina entered the doctoral program in counseling psychology at Stanford University. As a doctoral student she began a 20-year collaboration with Meyer Friedman on the study and treatment of Type A Behavior. Gina helped develop the treatment protocol for modifying Type A Behavior in the Recurrent Coronoary Prevention Project (RCPP). The RCPP reduced both Type A Behavior and the rate of recurrent heart attacks in a group of over 1,000 post-coronary men and women. In 1978 Gina married Peter Enemark. That same year she began to study Christian Science. In 1980 Gina's son David Price Enemark was born, and she received her Ph.D. in counseling psychology. In 1982 her son Daniel Price Enemark was born, and Gina published her first book, "Type A Behavior: A Model for Research and Practice." Gina led stress-management groups in the RCPP, at the Army War College, in the private sector, and in the Coronary/Cancer Prevention Project (CCPP). She also trained group leaders for the RCPP and for the CCPP. During the Soviet era, Gina traveled to Poland to teach the diagnosis and treatment of Type A Behavior there. She had a small private practice in Palo Alto, CA. Of all her professional activities, leading stress-management groups was the most important to Gina. Her observation that people with different personalities manifest Type A Behavior in different ways led Gina to study the Enneagram theory of personality types. She published her second book, "The Essential Enneagram: The Definitive Personality Test and Self-Discovery Guide," in 2000, which included a self-test (validated on a group of over 900 people) that Gina developed based on her work at the Army War College. Gina traveled to Greece, Latvia, Thailand and Turkey to conduct workshops on the Enneagram. Gina was a businesswoman, a scholar, a research scientist, an author, a therapist, a group leader, a wife and a mother. She always believed that being a mother was her most important role. Gina was a member of Second Church of Christ, Scientist in Palo Alto, CA, and a volunteer chaplain in the San Mateo County jails. A memorial service will be held at Menlo Park Presbyterian Church, on Saturday, May 28, 2005, at 11 am. For information contact Spangler Mortuaries, Mountain View, CA.

description: Clyde Simms has been living a dream and will awaken Saturday at Soldier Field in Chicago, where the United States men's national team will play England in an international friendly match.

title: Child Safety: Cleanliness Is Next to Clumsiness
description: Parents are often warned not to leave their young children alone in a bathtub. But even when grownups are in the room there can be danger, a new study finds.

title: Dragnet Arrests in Zimbabwe Send Warning
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 23 - With grocery stores bereft of basic goods and the currency once more in free fall, Zimbabwe's government said Monday that it had rounded up more than 9,600 residents of the capital, Harare, in a crackdown on black-market peddlers and "general lawlessness."

title: Mongolia elects ex-prime minister
Murder, Mogul, Marriage: Three Versions of Reality
description: The most surprising thing about the UPN reality show "Britney and Kevin: Chaotic" is not that Britney Spears cannot handle a videocamera or that she has the mind of a child trapped in the body of a blow-up doll. It's that the show's executive producer is Susan Zirinsky, a highly respected CBS News producer who was the model for the hyper-serious heroine of James L. Brooks's 1987 movie, "Broadcast News."

title: O'Neal Back, but Pistons Cut the Heat Down to Size
description: MIAMI, May 23 - Like a giant awakened from sleep, Shaquille O'Neal lumbered a bit, adrenaline carrying him off the bench and onto the court at American Airlines Arena after a 13-day layoff.

title: REALLY?
description: THE CLAIM -- Cranberry juice prevents urinary infections.

title: A New Career in Advertising, but Still With a Wicked Streak
description: There was something ace about Jenny McCarthy in the 1990's. On "Singled Out" she was so brash, so crass, so great-looking, so expertly just-shy-of-annoying. Or maybe she was annoying sometimes. But she was good at comedic saves, too; if you were annoyed, she made you think it was your problem and why didn't you know how to have fun? With her Playmate of the Year looks and her flooring-it party-girl persona, she came off like a low-cal Liz Phair, and she was by far the best thing on MTV's squealy dating show.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Judge Won't Throw Out Case In 1964 Killings
description: Judge Marcus D. Gordon of State Circuit Court refused to dismiss the case against Edgar Ray Killen, 80, a preacher and reputed Klansman accused of coordinating the killings of three civil rights workers in Neshoba County in 1964. Mr. Killen's lawyers had argued that the state had unlawfully singled him out for prosecution. Eighteen people faced federal civil rights charges in 1967 in the killings of the workers, James E. Chaney, Andrew Goodman and Michael H. Schwerner. Seven were convicted, and none served more than six years in prison. The jury deadlocked on Mr. Killen after one juror said she could not convict a preacher. The state had not brought charges until this year. Mr. Killen, who denies involvement, is scheduled to go on trial June 13. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Neither Side Eager to Call 5 Jackson Associates
description: SANTA MARIA, Calif., May 23 - As Michael Jackson's defense team nears the end of its case, it now appears likely that the jury will not hear from five of Mr. Jackson's closest associates, people who may be most knowledgeable about events at his Neverland ranch in early 2003.

title: Jammed Radio Signal Cited in Capital Plane Incident
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 - A Black Hawk helicopter dispatched to intercept a private plane that entered forbidden airspace here on May 11 directed the plane's pilots to tune to a frequency that was not usable at the time, the Department of Homeland Security acknowledged on Monday.

title: In Southern France, Strong Opposition to Europe Treaty
description: MONTPELLIER, France, May 21 - Over sausage sandwiches and vast amounts of beer and local wine, thousands of Frenchmen stood around and argued over how best to save France. Save France from Europe, that is: the Europe that France played a crucial role in building a half-century ago.

title: Arts, Briefly; Strike Averted
description: American Ballet Theater and its orchestra said yesterday that they had reached agreement on a new three-year contract, averting the prospect of a strike. The announcement came on the day of the company's season-opening gala at the Metropolitan Opera House. Although the orchestra had voted last week to authorize a strike, its union, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, said the players would have performed at the gala nonetheless because it is a fund-raiser. The union said the company had agreed in writing not to use a virtual orchestra machine, an issue Local 802 has been pressing at Broadway theaters and small opera houses. David Lennon, the local's president, said the company had been insisting until near the end on its right to use the machine, but it signed off on a ban as part of the agreement. Mr. Lennon said the local was demanding such a ban in all the union's negotiations. Rachel S. Moore, the executive director of American Ballet Theater, said the company had been committed all along to using live music. She said the delay came only because the company wanted to make sure that use of the machine could be negotiated as an exception for nonorchestral sounds, if necessary, in the future. She and Mr. Lennon said they could not comment on specifics of the contract until the membership voted on it tonight. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Islam can vote, if we let it
Death by a Thousand Blogs
description: BEIJING - The Chinese Communist Party survived a brutal civil war with the Nationalists, battles with American forces in Korea and massive pro-democracy demonstrations at Tiananmen Square. But now it may finally have met its match -- the Internet.

title: U.S. Cautions Bank on Fees Intended to Steer Retiree Accounts
description: The Labor Department has issued an advisory opinion that banks, brokerage firms and investment firms cannot accept payments from mutual fund companies in exchange for steering retirement account customers into those funds. The opinion may help eliminate some of the troubling conflicts of interest that exist in many individuals' retirement accounts.

Your vast memories and accomplishments have had a profound affect on all of our lives. You are loved and will never be forgotten. Ann, Bob, Neil, Cathy, Gina, Leif, Catrine and Elisabeth

description: CATANDUVA, Brazil - Not long ago, residents of this lush cane-growing region in southern Brazil needed to keep a close eye on the price of sugar in world markets to know if the local farmers were hiring or firing.

title: Car Bombings in Iraq Kill 33, With Shiites as Targets
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 23 - Insurgents carried out three major car bomb attacks against Iraqi Shiites on Monday, killing at least 33 and wounding 120 in what appeared to be the latest in a wave of violence intended to exploit the sectarian divisions that have tormented the country.

title: BBC Employees Stage 24-Hour Strike to Protest Planned Job Cuts
description: LONDON, May 23 - Thousands of people, from technicians to news correspondents and anchors, stayed away from work at the British Broadcasting Corporation on Monday in a strike over the company's plans to cut nearly 4,000 jobs in the next three years.

title: The College Dropout Boom
description: CHILHOWIE, Va. - One of the biggest decisions Andy Blevins has ever made, and one of the few he now regrets, never seemed like much of a decision at all. It just felt like the natural thing to do.

title: Los Angeles as It Was 30 Years Ago, in Memory, and as It Is Now
description: Over the past few months, any number of old memories of Los Angeles have come back to me. Most of them are not really memories of the place as it was 30-some years ago, when I last lived in the area. They are memories of illusions of the place, a forgotten chronicle of sightings, rumors, hauntings and strong impressions. The otherness of other lives always weighs heavily on my imagination, and to drive, as a young man, along elevated freeways, peering out into the palm-dotted neighborhoods that lay beyond them, was to be overcome by other lives. Los Angeles seemed far stranger to me then than it has these past few months. The difference may be age, but it may also be Los Angeles.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Orange: Councilman Pleads Guilty
description: An East Orange councilman, Zachary V. Turner, pleaded guilty yesterday to extortion for receiving $22,000 in bribes, federal prosecutors said. Mr. Turner admitted in United States District Court in Newark that he had demanded a $20,000 bribe from a city landowner to prevent the city from taking over the landowner's property and another $2,000 from a prospective buyer of properties owned by the city, the prosecutors said. His sentencing is scheduled for Sept. 7. The United States attorney, Christopher J. Christie, charged that Mr. Turner had conspired in the extortion with another man, Barry Turner. The two men are not related, prosecutors said. Barry Turner has pleaded not guilty and was expected to go on trial in the fall.

title: Corrections
description: A letter to the editor in Science Times on May 3 about mathematical probabilities in medicine misstated the chance of cancer in a person screened by a hypothetical test that is 99 percent accurate. If the cancer occurs in 5 of 1,000 people, the chance that a person who tests positive actually has the cancer is about 1 in 3, not 1 in 2. (Out of 1,000 people screened, 15 test positive: 5 who have the cancer and 10 -- the misdiagnosed 1 percent -- who do not.)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: British Land in Acquisition
description: The British Land Company, a leading property developer, agreed to buy Pillar Property in an offer valuing the smaller competitor at 811 million ($1.5 billion) to acquire shopping centers like Glasgow Fort in Scotland, left, and a 3.3 billion ($6 billion) fund management business. British Land, owner of the Broadgate office development in London's financial district, said it bid 855 pence ($1.56) a share in cash, or 7.5 percent more than the closing price on May 19, the day before Pillar said it was in talks. More than half of British Land's properties are retail outlets. Fund management will give British Land, based in London, a new income stream.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Island Could Become Park
description: Nine years after Donald J. Trump dropped plans to turn Davids Island into a millionaires' retreat, Westchester officials are moving to convert the island, in Long Island Sound at New Rochelle, into a park. Last night, the county's Board of Legislators made a formal request for a state-led, $1 million study into the cost of an extensive cleanup of the 78-acre patch of land, a onetime military base. If approved by the state, the study will mark an important first step toward conversion to parkland. Environmentalists have been pushing for that result for decades. David Scharfenberg (NYT)

title: Generic Drug Maker Recalls All Its Products
description: Able Laboratories, maker of about 40 generic drugs, said yesterday that it had suspended manufacturing and is recalling all of its products after a review found testing practices failed to meet federal standards. The news set off a 29.7 percent decline in the company's share price.

title: Weapons in Space
description: The Air Force is pressing hard to develop defensive and offensive space weapons without adequately considering the potential adverse consequences. At this point, it is not clear whether Air Force aspirations for these weapons are mostly technological fantasy or have some real hope of success. It is certainly true that the Air Force wants to achieve and maintain military superiority in space. "We haven't reached the point of strafing and bombing from space," an Air Force official said last year. "Nonetheless, we are thinking about those possibilities."

title: Facing Up to the Tragedy of War
description: One of the euphemisms of war is "friendly fire," reflecting the sad truth that in the frenzy of combat, a soldier can be killed by his comrades in arms. But there is an even sadder truth about the death of Cpl. Pat Tillman, the young patriot who after 9/11 renounced a millionaire's career as a football player to enlist in the Army Rangers and defend his country. It turns out the Army knew within days that misdirected gunfire from American forces took Corporal Tillman's life in Afghanistan last year. Yet a hero's death tale was concocted and the truth suppressed until weeks after a nationally televised memorial service had grievously misled the corporal's family and his countrymen.

The fee is similar to that charged by other agencies, like the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, that participate in E-ZPass, the electronic toll collection system. The estimated revenue from the fee, about $13 million a year, will help pay for administrative costs associated with managing E-ZPass accounts. title: Keeping Watch on the Watch Lists
description: KEEPING WATCH ON THE WATCH LISTS -- The government's bid to exempt from the Privacy Act portions of a vast new data bank, which includes information on blacklisted fliers, is coming under fire from corporate travel managers. The Association of Corporate Travel Managers began sounding out its members yesterday, and said that opposition is running 90 percent against the Homeland Security Department's plan to exclude from the protections of the privacy law its new compilation of data, including watch lists of suspect travelers kept by airlines and government agencies, as well as information about them drawn from both classified and public sources. The association says the change could make it even more difficult for travelers who share names with people on the lists to find out what the files say about them or to petition to correct errors. "Exempting this new database from the Privacy Act will make an unwieldy resolution process virtually impossible," said Greeley Koch, the president of the trade group. The indictment said that Mr. Ford, 34, had reason to believe the classified material "could be used to the injury of the United States and to the advantage of any foreign nation," but it did not accuse him of trying to sell or pass on the documents. He faces a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison if convicted. A spokesman for the agency said he could not discuss the case. Mr. Ford declined to comment. Scott Shane (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Journalism Program to End
description: After rumors about trouble and despite energetic fund-raising efforts, the National Arts Journalism program is being closed down at the Columbia University School of Journalism. In e-mail messages sent on Sunday to alumni of the 11-year-old program, which advocated and promoted the cause of arts journalism, an advisory board member, Doug McLennan, said the program had run out of money. Mr. McLennan, editor of the affiliated ArtsJournal.com said in his e-mail that when funding from Pew Charitable Trusts "ended a couple of years ago,"' the program had to raise its entire operating budget from other sources. "The program's budget of $1.6 million in 2002-03 fell to less than half that by the current year," Mr. McLennan wrote. He added that the board was seeking a new home for the program, which has had more than 130 fellows from 32 states and 2 foreign countries, and it has presented 35 symposiums and public events. The weak result contrasts with the record earnings reported a day earlier by the Mizuho Financial Group, Japan's largest bank, which has moved more quickly to eliminate bad loans. Sumitomo Mitsui said it trimmed its bad loans to 3.3 percent of its total loans as of March 31 from 5 percent a year earlier. title: Growth and the Poor
description: Last year should have been a good one for Latin America's poor; the region's economies grew by 5.8 percent. Yet outside Chile, Latin America's high growth rate is not cause for rejoicing. In places with relatively egalitarian income distribution, growth helps everyone. But in unequal countries, where the poor get only a few cents out of every new dollar, growth bypasses the poorest. Latin America is the world's most unequal region. That means growth will not reduce poverty unless Latin American governments redirect it to the poor.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Governor Rejects Bid To Delay Execution
description: Gov. Mitch Daniels, left, denied a temporary reprieve to a death row inmate who sought to delay his execution so he could undergo medical testing to see if he could donate his liver to his ailing sister, Debra Otis. The inmate, Gregory S. Johnson, 40, is scheduled to be executed today for breaking into a woman's house, killing her and setting her house on fire 20 years ago. title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Korean Investment in Steel
description: Dongkuk Steel, South Korea's third-largest steel maker, signed a preliminary agreement with the Brazilian mining giant Companhia Vale do Rio Doce to help build a $750 million steel mill in the South American country, the companies said. Under the terms of the deal, Dongkuk would have a 10 percent stake in the plant, which would be built in the northeastern state of Cear with the capacity to produce 1.5 million tons of steel slabs a year. Dongkuk will jointly operate the mill with the Italian steel-equipment maker Danieli, while Vale will supply the plant with 2.5 million tons of iron ore pellets a year. Separately, Vale said it would develop feasibility studies with Posco, South Korea's No.1 steel maker, for the construction of a plant in the Brazilian state of Maranho. Korean steel companies have been looking to expand overseas, where they have easier access to raw materials. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Nonfiction Is Flavor of Moment for Films
description: Cute children, family conflicts, social blights -- the big three subjects of documentary features are currently on screen in films like "Mad Hot Ballroom," "Tell Them Who You Are" and "Shake Hands With the Devil," part of an explosion of nonfiction films into theaters. But this boom, inspired by hits like "Spellbound" and "Fahrenheit 9/11," has its downside. Every week seems to bring another mediocre documentary, coasting on the strength of its content and its similarity to a better, more artistic film. Even as the genre leaps out of its niche, it is suffering from a tyranny of substance over style.

Over the past two weeks, the rover has spun its wheels enough to have covered 157 feet on flat, solid ground, but in the sand it moved only 11 inches. Mission managers are encouraged by the progress, saying the rover could be out of the dune in one to two weeks. Kenneth Chang (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; The Return of Lassie
description: Shooting has begun in Ireland on "Lassie, Come Home," the first film in more than a decade about Lassie, left, the adventurously altruistic border collie. The director, Charles Sturridge, also wrote the screenplay, which is based on a 1938 novel and follows Lassie on a 500-mile trek: after the caring but destitute Carraclough family sell their dog to a Scottish duke, she manages to return home to Yorkshire for Christmas. Peter O'Toole, Samantha Morton and Peter Dinklage play the main human parts, alongside the collies who share the starring role. (Fans expressed disappointment that not one of the three is a descendant of the original Lassie.) The six weeks of filming will take place in Dublin, in the Wicklow countryside south of the capital and on the Isle of Man. Lassie originated in a book by Eric Knight and was the subject of at least a dozen movies and nearly 700 television episodes after Elizabeth Taylor starred in the 1943 film version of the story. BRIAN LAVERY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TARNOPOL, MICHAEL ''MICKEY''
description: TARNOPOL--Michael "Mickey". Of New York City on May 23. Beloved husand of Lynne (Lichtenstein). Loving father of Lori (Moore) and Lisa (Silverman) and fatherin-law of David Moore. Adored grandfather of Jami and Nicholas Moore and Lucy and Jack Silverman. Vice Chairman of Bear Stearns, Vice Chairman and Trustee of the University of Pennsylvania, Trustee of Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Trustee of the Prostate Cancer Foundation. Funeral service today at 10 a.m. at Central Synagogue. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to: University of Pennsylvania, 3451 Walnut St, Room 627, Franklin Building, Philadelphia, Pa. 19104, attention John Zeller or Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, POB 27106, New York, NY 10087-7106 attention Barbara McLaughlin. TARNOPOL--Michael L. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center note with sorrow the passing Michael L. Tarnopol, a member of the Center's Board of Overseers and Managers. Mr. Tarnopol was a stalwart supporter and benefactor of Memorial SloanKettering's programs of research and treatment. Elected to the Board of Overseers in 2002 and to the Board of Managers the following year, he served on both the Joint Finance and Funding Committee and the Budget Subcommittee. Through the Tarnopol Family Foundation, he and his wife, Lynne, a member of the Administrative Board of The Society for Memorial Sloan-Kettering, have given generously to many Center efforts including the Campaign for Memorial Sloan-Kettering, the PepsiCo Foundation Prostate Cancer Fund, the D. Wayne Calloway Chair in Urologic Oncology, and numerous Society-related programs and events. Mr. Tarnopol was also a co-founder of the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center Golf Invitational to Benefit Prostate Cancer Research. Michael Tarnopol was a valued friend and colleague and will be deeply missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife and family. James D. Robinson III Honorary Chairman Douglas A. Warner III Chairman Richard I. Beattie, Vice Chairman Louis V. Gerstner, Jr. Vice Chairman John R. Gunn, Executive Vice President Harold Varmus, President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center TARNOPOL--Michael L. Larger than life and one of a kind, Mickey was an inspiration to all of his many, many friends and his family. Lived life to the fullest. Even near the end when mortals would have given up, Mickey persevered, thrived and built. Always there to support, encourage and fight for his wide circle of personal friends, business associates, clients, and, of course, his wonderful family. Mickey, we are among your "new friends", having known you for "only" 25 years. So many of your relationships go back so far, to college years and before. What a tribute to you to have forged such long lasting ties and to continue to be surrounded by people who genuinely admire, care and delight in our connection to such a special individual. You set the standard for all of us, your lifelong admirers. You will be terribly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to Lynne, Lisa, Lori and David and to Mickey's center of affection, grandchildren Nicholas, Jamie, Jack and Lucy. Cheryl and Michael, Jeni and Peter Joanna and Aaron TARNOPOL--Michael. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Michael "Mickey" Tarnopol, an esteemed and beloved leader whose boundless generosity and passionate dedication marked a lifetime of distinguished service in business and philanthropy. Mickey's deep devotion to humanitarian and educational causes had a global reach, enriching and strengthening millions of lives worldwide. Prior to that, he was a venture capitalist with American Diversified Enterprises and on the board of Golden Cycle Gold Corporation. He was also the vice president and treasurer of Sonesta International Hotels from 1960 to 1970 and formed Universal Hotel Company AG, based in Marbella, Spain. Mel, as he was known, served on the board of his Manhattan condominium and was the president of Dune Alpin Farm Corporation in East East Hampton, LI for the past 11 years. He is survived by his wife Gunilla, his sons Jeffrey and Kevin, and their mother Dorothy, Mr. Cooper's first wife and many, many friends. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in Mel Cooper's name to the charity of your choice.
