title: University Presses Challenge Google
description: How long is a snippet? That is one of more than a dozen questions directed at Google Inc. this week by the executive director of the Association of American University Presses, the trade group representing university presses. At issue is whether Google Print for Libraries, the company's plan to digitize the collections of some of the country's major university libraries, infringes the copyrights of the authors of many books in those collections. The program will allow users to search the contents of books, displaying context-specific "snippets" of the texts of copyrighted works. In a letter to Google dated Friday, the details of which were first reported by BusinessWeek on Monday, Peter Givler, executive director of the press association, said that Google Print for Libraries "appears to involve systematic infringement of copyright on a massive scale." Mr. Givler said the service has "the potential for serious financial damage" to the members of the press association, a collection of largely not-for-profit businesses that typically produce and sell scholarly works of nonfiction that have relatively little commercial potential. In a statement, Google said that it has an "active dialogue with all of our publishing partners," adding that it protects the copyright holders by allowing users of Google Print to view only a few short sentences of protected text. EDWARD WYATT

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: I.R.A Still Recruiting, Watchdog Group Says
description: The Irish Republican Army continues to recruit and train new members and maintain an arsenal, and it retains the ability to return to a full-scale terror war, according to a report by the Independent Monitoring Commission, a watchdog group set up by the British and Irish governments last year to check paramilitary groups in the province. The 59-page report found that both republican and loyalist groups were involved in crime and that loyalists were responsible for four times as many shootings as republican groups. The report "presents a disturbing picture," the Irish government said in a statement, and Britain's secretary for Northern Ireland, Peter Hain, demanded "crystal clarity from the I.R.A." on ending its activities. The four-member commission offered faint praise to Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing, for publicly urging the I.R.A. to seek an alternative to armed struggle. If the I.R.A. disbands, Mr. Adams "will have demonstrated leadership of a high order," it said. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILSON, DEREK R.
description: WILSON--Derek R. Beloved son and brother, died after a seven year battle with cancer on May 23, 2005 at his Gretna, LA home. He was 38 years old. He was a graduate of St. Stanislaus High School in Bay St. Louis, MS and received his degree from the University of Mississippi in Oxford, MS. He resided in Pass Christian, MS where he owned a small business prior to his illness. Derek loved his family, fishing, his friends and the New Orleans Saints. Mr. Wilson was a member of Kappa Alpha Fraternity and Pass Road Baptist Church in Gulfport, MS. Throughout his illness, Derek continued to counsel and help others who shared his rare disease. Survivors include his parents, A.W. (Buddy) and Joy Wilson of Gretna, LA and a sister, Cynthia (Missy) Wilson, of New York, NY and his dog Zoe. He was preceded in death by his grandparents, Alfred and Geneva Bendily and Lee Roy and Cecil Forehand Wilson. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the Funeral Service at Lake Lawn Metairie Funeral Home, 5100 Pontchartrain Blvd. (in Metairie Cemetery) on Thursday, May 26, 2005 at 2 P.M. Interment will follow in All Saints Mausoleum in Metairie Cemetery. Visitation will be at 12:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Survivor's Retreat Inc., c/o Dr. Gurtler, 3939 Houma Blvd., Ste. 6, Metairie, LA 70006. Please view and sign the Family Guestbook at www.lakelawnmetairie.com

On a sunny day last week, a photographer found sculptors, writers, bankers, professors, expectant mothers and procrastinating students seemingly eager to see and be seen in glorious displays of public gluttony. An agglomeration of so-called premium outlets, Woodbury Common posed a contradiction in terms. The word "premium" denotes superior quality, while "outlet" prompts visions of irregular poly-cotton sheet sets and pilling cashmere sweaters. Together they suggest the kind of place where one might find a scuffed Gucci handbag or a rack of dresses marked Famous Label. No thanks.

description: THE architect of New York's best-loved landmark, William Van Alen, has been all but forgotten in the half-century since his death. Even at the height of his career, Van Alen never approached the fame of Frank Lloyd Wright or Le Corbusier, but he was a major architectural figure and had been a star in the making since his student days. Soon after the Chrysler Building was finished in 1930, though, his professional standing began to slide, and he watched helplessly as his career unraveled, a victim, ultimately, of its greatest achievement.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighter Struck By Car
description: A firefighter from Ladder Company 30 in Harlem was struck by a hit-and-run driver as he climbed into his fire truck to return to the station yesterday, fire officials said. The firefighter, Sheldon George, was near 145th Street and Seventh Avenue when a driver in a gray Dodge Stratus hit him then drove away. A few hours later, the driver, whom the police identified as Katrina Samardzic, 27, of Elmhurst, Queens, turned herself in and was arrested. Charges against her were pending last night. Firefighter George was treated at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital for injuries that fire officials said were not life threatening.

Skinner, who was nominated last year to be the Environmental Protection Agency's head of enforcement, asked President Bush to withdraw his nomination so he could return to his family in Illinois. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit on Derivatives Trading
description: Socit Gnrale, a major lender in France, said its first-quarter profit increased 41 percent on higher revenue from equity derivatives and fixed-income trading. Net income climbed to 1.22 billion euros ($1.54 billion), or 3 euros ($3.78) a share, the bank said. Revenue rose 20 percent, to 4.7 billion euros ($5.9 billion). Socit Gnrale is benefiting from an increase in trading that has also raised earnings at securities firms like Deutsche Bank and the Goldman Sachs Group. The corporate and investment banking unit, headed by Jean-Pierre Mustier, above, posted a 57 percent jump in profit.

description: Iraq will seek the advice of Petrobras, Brazil's state-run oil company, to help raise its oil production, which has fallen 47 percent in five years. Iraq's oil ministry plans to form a technical committee with Petrobras to advise its state-run production companies on increasing output, now less than two million barrels a day, said Jabbar al-Leaby, above, director of the South Oil Company, Iraq's largest oil producer. Global companies, including Royal Dutch/Shell Group and BP, have agreed to help Iraq increase output from damaged fields.

National Briefing | South: Florida: Troubled Youth Held Without Bond
description: Lionel Tate, who was freed last year after a court overturned his life sentence for killing a playmate when he was 12, was ordered held without bond on charges of holding up a pizza deliveryman at gunpoint. Judge Jerry Pollock of Broward County Court said Mr. Tate, now 18, could not be released because he was being held on a probation violation stemming from the death in 1999 of 6-year-old Tiffany Eunick. On Monday, a search of the home of Mr. Tate's mother, Kathleen Grossett-Tate, revealed that three handguns she owned were missing. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: The 20's Come Roaring Back
description: WHEN the photographer Margaret Bourke-White moved into the Chrysler Building in 1931, her studio, top far left, epitomized sophisticated Art Deco design. More than 70 years later, with its polished nickel and aluminum, geometric patterns, deep seats and curvaceous lines, Art Deco "has finally reached the mainstream," said Elaine Griffin, a New York decorator who likes to incorporate it in her otherwise contemporary interiors. "An Art Deco piece adds a note of masculinity that almost every room needs, even the girliest one," she said. Originals are costly -- a 1920's lamp by Jacques-mile Ruhlmann sold last spring at auction for $421,900 -- but there is plenty of deco inspiration in new pieces in every price range.

description: ABOUT Helmut Lang's major influence over the fashion of the last 15 years there is little doubt. Consumers can thank him for flat-front pants, the number of buttons on men's suits -- first three, more recently two -- and the spiraling prices of designer jeans and T-shirts. An entire culture of prestige denim was born from Mr. Lang's low-rise jeans with intricate washes, for which he dared to charge close to $200 in the 1990's.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Challenge To Smoking Ban Dismissed
description: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit yesterday challenging the constitutionality of the city's ban on smoking in most bars. The lawsuit, filed in December 2003 by the Players Club on Gramercy Park, had charged that the city's smoking ban, which went into effect earlier that year, violated its members' First Amendment right to "expressive association." In his dismissal of the suit, Judge Victor Marrero of federal court in Manhattan cited a 2004 ruling issued in response to a challenge to the ban, which said that individuals have no fundamental constitutional right to smoke tobacco. After watching "A Mighty Wind," even a group as politically committed as Peter, Paul and Mary could never be taken quite as seriously again.

title: Too Cool for School? Not at Fashion High
description: ON a Friday in May at New York City's fashion high school, where the modeling class counts for gym credit, the auditorium roared with excited teenagers. The senior fashion show, all of the clothes designed, stitched and modeled by students, had begun. And if blunt emotion is rare when Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren or even Zac Posen show their collections, it is among the draws of this annual production at the High School of Fashion Industries in Chelsea. Not to mention the back stories, which play out like "Fame" for the "Project Runway" set.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: New Leader Steps Down To Campaign
description: Donald Tsang, who has been the acting chief executive since the resignation of Tung Chee-hwa in March, announced his resignation so he can run for the top post in the July 10 election. The move is required by law. Mr. Tsang is the heavy favorite in the election. Henry Tang, the financial secretary, will become acting chief executive. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: ETA Car Bomb In Madrid
description: The Basque separatist group ETA exploded a car bomb in Madrid, slightly injuring at least two people, the Interior Ministry said. The bombings followed statements by the government that it would open talks with ETA if it gave up violence. Renwick McLean (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TARNOPOL, MICHAEL ''MICKEY''
description: TARNOPOL--Michael "Mickey" of New York City on May 23. Beloved husband of Lynne (Lichtenstein). Loving father of Lori (Moore) and Lisa (Silverman) and fatherin-law of David Moore. Adored grandfather of Jami and Nicholas Moore and Lucy and Jack Silverman. Vice Chairman of Bear Stearns, Vice Chairman and Trustee of the University of Pennsylvania, Trustee of Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Trustee of the Prostate Cancer Foundation. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to: University of Pennsylvania, 3451 Walnut St, Room 627, Franklin Building, Philadelphia, Pa. 19104, attn: John Zeller or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, POB 27106, New York, NY 10087-7106 attn: Barbara McLaughlin. TARNOPOL--Michael L. Larger than life and one of a kind, Mickey was an inspiration to all of his many, many friends and his family. Lived life to the fullest. Even near the end when mortals would have given up, Mickey persevered, thrived and built. Always there to support, encourage and fight for his wide circle of personal friends, business associates, clients, and, of course, his wonderful family. Mickey, we are among your "new friends", having known you for "only" 25 years. So many of your relationships go back so far, to college years and before. What a tribute to you to have forged such long lasting ties and to continue to be surrounded by people who genuinely admire, care and delight in our connection to such a special individual. You set the standard for all of us, your lifelong admirers. You will be terribly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to Lynne, Lisa, Lori and David and to Mickey's center of affection, grandchildren Nicholas, Jamie, Jack and Lucy. Cheryl and Michael, Jeni and Peter Joanna and Aaron TARNOPOL--Michael L. The University of Pennsylvania mourns the death of beloved alumnus Michael L. Tarnopol, Vice Chairman of its Board of Trustees and longtime member of the Board of Overseers of Penn's Wharton School. Since his Wharton undergraduate days he has remained one of Penn's greatest advocates and closest friends. A founder of The Penn Club of New York, he also supported scholarships and professorships, and was Co-Chair of Wharton's Campaign for Sustained Leadership. We will miss him profoundly and extend sincere condolences to Mickey's wife, Lynne, and their entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Amy Gutmann, President James Riepe, Chairman, Board of Trustees TARNOPOL--Michael. All of us at the Hampton Classic Horse Show were deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and Past President, Mickey Tarnopol. Mickey's strength and great humor through our good times and bad times were an inspiration to us all. His presence, with Lynne, Lori and Lisa at several decades of our event were happy times and we will miss him always. Mickey helped us grow and showed us how to face both personal and business challenges with strength and courage. We are proud to have known our friend Mickey and will always remember him fondly. The Hampton Classic Board and staff TARNOPOL--Mickey. With profound sorrow, the Prostate Cancer Foundation notes the death of Mickey Tarnopol, an active member of our board of directors for the past decade and a leader in the race to find a cure for prostate cancer. Mickey was a dear friend and colleague who will be deeply missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Lynne and their family. Mickey valiantly fought prostate cancer both on his own behalf and on behalf of the two million men and their families battling this disease. We commit to him that we shall continue the battle. The Prostate Cancer Foundation TARNOPOL--Michael. All of us deeply regret the death of our longtime client and friend, Mickey Tarnopol. He was served closely for many years by our recently deceased colleague, Gail Winawer. We shared her admiration for him, and her dedication and cherished friendship. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to Lynne and family. The Managing Directors and Staff of American Express Tax and Business Services TARNOPOL--Michael. The Meltzer family deeply regrets the passing of a dear friend. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his wife Lynne, Lisa, Lori, David, their children and the rest of his family. He was a wonderful and loving husband, father and grandfather. A man of great distinction and integrity who left his mark and who was always sensitive to the needs of others. TARNOPOL -- Michael L. Mickey, you embraced our family as your own and we have been blessed by your love and warmth. As family, we will always treasure our shared memories. To Lynne, Lisa, Lori, David, Nicholas, Jami, Lucy and Jack, our hearts are with you today and always. Debra & Larry Halperin, Douglas, Katie, & Scott, Lisa Moore, Isadore Moore TARNOPOL--Michael L. Beloved brother-in-law and Uncle Mickey--you have been our guiding light, our inspiration to achieve only the best. Family always came first and your love of life and people came close behind. We miss you terribly and will think of you always. With love, Sande, Donald, Amy, Richie, Erica, Robert TARNOPOL--Michael. Mickey was a great man and an inspiration to everyone. He was the only person we knew who no one ever said a bad word about. We will always remember his kindness. We extend our sincerest condolences to our friend, Lynne and their children. Bruce and Robbi Toll TARNOPOL -- Michael L. Mickey, our matchmaker and friend, who epitomized loyalty, sincerity and elegance. You will always be in our hearts. Our sincerest condolences to Lynne and the entire family. Love, Marilyn, Alvin, and the Rush Family TARNOPOL--Michael L. Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Michael L. Tarnopol, and extends sincere sympathy to his family and friends. Michael Stein, President Stephen Fiverson, Secretary TARNOPOL -- Mickey. To Lynne, Lori, Lisa, David, Nicholas, Jami, Lucy and Jack, we know how special Mickey was and how much you will miss him. We were honored to know him and share his warmth and love. Mindy, Michael, Katie and Jake TARNOPOL--Michael L. 45 years of friendship and love. Mickey, you were something special. We will rememberyou with deep affection and admiration. Lynne, all of our love to you, Lisa, Lori, David, Nicholas, Jami, Jack & Lucy. Always, Edie and Marvin TARNOPOL -- Michael. A great and good man who never let his deserved success diminish his humanity. Our deepest and heartfelt condolences to Lynne, Lisa, Lori, David and all grandchildren. Catherine and Fred TARNOPOL--Michael. Thank you to Mickey for his mentoring and friendship. We will miss his wisdom. Our deepest condolences to Lynne, Lisa, Lori, David and grandchildren. We feel blessed to be a part of your extended family. Alan and Steven Mnuchin

title: Dancing to New Rules, a Rhapsody in Chrome
description: MOST buildings acquire a certain musty ridiculousness after a generation, like the clothes one wore in high school (although they cannot be hidden as easily in the back of the closet). But the Chrysler Building does not seem ridiculous; it does not even seem old. In an odd way, it is as contemporary a building as New York City has, the product of a society that was blissfully throwing off rules and discovering itself, of modern America being born.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: 19 Charged In Counterfeiting Ring
description: Nineteen men have been arrested on charges related to a check counterfeiting ring, the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, said yesterday. Ms. Pirro said investigators followed the men, who were operating from an Elmsford motel, to Catskill, where they posed as employees of a local tire recycling company to cash 34 bogus checks for a total of $13,000 at a gas station. They were arrested and charged with criminal possession of a forged instrument. Ms. Pirro said investigators later discovered more than 100 counterfeit checks and fake identification cards. Lisa W. Foderaro (NYT)

World Briefing | Asia: Indian Kashmiri Separatists Agree To Visit Pakistan
description: A separatist faction from the Indian side of Kashmir said it would accept an invitation by President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan to visit the Pakistani side next month. Mir Waiz Umar Farooq, viewed as a moderate leader of the separatist alliance All Parties Hurriyat Conference, said the delegation would apply for travel documents with the Indian authorities and travel on the new bus line that connects the two Kashmirs. A faction of hard-liners who have been critical of the bus and other measures to ease the long-running dispute between Indian and Pakistan have yet to decide whether to accept the invitation. Nor has India said whether it will allow the separatists to travel. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: 5 Leading Institutions Start Journalism Education Effort
description: The leaders of five of the nation's most prominent journalism programs are joining in a three-year, $6 million effort to try to elevate the standing of journalism in academia and find ways to prepare journalists better.

title: Review of hedge-fund instant messaging is urged
Nokia loses some grip in mobile phone market
New business laws unlikely in Germany
Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Rell Pushes Aid For Adoptees
description: Gov. M. Jodi Rell urged legislators yesterday to extend college aid to foster children who are adopted. The state provides aid to foster children, but not to those who end up being adopted. Mrs. Rell said that providing assistance would cost $415,000 for the next two years. She said some foster parents had chosen not to adopt because of college costs. "No child should be forced to choose between their family and their future," Mrs. Rell said. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Central Park Is the Scene of 2nd Robbery in 2 Months
description: A couple strolling in Central Park yesterday afternoon were robbed at gunpoint by a man who demanded their money, then fled with about $200, the police said.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: 15-Year Sentence In Molesting Case
description: A 62-year-old Baltimore man was sentenced to 15 years in prison for traveling overseas to engage in illicit sex with a minor, closing one of the first cases under a 2003 law giving federal officials new powers to prosecute Americans suspected of molesting children in other countries. The man, Richard A. Schmidt, a former teacher who had served 13 years in prison for sexually abusing a boy in Baltimore, was arrested by Cambodian officials in December 2003 after he was seen checking into a guesthouse with a 12-year-old boy. James Dao (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Sweeps Its Rivals
description: On Tuesday, the two "American Idol" finalists, Bo Bice, below, and Carrie Underwood, had their final showdown on Fox, drawing an estimated 27.2 million viewers, an 8 percent improvement over last year's equivalent show. The gap between first-place Fox and every other network on Tuesday was vast, and Fox's rating among 18-to-49-year-olds pulled it into a tie with CBS in that demographic for the May sweeps. Among the night's also-rans were CBS's "Rob and Amber Get Married" (9.93 million), NBC's series finale of "The Contender" (7.97 million) and ABC's "Trump Unauthorized" (5.61 million). At 10 p.m., the season finale of "Law & Order: SVU," one of NBC's few bright spots this season, won the hour with an audience of 15.86 million. KATE AURTHUR

title: Decline and Fall of Helmut Lang
description: ABOUT Helmut Lang's major influence over the fashion of the last 15 years there is little doubt. Consumers can thank him for flat-front pants, the number of buttons on men's suits -- first three, more recently two -- and the spiraling prices of designer jeans and T-shirts. An entire culture of prestige denim was born from Mr. Lang's low-rise jeans with intricate washes, for which he dared to charge close to $200 in the 1990's.

title: Ford to rescue Visteon, taking over 24 facilities
In blackout and swelter, Moscow plays it cool
A Teenager, a Phone Battery and a Back-to-Basics Flashlight
description: Like many teenagers, Benjamin Henry tinkered with electronics. But an ultraminimal flashlight he created five years ago, when he was 15, has become a business.

title: Austria ratifies the EU treaty
With the Gloves Off
description: A photo of President Bush gingerly holding a month-old baby was on the front page of yesterday's New York Times. Mr. Bush is in the habit of telling us how precious he thinks life is, all life.

title: Embassy in Jakarta Is Shut
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, May 26 - The United States Embassy and other American government offices in Indonesia will be closed indefinitely because of a security threat, the embassy said Thursday. The embassy provided no details, but a private security analyst said the reason was a "distinct, direct terrorist threat." The last similar closing was more than two years ago.

title: Senate Backs First of Judicial Nominees Promised a Vote
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 - After four years, hour upon hour of debate and four failed efforts to end filibusters against her, the Senate on Wednesday confirmed Justice Priscilla R. Owen for a seat on the federal appeals court in New Orleans.

title: World Briefings
description: ASIA

title: Pentagon Denies Preparing to Down Stray Plane
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 - Top military and civilian officials gathered on a conference call when a private plane strayed into restricted airspace over the District of Columbia on May 11, but they never reached the point of authorizing jet fighters to shoot it down, a Pentagon spokesman said Wednesday.

title: A Natural Alliance
description: Earlier this week I listened to Rick Warren speak at a conference sponsored by the Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life. Warren is the pastor of the Saddleback Church in California, the country's largest megachurch where 20,000 people or so go to worship each Sunday. He's also the author of "The Purpose Driven Life," which has sold more than 25 million copies in English alone.

title: U.S. Shifts Strategy on China Currency, From Float to Revaluation
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 - Even as it publicly pressures China to let its currency rise in value, the Bush administration has quietly softened one of its key demands.

title: Pentagon says lost plane was not a target
Paid Notice: Deaths   BRAVERMAN, CHARLOTTE
description: BRAVERMAN--Charlotte, on May 24. Devoted wife of the late Joseph Braverman. Beloved mother of Carol Brill, Betty Braverman, and Mark Braverman. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey Brill, Heather Brill, and Juliana Braverman. Dear sister of Milton Aidus.

title: Student's Start-Up Draws Attention and $13 Million
description: It is not easy capturing the attention of Jim Breyer, one of Silicon Valley's leading venture capitalists. But Mark Zuckerberg, a 21-year-old Harvard student, managed to do it with a Web site that has attracted 2.8 million registered users on more than 800 campuses since it began in February 2004.

title: Corruption troubles Philippine military
Up, Please. And Don't Mind the Gorilla.
description: ALBANY - EVERY evening during the waning days of October, shrieks could be heard echoing through the marble halls of the State Capitol. And they were not from Republican Senators fearful of losing their majority on Election Day.

title: Other Views: Daily Telegraph, Toronto Star, Straits Times
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mitsubishi Tokyo Profit Falls
description: Net profit at the Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group sank 40 percent, to 338.4 billion yen ($3.14 billion), for the year ended March 31, after the group took heavy charges for bad loans. The company said it reduced its bad loans to 2.7 percent of total lending by the end of March, from 2.9 percent a year earlier. Mitsubishi Tokyo forecast net profit would increase 18 percent, to 400 billion yen ($3.72 billion), for the current fiscal year after its planned merger with the Japanese banking group UFJ Holdings. The merger would create the world's largest financial group in terms of assets. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Stocks: Jump in oil price overshadows goods data
Prosecutor Says Fund-Raiser for Clinton Took Secret Gifts
description: LOS ANGELES, May 25 - As the trial of Hillary Rodham Clinton's former chief fund-raiser drew to a close, federal prosecutors said on Wednesday that the defendant, David F. Rosen, had accepted lavish, secret gifts that were "clearly meant to buy influence and access."

title: M.T.A. Adopts Ethics Code Curbing Gifts to Employees
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority adopted a code of ethics yesterday for its 65,000 employees, establishing a "zero-tolerance policy" toward employees who receive gifts from companies and individuals that do business with the authority.

title: Japan and Malaysia reach free trade deal
Ismail Merchant, Producer of Sumptuous and Literate Films, Dies at 68
description: Ismail Merchant, whose filmmaking collaboration with James Ivory created a genre of films with visually sumptuous settings that told literate tales of individuals trying to adapt to shifting societal values, died yesterday in a London hospital. He was 68.

title: A Triangle of Sex, Love and Anguish
description: Boris Eifman is an acquired taste, at least for non-Russian audiences, and it seems fair to say that a lot of New York dance connoisseurs have not yet acquired it. They express their disdain by boycotting performances of the Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg or by complaining about them if they do attend.

title: Profit Down 13% at Canadian Bank
description: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said yesterday that profit fell 13 percent in the second quarter after it set aside 75 million Canadian dollars ($60 million) more to cover costs in an investigation of trading with United States hedge funds.

title: Handing the 21st century to Asia
For the Coolest Ear Dcor,Buds You Can Barely See
description: For some music purists, even the white ear buds that dangle from iPods are terribly 2001. Instead, they show off noise-canceling in-the-ear models that are more Secret Service man than rock fan.

title: 10 Insurgents Are Killed in New Round of Battles in Iraqi City
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 25 - American and Iraqi military forces swept into Haditha, in western Iraq, before dawn on Wednesday, fighting street battles with insurgents in a new offensive to stamp out the violence that has plagued the restive west.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MAYER, MIRIAM
description: MAYER--Miriam. On May 25, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Gerald. Devoted mother of Cynthia & Robert. Cherished grandmother of Scott, Nick and Sam. Services Friday 11:30AM at "The Riverside", 76th Street, and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, DORA R.
description: DAVIS--Dora R. On May 25, 2005. Loving mother, sister, grandmother, aunt and dear friend who will be missed by all. Services will be 12:30 P.M. Friday, May 27 at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Times Co. Will Cut 190 Jobs in New York and Elsewhere
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it planned to eliminate 190 jobs at its flagship newspaper and the division that owns The Boston Globe.

description: IT is perfectly imperfect.

description: Lottery Numbers

Corrections
description: A Spotlight Baseball column on Sunday about Congressional testimony by Bud Selig, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, referred incorrectly in some copies to the movie in which the character played by Paul Newman is beaten after repeated escape attempts -- a plot line to which the commissioner's experience was compared. The film is "Cool Hand Luke," not "Hud."

title: New York and Rome
description: TWO shops opening in East Hampton are a sure sign that summer in New York is but a Memorial Day barbecue away.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Atlantic Yards Proposals Sought
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is seeking competitors for the development of its Atlantic Yards site, and has set a deadline of July 6 for proposals. A proposal by Bruce C. Ratner to build 6,000 housing units and a stadium for the Nets basketball team on the site has already won endorsements by the city and the state, which have each offered to pay $100 million for site improvements. But Tom Kelly, a spokesman for the authority, said yesterday that the agency had decided to consider other proposals in part because of its experience with its West Side railyards, which became the focus of a bidding war before an agreement was reached to sell the property to the New York Jets. Mr. Kelly said he knew of no other bids that were being prepared for the Atlantic Yards site. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Ismail Merchant, maker of elegant period films
Paid Notice: Deaths   FAHY, JOHN J.
description: FAHY--John J. on May 25, 2005 of Douglaston, NY. Beloved husband of the late Eileen Fahy (nee Cannon). Loving father of Karen. Decorated W.W. II Veteran, served FDNY 42 years, retired Battalion Chief. Interment private. Donations to the Cornell Burn Center, 525 E. 68 St., Room L706, NY, NY 10021. For information Doyle B. Shaffer Funeral Home.

title: World Briefing | Australia: Moves To Soften Asylum Policy
description: Prime Minister John Howard's policy of mandatory detention for asylum seekers is under attack from within his own right-center Liberal Party. Several moderate senators are calling for a softening of the policy, by making mandatory detention of illegal immigrants harder, reducing the holding period -- it can now last years -- and allowing for judicial review. Hundreds of men, women and children, a large number from Afghanistan and Iraq, have been held in isolated camps or on the tiny Pacific island of Nauru in the last four years. Adding to the debate, the immigration minister, Amanda Vanstone, said there may have been as many as 200 cases of wrongful detention of immigrants in recent years. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: NBC News May Get New Chief
description: Neal Shapiro, the president of NBC News since 2001, has told his superiors at the network in recent days that he would like to leave his post, two senior executives at NBC Universal said yesterday.

title: Shakeup is expected after French EU vote
Accounts
description: Northwestern Mutual Financial Network, Milwaukee, began a review for its account, which has been handled since 1948 by the Chicago office of JWT, owned by the WPP Group. Spending was estimated at $15 million to $20 million. JWT Chicago will take part in the review, which is being managed by Jones Lundin Beals, Chicago; the other participants have not been identified.

title: Next call for Net phoning: Regulation
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Three-Alarm Fire On Upper East Side
description: Residents of an Upper East Side building had to flee their apartments last night when a stubborn three-alarm fire spread to at least three floors of the five-story building, the Fire Department said. The fire, at 513 E. 81st Street, near East End Avenue, started in a second-floor apartment and quickly spread through a shaft to other floors, Deputy Assistant Chief John Coloe said. He said the apartment where the fire started was like a Collyers' mansion, the term firefighters use for a residence piled with belongings. Once fire hoses sprayed water on the fire, Chief Coloe said, the piles of belongings collapsed into the narrow passageways throughout the apartment, making the firefighting effort a great deal more difficult. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries, Chief Coloe said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Deadline for Beverage Offer
description: A consortium led by Constellation Brands, the world's largest wine producer, has until June 29 to make a bid for the beverage company Allied Domecq, British regulators said. Allied Domecq agreed to be bought for about $14 billion by Pernod Ricard of France in April. Constellation, working with Brown-Forman, the maker of Jack Daniels bourbon, and two private equity firms, said it might make a higher offer. If the Constellation group does not make a formal bid by deadline, the consortium must wait six months before trying again. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: For Chrysler, a Tribute to His Own Rise
description: IN 1930, when the first visitors to the Chrysler Building's 71st-floor observation deck made their way out of the elevator, they passed a vitrine containing a box of metal tools -- wrenches and rulers and other engineer gear. Walter P. Chrysler, who had made them himself and used them in his early career as a machinist, was displaying them as emblems of his rise.

title: Climate Change And the President
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JONES, JENNIE ROTHMAN
description: JONES -- Jennie Rothman. The leadership and staff of United Jewish Communities/ Federations of North America mourn the loss of Jennie Rothman Jones, UJC National Women's Philanthropy board member. Mrs. Jones dedicated her life to Jewish communal service and advocacy. May her memory be a blessing.

title: Shiites Offer to Give Sunnis Larger Role on Broader Panel Writing a Constitution
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 25 - Under American pressure to draw Sunni Arabs into the drafting of Iraq's constitution, the Shiite religious parties that dominate the transitional government agreed Wednesday to re-establish a constitutional commission with as many as 15 of the 101 seats reserved for Sunni Arabs.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesian Airline Picks Boeing
description: The Boeing Company is expected to sign a purchase agreement today with Lion Air of Indonesia, the company said. Amanda Landers, a spokeswoman for Boeing, which is based in Chicago, declined to comment about details of the order. Lion Air was expected to decide on as many as 60 Boeing 737's or Airbus SAS A320 planes as a replacement for its fleet of MD-80 aircraft, Joseph Nadol, an analyst at J.P. Morgan Securities, wrote in a report.

title: The President's Stem Cell Theology
description: President Bush seems determined to thwart any loosening of the restrictions he has imposed on federal financing of embryonic stem cell research, despite rising sentiment in Congress and the nation at large for greater federal support of this fast-emerging field. His actions are based on strong religious beliefs on the part of some conservative Christians, and presumably the president himself. Such convictions deserve respect, but it is wrong to impose them on this pluralistic nation.

title: Judge Directs Scrushy Jury to Do Its Job
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 25 - Facing confusion and disagreement among jurors, the judge in the fraud trial of Richard M. Scrushy, the former chief executive of HealthSouth, directed them on Wednesday to continue deliberating and urged them to work hard to reach a verdict.

title: Developer dials up new future for Dome
Velocity
Corrections
description: A front-page picture grouping in The Arts yesterday with a review of American Ballet Theater's opening gala, at the Metropolitan Opera House, carried an incomplete credit. The three pictures of Savion Glover were by Richard Termine, but the picture of dancers in "Swan Lake" was by Sara Krulwich of The New York Times.

title: Her Hand Has a Mind of Its Own
description: "Dress Suits to Hire," a lesbian love story told in the overheated style of film noir, begins with a wink at the audience. A femme fatale struggling with her sexuality, Deeluxe (Peggy Shaw), is strangled by her own right hand. Michigan (Lois Weaver) walks toward the body and looks at the hand disapprovingly. "I suppose you know what this will mean," she says. "She will be unable to do the show."

title: Leaping the Chrysler in a Single Bound
description: 1. NOW that the landmark Plaza Hotel is going condo, Ralph Lauren has bought every shingle, sash weight, suite, room, closet and hallway from the rooftop down to the 11th floor and will move the whole shebang intact to a new home atop the former Huntington Hartford museum on Columbus Circle. By lifting people's gazes up and away from the eyesore museum to the Beaux-Arts elegance of the beloved old Plaza towering above, Mr. Lauren will be performing a civic service as well as boasting the classiest corporate headquarters since Napoleon took over Versailles.

title: In the Chatting Olympics, Look for Merv Griffin
description: Correction Appended

title: One Tough Little Camera
Loud, Proud, Unabridged: It Is Too Reading!
description: JIM HARRIS, a lifelong bookworm, cracked the covers of only four books last year. But he listened to 54, all unabridged. He listened to Harry Potter and "Moby-Dick," Don DeLillo and Stephen King. He listened in the car, eating lunch, doing the dishes, sitting in doctors' offices and climbing the stairs at work.

title: Ex-School Official Accused of Personal Use of District Funds
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., May 25 - A former Mineola school administrator used school contractors to install a new driveway, brick patio, Japanese fish pond with waterfall, lawn sprinklers, sod, shrubs, trees and landscaping stones at his home in Commack, according to a 20-count indictment announced on Wednesday.

title: Iraq Announces Major Effort to Curb Insurgents
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 26 - In a sweeping effort to strike back at a violent insurgency that has hobbled Iraq's new government since it took power nearly a month ago, the Defense and Security Ministers said today they would deploy thousands of troops to stage a massive search-and-arrest operation in the capital over the next week.

title: Anheuser-Busch Issues Profit Warning
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, the world's largest brewer, said second-quarter profit would decline from a year ago because its beer sales were slipping in the United States.

title: Runaway Bride Is Indicted
description: ATLANTA, May 25 - Jennifer Wilbanks, whose disappearance during a jog in Duluth, Ga., days before her wedding prompted a costly manhunt last month, was indicted Wednesday by a Gwinnett County grand jury on charges of lying to the police.

title: CUNY Finds a Way to Lure the Brightest
description: As first-place winner in the Intel Science Talent Search this year, David L.V. Bauer, a senior at Hunter College High School, could have had his pick of colleges. He chose the Honors College at City College.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: 2 wounded in Madrid car bombing
Were You Raised by Wolves? Or Perhaps Weight Lifters?
description: SWEAT puddles left unwiped on exercise benches, dirty tissues tossed on the floor, members whose unwashed T-shirts reek of days-old perspiration, cranky gymgoers who berate the staff when their favorite class is full: poor manners are rampant at health clubs. And all too often one quarrelsome member lashes out at another.

description: More Battles in Iraq, Military and Political A joint force of United States marines and Iraqi Special Forces moved into Haditha, in western Iraq, to root out insurgents, the military said. Ten insurgents were killed.

description: To the Editor:

title: False Advertising: Same Old Mets
description: ATLANTA, May 25 - For a while, it was enough that the Mets had a new manager from Brooklyn and a new general manager from Queens, a center fielder who cost $119 million and an ace pitcher who could make everybody dance in the aisles.

title: Dueling Styles and Political Legacies Shape a Republican Primary
description: WEST WINDSOR, N.J., May 25 - They were both Republican mayors who took office as development was beginning to explode in their communities. But beyond that, Bret Schundler and Douglas R. Forrester, the leading candidates in the Republican primary for governor in New Jersey, have about as much in common as a skyline and a subdivision.

title: Currencies: Euro gets a respite from dollar's gains
A Keyboard That Lets the Supremely Confident Show Disdain for Qwerty
description: In the programming world, only the strong survive. But what about the smug? A new product, Das Keyboard, seems to have both in mind. It's a regular 104-key keyboard -- except that nothing is printed on the keys.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINKOFF, HARRY
description: MINKOFF -- Harry. Passed away at his home in Great Neck, NY on May 7, 2005 at the age of 87. Born in Brooklyn on March 28, 1918. Graduated CCNY in 1940, married Ruth Blumenfeld the same year. Fought in the Battle of the Bulge during WWII. After the war he founded Gift-Pax, an international product sampling firm, serving as President until the 1980's. Harry had a deep commitment to the arts, education, and the Jewish world. He served the boards of numerous organizations. He is survived by his wife, Ruth; three children, Jane, Larry and George; and seven grandchildren. A memorial service was held on May 11, 2005 at Temple BethEl in Great Neck. Memorial contributions can be made in his name to the UJA Federation of NY.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: H.I.V. Infections Slow
description: India, which is estimated to rank second, after South Africa, in the total number of AIDS cases in the world, announced that H.I.V. infection rates in the country had slowed substantially. The Health Ministry reported that 28,000 people became infected in 2004, compared with 520,000 in 2003. India seized on the data to argue that its prevention efforts have paid off. Critics here and abroad have criticized India for not tackling AIDS early and aggressively enough. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Six Men, Said to Be in Gangs, Are Charged in Killings
description: Six Brooklyn men described as members or leaders of a violent gang responsible for five killings and for attempts to kill police officers were indicted yesterday on charges including racketeering and murder, the police and federal prosecutors said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Senators May Try to Block Vote on Nominee for U.N. Post
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 - Senate Democrats signaled Wednesday that they would try to block Republican efforts to push through a confirmation vote this week on John R. Bolton to be ambassador to the United Nations unless the Bush administration first provides classified documents that could shed light on his role in the handling of secret intelligence matters.

title: In the Background, but No Bit Player
description: IT rises like a glistening flute of Champagne from the beer-bottle skyline, as if in toast to a New Year's mix of emotions: hope and loss; love found and love betrayed; what can be and what almost was. And when you see it, you know instantly, absolutely, where the movie wants you to be.

title: The Chrysler After-Party
description: THE Art Deco Society of New York, which is celebrating its 25th anniversary, is the host of the World Congress on Art Deco, which takes place every two years in a different city. Several of the events will be open to the public, starting with a symposium today, held at the Proschansky Auditorium at CUNY Graduate Center, Fifth Avenue at 34th Street, from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. Speakers will include Carol Willis, the director of the Skyscraper Museum of New York, who will talk about Art Deco skyscrapers like the Chrysler Building, the Empire State Building and Rockefeller Center, and Sandra Cohen-Rose, the author of "Northern Deco: Art Deco Architecture in Montreal" (Corona, 1996). The fee for the symposium is $50.

title: Ground Rules for the Windows-Macintosh War
U.S. hints at return to WTO over subsidies
The Farm-Subsidy Model of Financing Academia
description: THE University of Michigan received $4 million for curriculum development and training at its Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy. Marshall University in West Virginia received $11 million for a new heart institute. The University of Iowa is hoping to get $16.5 million from a pending highway bill to study taxation of drivers based on miles driven on certain types of highways.

title: Commerce Bank's Robberies Counter a Citywide Decline
description: Bank robberies and attempted bank robberies are down 45 percent in New York City this year compared with last year, in part because of an aggressive police campaign that started in July 2003, according to the police. But Commerce Bank, which bills itself as friendly and convenient, is apparently that to robbers as well -- it's experiencing more robberies now than it did then, the police say, making it the most robbed bank in the city.

title: Triumph for Fox, but Pain for NBC
description: One of the most competitive and volatile network television seasons ever recorded ended officially last night with three networks, Fox, CBS and ABC, celebrating and one network, NBC, decelerating.

title: U.S. Embassy in Indonesia Closed After Threat
description: JAKARTA, May 26 - The American embassy was closed today because of what officials would describe only as an unspecified security threat. But a Western counterterrorism official and a private security analyst said the decision was made after a diagram of the embassy and details of how to carry out an attack using explosives were posted on an Islamic Web site.

title: Before the Crash: Bringing in the Blue Chips
description: ALTHOUGH his ego played a role in the creation of what he once called a "monument to me," Walter P. Chrysler also had millions of his own dollars invested in his skyscraper. It had to pay.

title: The Red Sox Are Finding a Way to Win and, Maybe, Repeat
description: TORONTO, May 25 - The chatty starter named Curt Schilling has appeared on more sports talk radio shows in Boston than games for the Red Sox. David Wells, another motormouth starter, has won only two games and has even mused about nearing the end. Closer Keith Foulke has been miserable. Fans are treating Edgar Renteria, the $40 million shortstop, as if he is wearing a Derek Jeter mask.

title: A Wild but Wily Hodgepodge of Chaos
description: Movie music is a kind of ectoplasm. We hear it and yet we don't hear it. It's there and it isn't. Its importance as something independent is an idea very much in fashion now, but to take one example, Bernard Herrmann's music does not survive long without Hitchcock's images. On the other hand, "Vertigo" does not survive without Herrmann's music.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CAPELLUTO, VICTOR
description: CAPELLUTO--Victor. Missing you so much each day. You are forever in our hearts. Laura, Betty and Shirley

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBINS, STANLEY
description: ROBINS -- Stanley, 80, of Ocean Township, formerly of West Orange, died Tuesday, May 24 at St. Barnabas Hospice, Long Branch. He was born in the Bronx, NY and raised in Brooklyn. He is survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Janice; his children Andrew Robins and Dr. Michele Schultz Robins of Wayside and Rachael and William Barish of West Orange; and his three grandchildren Jake, Evan and Ali Robins.

title: Schrder's gamble
Documents Say DetaineesCited Koran Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 - Newly released documents show that detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, complained repeatedly to F.B.I. agents about disrespectful handling of the Koran by military personnel and, in one case in 2002, said they had flushed a Koran down a toilet.

title: More gadgets, more lost, more found
Takeover bid for Australian grocer
With a Little Help From Our Friends
description: Kandahar, Afghanistan - ON Saturday, May 14, several hundred people gathered in the windswept main street of Qalat, the capital of Zabul Province in southern Afghanistan. Led by local religious leaders, the crowd chanted slogans protesting the supposed desecration of the Koran by interrogators at the detention center run by the United States at Guantnamo Bay, as reported in the May 9 issue of Newsweek.

title: A Lawmaker Works, Oddly Enough, to Keep His Voters' Backyards Dangerous
description: Dallas - It is no surprise, given the close ties between industry and regulators in Washington these days, that Joe Barton is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Mr. Barton, a Texas Republican, is such an energy industry loyalist -- and so soft on air pollution -- that his hometown paper dubbed him "Smokey Joe." He has regularly helped his industry friends by weakening environmental laws and handing out tax breaks. But now he seems poised to do something far more disturbing: block legislation to secure chemical plants against terrorist attacks.

title: An institution for the counterculture
Jeter's Catch Keeps Yankees on Collision Course
description: When a team wins for the fourth time in five games and for the 14th time in its last 16, the credit gets spread around the way it was last night after the Yankees defeated the Detroit Tigers, 4-2, at blustery Yankee Stadium.

title: New School, in Split With Actors Studio, to Create Own Program
description: New School University has announced plans to establish its own graduate acting school, naming a pair of Broadway veterans to run it and officially severing its ties with the Actors Studio, the venerable association that had run the university's drama department for more than a decade.

title: Another View of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Blames Boston Police for Errors in Fan's Death
description: BOSTON, May 25 - Planning and tactical errors over several months by the Boston Police Department led to the death of a 21-year-old college student who was struck by a pepper spray ball outside Fenway Park in October, an independent commission said in a report released Wednesday.

title: Rapunzels Of a Certain Age
description: IT just got harder to judge a woman's age by the length of her hair. Not so long ago if you found yourself walking behind a woman with soft curls reaching below her shoulders, you could guess with 99 percent certainty that she was younger than 40, probably a lot younger.

title: Arts, Briefly; Rock Reigns on the Chart
description: With no new hip-hop contenders for the top of the Billboard album chart, rock continues to reign. System of a Down's new "Mezmerize" (American/Columbia) is the fifth rock album in row to top the chart. It sold 453,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, about 170,000 more than its nearest competitor, Toby Keith's "Honkytonk University" (DreamWorks Nashville). Mariah Carey's "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island/Def Jam) holds at No. 3, with sales of 173,000; last week's No. 1, the Dave Matthews Band's "Stand Up" (RCA), dropped to No. 4; the R&B singer Kem reached No. 5 with his "Kem II" (Motown). The only hip-hop album in the Top 10 is 50 Cent's "Massacre" (Interscope), which dropped three spots to No. 7, though with 81,000 sales last week it continues to be a steady seller. BEN SISARIO

title: World Briefing | Asia: Singapore Advises China And Japan To Cool Off
description: Tiny Singapore stepped forward to counsel peace between Asia's quarreling giants, China and Japan. "The two countries have not reconciled and come to terms with the history of the Second World War, the way Germany and France have done," Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, told Japanese business leaders on a visit to Tokyo. Friction "is inevitable" as their influence grows, he said, but a "collision is not inevitable." Both sides, he said, "need to moderate nationalist sentiment." James Brooke (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Return of 'The Caine Mutiny' to Broadway
description: After the success of the revival of "Twelve Angry Men," another beloved courtroom drama is coming to Broadway. Herman Wouk's "Caine Mutiny Court-Martial" will open in the 2005-6 season, said Jeffrey Richards, one of its producers. Jerry Zaks will direct. Adapted by Mr. Wouk, who turns 90 tomorrow, from his Pulitzer Prize-winning novel "The Caine Mutiny," the play follows a trial for mutiny aboard an American minesweeper during World War II. Starring Henry Fonda as the defense lawyer, it had its premiere on Broadway in a 1954 production at the Plymouth Theater and was turned into a film later that year with Humphrey Bogart, left, as Queeg. No theater has been named for the revival. JASON ZINOMAN

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: One Of Two Women In Leader's Race Bows Out

Ms. Alvear, a former foreign minister, was one of two women seeking the nomination of the center-left coalition that has governed Chile since the fall of Gen. Augusto Pinochet in 1990. Her pullout leaves Michelle Bachelet, a Socialist and former defense minister, as the only candidate on the now-united left and makes her the favorite to defeat the two men who are battling for support on the right. Leaping the Chrysler in a Single Bound
description: NEW YORK skyline watchers are agog over three handsome buildings rising in Gotham: large, middling and sawed-off, and identified only by the numbers on their facades. What do that 20, 15 and 10 signify? Smart new business addresses? Number of floors? Trendy company names? None of the above. In a brilliant melding of architectural ingenuity and fiscal pessimism, the new corporate headquarters of General Motors is a choice of three corporate headquarters, depending on how much further the company's share of the United States automotive market declines: to 20 percent, to 15 percent or to a mere 10 percent, with the reduction in space exactly proportional to the reduction in staff. And at heads-up General Motors nothing goes to waste: the two unused buildings will serve as storage for unsold vehicles.

description: Voters overwhelmingly approved a constitutional change to allow Egypt's first contested presidential election, Interior Minister Habib el-Adly announced on state-run television. He said that 83 percent of the voters in the referendum on Wednesday had backed the change and that 54 percent of the country's 32 million registered voters had participated. Opposition figures -- who had called for a boycott of the referendum -- quickly dismissed the figures. In Washington, President Bush criticized the government of President Hosni Mubarak for the violence during the voting, including the beating of opposition demonstrators. "The idea of people expressing themselves in opposition to the government, then getting beaten, is not our view of how a democracy ought to work," Mr. Bush said. title: The Listings; ELEPHANT LARRY
description: "We pursue understanding beyond the limitations of existing knowledge, ideology and disciplinary structure," the mission statement of Cornell University says, and five of its former students seem to have absorbed that methodology, in a fun-house-mirror sort of way. The five, who met at the campus and are now in their mid-20's, constitute the sketch-comedy troupe Elephant Larry, and they have been selling out "Boom," their Saturday night show at the People's Improv Theater, since early April with a hilarious multimedia mix of the deadpan and the maniacal. The sketches call to mind, variously, Monty Python, Kids in the Hall and Second City, yet they don't feel like knockoffs. Perhaps that's because they ricochet fearlessly from subtly savvy to aggressively lowbrow. In the latter category are a sketch in which Frankenstein's monster makes his own monster and another called "Goblins America" with the troupe in ridiculous masks, singing a ribald song to the tune of "God Bless America." Geoff Haggerty, who founded Elephant Larry three years ago with Chris Principe, Jeff Solomon, Stefan Lawrence and Alexander Zalben, said that "Goblins," like much of the troupe's material, came about through serendipity: somebody made a reference to the patriotic song, somebody else misheard him, and by the time the riffing was done they had a sketch. As for the subtle stuff, Mr. Principe and Mr. Haggerty (above in goggles with Mr. Solomon, left; Mr. Zalben, with bucket; and Mr. Lawrence) show a knack for respecting the audience's intelligence with a droll sketch in which they are 19th-century fellows who can't remember what year it is; the references they drop will wake up all those brain cells that have been dormant since your high school history final. Oh, and don't expect much time to catch your breath during "Boom": the quintet covers its costume changes with nutty film clips. (People's Improv Theater, 154 West 29th Street; (212)563-7488.) NEIL GENZLINGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEILBUT, MONIKA
description: HEILBUT--Monika, on May 24, 2005 at age 56. Taken from us much too young, Monika was the beloved mother of Lili and friend to so many. Monika was born in Ravensburg, Germany on June 4, 1948 and became a U.S. citizen in 1975. She was an accomplished gymnast and was a judge in the Olympic Games in 1984. She taught at the Chapin School in New York and worked most recently at Synapse Group, Inc., a division of Time Warner. Monika was loved for her quick wit, her effervescent smile and her irrepressible spirit. Never one to suffer fools, she also loved museums, great shows and opera, fine dining and her only daughter most of all. We mourn her loss. She is survived by her mother Elli Volkmann, sisters, Regine and Susanne, and brothers, Peter and Uli, all of whom remain in Germany. Monika's wake will be held at the Bouton Funeral Home in Georgetown, CT from 7-9 PM on today, May 27. Funeral services will be at the Bethlehem Lutheran Church in Georgetown, CT on Saturday, May 28, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lili Heilbut Education Fund, C/O Michael Loeb at Synapse, 4 High Ridge Park, Stamford, CT. 06905.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TYLER, HAROLD R.
description: TYLER--Harold R. We are profoundly saddened at the passing on May 25 of our sole surviving name partner, the Honorable Harold R. Tyler. Judge Tyler was a partner with the firm from 1977 to 1991 and Of Counsel from 1992 until his death. Judge Tyler's distinguished career prior to joining the firm included service as an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York from 1953 to 1955 and as U.S. Assistant Attorney General for the Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department from 1960 to 1961. He was appointed as a federal judge in the Southern District of New York by President John F. Kennedy in 1962 and served on the federal bench until 1975, when he was appointed Deputy Attorney General of the United States. When he joined the firm of Patterson, Belknap & Webb in 1977, its name was changed to Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler. Judge Tyler brought distinction to the firm every day, and we will miss his presence sorely. We join his many friends in sending our deepest condolences to his family. All of Us at Patterson Belknap Webb & Tyler

title: A Season's Joys: Mopeds and Nostalgia

And, of course, the hushed sound of windless waves on the beach after everybody but you and yours has packed up to get to the market before it closes, a sound that is inevitably accompanied by the observation: "Why don't we always stay this late? title: 'KOYAANISQATSI'
description: It's been more than two decades since the director Godfrey Reggio teamed up with Philip Glass and the cinematographer Ron Fricke to create this sweeping film about runaway technology, modern urban living and the widening chasm that separates us from the natural world. The Hopi title translates as "life out of balance," and there is no dialogue or characters -- just an arresting collage of images that contrasts the pristine beauty of the sky and the wilderness with the chaos of city life, often sped up into a hypnotic swirl. Mr. Glass's score is full of primal chants and restless, churning music that help the visuals reach their emotional mark. Viewed today, "Koyaanisqatsi," above, may seem like a vintage artifact of the early 1980's and of an earlier chapter of the environmental movement, but the film also comes across as eerily prescient. Mr. Reggio, a former monk, later expanded his critique with "Powaqqatsi" (1988) and "Naqoyqatsi" (2002), and this week brings a rare opportunity to consider the trilogy as a group. Beginning Thursday with "Koyaanisqatsi," probably the best of the trio, Lincoln Center will present all three films on consecutive nights, with a live performance of the scores by the Philip Glass Ensemble, conducted by Michael Riesman. (Thursday at 8 p.m., Rose Theater, Broadway at 60th Street, (212)721-6500; $35.) JEREMY EICHLER

description: Stupefying is one word for Ara Peterson's short, mostly abstract maximalist-minimalist videos, 11 of which play in a sequential loop at John Connelly Presents in Chelsea. Manic examples of virtuosic editing, they are rapid-fire successions of changing, pulsating patterns, some geometric, others lava-lamp oozy. One new black-and-white piece, "Flip Grid Cycle," looks like a corporate logo repeatedly forming and breaking apart, while "Kaleidoscope Feedback I," a collaboration with the artists Eamon Brown and Jim Drain, suggests amoebas jostling on a microscope slide. Earlier color videos, made when Mr. Peterson and Mr. Drain were members of Forcefield, are aggressively hypnotic. Later pieces -- "Energy Fields" (2003), above, is an example -- are like Op Art on fast-forward and also like flashbacks to the light shows of the 1960's drugs-and-music culture, though there is nothing mellow about them. Their optical assault is a reminder of how unlaid-back and on-the-attack that culture could be. The show's one figurative video, "UV" (for Ultra Violence), pieced together from movie clips of people being shot, stabbed and sliced, and seen here in a reduced version, is a killer: a 3-minute, 9-second bad trip coming at you like a spray of machine-gun fire. It rescues Mr. Peterson's work from the creepy, craftsy, Summer of Love category to which it has thus far been assigned and makes it something that Andy Warhol, of the candy-colored disasters, or maybe Charles Manson, could love. (John Connelly Presents Annex, 526 West 26th Street, (212)337-9563, through June 18.) HOLLAND COTTER

"Europe would break down" if the treaty were rejected, he warned, while "France would be less strong in defending its interests." But poll after poll has predicted that the French will reject the treaty, and the latest, for Le Figaro, gave the "no" camp 55 percent. The constitution needs a unanimous yes from the union's 25 countries to come into force, and its rejection by France would be humiliating personal defeat for Mr. Chirac. title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: W.T.O. Names a Director General
description: The World Trade Organization appointed Pas-cal Lamy, the former European Union trade negotiator, left, as its next director general. Mr. Lamy will begin his four-year term Sept. 1 after Supachai Panitchpakdi leaves the post. Mr. Lamy was approved without the usual regional animosities, as developing countries warmed to his stance that the poorest countries should not have to open their markets as quickly as richer nations. As the trade representative, Mr. Lamy often fought with the United States on issues from steel production to genetically modified crops, but he managed to maintain good relations with Washington in part because of his friendship with Robert B. Zoellick, the former United States trade representative. Mr. Lamy's efforts to get the European Union to cut farm subsidies, which hurt the developing world by depressing prices, also pleased poor nations, though it earned him criticism at home in France. Mr. Lamy's first job will be to prepare the W.T.O. for a meeting on the current round of trade talks in December. Tom Wright (IHT)

title: A Cruel Choice for a Priest Manipulated by the Nazis
description: Tall, hollow-cheeked and unnervingly thin, the German actor Ulrich Matthes is well suited to playing men living at moral extremes. In "Downfall," Oliver Hirschbiegel's drama of Hitler's last days, he played Joseph Goebbels, and his quiet, weirdly sensitive portrayal of Goebbels's fanatical loyalty was, in its way, a more frightening portrait of monstrosity than Bruno Ganz's ranting impersonation of the Fhrer himself. Now, in "The Ninth Day," a somber, thought-provoking new film by Volker Schlndorff, Mr. Matthes approaches the historical catastrophe of Nazism from the side of its victims. He plays the Rev. Henri Kremer, a Roman Catholic priest from Luxembourg who is sent to Dachau and then released in an act of clemency that only reveals the depth and inventiveness of Nazi evil.

title: LUCIANA SOUZA
description: This singer inarguably lives in the jazz world: she plays regularly with a quartet, writes for it, teaches it. But being Brazilian Ms. Souza, above, also sings samba, and sings it with satisfying care and energy. Her abilities as a composer and bandleader have enabled her to pick and arrange all kinds of sambas for voice and guitar alone, and her first album along these lines, "Brazilian Duos," from 2002, was a display of almost effortless authority. The second helping, "Duos II" -- just released on the Sunnyside label -- tops it in places. The album was recorded with a number of different guitarists in America and Brazil, but her regular duet partner in New York is the guitarist Romero Lubambo, who gives her the counterpoint and speed and swing she needs. It's an affectionate partnership, and a true pleasure to watch. (Luciana Souza and Romero Lubambo: "Brazilian Duos," Tuesday through next Sunday, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., with an 11:30 p.m. set next Friday and Saturday, at Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street; (212)576-2232; cover, $20; $25 next Friday and Saturday.) title: St. Simons Island, Ga.
description: THE Golden Isles, the barrier islands of Georgia's coast, meld two worlds: the sunny beaches and lollygag pace of island life and the stately Spanish moss-draped grace of the South with antebellum graveyards and ruined plantations. St. Simons, about equidistant between Jacksonville, Fla., and Savannah, Ga., in particular is a literary haunt, the favored island of writers like Tina McElroy Ansa, whose popular black heroine, Lena McPherson, can see ghosts, and William Diehl, whose bestselling thrillers involve assassins and espionage. Hidden amid the island's resorts and golf courses are remnants of the time when the only residents were Gullah-Geechee people, rice-tenders descended from slaves who speak their own blend of African languages and English. St. Simons, where oak trees turn avenues into tunnels of green, is the hub of the barrier islands, with about 13,000 residents and a bustling strip of restaurants and shops called the Village. SHAILA DEWAN

The fiery mane either loosely billows, as free as the spirit to which it is attached, or hides from view in a severe turban, but neither humidity nor hats diminish its redoubtable bounce.

title: Arts, Briefly; Goldman Band Closes Down
description: The Goldman Memorial Band, one of the oldest and largest concert bands in the United States, has closed down after the members, who are represented by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, rejected its proposal to reduce its size. The band's management had sought to cut five members from its ranks over three years, to 48 players, said Mark Heter, the group's secretary, but its proposal was voted down on Monday evening. The reduction would not have cut any of the band's 45 tenured posts, Mr. Heter said. The Goldman Memorial Band, based in New York, was founded in 1911 and was known as a force in the development of the concert band repertory. The band's termination takes effect immediately; its annual Memorial Day weekend concerts at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn and at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx will not take place. description: Alaska Airlines and its pilots' union reached an agreement on a new contract yesterday that would cut wages by 20 percent and replace a contract installed after an arbitrator said this month that pay should be cut 26 percent. The new five-year agreement is subject to approval by the carrier's 1,465 pilots, who are represented by the Air Line Pilots Association. A spokeswoman for the union, Jenn Farrell, said union leaders would meet Wednesday to decide whether to send the proposed contract to pilots for a vote that would occur by the end of next month. Company and union negotiators were able to reduce the size of the pay cut by changing some work rules to gain more productivity for the airline, both sides said.

For connoisseurs or even customers, this was distressing. (Imagine how Miles from "Sideways" would have taken such news.) For those who run a growing number of family vineyards across the country, such barriers make little sense. Now, a recent Supreme Court ruling gives New York and other states the best opportunity in years to ship their local vintages out of state.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechen Warlord Says He Caused Moscow Blackout

In an e-mail message to a separatist Web site that often posts his messages, Mr. Basayev, who has said he planned and ordered the seizure of a Beslan public school last year that ended with more than 330 deaths, said his latest operation had exceeded his expectations. The Kremlin, which says the blackout was caused by technical problems, promptly rejected his claim. "This is ridiculous," said Dmitri S. Peskov, a spokesman for President Vladimir V. Putin. Paid Notice: Deaths   ANGLIN, HELEN
description: ANGLIN -- Helen, Grand Dame of New York City, dies at 102. Helen Anglin was born in Youngstown, Ohio to John and Elizabeth Verosic in 1902 and had six siblings: Michael, Louis, John, Joseph, Stephen and Elizabeth. She left Youngstown to pursue her dreams of opening a millinery store in New York City at the age of 15. She lived on the Upper East Side and Atlantic Beach and met the friends that she would have for the remainder of her life. She was married to Michael Angelino in the late 1920's but chose divorce after four years and spent the remainder of her life as a fun-loving single woman. The love of her life was Phillip Bookbinder, with whom she spent 25 happy years until his death. Her great-niece, Janet Carlson Sanders, was made her legal guardian in 1996, and then Helen moved to her home in Brooklyn Heights and lived her remaining years with Janet, her husband John and their children, twins Helen (named for her great-great aunt) and Harry. Her beloved nurses, Shari Collazo and Ann Holder, who became members of her family, cared daily for Helen. She was a well-known and infamous figure in her neighborhood and was active in her church, St. Charles Borromeo. Mass of Christian burial at St. Charles Borromeo on Saturday, May 28, 2005 at 10AM. For more information, call Scotto Funeral Home, 718-875-2515.

title: Arts, Briefly; Critic Beats the Blues

The reason? "I'm working for Bloomberg," he said in a telephone interview. "I'm going to reach all kinds of people all over the world, even in print form, but mostly on this giant Web." He said he would become the theater critic for Bloomberg.com., with a column appearing Fridays. "That puts me parallel with the newspapers," he said, alluding to the day when reviews of many major plays appear. "Before," he said, recalling his years with New York, "we were a few days after. This is a real plus." Mr. Simon said he expected to begin his Web assignment "next week or the week after." PAULA SCHWARTZ

Although Mr. Rosenberg will lose his job as the sports news reporter on the morning show, he will keep his spot as co-host of the 10-a.m.-to-1-p.m. show with Joe Beningo. "He's off Imus's show for some remarks he made that I would really rather not repeat," the station's general manager, Lee Davis, said yesterday. Mr. Rosenberg made the comments during the May 18 broadcast. Chris Carlin, the overnight host, has moved into Mr. Rosenberg's reporting spot on the Imus show. Jerry Recco, WFAN's Giants reporter and a sports news anchor, and Tony Paige, the Saturday night host, will temporarily fill the overnight host position. JOE BRESCIA

A turf war among rival drug gangs has unleashed a devastating wave of violence in Nuevo Laredo, with more than 50 people killed so far this year. title: Gross Profits
description: Clorox ToiletWand "The disgusting is marvelously promiscuous and ubiquitous," William Ian Miller observes in his book "The Anatomy of Disgust," at the start of a chapter titled "Orifices and Bodily Wastes." This is no doubt true, even if, by and large, we would rather not hear about it. Certainly you would get no argument from the parties involved in designing a popular product called the Clorox ToiletWand. Introduced last year, this $10 item (or "system," as Clorox calls it) differs from the traditional toilet brush by relying on a disposable head that is tossed out after use; replacements cost about $3 a half-dozen. This development is described by the company as a "game changer" in the field of bathroom cleaning, but it is also just one example of a growing number of products designed to help us cope with ubiquitous disgust.

World War II descended on planet earth as swift and deadly as a desert whirlwind, but the forces that unleashed its terrible power had been building beyond the horizon for years. Whole libraries exist to house only the books that grapple with the roots and causes but, as most wars do, it boils down to three simple things: pride, property, and power-and two more complicated things: prejudice and persecution. With this in mind I believe it is useful for readers of this story to have an appreciation, however abbreviated, of the events leading up to the critical year of 1942, and in that spirit a concise narration is offered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELKIN, LORRETTA
description: ELKIN--Lorretta, died on May 10, 2005, at Medford Leas. Born in New York City, she lived in Pennsylvania and New Jersey for the past 50 years. A member of Phi Beta Kappa, she received a BA from Washington Square College and MA from the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, NYU. Her childhood and young adult years were spent in the theater, including Broadway shows and two USO tours. After a short period of teaching English literature at the college level, she joined ETS, from which she retired as Managing Editor of Test Editing. Her retirement activities included broadcasting news at Audiovision, an arm of the Library for the Blind and Handicapped, and travel. Ms. Elkin is survived by her sons, Dr. Peter Elkin of Rochester, MN, and Roger Elkin of Hoboken, NJ; daughters-in-law, Margaret and Tasha, and grandsons, Jared and Aaron. There will be neither burial nor services. Memorial contributions, if desired, should be made to the donor's favorite charity.

title: No Water, Thanks, Subdivision Foes Say
