title: 'The Job,' Before That Other Job
description: WHEN Denis Leary's firefighter series, "Rescue Me, " made its debut last year on the FX cable channel, it was notable for, among other reasons, being one of the first television programs to substantively address the fallout from 9/11. While Mr. Leary, who produced and starred in the show, has something of a soft spot for the city's blue-collar guardians, the show succeeded precisely because it avoided canonizing.

title: Corrections
description: The National Perspectives article last Sunday, about the construction of small houses in Dallas, misstated the occupation of Mil Bodron and the location of his house. He is an interior designer, not an architect; the house is in Dallas, not Highland Park.

title: Please Be Quiet, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Open-Wheel Unification Would Complete the Circle
description: The Indianapolis 500, the premier race in the Indy Racing League series, will be run for the 89th time today. Talk of unification between the two major open-wheel series in this country, the I.R.L. and what is now the Champ Car series, always seems to intensify in May.

title: DataBank; Stocks Climb as Inflation Fear Recedes
description: The stock market rose last week on optimism that the economy would grow without setting off serious inflation.

title: Sated With Snuff, Swedes Take Smoking Ban in Stride
description: STOCKHOLM, May 28 - Sweden is a few days from joining the select group of European countries that have banned smoking in restaurants and bars. But unlike Ireland, where the ban upset pub owners, or Italy, where cappuccino drinkers complained about having to smoke outdoors, no one here expects the June 1 event to be met with much protest.

title: An Indicator That's Almost as Good as a Time Machine
description: AN investor's fantasy might be to glimpse stock or bond market prices for a trading session yet to come, perhaps next month or in 2010.

title: 2 Teenagers Are Charged in Killing of Immigrant
description: Despite missing paperwork that delayed a police investigation for nearly two weeks, two Brooklyn teenagers were arrested Friday in the killing of a 51-year-old Bangladeshi immigrant who died after he was beaten into a coma, the police said yesterday.

title: Blendwords
description: ' Everybody wants to get inna de act" was a signature line of a mock-furious Jimmy Durante. Now, armed with a couple of simple techniques, anybody can get into the act of coining neologisms.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: COUNTRY MUSIC GETAWAY -- The party, parade and live music-filled Summerfest weekends begin this week at the 2,881-room Gaylord Opryland Resort in Nashville. Most of the festivities happen under the hotel's climate-controlled atrium (covering nine acres of gardens). Summerfest packages start at $114 a person, double occupancy, for one night; $167 a person for two nights, double occupancy, and $223 for three nights, double occupancy, plus 14.25 percent tax and a $10 daily resort fee. Included are hotel and garden tours and admission to the Grand Old Opry Museum. A coupon book offers more admission discounts. For details call (888) 999-6779, or see www.gaylordopryland.com.

title: Temple of Commerce, at a Certain Age
description: WHITE PLAINS - WITH its luxury stores, skylights and gurgling fountains, The Westchester mall clearly has a reputation to uphold. Now 10 years old, it is reaching a financial benchmark of sorts: Many of the first tenants' leases are coming up for renewal, and not everyone is sticking around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, SHIRLEY
description: COHEN -- Shirley. Beloved wife of Morton. Devoted mother of Penny Ship and Susan Anton. Loving grandmother of Jayme, Morgan, Matthew and Stacey. Services today, 12 noon, at "Gutterman's," 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

description: ON that Christmas day in 1998, life could hardly have seemed better for the Gordon brothers, David and Greg. They brought their wives to celebrate the holiday amid the festive dcor of their parents' home in Conroe, Tex., a onetime oil boom town north of Houston. As family members relaxed, the brothers eagerly compared notes about their triumphs of the last year.

description: Union actors who provide the voices in many video games are contemplating a strike, seeking more money from an industry that by some financial measures now surpasses Hollywood.

description: TEHRAN, May 28 - From nuclear negotiators to student dissidents, from bazaar merchants to turbaned mullahs, Iranians agree: the right to develop nuclear power is a point of national pride.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FARBMAN, RUTH
description: FARBMAN--Ruth. Died on May 19th, 2005. Beloved wife of Jerry. Devoted mother of Caroline Norman, Peg Wachowski & Ben Farbman. Adored grandmother of Judith, Sara, Katie, Beth and Jeffrey. Great-grandmother of Benjamin. Ruth's zest for living inspired both family and friends. For further information, call the Ira Kaufman Chapel 248-569-0020.

description: I started my married life in Stuyvesant Town. Both my children, now 46 and 44, were born there.

description: I was delighted to read Daphne Merkin's well-researched, sociologically accurate, informed and balanced essay on dogs and their owners (The Way We Live Now, May 1). But most dog owners I hang out with know that they have dogs and simply enjoy a very special bond.

title: Other Voices: Goodbye, Public Editor No. 1, and Thanks
description: Though I couldn't agree with you all the time, you served the readers well. There seems to be a lack of respect for varying views these days. While I don't really want to change my own ideas, I welcome the views of others -- just in case I can learn something and might, just might, change my mind.

title: Diane Chira, Britt Matthews
description: Diane Louise Chira, a daughter of Estelle and Joe Chira of Rye, N.Y., is to be married today to Britt Matthews, a son of Lee Matthews of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and the late Willie H. Matthews Jr. Cantor Kerry Ben-David is to officiate at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELLIS, JAMES H.
description: ELLIS--James H. Died suddenly on Thursday, May 26, 2005. Jim lived with joy and love for life, for his family, for his work, and for his friends. A passionate supporter of the performing arts, he was president emeritus of the Parsons Dance Foundation, board member of the Stamford Center for the Arts, and cochairman of the Theater and Performing Arts Committee of the New York State Bar Association. He is survived by his loving wife, Linda, his devoted children, Jimmy and Melissa, Nancie and Geoff, and Arthur and Abby, his six grandchildren and his brother Joel. Donations may be made to the Linda A. and James H. Ellis fund in care of Westchester Community Foundation, 200 N. Central Park Ave, Hartsdale, NY 10530. Funeral service Sunday, May 29, 2005, 10am from Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. ELLIS--James. The Parsons Dance Company family is deeply saddened by the loss of our beloved President Emeritus, James H. Ellis. Jim joined our board in 1995 and served as board president for six years. We will miss his commitment, passion and enthusiasm for our Company and for dance. His kindness, friendship and generosity will not be forgotten. Our condolences to his wife Linda and their family. With love, David Parsons and the Parsons Dance Company

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENDICH, JOSEPH
description: BENDICH--Joseph. 87, of Sun City, AZ, died suddenly on May 21st, 2005. Devoted husband of the late Lillian. Father of Adrianne and Elaine, father-in-law to David, beloved grandfather to Jorden, Debra, Brian and Dustin and daughter - in - law Debbie. Adoring great-grandfather to Tyler, Rebecca and Jacob. Survived by his dear brother Max and his family and many nieces and nephews and their families. Survived by his dear wife Zelda and her family. Will be forever missed.

title: Let the Fur Fly
description: Have you ever devoted the majority of the magazine to letters to the editor? I would love to see a volume of responses to an essay that clearly hits a nerve, as I suspect Daphne Merkin's article has.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 15 about annuity sales practices omitted a word in some copies, thus reversing the meaning, in citing a company's response to a California officials' lawsuit accusing one of its units, among other defendants, of tricking retirees into using their retirement investments to buy annuities. The company, the AmerUs Group, said that while it was taking the accusations very seriously and had strong sales and compliance practices, it did not comment on pending legislation.

title: Emile Hirsch: Rolling With the Big Dogs
description: LOS ANGELES - EMILE HIRSCH didn't seem in a mood for a night on the town. His friend Raphael Verela was taking his sweet time getting to Mao's Kitchen, the Chinese dive in Venice, where Mr. Hirsch waited at an outdoor table in the waning evening light. He yanked the hood of his Alpha Dog sweatshirt over his head and amused himself by hurling ice cubes and attempting to suck a lemon slice out of his water glass with a straw.

title: The Weekend in Your Tote
description: Memorial Day marks the unofficial start to summer and the official start to summer hauling. Stores are selling travel bags that follow this season's three C's: colorful, capacious and compact. The bags make room for all manner of summer gear, paving the way for a fourth C, which stands for chic.

title: History at Jones Beach, A New Park in Jamesport
description: Jones Beach State Park, visited by an estimated half-billion people since Robert Moses opened the gates in 1929, has gained recognition as a National Historic Site. Bernadette Castro, the state parks commissioner, said this month that the National Park Service, at the state's request, had added the 2,413-acre park to the National Register of Historic Places.

title: A Kaleidoscope of Tastes
description: COLLAGE can refer to art or food. Both are in play at the new restaurant of that name in Huntington. There are collages on the wall, while the food appears as a kaleidoscope of tastes, textures and colors from a host of countries.

title: Forensic officers search for clues amid debris of Indonesian bombs
Other Voices: Goodbye, Public Editor No. 1, and Thanks
description: While it's true that, unlike the foreign correspondents Dexter Filkins and Steven Erlanger, you don't actually face the possibility every day of being shot in the line of work, the public editor has a near-impossible job. And your passion, energy, and -- yes -- humility, were more than a breath of fresh air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERRIN, FORREST G.
description: PERRIN--Forrest G. Pianist, musical director, and society orchestra leader, died of pneumonia on Friday, May 27th, 2005, in New York City at the age of 88. He is survived by his loving wife Lesley Davison Perrin; two children, Wendy Perrin Baker and Christopher Scott Perrin; two grandchildren, Charlie Baker and Douglas Baker; and sister Margaret Perrin of Atlanta, his former two-piano-team partner on ABC Radio's Piano Playhouse. Everybody loved him for his kindness, good nature, quick wit, and wonderful talent. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: U.N. Party Planners Wonder, Will Bush and Friends Attend?
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 28 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice has indicated she will not attend. So has former President George H.W. Bush. The controversial nominee for United Nations ambassador, John R. Bolton, has not been heard from, nor has President Bush, who was sent an invitation in February.

Hoffman and Bruce H. Hoffman of Rye, N.Y. Cantor Judith Koeppel Steel is to officiate at the Garrison, a resort.

description: BEACON - THERE must be $100 million worth of artwork in "Dia's Andy: Through the Lens of Patronage," the lushly appointed, eye-catching but pretentiously titled exhibition of the artist's paintings, sculptures, films, wallpaper and memorabilia at Dia:Beacon. Part exhibition, part hagiography, the show is a shrine to the ever-growing worldwide cult of this contemporary-art saint.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Peter Deilmann Cruises is now offering bicycle touring on some of its European river cruises. On selected Danube, Rhone and Seine River cruises, passengers sightsee via bicycle rides through the countryside. Prices start at $2,225 per person, double occupancy, and include bike rentals, escorted cycling tours, excursions and entrance fees. Noncycling cruise passengers receive a price deduction. Information: (800) 348-8287 or www.deilmann-cruises.com. The Spanish airline Air Plus Comet has added New York to its catalog of destinations, with a flight to Madrid leaving Kennedy airport on Friday afternoons. Information and reservations: (877) 999-7587 or www.airplususa.com. More American teenagers are traveling overseas these days, according to the Gallup Youth Survey. The poll, conducted this year, found that 27 percent of the 13- to 17-year-olds surveyed have gone overseas, compared with 16 percent in a similar 1986 poll. Celebrity Cruises has postponed plans to position a cruise ship in Asia. The company expects to place a ship in Asia for its 2007 itineraries, rather than for the 2006 schedule. MARJORIE CONNELLY

title: A Complex Complex
description: We were among the first tenants in Stuyvesant Town. We qualified since my husband was a veteran -- and after an inspection by an agent of Met Life of our one-room apartment in Brooklyn.

title: Now You See It, Now You Wonder Just What 'It' Is
description: MAGIC is like beauty: without an audience it is just a trick of the light. The same could be said of art, which without appreciation is a tale full of paint and canvas, signifying nothing. The Swiss artist Sylvie Fleury realizes this better than most, which is why she is more fond of questions than of answers. Even when she says moisturizing is the answer, as she did in a 1995 artwork bearing those words, she wants you to wonder, Well, is it?

title: When the Numbers Don't Match
description: AS real estate prices have soared in recent months, some buyers have found that the apartments they've agreed to purchase were appraised for less than the sale price -- with often knotty consequences.

title: Watercraft Accident Kills a Man Off L.I.
description: A Nassau County man riding a motorized water scooter in the Great South Bay off Massapequa was killed yesterday when he struck the anchor line of a sailboat that had run aground in shallow water, the police said.

title: Crossing a Land of Snakes and Aboriginal Lore
description: LICKING green tree ants is not as difficult as it sounds. Simply pluck an ant from a branch, firmly but gently, and then position it so that your tongue can brush the insect's lime-colored abdomen -- not its biting mandibles. The result is a jolt of citric acid to the palate, a potent injection of bitter, green apple that leaves a pleasant numbness for several minutes. It is essential, however, that you examine the branch beforehand to ensure that it is not also occupied by one of the poisonous snakes that inhabit the far northwest of Australia, a bite from which could be deadly.

title: A Teacher Improvising as He Goes
description: DANCING or teaching, David Dorfman celebrates the human spirit. He is the artistic director and choreographer of David Dorfman Dance, one of the nation's leading modern dance companies, and is associate professor of dance at Connecticut College, which has one of the nation's leading academic dance programs.

title: Name Games and the Science of Life
description: WHAT'S in a name? When it comes to controversial science, a lot.

title: Just Do It Yourself
description: A store is born in New York about as often as a Broadway hopeful arrives at the Port Authority. These days, however, jaded consumers expect more boogie-woogie than the retail equivalent of a matinee for the blue-rinse set. Temporary guerrilla stores, traveling boutiques and hybrid emporiums, selling everything from Belgian fashion experimentalia to limited-edition Japanese toys, are just some of the novelties setting the stage for a serious denouement at the cash register.

title: Old Soldiers Proud of Their Scars, but Unsure They'd Join Today
description: Levittown, N.Y. - THERE is plastic red, white and blue bunting above the U-shaped bar at American Legion Post 1711 on North Jerusalem Road, and a 20-foot-long torpedo outside. There are dozens of Little League and softball trophies in the meeting room upstairs, a forlorn copy of an ancient record album, "Connie Francis Sings Italian Favorites," and pictures of the post commanders going back to 1952. You can set your clock by the regulars who show up every day at 2 p.m. for the three-ball game at the pool table.

title: The White Stripes Change Their Spots
description: MAYBE it's time to retire the term "retro-rock." Not because it doesn't fit but because it fits too much too well -- it's becoming redundant. These days, rock tends to be retro by default, whether on the pop charts or on MP3 blogs. The million-selling Las Vegas band the Killers became a mainstream sensation by reviving the sound of 1980's new wave, while the beloved Scottish cult band Bloc Party became an underground sensation by ... well, by reviving a different strand of 1980's new wave. From Gap commercials (where you can find the 18-year-old Joss Stone belting out the half-century-old "Night Time Is the Right Time") to indie record shops, rock 'n' roll nostalgia is everywhere. A young listener might well wonder what other kind of rock 'n' roll there is, and an older one might find that a surprisingly difficult question to answer.

description: LAREDO--Ruth. It is with profound sadness that we mourn the death of our beloved friend, pianist Ruth Laredo. She became a part of Young Concert Artists in 1962 and we were proud of the range of her career as a soloist, chamber musician and as an inspiring mentor to young performers. title: Inside the List
description: TALL, DARK, STUDLY: John Camp, who writes thrillers under the pseudonym John Sandford, is among this country's least pretentious brand-name writers. He's got an aw-shucks attitude about putting words down on paper, and can make it all look pretty easy. "You can teach yourself how to write thrillers," he once told The Associated Press, "the same way you can teach yourself how to write journalism." Yeah, O.K. But keep in mind that Camp was no slacker as a journalist, either. (He won a Pulitzer Prize in 1986 for a series of articles, written for The St. Paul Pioneer Press, about a Minnesota farm family.) His new book as Sandford, "Broken Prey," enters the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 3 -- it's the first of his last six novels not to make its debut at either No. 1 or No. 2. Camp, who is 61, began writing thrillers in the late 1980's after realizing that even a prizewinning journalist might have trouble putting two kids through college. He published "Rules of Prey," the first novel in what would become his Prey series, in 1989. That book introduced his stud-muffin hero, Lucas Davenport, an unconventional Minnesota lawman. "Lucas is a composite of cops and movie stars, with the emphasis on movie stars," Camp said in a recent interview. "He certainly doesn't resemble any real cop I've ever met. I mean, he's tall, dark, handsome, rich, drives a Porsche, has killed too many people . . . give me a break."

Dancers and choreographers have been succumbing to this work since its premiere at the Paris Opera, in 1876, and it's easy to see why. The irresistible score, by Lo Delibes, abounds with melodic grace and rhythmic verve, and the remarkable heroine, a follower of the goddess Diana, combines the confidence and athleticism of a huntress with the melting vulnerability of a lovelorn nymph.

He also served as Director of the Illinois Mental Health Institutes at Chicago, Director of the Illinois State Psychiatric Institute and Professor and Head of the Department of Psychiatry at the University of Illinois Abraham Lincoln School of Medicine in Chicago. Dr. Rudy was a consultant to the NY Department of Mental Hygiene in 1967 and was very active in the American Psychiatric Association throughout his career. He was a veteran of World War II, serving in the South Pacific with the American Division 1942-1946; he was the recipient of three Bronze Star Medals, one with Oak Leaf Cluster. title: Fiction Chronicle
description: BOOGALOO ON 2ND AVENUE: A Novel of Pastry, Guilt, and Music. By Mark Kurlansky. (Ballantine, $24.95.) Loose and jangly, Kurlansky's novel is a joyful celebration of a New York neighborhood in the late 1980's, a time when Darryl Strawberry was hitting, Michael Dukakis had not yet climbed into the tank and East Village residents could almost ignore the encroaching signs of gentrification. Against this backdrop, Nathan Seltzer, Kurlansky's mid-30's, married hero, contemplates selling his copy shop and has an affair with a pastry maker. The neighborhood's lively mix of cultures and languages -- English, Spanish, Italian, Yiddish and German -- pulls him in many directions, encompassing everything from Caribbean black magic to Eastern European minyans. A columnist for Food & Wine magazine, Kurlansky knows how to make food sexy and sex foody -- especially in the scene where Nathan's lover teaches him to make chocolate buttercream frosting. Although the plot of "Boogaloo on 2nd Avenue" is impossibly Dickensian, it works because Kurlansky is so clearly in control -- and so clearly enjoying himself. He certainly has a knack for incorporating eccentric detail: who knew that the cost of turning a Puerto Rican into a Dominican, tattoos included, was $987.45?

title: When Evil Could Be a Rabbit-Loving Grandfather
description: IT took daring in 1967 for a young French director to make a warmhearted comedy about wartime anti-Semitism, when the shame of his country under German occupation was still fresh in people's memory. But Claude Berri's first feature, "The Two of Us" -- based upon his own experiences as a hidden Jewish child in France during World War II and rereleased on Friday -- also owes its wild charm to two brilliant performers. Alain Cohen was 9 when Mr. Berri cast him as Claude, a Parisian scamp whose parents, fearing for his safety, ship him off to the countryside with only a shaky grasp of the Lord's Prayer and a new, very Gallic last name. The legendary actor Michel Simon, then 72, played the gruff farmer who, unaware of the boy's origins, takes him in; this elderly vegetarian loves his aged dog as much as he hates the "enemies of France," including, and especially, the Jews. An unlikely affection blossoms between the two, a fierce tenderness born of their mutual isolation in a world of encroaching darkness.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FULTON, ROBERT EDISON
description: FULTON--Robert Edison, was one of the most interesting men I have ever known. He was a philosopher, musician, poet, director, cinematographer, aerial cinematographer, filmmaker and, most of all, an incredible man. Bob was highly skilled in all these areas. He won many awards including an Emmy for his work. He was a devout Buddhist. Bob was extremely humble and never talked about himself or his accomplishments, but only about the love of his work. Bob did everything in such a unique way that his friends and family referred to his lifestyle as Fultonian, as if he had developed an entirely different culture and way of life. To tell one's story about Bob was never enough, people always wanted to hear more and know more about this fascinating man. To watch Bob fly a plane was like watching a virtuoso playing an instrument. He taught me many things, both in the sky and on the ground. His lessons of "point of intended touchdown" is something I will never forget. A wonder with words, Fulton never used profanity; he thought it was an abuse of the English language and demonstrated a lack of a proper vocabulary. I miss my generous mentor and good friend, Bob Fulton, who is in my thoughts every day. Taz Saunders FULTON -- Robert Edison. Dear Bob, hard to believe years have gone by since that fateful night. Every day we think of you and miss you. Brilliant Emmy award winning photographer, astounding pilot, charming, talented wit, gifted teacher, wonderful musician and rare friend. We know you are flying on the "wings of man" wherever you go. You are ever near and yet so far. Jordan and Tom Saunders Calvert and George Moore

title: Eat, Memory: American Dreams
description: When I was a teenager in the 1970's, I lived with my parents in Durban, South Africa, where my father had been sent by his employer, Carnation Milk. It was here that I learned about homesickness and the odd melancholia of Sundays in foreign places. When we arrived from Los Angeles in 1972, I was a wary 10-year-old, and my impressions of the place were formed as I got off the plane and saw the "This Door for Whites Only" sign in the terminal. Over the next few years, I came to recognize the colonial old-boy British superiority for what it was: a poison toad, the last gasps of a dying empire, only surpassed in its lazy smugness by the breathtaking meanness of the Afrikaners and their ruling Nationalist Party. title: Contest Contested
description: My son's school announced that a $750 scholarship would be awarded to the senior submitting the best short essay by Feb. 1. After the deadline, the school announced that because only one student had applied for the scholarship, it was extending the deadline. My son protested: according to the rules, he should be the winner because he submitted the only and therefore best essay. Was it ethical to extend the deadline? Steven Tanzer, Bayside, N.Y. Even if your son were content to win on a technicality, he doesn't have much of a case. If the prize is for "the best short essay," the school may not award it to him. The superlative "best" necessarily refers to the most impressive of three or more -- good, better, best. If there are not at least three entries, there can be no best essay. Live by legalisms; die by legalisms. (I feel like Portia in "The Merchant of Venice" -- minus the anti-Semitism and the cross-dressing.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LARK, CYNTHIA ANN
description: LARK--Cynthia Ann. Longtime biologist, passed away Tuesday, May 24, 2005. Born in Shawnee, OK, on New Year's Eve, 1928, to Lester Thompson, a petroleum engineer, and Eleanor Folz, she pursued a scientific career while raising a family of four children at a time when women in science had to choose between having a family or a career. After graduating from Mount Holyoke College, she met her future husband Karl G. Lark at Cold Spring Harbor, NY, where they were both involved in research. Thereafter, they collaborated frequently over a long and distinguished scientific career that took her from Washington University in St. Louis to Manhattan, Kansas, and ultimately to the University of Utah, in Salt Lake. Before retiring, she was a persistent researcher and teacher, traits she carried into retirement where she devoted her energies to developing an exotic garden full of plants she handpicked from all over the globe. At home, her teaching showed her children the how and why of scholasticism instead of just accepting easy answers. "Look it up" was a mantra: learn the tools and you never forget the answers or how to solve difficulties. She stimulated interest in literature by encouraging exploration of local libraries and ignoring those pesky age delimiters that promoted certain books and hid others from curious minds. As her children matured and pursued their own interests, she brought a number of uniquely individual dogs and cats into the home. They provided constant companionship and vitality, often traveling on trips to Colorado, along with her husband. In addition to her husband and four children (Clovis, Ellen, Susie, and Caroline), she is survived by a brother, David Thompson, of Florida. Funeral arrangements are private. An open memorial service is planned for late June or July. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Cynthia's name to Best Friends Animal Sanctuary, 5001 Angel Canyon Drive, Kanab, UT 84741.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEMANS, DR. JAMES H.
description: SEMANS--Dr. James H. A Duke University surgeon and urologist who combined a career as a leading medical scientist and physician with a passion for the arts and charitable causes, died at his Durham, NC home on April 21, 2005. He was 94. Semans was a pioneer in rehabilitative and urinary surgery who during World War II developed an operation to relieve retained urine due to spinal cord injury. At that time, renal failure was the primary cause of an early death in paralyzed veterans. In addition to his leadership as a medical scholar, Semans, along with his wife of 52 years, Mary Duke Biddle Trent Semans, was involved in numerous arts and charitable causes. Semans helped lead the establishment of the North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem in the 1960s and served as chairman of the school's board of trustees for the first 17 years. He also served for 48 years on The Mary Duke Biddle Foundation and was chair until his retirement in 2004. The Mary Duke Biddle Foundation funds charitable activities at Duke and other institutions in North Carolina and New York. As leader of the Biddle Foundation, he was asked to assist with the development of arts education and performing components at Duke, and was instrumental in the establishment of the Ciompi Quartet and the Institute of the Arts. Semans served on dozens of nonprofit boards of directors. He was president of the North Carolina Society for Crippled Children and Adults and vice president of the National Paraplegia Foundation and served on the Governor's Committee for Employment of the Handicapped. He was also an active leader in many arts, educational and cultural institutions and organizations. As a member of the North Carolina State Arts Council, Semans suggested establishing an emerging artists program that today provides programs in communities across North Carolina. For years he served on the Advisory Board of the Institute of Fine Arts, New York University, and on the Advisory Council of the School of American Ballet. Born in 1910 in Uniontown, PA --the youngest of seven boys and one girl --Semans received his bachelor's degree in 1932 from Princeton University. He earned his medical degree in 1936 from the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, where he graduated Phi Beta Kappa and where he remained on staff as a urologist. During World War II, he served for two-and-a-half years as a major in the Army's medical corps and cared for hundreds of injured soldiers. It was during this time that he developed a deep interest in people with disabilities, a population for whom he was an advocate all of his life. After the war, he entered private practice for six years in Atlanta before joining the Duke medical staff as a surgeon and associate professor of urology. He was promoted to professor of urology in 1961. In 1953, Semans married Mary Duke Biddle Trent, the great-granddaughter of Washington Duke, in whose honor Duke University was named. Together they focused their energies on charitable work, especially involving the arts. At Duke the Semanses and the late Dr. Wayne Rundles established a premiere hospital arts program --now known as The Health Arts Network --at Duke Medical Center. Semans was an advocate for Duke establishing a world - class university museum and was instrumental in the development of the new $23 million Nasher Museum of Art, which is scheduled to open at Duke in the fall. In 1997, the Semanses were awarded the North Carolina Philanthropy Award. In recognition of their leadership in human relations, the Semanses received the first Humanitarian Freedom Award given by the Durham chapter of Hadassah in 1960. Nine years later, they received the National Brotherhood Award from the National Conference of Christians and Jews for distinguished service in human relations. Semans also was honored by the North Carolina School of the Arts, Duke University, Duke University Hospital and the North Carolina Association of Arts Councils, among others. In addition to his wife, Semans is survived by seven children: Mary Trent Jones of Abingdon, VA; Sally Trent Harris of Charlotte, NC; Dr. Rebecca Trent Kirkland of Houston; Barbara Trent Kimbrell of Sullivan's Island, SC; Jenny Semans Koortbojian of Durham; James Duke Biddle Trent Semans of Chapel Hill and Beth Semans Hubbard of Los Angeles; 16 grandchildren and 22 great-grandchildren. His funeral was April 26 in Duke Chapel. Memorials may be made to the Semans Art Fund at the North Carolina School of the Arts or the James H. Semans Fund, Duke University Division of Urology.

title: Card Stud
description: Daniel Negreanu is a vegetarian, without much interest in food. "I ate two days ago" is the kind of thing he says. His disdain for food is a reaction to his mother, who is obsessed with food. Mommy, as he calls her, likes to serve people food, then sit down and smile at them as they eat. When Negreanu was growing up in Toronto, Mommy sent him to school with his lunch packed in a brown bag. When he went to McDonald's with friends, she gave him a brown-bag lunch. When he got his first job as a telemarketer ("I lasted a day," he says), Mommy packed him a brown-bag lunch. When he got his next job at Subway ("I was a good sandwich maker"), Mommy packed him a brown-bag lunch. These days, when Negreanu goes to work at night at the Bellagio casino in Las Vegas, Mommy packs him a brown-bag lunch.

John J. Petillo said UMDNJ will halt all political contributions, create an office of compliance auditor and hire Gary Stein, a retired New Jersey Supreme Court justice, to conduct an independent review of purchasing and waiver procedures. John Holl

description: Shootouts Are a Scar

title: A Mothers' War
description: They were talking about military burial benefits as the waitress took the salad plates away, and one of them had come up with something perversely humorous even on this subject, so they had been laughing. Now there was a brief, comfortable silence. They had one of the back rooms at Boone Tavern in downtown Columbia, Mo., where they usually go. It was a Friday night in February, and because one woman had other plans, there were only five of them, which made the big, round table seem too large. Instead of spacing themselves around it, they had taken seats along one side, closer to one another.

title: Mr. Mayor and Me in Mexico
description: Mexico City - ALL throughout the rocky month of April, television news crews were almost useless. On April 7, Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador, the leftist mayor of Mexico City, addressed 300,000 supporters before being stripped of his official immunity in a land dispute. A step toward bringing him to trial, it could have ended in his imprisonment and ineligibility as a 2006 presidential candidate. But state television and the private duopoly of Televisa and Televisin Azteca transmitted only the essentials of a daylong process that took place in the Chamber of Deputies, giving it routine treatment on the nightly news (though it was fully covered on the cable channel of the Chamber of Deputies, which almost no one watches). On April 24, as more than a million Mexicans joined a "march of silence" in protest, more ambitious coverage was organized by the Argos production company, which was broadcast only on Channel 40, a cable channel.

title: Katherine Franch and Matthew Langer

description: GOLD is not having a good year, but its poor cousin, silver, is doing nicely.

He clutched news clippings on class in America, and atop the pile was a manifesto in his own hand. He was gone in an instant, but Karl's manifesto on modern America remained. This is what it said:

title: Found in Translation
description: BY now it is something of a migratory pattern. Canada geese fly south in the winter; Americans flock to France in the summer. The trip today is easier than it was in the 19th century. Then it was said that a good American went to Paris when he died; a good American need now only hoard his frequent flier points. But the city beckons still as a paradise, robust euro aside. An American in Paris is a liberated (and yes, sometimes liberating) American. He remains a cause for song and celebration, a four-word recipe for happiness.

It would also prevent undue government intrusion into sensitive treatment decisions.

description: Correction Appended

description: AS legislators continue to debate what programs to finance and what services to cut in a state budget that is anticipated to be more than $15 billion next year, a little-mentioned but startling financial statistic lurks in between the line items and the bottom line: Connecticut leads the nation in per capita debt, at $3,614.

description: A SUNDAY in spring! Finally. Sunshine that's intoxicating as opposed to sunshine that demands Polartec.

title: APPROVAL FOR HARRAH'S
description: Despite warnings that there could be antitrust problems, the Casino Control Commission last Tuesday approved the $9.4 billion takeover of Caesars Entertainment by Harrah's Entertainment. The combined company will hold 40 percent of the casino floor space and hotel rooms in Atlantic City with its Caesars, Bally's, Harrah's and Showboat properties. The takeover still needs approval from regulatory bodies in Nevada and the Federal Trade Commission; that is expected by mid-June. Robert Strauss

In fact, his sterling performance will certainly put him at the top of the world rankings. Only the retired and thus hors de combat Garry Kasparov will have a higher number.

title: A German Contender Is Hard to Read
description: BERLIN, May 28 - The pictures in the German papers these days show the contrast. One is of Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany in a pose of grim fortitude. In the other Angela Merkel, often shown against a blue backdrop printed with the word "Better," smiles confidently. She looks like the relaxed beneficiary of a political gift -- not just a chance to become chancellor of Germany but to do so a year before anyone thought it would be possible.

title: What's New?
description: This summer, more than ever, Hollywood is being slammed for offering nothing but sequels, remakes and adaptations among its big-budget, big-risk films. Here are the real numbers: A look at the slate of major studio releases scheduled from just before Memorial Day (when "Revenge of the Sith" kicked off the season) through the Labor Day weekend shows that slightly more than half -- 22 out of 39 -- had at least one obvious source other than the screenwriter's imagination. Is that too many? Actually, given the common wisdom that sequelitis rules, it's surprising that nearly half of the summer's movies appear to be original. (Of course, "original" is a flexible term in Hollywood, and several of those films, like the Jim Braddock biopic "Cinderella Man," are based on true stories). Here is the list, with ancestors noted where appropriate.

title: Try the 'Friends' Couch (Friends Not Included)
description: The set of blue coffee mugs seemed generic, the table they were resting on only vaguely familiar, but when Roland Fontanares took a closer look and spotted the brown, overstuffed couch that was also on display, he figured out exactly what he had stumbled on.

title: The Shore Forecast: Warm but Cool, Wet but Dry
description: Look's like you need more than a weatherman to know which way the wind -- or in this case, the sea breeze -- blows. Just ask Joe Miketta, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Mount Holly.

title: Goals Reached, Donor on Right Closes Up Shop
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 - Without it, the Federalist Society might not exist, nor its network of 35,000 conservative lawyers. Economic analysis might hold less sway in American courts. The premier idea factories of the right, from the Hoover Institution to the Heritage Foundation, would have lost millions of dollars in core support. And some classics of the conservative canon would have lost their financier, including Allan Bloom's lament of academic decline and Charles Murray's attacks on welfare.

title: PHOTO-OP
Alderbrook Resort and Spa
description: THE BASICS -- It's a short flight west from Seattle to the Alderbrook Resort and Spa, which reopened last July on the Hood Canal in Union, Wash., after a $13 million, two-year renovation by its new owner, Jeff Raikes, a Microsoft vice president. (His colleague Bill Gates owns the compound next door.) Mr. Raikes bought the beloved but run-down resort in 2001. Since it first opened in 1913, Alderbrook has been a vacation spot for Seattle and Tacoma families. The resort's face lift, by the Seattle architect Dan Foltz, is neo-Craftsman. Its materials, colors and detailing inspired by the Arts and Crafts Movement, the turn-of-the-century school of design that emphasized simplicity and natural materials. In the lobby, a stone fireplace reaches to the 30-foot-high ceiling, 20 peeled logs support the beams and the huge windows overlook the natural, Northwest-style landscaped courtyard and the canal beyond. Alderbrook has a gabled roof, lots of wood and stone, and shades of brown and green that blend with the resort's forested and mountainous environment. But it's a Northwest vacation lodge with big-city amenities, including a full-service spa, a 55-foot heated glass-enclosed swimming pool, and a whirlpool. Guests receive preferred tee times at the neighboring 18-hole Alderbrook Golf and Yacht Club. The Restaurant at Alderbrook (run by Tom Black, an award-winning chef) serves breakfast, lunch and dinner.

title: It's a New World, and Everybody Gets to Play Maxwell Smart
description: WASHINGTON - IF it is true that, as an old Chinese proverb says, crisis equals opportunity, then the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, have yielded a bonanza. Billions of dollars have been poured into homeland security by the cabinet department of the same name, the Pentagon, law enforcement and corporations. With so much money available, more than 500 exhibitors at a security conference here last week were out to reap their share.

title: Who Needs the Riviera?
description: THE Hamptons may be groaning under the strain of development, skyrocketing real estate prices and disappearing farmland, but for many Europeans with euros to spend, Long Island's East End is a respite from the Riviera, Deauville and the Italian and German coasts.

title: Of Two Minds
description: Jim Holt's suggestion that we might have two minds, each associated with the different cerebral hemispheres, has much more evidence than he mentions (The Way We Live Now, May 8). In a study of two split-brain patients, my colleagues and I reported that not only were there two minds but also that these minds were psychologically different. One hemisphere of one patient, bullied as a child, was still very upset by that past trauma, while the other hemisphere was well over it.

title: Settlers' Cemeteries And a Town's Choices
description: JEFFREY DOUGLAS first heard about an unmarked cemetery in Cedarhurst when he was in the fourth grade. Five years later in 2000, he researched the cemetery for a high school project and discovered that there were at least two old family burial sites in the area.

title: Up Front
description: This week Toni Bentley makes her first appearance on our cover with her review of Lyndall Gordon's "Vindication: A Life of Mary Wollstonecraft." The subject is of longstanding interest to Bentley. At 13, she began collecting biographies of "incredible" women: "Nin, Sand, Woolf, Colette. I always read their books, but I was interested in their lives," she said in a telephone interview. "I wouldn't have known how to live my life if these women hadn't done it before me." She recalls reading, and heavily underlining, Emily Sunstein's biography of Wollstonecraft, "A Different Face," a couple of years later.

title: Charlotte, Grace, Janet and Caroline Come Home
description: While I appreciate the coverage The New York Times Magazine devoted to the exploitation of children in Uganda's civil war, I would like to clarify a few aspects of Melanie Thernstrom's description of our work at World Vision (May 8). In her article, she writes about our rehabilitation center for former child rebels in Gulu, northern Uganda, World Vision's Children of War Rehabilitation Center. But she does not mention that World Vision is a global relief and development organization with programs that help address poverty and injustice in nearly 100 countries. The Children of War Rehabilitation Center is only one such program.

Memorial Day weekend usually jump-starts this ritual. After that, those of us who do not have a weekend retreat (or friends who do) must look closer to home for relief.

title: Finally, Progress in Restoring Bridgeport's Grandeur

But now, with nearly 25 percent of the historic downtown district about to undergo a major rehabilitation, developers are champing at the bit to enter an emerging mixed-use market that, despite being situated in the richest county in Connecticut, suffers from an image problem.

title: Devils and Ducks
description: Central Long Island, that drab inland zone of crisscrossing highways and office parks, is not much to look at. But don't be fooled: It's a hot spot for raw human drama, for unscripted collisions of fierce passions and tragic destinies. It has all those courthouses, after all, and the county Legislature. And it has a minor league ballpark, where you can savor raw human drama with a hot dog and a beer.

title: 'Vindication'
description: In December 1792 an Englishwoman of thirty-three crossed the Channel to revolutionary France. She was travelling alone on her way to Paris at a time when Englishmen like Wordsworth were speeding in the opposite direction - back to the safety of their country, in fear of the oncoming Terror. When, at length, Mary Wollstonecraft arrived at a friend's hotel, she found it deserted, one folding door opening after another, till she reached her room at the far end. There she sat by her candle, knowing no one and unable to speak the language. The silence, in contrast to London, was eerie. As she looked up from the letter she was writing, eyes glared through a glass door. Looming through the darkness, bloody hands showed themselves and shook at her. She longed for the sound of a footstep; she missed her cat. 'I want to see something alive,' her pen scratched, 'death in so many frightful shapes has taken hold of my fancy.'

The destination is a three-acre spit of floury white sand called Ranguana Caye, 18 miles off the coast of southern Belize. Local residents have intoxicated me with stories of fishing and of snorkeling alongside dolphins in the world's second largest reef.

An uncomfortable, neoclassical presence that ruins Columbus Circle, the lollipop building was designed as an attack on Modern architecture to house an art collection that was an attack on modern art.

title: Jane's Next Role

After 15 years away from the movies, she actually did all right with "Monster-in-Law," opening at No. 1 for New Line Cinema and reaching $44 million in ticket sales in two weeks of release. The film even put some sizzle back in Jennifer Lopez's career. So what now? Hollywood isn't exactly crawling with roles for 67-year-old comeback queens. But those who get a kick out of watching a smart, intact, somewhat neurotic woman of a certain age go through her paces would love to see Ms. Fonda get a shot at some of the projects working their way through the pipeline. The casting director Felicia Fasano ("Bad Santa," "Barbershop") scouted some possibilities:

title: Rebel With a Surprising Legacy
description: JAMES DEAN was a myth almost before he was an actor. When he died in a car crash, on Sept. 30, 1955, he was just 24 years old, and there are few things more romantic than premature death: all that potential tragically unrealized, with none of the indignities and disappointments and bad decisions of middle and old age to mar the purity of early achievement. (Talk about romantic: Keats lived longer than James Dean.)

Solomon and George M. Solomon of Arlington, Va. Rabbi Eliezar Zaslikovsky is to officiate at the Shackamaxon Golf and Country Club in Scotch Plains, N.J.

Yet Peterson seems certain that nothing is wrong with Ishii's pitching mechanics.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: May 29-June 4; POP/JAZZ
description: When the German electronic act KRAFTWERK started releasing its startling experiments in the early 1970's, electronic music was something you created in a lab. Now it's something you dance to in a club, thanks in large part to the music of Kraftwerk, which helped inspire a whole generation of machine music: disco, hip-hop, new-wave, house, techno. When Kraftwerk arrives in town on Wednesday, here's hoping attendees expecting a dance party will get, instead, a lesson in minimalist electronic composition. More important, here's hoping it works the other way around, too. 7:30 p.m., Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, garment district, (212)279-7740; sold out.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: May 29-June 4; THEATER
description: MIKE NICHOLS and ELAINE MAY: together again! Well, not so much together as nearby. When Ms. May's new play, "AFTER THE NIGHT AND THE MUSIC," opens at the BILTMORE THEATER on Wednesday, the celebrated comic duo will both be back on Broadway at the same time. Although they have largely pursued separate careers, Mr. Nichols and Ms. May began their long careers together, way back in the middle years of the last century, as performers of their own material. Since then, they have largely worked behind the scenes in movies and the theater. Mr. Nichols is, of course, the director of this season's monster-hit musical "SPAMALOT." Ms. May's new production consists of three one-act plays about the absurdities of life and love in the new millennium. Although her record has been spotty in recent years -- her last play to be produced on Broadway, "TALLER THAN A DWARF," was about as appealing as its title -- Ms. May has been manufacturing laughs for nearly a half-century now, and experience counts for a lot in comedy. Opens on Wednesday at the Biltmore Theater, 261 West 47th Street, (212)239-6200.

But the tale may be nearing its conclusion, as part of a $3 million park renovation set to begin in September.

But more than two years after that effort began, with a visit by the president and his cabinet to these arid backlands, the program here has fallen far short of expectations.

description: PARIS, May 28 - It has been a much less eventful run to this French Open fourth round for Marat Safin. A year ago, he was pulling down his shorts, suffering from mysterious blisters on his hands and carrying on a running, animated conversation with himself as the rain and other vagaries of the sport he both loves and resents played tricks with his mind and rhythm.

title: The Comfort of Strangers
description: I moved to Cairo from Colorado in 2003 to work as a teacher and journalist. I had recently converted to Islam and wanted to spend time close to the source of the language and culture that had given rise to my religion. The transition between life in red-state America and life in the Arab capital was at times overwhelming because of the traditional segregation of men and women in many public and private settings. Especially difficult to navigate at first was the Cairene metro, where choosing to ride in the wrong car could result in serious awkwardness.

They had four children: Dolores (Paul) Warren who died in 1971, Gloria (Edgar) Zimmerman of Delray Beach, FL, Leah Shapiro Klein of Key Biscayne, FL, and Joseph Shapiro formerly of Atlanta, GA, now living in Miami. She is survived by three children and 12 grandchildren: Garry (Robin) Zimmerman of Chicago, IL, Keith (Elisabeth) Zimmerman of Chicago, IL, Richard (Susan) Zimmerman of Chicago, IL, and Jody Bradley of Delray Beach, FL, Sharon Solomon of Wellington, FL, Cookie Durand of Duluth, GA, Bruce (Sharon) Wilson of Bedford, NY, Mark (Debi) Klein of Scarsdale, NY, Michael (Beth) Klein of New York City, NY, Rachel (Steven) Forest of New York City, NY, Stephen (Jackie) Shapiro and David Shapiro both of Los Angeles, CA, area. She also had 22 great-grandchildren: Aaron, Ariel, Jory, Nicholas, Kristopher, Gregory, Julia, Katie, Bill, Kirby and Spencer Zimmerman, David Solomon, Peter Theise, Didianne Durand, Alex and Dana Wilson, Jessica, Jacob and Barry Klein, Anna and Ryan Forest and Jake Shapiro. Funeral services will be held 11 AM. on Tuesday, May 31, 2005, at the Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 1920 Alton Rd., Miami Beach, FL, followed by interment at Mt. Nebo Cemetery in Miami, FL. Donations should be made to National Hadassah for use at the Hadassah Hospital in Ein Karem, Jerusalem, Israel. National Hadassah is at 50 W. 58th St., New York, NY. For 2005-2006, with projected enrollment down by more than 300 students since 2001, the board of education proposed raising $72 million, a 60 percent jump in the levy per pupil over just four years.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 6 Stabbed In Fight
description: Six men suffered minor stabbing injuries in a fight outside a Harlem restaurant early yesterday, the police said. The fight broke out shortly after 4 a.m. between two groups of men outside Revival, a restaurant at 2367 Frederick Douglass Boulevard at West 127th Street, the police said. It was unclear why it occurred. Six men, ages 16 to 23, suffered superficial cuts, and three others were arrested. The suspects, charged with second-degree assault, were identified as Jose Garcia, 18, and Rene Moran, 21, of the Bronx and William Veras, 22, of Inwood in Manhattan. The restaurant normally closes at midnight but remained open late for a private party, said Shankar Narayanan, 28, the chef and manager. "People were leaving to get home. I don't know what happened," he said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Mixing It Up, With an Accent on African Rhythm
description: Part of the fun of DanceAfrica, a Memorial Day weekend tradition now in its 28th year, is roaring out Swahili greetings under the tutelage of Chuck Davis, the festival's artistic director and jovial host. The tribute to community elders is also unfailingly poignant. The performance by the youngsters of the BAM/Restoration DanceAfrica Ensemble, in tribute to Representative Major R. Owens, a Democrat of New York, at the Saturday matinee at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, was charmingly fervent.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Freeport: Girl, 12, Held In Mother's Death
description: A 12-year-old Long Island girl has been arrested in the strangling of her mother, the police said. According to a statement from the Nassau County Police Department, the police were called shortly before midnight Saturday with a report that the woman, 45, was not breathing. She was rushed to Nassau University Medical Center, where she died at 12:43 a.m. yesterday, the police said. An autopsy revealed that the cause of death was strangulation, the police said, but they did not elaborate. They did not reveal the names or the address of the woman and the girl, who they said will be charged as a juvenile delinquent in Family Court. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Traffic Warning For Bronx-Whitestone Bridge
description: Construction to replace a roadway deck will shut down a lane of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge around the clock until further notice starting Thursday night, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said. To help prevent tie-ups during the project, a median barrier will shift position during rushes. For the morning rush, there will be three lanes for Bronx-bound traffic and two lanes for Queens-bound vehicles. In the late afternoon and the evening, there will be three Queens-bound lanes and two heading to the Bronx. At various other times, two lanes will be closed.

For weeks, it sounded as if amateurs had been bleeding their voices into the broadcasts of stations in Akron, Ohio, owned by Clear Channel, the corporate radio giant. At the Web site www.radiofreeohio.com, there was a manifesto about "corporate-controlled music playlists" that took potshots at several local Clear Channel stations. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSMITH, LEONARD
description: GOLDSMITH--Leonard. 86, formerly of Caldwell, NJ, died peacefully at home in Tacoma, WA, May 28th. Born in Worcester, MA, a graduate of Worcester Polytechnic Institute, he played clarinet and sax in a big band. He served as captain in US Army in WW II, installing radar in Latin America. He raised two sons in Valley Stream, LI, with Marcia, his wife of 58 years, while working as an aerospace engineer. He was a loving husband and an involved and caring father, who passed on to all his love of music, art, physics, tennis, hiking, conservation and the great outdoors. He is survived by his wife Marcia Skeist Goldsmith; his sons, Dr. Martin Goldsmith of Tacoma, WA, and Richard Goldsmith, a filmmaker, of Berkeley, CA; daughters-in-law Jodie Zaricor and Susanna Tadlock; four grandchildren, Toby, Noah, Emma and Jamie; a sister Beatrice Victor of Staten Island; and a brother Albert Goldsmith of Newburgh, NY. title: A Season of Commemoration
description: Memorial Day may feel like a summer holiday -- an early antecedent to the Fourth of July -- but it is still, even in these days of early warming, a rite of spring. The leaves on the trees may be darkening toward full summer. A hot afternoon may suddenly seem to eclipse any thought of May. But there is still a newness about these hints of summer, a reminder that spring was just here. Three weeks of that now-fragile season remain. A winter can easily freeze on into April, and summer knows well enough how to prolong itself into early October. But what spring has ever really lasted until the 21st of June? We would all feel defrauded if Memorial Day didn't seem to hurl us into the heart of summer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FULTON, ROBERT EDISON
description: FULTON--Robert Edison, was one of the most interesting men I have ever known. He was a philosopher, musician, poet, director, cinematographer, aerial cinematographer, filmmaker and, most of all, an incredible man. Bob was highly skilled in all these areas. He won many awards including an Emmy for his work. He was a devout Buddhist. Bob was extremely humble and never talked about himself or his accomplishments, but only about the love of his work. Bob did everything in such a unique way that his friends and family referred to his lifestyle as Fultonian, as if he had developed an entirely different culture and way of life. To tell one's story about Bob was never enough, people always wanted to hear more and know more about this fascinating man. To watch Bob fly a plane was like watching a virtuoso playing an instrument. He taught me many things, both in the sky and on the ground. His lessons of "point of intended touchdown" is something I will never forget. A wonder with words, Fulton never used profanity; he thought it was an abuse of the English language and demonstrated a lack of a proper vocabulary. I miss my generous mentor and good friend, Bob Fulton, who is in my thoughts every day. Taz Saunders

title: Ending the Gerrymander Wars

title: Repairing the Alternative Tax
description: Lawmakers have long known that the rich have ample opportunity to avoid paying income taxes. This year, for instance, an estimated 7,600 millionaires would owe no income tax at all if it were not for the anti-sheltering provisions, known collectively as the alternative minimum tax.

title: The Amazon at Risk
description: Even the government of Brazil seemed shocked by the news that despite efforts to curb deforestation -- including a $140 million package of conservation measures announced last year -- the destruction of the world's largest tropical forest, the Amazon, proceeds apace. In the 12-month period ending last August, farming and logging, much if it illegal, destroyed 10,000 square miles of forest, an area almost the size of Massachusetts. This was the biggest one-year loss since 1995, when the Amazon shrank by about 11,000 square miles.

A third attacker was also wounded, and was arrested. Later, angry mobs protesting the attack set fire to more than a dozen vehicles, two gas stations and a KFC restaurant. Today the police discovered the bodies of six people who were burned alive in the fire at the American fast food outlet, Agence France-Presse reported. Paid Notice: Deaths   HEALEY, JOHN ANTHONY, ''TONY.''
description: HEALEY -- John Anthony, "Tony." Died on May 28 in New York City at the age of 69 after long suffering from the effects of the neurological disease Multiple Systems Atrophy (MSA). He is survived by his beloved family: wife Louise, daughter Virginia, son John, daughter-inlaw Christina and two lovely grandsons, Jack and Scott, who were the apples of his eyes. He is also survived by his brothers Father Joseph G. Healey, Thomas J. Healey, sister Ann Oglesby and stepbrothers Michael K. Sheehan, Peter C. Sheehan, and predeceased by Barry C. Sheehan. Upon his retirement, Tony was a Managing Director at TCW and prior to that headed up his own private financial services firm specializing in international projects in energy, natural resources and the emerging markets. He also had been a partner at A.W. Jones. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 2, at 11:30 AM, at St. Ignatius Loyola, 84th and Park Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The memory of John A. Healey, The Department of Neurology, Columbia University at 170 West 168th Street, New York 10032.

World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Minister Testifies In Syria Torture Case
description: Defense Minister Bill Graham said he was frustrated by the assertions of United States officials, including the former secretary of state, Colin L. Powell, that someone in Canada had "given them the go-ahead" to deport Maher Arar, the Syrian-born Canadian detained in New York in 2002 and sent to Syria for 10 months, where, he said, he was tortured. Mr. Graham, who was then the foreign affairs minister, told a federal inquiry into what role Canadian officials played in Mr. Arar's deportation that he could not verify the American claims with Canadian police and security officials, although he added that he had some uncertainty about the quality of the briefings he was getting. Mr. Graham also testified that he did not know Mr. Arar's whereabouts in the months after he was deported by the United States. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: High Cholesterol? With Children, It May Not Matter
description: Dr. Thomas B. Newman doesn't like the use of heart-rending stories to sway medical decision makers. He prefers statistical proof, the cold calculus of numbers. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARMSTRONG, SHEILA H.
description: ARMSTRONG -- Sheila H. Died at home on Saturday, May 28, at age 93 after a long illness. Devoted wife of the late Edward, and beloved mother of Edward, John, and Sheila A. Hoerle. Adored grandmother of Jeffrey, Scott, Alex, Ian, and Anne. Great grandmother of William, Elizabeth, Nicholas and Katharine. Sheila was a past President of the Women's National Republican Club, and of the board of the Knickerbocker Greys. Her indomitable spirit will long be remembered by her family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the John G. Armstrong '03 and Edward M. Armstrong '04 Scholarship, Princeton University, PO Box 140, Princeton, NJ 08544.

World Briefing | Middle East: Israel Strikes Gaza Refugee Camp
description: An Israeli drone aircraft fired missiles near a Palestinian refugee camp in Gaza, destroying two rocket launchers belonging to the radical Islamic Jihad organization. Three bystanders, including two sisters, were wounded by shrapnel, but the militants preparing to launch rockets escaped, after having fired three rockets at an Israeli town outside Gaza, Islamic Jihad said. In Israel, Foreign Minister Silvan Shalom said he expected Prime Minister Ariel Sharon to meet with the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, in the next two weeks, their first meeting since Feb. 8. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: New Public Editor Hosts Paul Krugman-Daniel Okrent Debate
description: Daniel Okrent, in his May 22 farewell column as the first public editor of The New York Times, criticized Paul Krugman, an Op-Ed columnist for the newspaper. Prof. Krugman, who disputed the validity of Mr. Okrents comments in the public editors regular reader-letters column in The Times on Sunday, elaborated in a longer e-mail message for this Web Journal  with the understanding that Mr. Okrents response would be posted simultaneously.

title: Paul Krugman Responds to Dan Okrents Response
description: Just one last word. Mr. Okrent has so far offered only one example that, if true, would have justified his all-out attack on my ethics. Everything else is picking nits: I could explain why 77 percent, not 64 percent, is the right number, but does it really matter? The only significant example was his claim that I blended household and establishment survey data on jobs, in an attempt to score political points. But as I showed in the previous note, I didnt and in the column itself I pointed readers to the correct data. Now Mr. Okrent claims that he was only referring to my assertion that the economy needs to add 140,000 payroll jobs per month, which for some reason he thinks comes from the household survey. (It doesnt.) Sorry, thats an unconvincing evasive maneuver. Mr. Okrent clearly accused me of playing mix and match with the job numbers themselves. In fact, in our correspondence, when I said that it was all payroll data, he declared that your insistence that you relied only on one set of numbers is very puzzling. I dont see how the math works any other way; maybe you could further enlighten me. In other words, the only accusation that could have justified Mr. Okrents attack was completely unfounded. And now hes not enough of a mensch to admit his error.
